Title: Great place
View8: Culture Benefits Employees Leadership Work life balance
View10: There are no cons, great place to work.

Title: Great career-starting company
View8: Benefits including profit sharing and bonuses are great. The breadth of this company provides a great opportunity to try out different career paths or boost your current one.
View10: In my current role, I am working overtime more often than I'd like with recognition that seems to only go so far until it sizzles out. That may be tied to the size of the company itself, where promotions work in a "trickle down" manner.

Title: No respect
View8: The benefits are solid... Or so I'm told honestly I don't understand why we don't have a single payer system it's insane that to have health care you need a stable job.  Don't even get me started on dental... What are they?  Luxury bones?
View10:
Despite the fact that the average employee of this company can't even power on a computer my role is the lowest paid in the company.

To be clear the folks who work from home taking chats/calls who escalate their tickets to my team make more than my team. 

Let's talk numbers.

Inflation in 2021 was around 9% but the average raise for my team was 2%.

2022 was again around 9... But we got a whopping 7%.

That's a pay cut baby.  When we spoke to our leadership they literally told us to go find another job.

What's more is there is no out. You are trapped in this role forever or until you find something better elsewhere.  They offer programs to "help you progress." but then banish the techs because they don't want tech people. 

They also abuse the ever living crap out of contractors.  They want you as an employee handling people with millions of dollars in trades laptops but they don't wanna give health care.  Incredible.

Title: Ehh...
View8: The starting pay is pretty good for a call center. Great benefits as well.
View10: They claim that there are so many different opportunities to grow within the company, but make it impossible to explore those options due to working a strict schedule on the phones. The call volume is back to back with no room to breathe in between calls. You go through 3 months of training and still feel confused at the end. They encourage you to ask questions and reach out for help, but when you reach out for help, you're reprimanded for doing so. You have no say so in your schedule and you have to work between 12pm-8pm so say goodbye to having any type of social life. They offer free therapy and after working there for about a week, you'll quickly understand why.

Title: Let Go While 7 Months Pregnant
View8: I was drawn to the training program for the Financial Consultant role. Good 401k match.
View10: I was in a 1 year training program for the Financial Consultant role while completing my CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER™ certification. I was told I needed to sell more insurance, annuities, and managed accounts in order to continue on as a Financial Consultant. I was let go as soon as I hit the 1 year mark, shortly after I became a CFP® professional. I had told HR that I was pregnant when I became concerned about losing my job and asked to be considered for a different role within Fidelity (since I knew I would not be able to interview and start another job at 7 months pregnant). After I was let go by my manager, I reached back out to HR and they were not even aware that my employment was being terminated. Everyone I dealt with at Fidelity was extremely insensitive to the fact that this would cause a huge amount of stress to me and my family at a time that stress had serious potential health risks to myself and my baby. I ended up being unemployed for close to 9 months. I was interviewing for new jobs while also taking care of a newborn and paying extremely high premiums for health insurance for my family. Only 23% of CFP professionals are women, and only about 15% of financial advisors are women. Even though Fidelity touts its family values and culture, I would not recommend Fidelity to women based on my experience.

Title: Not what it seems
View8: The people outside of the onboarding group are amazing and extremely helpful.
View10: Toxic doesn't begin to describe how things are. The onboarding managers openly compare you to others, bring up personal things in 1 on 1s about other associates and make comments about your life like suggesting you should be married or have children by now. They yell at you on the floor in front of the entire facility if you do something they don't like. The don't advocate for people who have disabilities when it comes to learning the material so you're constantly compared to others openly. They require you to work multiple hours a week UNPAID after your schedule and on weekends. They SUGGEST you should work through your breaks and lunches.

Title: Great company for long term career
View8: Fidelity has two main driving goals, first is customer experience/satisfaction and the other is retaining talent. These can be challenging to balance at times, but they do their best and are mostly successful at it. Flexible work schedules is primary reason Fidelity is retaining a lot of their talent. It's for these reasons I've been with the company almost 20 years and plan to retire here if possible.
View10: Lately the company has been getting a little political and pushing some activist type initiatives, which doesn't sit well with many employees. They of course won't speak up and say much, especially ones who've been around a while. The company needs to stick to financial matters and stay away from woke agendas or they may face backlash even if their intentions are sound.

Title: Good company, but could be so much better
View8: Encourages career mobility, benefits, work/life balance, dynamic working option for those who want it (1 week in office for local remote workers), own entire end-to-end initiatives in 1 business unit or just projects in the other, ux team apart from product team but still integrated, some autonomy on how you work, ux culture, company culture, maintains accessibility standards, employee resource groups, learning day every 2 weeks
View10: Slow production cycle, corporate red tape, some product directions are not defined, communication from management, managers not knowing how to manage,  new design systems every few years, hard to get promotions within team unless you're a white male,  boys club, enforcement of connect weeks (no flexibility of when you come in & forcing us to come in in the first place), promotes agile but doesnt practice it well, strained ux research team and limited access to users, wants to sacrifice ux principles for sake of visual alignment

Title: Constant opportunity for development and growth for those who want it
View8:
Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work.
Fidelity provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for those who are willing to wait.
View10:
Fidelity retail is open 24 hours, causing scheduling conflicts for some candidates
Career tracks within the firm can be limited due to licensing requirements, or lack of licensing flexibility in the groups

Title: Good but not great
View8: Over 10 yrs with the company and there is a lot to like about Fidelity. Their 401k match and profit sharing is impressive. Great starting place for a career. Career mobility is available yet there can be ceilings for advancement. Their products and platform solutions are also quite good. Truly a client centric organization and is focused on maintaining that perception. Their approach during Covid was pretty level-headed.
View10: Consistent theme where senior mgmt proved to be disinterested and detached from the happenings on the ground. In retrospect, there is also an unhealthy fear within the workforce. There was always a worry about a rumored layoff and then those that always make a point to ‘appear busy.’ Often you will hear from peers or managers that the grass isn’t always greener or that you should think twice before leaving. Other comments regarding excessive workload expectations and having a stressful work environment are also understated. That is pretty consistent across the channels.

Title: Great place to work
View8: Fidelity is a great place to work for several compelling reasons. Firstly, the company's commitment to fostering a collaborative and inclusive culture sets it apart. Employees at Fidelity experience a supportive environment that values diversity and encourages open communication. Secondly, Fidelity places a strong emphasis on professional development, offering numerous opportunities for career growth and skill enhancement. The company's dedication to innovation and cutting-edge technology ensures that employees have the tools and resources to excel in their roles. Lastly, Fidelity's unwavering focus on work-life balance and its recognition of employee contributions through various programs make it an employer of choice, creating a positive and rewarding experience for its workforce.
View10: work life balance not always the best call center environment

Title: Great Benefits and Managers, but Old-fashioned approach to work
View8: 6% 401(k) match, Volunteer time off in addition to Paid time off. PTO is about five work weeks. Managers are very understanding of your personal life. Career development is great; you get promoted quickly. They also have a "Fidelity Made" program for people interested in tech.
View10: Upper leadership doesn't listen to employees. Every quarter, they require employees to come into the office more and more, and they took away the free meal on top of that. So you end up spending a lot of money going to work. They kept saying, "It was always our intention to go back to the office." even though the majority of the people who work there were hired during the lockdown and were attracted because of the remote option.

Title: Fidelity EA
View8: the people. the technology. working remote.
View10: EAs pigeonholed. Managers not willing to support career advancement. Feeling of not being a part of a team and unappreciated, undervalued. Reporting to an Admin instead of Senior Executives. Low pay scale compared to other large Boston firms.

Title: Amazing entry-level opportunity with great benefits
View8: I enjoyed all the essential skills, especially in customer service, and retirement planning that I developed during my experience at Fidelity. I also appreciate how amazing the benefits were and how well I was trained to excel on the job.
View10: Servicing 60+ calls each day can be exhausting especially during the early to the middle of the year. I also believe that I didn't receive as much support as I would've liked in career growth based on the areas I was interested in within the company based on my overall interests.

Title: It was good until it wasn't
View8: Generally a good place to work. Decent pay. Great benefits. Relatively high UX maturity. Out of the hundreds of people I've met and worked with, there are only a handful that I wouldn't want to work with again, which I think says a lot.
View10: D&I efforts are limited and often just checking boxes. Win awards for employing women, but is still very much dominated by men. Very cheap regarding training and conferences. Once you've been there a while, your pay becomes less and less competitive with the market. Performance is competitive (only certain percentage can be at top), which hurts collaboration and is demoralizing when you do great work and aren't recognized for it.

Title: Great Culture, Great Underpay
View8: Good support system and benefits, lots of opportunity to move up and they allow a decent work life balance
View10: Pay is not where it should be with the level of work you do with clients, days can be long and you can be talking to people about very complicated investments and goals with little reward. They underpay then offer a quarterly bonus that you have absolutely have to grind all quarter to get the full amount which still doesn’t add up to what your worth

Title: Positive Experience
View8: People, technology, culture, and benefits were all very strong. Only left because a great offer for more money came up outside or else could have stayed for decades.
View10: Its a company of 60,000 so it's hard to go outside the box with new ideas without it taking years for approval and through several layers

Title: Racist Manager & Definition of Micromanaging
View8: The licensing training program was good
View10:
Despite the company promoting " how friendly/ welcoming their company culture is", the manager I had was racist and unprofessional and I had to report HIM AND FIDELITY to EESO. 
They also brainwash you into thinking you are some sort of "financial professional" --this is just a call center job...
 Believe every single negative review you see here cuz they are true!!!
If you like to work at a Cult--this is the place for you!

Title: They care about their employees
View8: They seem to care more about their employees than most other firms I’ve worked. Maybe bc they’re private but would recommend for culture over other firms.
View10: Pay. They also have a hierarchy for promotions that isn’t as seamless or lateral as they like to showcase it to be. There is a lot of competition since there is a lot of folks w your exact skill set in your exact role gunning for your desired position and can be make it really timely or difficult to advance if you have your eyes set on a specific role. (Or location)

Title: Excellent Organization to grow with
View8: They enable potential employees with the tools, vision, and experience of what their future will encompass once they are onboarded. They help you to become successful in your career journey at Fidelity.
View10: I can't say this is a con, although the rigorous testing and interviewing process can be tedious and intimidating to some.

Title: Good Benefits
View8: Good Work culture - But it will depend on the team and the manager. Good 401K match and Profit sharing - Will take care of your retirement. You can use the net salary for other things and not worry about the retirement,
View10: If you join in Feb or Mar you will work for 11 or 10 months in that year and won't be eligible for the profit sharing next year. Vs someone joining in Nov or Dec, they may not get profit sharing for just 1 or 2 months. This to me look little unfair.

Title: Equitable
View8: They really lookout for your mental health and assist with non-work related wellness. As part of the many benefits are support for family support, maternity/paternity leave, access to mental health support, student loan reimbursement, home buying assistance, and concierge to assist with basically anything! I can't cover everything they do for you here, it's a village for you and your family to build a career on. The company really believes, if you're a well rounded individual- your satisfaction will be mirrored in the client's satisfaction.
View10: Pay is lower starting out than other companies, but the benefits and work/life balance (only required to be in office 1 week out of the month) more than makes up for the lower pay. while the company is working to create a more equitable workspace, the employees themselves are often clicky (whether it's religious or gender based). Things are getting better, but it will take more time for the overall culture to change.

Title: Good experience
View8: Good people and potential for networking
View10: micromanagement, promotions vertically, and true manager 1-1 development

Title: Call Center
View8: Really good benefits, WFM options, clean facilities, paid licensing, friendly managers and teammates, strong company culture
View10: The company is fine but this is a call center role. Once you finish your licensing, you're on the phones or on chats most of the time. Clients can be demanding and your success is dependent on your metrics. The only way to move into a new role is by being really efficient with your calls, regardless of your other qualifications or if the desired role is even on the phones.

Title: Work
View8: Nice people, professional environment and office space was very nice
View10: Too many meetings during the week

Title: Excellent company
View8: I work remotely and my schedule is very flexible. I’ve never felt micromanaged in the 3 years I’ve worked for Fidelity. I can’t say enough good things
View10: Salary is good.- but could be better

Title: Overall great place to start my career
View8: Great people, great office with great amenities. My managers are excellent people and have been training me well in my role. I am getting a manageable workload with plenty of leeway for my study time. Overall great place to work, although I don't have much to compare it to since this is my first full time job.
View10: This job is in consulting, which may appeal to everyone.

Title: Company Culture Took a Nose Dive
View8: Robust benefits package that included 7% 401k match and profit sharing.
View10: Fidelity used to be a champion for their associates but after requiring employees to work remotely for over 2 years that came to an abrupt end in favor of real estate value. Associates stepped up to make Fidelity look good and maximize profits when the pandemic started, pivoting to working at home at a moments notice only to be bullied to return to the office and micromanaged despite the overwhelming request of associates to remain remote. Gone is the autonomy and flexibility as "Big Brother" started watching your every badge swipe. Go ahead take PTO during a Connect Week, but be prepared to have to make those days up in the office. The required in-office attendance wasn't really helping with collaboration, associates kept earbuds in and to themselves anyway and still attended all meetings virtually. Associates who moved hundreds, or even thousands of miles away from a Fidelity campus were not exempt from the Connect Week requirements forcing many great associates to leave the company.

Title: Great workplace
View8: benefits people career mobility flexibility work life balance is top of mind
View10: sick time is part of PTO

Title: Amazing company to work for
View8: The people and management at Fidelity are top notch. I feel valued and heard by management. I love the people I work with. There has been exponential room for growth.
View10: The strict schedule adherence feels like we're being micromanaged. The biggest con is the lack of flexibility in the job. Also can feel burned out by the constant service to planning call model.

Title: Not as they seem
View8: Great benefits, remote work, and a good starting pay.
View10: They don’t tell you that if you don’t pass exams you get fired. They give you 30 days to find a job within the company, but fail to tell you that most jobs either ask for experience or wait till 30 days is up to reapply.

Title: Ok
View8: Good environment and work life balance
View10: Managerial staff will forget about your request I.E. shift change if you are doing well and if it is not beneficial for them to move you

Title: It’s alright
View8: Great benefits Workplace is actually nice
View10: Management is alright, depending on who your team lead is. It can be the best or worst

Title: Fidelity Boston
View8: Good benefits, profit sharing, 401k match up to 6%, time off encouraged. Outgoing teams. The company tries to provide lots of learning, social engagements, training and networking opportunities internally.
View10: High stress levels (depending on position), moving towards more in office time than hybrid roles. Key location Boston, but can also work in Smithfield, RI or NH. Likes to start people in contract roles initially. You then have to apply for FTE opportunities. Sometimes very hard to get into, depending on the business unit.

Title: Good Growth Opportunities and Culture
View8: The company has been excellent in the year I have been with them. The company cares about developing its people and has created an environment to promote that.
View10: The rice in the cafeteria is usually too dry

Title: Great company to work for.
View8: Very collaborative and balanced work environment.
View10: Open floor cubicle layout but that's currently being revamped which is a huge mood changer when in the office

Title: Non existent
View8: Nothing good lately. Use to be a great place to work.
View10: Terrible middle management. Too many people with no practical management knowledge making decisions. Use to look at skill sets to match jobs. Now just wants to take every person and turn them into a robot to do what they say when with no actually thinking required on employees part.

Title: Not competitive with other programs
View8: -culture -ample break time -profit sharing
View10: -pay is low for what you can get at other financial firms -hard to leave a department if not a good fit

Title: Work-life balance is great!
View8: People are always willing to help teach, and I love the work-life balance
View10: I don't feel like all my skills from previous employers are valued

Title: Company is good, but call center job is unsustainable
View8: Good benefits, good facilities, on-site cafeteria
View10: Extremely restricted schedule, sometimes mandatory overtime, moving up = dealing with the most difficult customers

Title: Work
View8: 401K match and the leap program
View10: Infrastructure and roadmap mot clear.

Title: Early Career Start to get your licenses
View8: 401k match, health, vision and dental benefits are good and bonuses
View10: work life balance, have to bid for popular holidays, no room for growth and development

Title: Great Benefits Promotions are based on favoritism not performance
View8: Great Benefits and pay. Training is really good.
View10: Promotions are based on favoritism, a lot of management saying one thing and doing another. Inconsistent management practices.

Title: Great Company
View8: Always hiring so many resources for successful believe in the mission of helping people and win at so many things Fast adapting
View10: it can be difficult for those who do not have a passion

Title: ITs nice
View8: -good work culture -very flexible -amazing teams
View10: -salary not so high -boring work

Title: Unwilling to evolve with today’s workforce
View8: Fidelity’s salary and benefits are competitive.
View10: Fidelity’s executives are completely out of touch with employee needs. Even if your entire team is scattered across the globe, they still require you to come into the office to do Zoom meetings. 🤦🏻‍♂️ As polite as the employees are, they are definitely herd followers. Employees here do not want to be held accountable, so meaningfully change is rarely seen at Fidelity. They also generally have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo.

Title: Great Co-workers, Horrendous Management
View8: The benefits are amazing. Whether it be the adoptions benefits, 401k match, profit share, PTO, the benefits are what keep me around. Coworkers are always very friendly and wonderfully supportive.
View10: Management, especially at the WI VP level lately, has begun to treat strangle its workforce. It is courting the 401k 403B business to the last penny and is willing to sacrifice its associates well-being. Any problem that occurs is blamed on the lowest on the pole. Lots of monitoring of our movement (92% has to be at the desk of your day) and very little time to learn or move up. Managers on a whole are good people but have no power to help. Lower managers also tend to favor the people they manage on site for promotions.

Title: Easy interview
View8: Easy to get in Some cool projects
View10:
Too political 
Can’t advance without professional relationships

Title: Safe place. Money culture.
View8: Safe place to work if you produce consistent results.
View10: Culture is all profit driven. Nobody actually cares about anything else but making money. Money hungry mentality.

Title: CRA role: read this first!
View8: 1.) About 20 PTO days, benefits, lots of perks like a concierge you can call to help with anything. 2.) My managers were very good at communicating and looking out for my mental health. I was going through licensing for a call center role and was getting a little burnt out. One of my managers even had a real talk with me about how hard the role was and supported my decision to leave the company. The managers are the real gems.
View10: 1.) Fidelity requires associates to be in one week every month. Though it was nice to work from home most of the time, the in office week was required and NOT flexible. Sometimes I had to use my PTO days because I was sick and couldn't make it to the office. I would rather be in the office any 5 days of my choosing. 2.) Licensing is hard. Many people left because they couldn't pass the tests (including me). I was in training long enough to see what my role looked like after licensing and it only gets harder. 2.) If you're in the CRA role, please read this first. Do you really want to stay in a job where it's just one call after the other, no idea what it's going to be about, no idea if the client is going to scream at you, and thrown into it without any real training? Fidelity training is very long but does not go over every scenario there is; they expect you to know 100 things while doing something as simple as phone calls. Most of them were password resets or transfers to branches and while most clients were very pleasant, there were some that were outright abusive. I don't blame them as it's managing their money but some could ruin your day. I would not doubt it if my role was completely taken over by AI in a few years. Licensing was fine but once you get to the job it is very overwhelming and exhausting. I knew some coworkers who said that it was very stressful learning so much while also not knowing everything. There just isn't enough time fit everything in your schedule. This was what my day was like when taking calls for two weeks: - 8am: 30 minute team meeting (sometimes this was at 4:30 depending on schedule) - 8:30am: start calls for the day - 10:30am: take 15 min break - 12pm: break for lunch - 1pm: start calls again - 3:30pm: take 30 minute break - 5pm: end day I could take a 45 min break which is measured to the minute while lunch after training is only a half hour. Your whole day will just be phone calls. On my worst day I took about 40 but I've known people who took 60. Even just two days on the phones burnt me out so much.

Title: Not a great job
View8: Training is great, support is great. Fidelity can't hang on to talent. They maintain folks who can give all their blood and never provide recognition
View10: Constant negative feedback, never happy even when you have great results. Most employees are miserable

Title: I wish I could of passed the SIE
View8: Excellent company benefits, growth opportunities, and co workers from so many diverse backgrounds. The cream of the crop works here for sure.
View10: I could pass my SIE exam, so I got let go. They did it with dignity and even let me finish out the month. I wish that exam wasn’t necessary.

Title: Solid place to work
View8: Career development, lots of perks, generally work with good people.
View10: Always too much overtime during tax season. Some metrics for being on phones promote poor practices by other employees and then you may get the call of an upset client. At the phone site it can be difficult to move up because everyone is gunning for the next spot.

Title: Go for it!
View8: Great benefits, hybrid work model (or fully remote if you don't live near a regional office), a lot of opportunity for growth. If you're hired into a role that requires licensing, they provide all the training and materials you'll need to pass the licensing exams, plus they pay you to study and prep!
View10: I did not experience any cons.

Title: Base pay well below market value
View8: Good work/life balance, good benefits, good people
View10: The base pay compared to other similar companies and beyond is WAY below average. They rely heavily on the notion that their benefits package and bonus structure make up for this, but it does not. Most companies offer very similar benefits and then some at this point.

Title: Great Company
View8: Great culture. Nice amount of PTO. Great benefits. Pay for CFP and help with higher education
View10: I dont have any cons. Perhaps to pay a little bit more

Title: Great Comp and Great place to start career but do not truly care about customers
View8: Amazing pay for start of career. Good training for fundamental concepts but once this is established not a place for creative concepts and independent thinking. Management wants you to ask same questions and run same exact process on every single client regardless of situation.
View10: Middle management doesn’t care about clients and relationships. This is strictly a sales role and very minimally a planning role. I think if upper management knew how investor centers were being run and how churning clients and quick selling was being pushed they would be disturbed. Clients usually sell out of managed money within 5 years bc they were falsely sold, they’ve had advisor turnover once or twice in that timeframe, and managed accounts underperform their own asset manager funds. If you want a real financial planning career go to an RIA after 1-2 years in this role

Title: Great place to work
View8: Benefits, culture, camaraderie, home office is very nice. Work from home or office, free equipment and 7% 401k match with surprise bonuses
View10: None! Work hard and reap the rewards.

Title: Tied to the phones
View8: 8 hours of phones. IF you love talking to people then it would be a great fit for you. Not hating on the job at all, you can really help people. But talking to people for 8 hours is not for me.
View10: Stuck to your desk on the phones.

Title: It's pretty good
View8: Company is great benefits are great people are nice
View10: Phones are not fun ever

Title: Sexual Harrassment & Mandatory Overtime
View8: In retrospect it's a very dark aura. Mandatory Overtime. Sexual Harrassment
View10: Sexual Harrassment by High Level Management. The Company" does not stand by it's Anti-Harassment Policies. It's nothing more than words on paper.

Title: Solid firm
View8: Great benefits, great people, work life balance
View10: Limited roles for work from home

Title: Would recommend
View8: Work life balance, focus on investing in people, lots of opportunity, great benefits
View10: Few. It's hard to get a pay bump, and I'm not a huge fan of bonuses (they're taxed heavily - not Fidelity's fault, but I wish I could opt out for a base pay bump)

Title: Incredible company, but could care more about employees
View8: -Generous retirement matching & other benefits. -Excellent facilities. -Paid time for continuing education.
View10: -Quarterly bonus affected by negative customer surveys, even if the customer had a good experience with you. -High turnover leaves highly specialized groups with low staffing, adding the customer frustration/wait time. -Potentially stressful work with very little breaks/downtime, especially during periods of high call volume.

Title: Was alright
View8: They have great benefits, will match 401K after 1 year of employment. The pay was good and they had some great options for bonuses and some overtime.
View10: Was very stressful. The training was very long and yet was somehow left feeling like I barely knew anything. Felt very sink or swim. They want you to try and completely resolve all of the issues for the customers without having all of the resources and are very hesitant to allow a manager take over a call for some reason.

Title: Great for new professionals.
View8: Great job for young professionals, new graduates, and people without a college education. Lots of room for growth and development. Generally positive coworkers and managers.
View10: Very political. "Who you know" culture, not "what you know". Management keeps slowly wiping away benefits, most namely remote work. Roles that were fully remote prior to Covid are now being required to come into office based on some weird political anti-WFH movement. Pay is below industry standard for mid career professionals.

Title: Great Employer
View8: Amazing benefits, clear on expectations that are needed for promotion, great career program to become an excellent advisor
View10: Base salary for this role could be higher. Appropriate Base Salary for 2019 Cost of living, but life has gotten more expensive since. Would be good to have a pay bump in base salary

Title: Fidelity takes good care of its people
View8: If clients are nasty and offensive on the phone, Fidelity will discontinue business with them regardless of their assets held. Fidelity has their employees' backs. I appreciate that. Great benefits, work from home 3 out of 4 weeks a month, lots of paid breaks. Amazing opportunities for advancement - I've already received a promotion to a higher paying job and I'm only a month out of training. By the way - I had October-June training. Paid! Mostly from home! It's unheard of. I appreciated it immensely. Tons of support and resources.
View10: So far, none! I've been there for 10 months so far - I'm treated fairly and the job is great for someone like me who enjoys talking on the phone.

Title: Great WLB
View8: Fidelity is great company and everyone from my team have been supportive. It's definitely an ideal work environment
View10: Tech jobs are a paid a bit lower than other tech companies

Title: Mah mans fired me and gave ME a 2 week notice
View8: Mans paid me 2 weeks to look for a new job and told me EXACTLY what about my performance wasn't good. Did a Transfer before terminating. Advised on how to advance my career in the "you're fired" talk. OH! And he met me IN PERSON to have this talk. Private 1 on 1. You're treated quite human since Fidelity profits off the public market knowing it's cancer and stays private. I think officially it's 8 to 5 work hours but I roll up 9~10 and it's all good. I can leave like 3. As long as my work was getting done, it was good. WFH is awesome.
View10: When they put out the snacks, the packs of nuts are coated in sugar. Have to pay for food at the cafeteria now even though the chefs manage to somehow burn cauliflower. Only edible food is fried food. Even then occasionally it's feked I believe there is poor communication throughout the company. You have to talk to like 30 people on every task you do. Scrum masters don't understand programming and are like "bro, why isn't this done" despite you just telling him why it's not done. The encouragement I received was "Okay, try and get this done before the end of the sprint" wow... why didn't I think of that! STFU.

Title: Great Company!
View8: Fidelity Investments values their employees and provides support to put them in a position to be successful. When talking to people who work there, the passion and love for the company radiates. Speaking of culture, it's almost cult like; if you assimilate and subscribe to it, you're more than likely to rise the ranks.

The fast press to get liscences, not condusive to neurodivergent learning. Do not take the relocation package. Better to put on a card and pay off on your terms then claim in taxes. If you leave they want money back in firm of check suddenly, 10 day warning.

Title: Not a Healthy Culture
View8: Benefits were great! The profit sharing each year was awesome and after 10 years of employment I had a nice medical fund where they put $3200 a year into.
View10: When I started at Fidelity it was a great place to work, the culture was amazing, people were celebrated and you felt appreciated for your hard work. However, once Abby took over the company from her father, all that changed. Getting rid of people over 55 was clearly a high priority, everyone was overworked, appreciation went out the window and I felt like just a number. There was no such thing as work life balance. I would not recommend this company to anyone. I left 5 years ago and never looked back. Although I was there for 13 years, I hardly know anyone that still works there from when I was there.

Title: Great Company for hybrid work

Title: Personal Investing Team Leader
View8: Honestly, there are a lot of pros about the company! Great benefits, career mobility, in-office perks, etc. Very easy to move throughout the company, and they give you all the tools you need to be successful. Pretty decent pay, depending on your role!
View10: If you want to be a little fish in a massive pond, this is the company for you! As a team leader it felt like there were still 17 levels of people above me communicating decisions, and there was a real disconnect between the front-line and the very top on what was needed and wanted. Pay was decent, but HR makes it about impossible to negotiate numbers or get pay bumps off-cycle. Also - the company is kinda culty, if you're super into a culture where everyone sleeps, eats, and breathes the company, this will be for you! if you just want to do your job and go home, you probably won't like it.

Title: Great Core Values

Title: Solid, Steady, Ethical

Title: Stressful but well compensated
View8: Pay is decent for the role, benefits are excellent and I truly loved my team and coworkers. Lots of room to move up and quickly, but this is mostly due to the location of the regional center I worked at. Lots of training and support.
View10: Calls can be stressful, volumes are high and burn out is somewhat inevitable. While hybrid, position was at some point entirely remote and having to return to office and commute made it impossible as a mom of a small child.

Title: Not “really” a diverse company
View8: I met some of the most amazing people there. Literally some of the best relationships and friendships I have ever had at work!
View10: Worked there for almost 9 years drank the green koolaid! I bought the “benefits” package and the ERG noise into believing that all my side of desk work and participation in the equitable and social work ERGs do would provide me with the uplift I worked so hard for! Don’t buy it they may welcome you and preach of equality but in HR the bigotry and racism is real. Take a close look at the leadership before you sign!

Title: Good company, great benefits; but you're just a number.
View8: Fidelity is an absolutely great company to work for, the benefits are astounding and the work environment they have cultivated is top-notch. You get a very solid vacation package (I started with 18 days), a top-tier 401k match, and access to their wide array of brokerage tools. Everyone is really friendly and helpful, and I always felt like I could find someone to go to if I ever didn't know the answer to something.
View10: After training I was assigned a permanent shift which was completely terrible. They offer a shift-bid but it's based on tenure and not time bid. So if you bid monthly to try and get a new shift 20 times in a row, and then someone who's just been there longer decides they want a new shift at the same time... they're getting it. I worked 4x10 M, W, F, Sa from 12:30 - 11pm. Despite all the amazing things about this company, you are in a call center if you take the high net worth role.. and they will put you on a schedule that fits the call demand not your lifestyle.

Title: Great place to work
View8: Company benefits are on par. Compensation (overall) is excellent. The company REALLY cares about its employees.

Title: Run away from this company
View8: Great brokerage platform for self directed investors.
View10: They have massively over hired where there are too many advisers and not enough opportunities to successfully build a practice. Relationship building and financial planning with clients is not prioritized and the only thing that matters is how much managed money and annuity business you do each month. Management is horrible and does not value or respect their advisors. They look at everyone as expendable. Micromanagement of number of appointments (they expect you to have 20 appointments a week), dials, and clicks on various tools. Anyone with self respect and dignity, eventually leave. Fidelity is running their brand into the ground.

Title: Great National Firm with lots of Local Pitfalls, questions and issues
View8: Fantastic starting company to gain experience and learn more about Financial Services. Compensation is competitive, Benefits package, company matching and overall sense of caring for employees from Senior Management is remarkable. Opportunities for advancement from within in many locations, less so in the local investment branches. Technology and tools are amazing, just not used properly to be the best firm (See Below!)
View10: Significant benchmarking nationwide, yet markets are not all managed the same way. Local leadership has tremendous impact on career development and leads shared. One would think top producing advisors would be rewarded, but only in certain markets is this the case. There is no traditional "Book Building" and each and every year you basically start from scratch so you feel like a mouse on a wheel. I have seen some movement away from relationship building and doing what's best and right for the client to more sales and "Selling" something, which is a message in certain markets and could be based on poor performance from those markets. Overall guidelines for planning is a means to sell, and not offering the client's the planning for a means of setting clients at ease, esp. in volatile markets like we have seen.

Also, similar to most call centers, people just forward calls back into the system adding to the high volume of callers and frustrated customers when you answer.

Title: RUN. Don't work here if you value your mental health
View8: UMR insurance is good and PTO is generous
View10: I don't even know what to say or where to start. This call center prison has caused me to have to start taking depression medication and I get constant anxiety attacks and have mental break downs every week. This sad excuse of a company does not value their employees on the 401K WI side WHATSOEVER. We are the slaves and minions to their system, bottom of the totem pole and viewed as garbage employees who have to take main majority of ALL calls that come through. So we get ALL the grunt and BS for the lowest amount of pay, go figure. It's back to back calls with not even a 1 second break between calls, you have to follow your schedule down to the second or you "schedule adherence" will mess up, can't be under 88% out of a capped out 94% scale or you get in trouble. We are treated like children. We are so incredibly micromanaged to the point I want to get sick. Also, good luck going to the bathroom or God forbid you have children or an emergency while on the clock. The script we have to follow make us sound so robotic and saying that 50 times a day can drive one to insanity. Oh and they record every call and if you miss any important points in your script, well you pretty much fail. Anything below a 90% to Fidelity is a fail. Shame on this company. I can't WAIT for the day I can leave this place and never turn back. Just horrible! Never in my life have I worked for such a terrible company. I will be moving my assets and funds out of Fidelity when I leave.

Title: Associate Software Engineer Fidelity
View8: Good experience new grad. Lets you get expereience with Agile
View10: Hourly and you work like full time. Will work on weekends on rotation even though hourly and expected to only work > 40 hours but you will work more.

Title: Good ideas and intentions, mediocre execution
View8: They hire individuals from diverse backgrounds, even when their resume wouldn’t indicate that they’d be a good fit for the role. They actively try to keep a pc work environment, beyond the virtue signaling you usually see at large corporations, it’s been a nice change of pace feeling like you are truly in a seemingly inert workplace. The expectation for hourly roles is: you clock in on the dot and punch out on the dot without pressure to work extra. They respect your boundaries in this way which is appreciated. The way licensing was structured was nice, you study 90% of the week then come in for a half a day of phones to keep those skills somewhat ready for when you pass. Overall if you’re a recent college grad or looking to make a career transition from another industry this isn’t a bad place to be, you’ll likely get an offer because they have a lot of seats to fill and a decent amount of turnover at the 1-2 year mark.
View10: I have worked in other industries and other large corporations before coming to Fidelity, if you’re new to the workforce or new to working for a decent large corp this experience may seem amazing but it’s mostly external and internal marketing driving that narrative. Most of the 5 star reviews for this role specifically must be from somewhat naive folks or folks that can’t see through the “lifestyle” aspects of the culture and can’t see it for what it really is. The recruiter described the training program as “world class” explaining it would be this 8 month process where you’d emerge out the other side a “financial professional”. You certainly learn a lot but most of us who finished the entire program still feel like we don’t know much, it seemed like an long-winded waste of time, Mgmt seems content with the quality of the reps that exit training and Fidelity certainly seems to overpromise and under-deliver on the onboarding side of things but that’s typical for a large corp. Their goal with training is, in their words “pace over perfection” I can’t imagine touting my reps as remotely competent or being a reputable company when the rep answering the phone doesn’t really know what they’re doing. You should change your objective to: “profits over proficiency”. The job is answering 30-40 calls per day, some good some are bad but it’s definitely more customer service orientated, your most prevalent inbound demographics for this role are the elderly, and rude clueless people that can’t do simple transactions on the website. Pay is bad, 23 an hour start, 24 after that, quarterly target is 800.00 and if you exceed the benchmark, which can be challenging with the callers you get (hour long password resets/account management are fairly common and kill your stats) you can be eligible for year end bonus. 51-54k total comp in a metro area is a tight budget to live on.

Title: I do not recommend. Demand does not match pay.
View8: You learn a lot about 401k investments.
View10: Inconsistent. The communication. The job description and entails do not match up. Bullying and abuse of power. Demand does not equal appropriate pay. You have an obscene workload. Calls are timed and scored. In training it was a lot of making fun of people for incorrect answers. You do an invasive and demanding background check for a pay and benefits you can get at basic companies. Diversity is next to none but in my class there where 3 people outside of white 2 of them where already with the company and was switch departments. I would I have recommended this for someone just starting their career but the intense background, drug screening you have to fill 3 cups up. Demand and low pay is not worth it. You can get the same pay with a better environment and same benefits working for regular call centers or basic store/ entry level office jobs.

Title: Great benefits low compensation

Title: WFH flexibility is going away
View8: Reasonably happy place to work. I don’t feel that the culture is as toxic as other similar companies. There are SO many options for career mobility and they seem genuinely interested in helping you explore that and get the right training.
View10: Now that the “hybrid” return to office has started they are really starting to micro manage it. You must go in all 5 days of your monthly “connect week”…even if there is absolutely NO value added by being in the office (my manager and entire team are in other states). This wasn’t explicitly disclosed to those who started during the pandemic and got used to working 100% remote.

Title: A forward thinking, culturally progressive and wonderful place to work, grow and learn

Maturing diversity to include the mature population and not just the upcoming population. Empowering middle and lower management to make human decisions.

Title: Love Company Culture
View8: Reputation and Stability: Fidelity Investments is a well-established and reputable financial services company with a long history of success. Working for such a renowned organization can enhance your professional profile and provide stability in your career. Learning and Development Opportunities: Fidelity offers a variety of training and development programs to support employee growth. You can benefit from continuous learning opportunities, including workshops, seminars, and online resources, to enhance your skills and knowledge in the financial industry. Competitive Compensation and Benefits: Fidelity is known for offering competitive compensation packages and comprehensive benefits to its employees. This includes health insurance, retirement plans, paid time off, and other perks, ensuring a satisfactory work-life balance. Career Advancement Opportunities: With its size and diverse range of business areas, Fidelity provides numerous opportunities for career advancement. You can explore different roles, departments, or even geographical locations within the company, enabling you to expand your skills and progress in your career.
View10: I don't have any cons for Fidelity Investments

Title: Great company
View8: Great company to work for. Benefits are amazing. Work/life balance great. Growth opportunities abundant.
View10: Work can be repetitive. Hustle is required.

Title: Great company, great managers
View8: they do not micro manage people, managers are all treated very well and treat their reports well
View10: there arent many advancement opportunities that pay in the 150k - 180k range so a person can be stuck in the same role for many many years potentially

Title: Great Benefits
View8: Remote with good pay and great benefits
View10: no room for advancement in the remote space

Title: Decent start
View8: A great job to have if you want decent money with little stress. Very simple job, but not boring either. It depends on what you do with your free time. Great company in general and lots of opportunity to learn new skills.
View10: You can get dangerously comfortable here, so be careful and have a plan.

Title: Great place to start
View8: a lot of career development and mobility. Big company
View10: You have to take initiative for your own growth since it is a big company. Compensation could be better, but can also grow fast

Title: It is a call center job to put it short
View8: After training you do get time to be off the phones if you put in for it and you get approved. You can get licensed after 6 months if you find a position opening.
View10: Micromanaging. Stats on your calls are everything. Little to no room to move until after 12 months. It is more about who you know and not what you know. On high volume days you are barely able to get a break. If you have mental health issues related to easy stress, this will most likely make it worse.

Title: A great deal of work but it's a great company
View8: Great hardworking coworkers A great deal of resources Many companies to choose from; one company with many many companies (personal investing, workplace investing, PAS/PPS, etc) Great pay Great bonuses
View10: Sometimes you have to work a good deal of overtime, nothing wrong with that. Like all jobs, it all depends on management. I was always lucky in that I had great directors and managers who supported me. Fidelity is a GREAT company.

Title: Great Company
View8: Great Culture Awesome People Events happening everyday
View10: Very hard licensing, especially for this role for someone with no financial background. Tough training but you will get through it.

Title: Great place to work
View8: Fidelity was a great place to work. They are very supportive of career development. It is a very engaging work environment. They really seem to care for employees and try their best to help with work/life balance. Excellent training is provided. They also have excellent benefits.
View10: It can take a long time for process improvements to take place. The amount of systems needed is very convoluted.

Title: Great Company, Highly Recommend
View8: Fidelity has such a great culture and some of the best benefits I’ve ever seen. I started here not really knowing about how important benefits were until I got pregnant. I was so lucky they give 4 months maternity leave and 3 months paternity. If you want to work for a company who values acceptance and diversity while also making sure their employees and their families are taken care of choose fidelity for sure.
View10: It’s growing quickly so management does change pretty frequently but not too big of a deal.

Title: Not Great Pay
View8: Train you well and bonus received for. Completing trainjng
View10: Continued pay is very minimal for what you deal with on the phone.

Title: Great place to work
View8: Friendly culture and great benefits.
View10: Remote work is being removed as people are required to spend more and more time in the office.

Title: Great place for technical staff to flourish
View8: They value technology Lots of growth in role Pay is decent though Abby cut it via bcg recommendation

Title: Good but boring
View8: The income is stable and quarterly bonuses are great. Benefits are good as well when you qualify: yearly profit sharing of 10% of income, 401k match, insurance, student debt repayment, tuition reimbursement, gym reimbursement, etc. The people are actually really nice.
View10: It is hard to move up when you don't know someone. Roles are usually already taken or hiring managers have someone in mind before posting. You have to come to the office for your assigned week every month. The constant change of managers and team members doesn't allow for growing real connections. Lack of diversity in day-to-day activities. Almost impossible path of moving off a phone role.

Title: Proud to have made a career at Fidelity Investments
View8: Exceptional company to be part of. Autonomy, growth potential, support & eduction, and the benefits are unbeatable.

Title: Good place
View8: Chill place to work, good wlb
View10: Low pay, forced to go in office

Title: Benefits

Title: Great company if you find the right position
View8: Great company to work for with amazing benefits and training program to get your license. Lots of flexibility. If you find the right position within the company, you can make it a lot long career
View10: The job is a grind, metrics keep getting raised, and burnout happens quick. Extremely draining. There’s work life balance if you have the energy to pursue a life outside of work after having to be on the phones nonstop.

Title: Stepping Stone to Aligned Book of Business
View8: Flexible schedule, travel, work from home
View10: None, I love my job and Fidelity.

Title: Great company to work
View8: Great work culture across all teams Lot of learning opportunities for starters
View10: Higher red tape Some teams are difficult in growth

Title: Fido good/bad
View8: nice overall benefits, weak on salary adjustment$, lots of opportunity to move around though
View10: competitive, easy to have outstanding accomplishments overlooked, seldom give raises even to match inflation

Title: Great Place to Start/Build Your Career
View8: After "paying your dues" in the entry level role (Customer Relationship Advocate/CRA), you can get promoted to High Net Worth after 3 consecutive months of strong phone stats. Personally I did not find that difficult, but some do. The comp in this role is very competitive when factoring in bonuses, 401k match, and profit sharing. There are no commissions in this role as many reports indicate - we don't sell anything. Generous quarterly bonuses though, based off phone stats.
View10: The 5-days-per-week, one-week-per-month policy is a bit silly. I'd much rather come in 1-2 days per week, every week. Very little remote work flexibility due to regulatory requirements. Unless you have a special exception, you must work from your home address. Very little diversity of day in the inbound phone roles.

Title: Phenomenal
View8: Great place to work. Great team and a phenomenal company. They’ll help you learn the industry and provide opportunities to grow. Forgiving and encouraging management.
View10: The role requires you to be resourceful. There’s plenty of resources and availability to help, but you have to take initiative.

Title: Awesome place
View8: Not only do you teach others as an employee but you learn a lot as well. The facility is great, a lot of extra curricular activities available as walking trails, ping pong, quiet rooms, horse shoes. They also have their own cafeteria. They used to have free meals but not anymore but still decently priced . The company encourages growth is what I love, they don’t want you to stay in the same position. Opportunities are always given as long as you do your work proficiently. Training was fun and great. Hybrid working from home and office.
View10: They got rid of profit sharing and free meals. Strange for a company that is so profitable. Not much cons unless you don’t want to put in the work as some may see it as performance and service driven.

Title: Very mixed feelings
View8: Lots of great benefits! Adoption assistance, 7% 401k match, tuition assistance and many more. People are upbeat, kind and respectful. In the rare cases when someone is not treating co workers with respect, or is reported for sexual harassment it is promptly handled. The culture is inclusive to women, people of color, people who are disabled and the LGBTQ community. Great options for career mobility and development. Paid training for people getting licenses. Work life balance is positive for many roles.
View10: Pay is low for the work we do and though management can be well meaning, the real decision makers do not care. Raises are only given for good performance if HR decides that it is merited for that year. It’s very ambiguous and leaves many employees feeling sour. Raises are usually only given from promotions, which keeps people trapped in mid tier pay despite hard work and dedication. Resources necessary to answer customer questions are inconsistent, leading to lots of extra work and follow up required. This is another known issue for the call center reps that never gets fixed. Little is done to mitigate abuse from customers. Significant micromanagement due to metrics of being in a call center, while trying to balance extremely complex needs from highly compensated customers.

Title: Worst Company; Disorganized & Toxic
View8: great benefits, pay towards student loans, beautiful offices
View10: Micro manage you by 15 minute increments, expected to work late nights daily and weekend for a salary '9-5' hire with little training, few resources, departments don't communicate between each other, causing a huge waste of time and money in the effort to fix issues

Title: exhausting
View8: pretty good benefits. Licensing was great. they paid us to study and take the tests. You have to put effort into studying, I enjoyed it. Was able to pass my tests on the first attempt.
View10: Once you pass the tests and become fully trained, you get stuck in a shift that you probably didn’t want. It’s so difficult to move out of a phone role. It’s almost like they’re punishing you for passing the tests instead of rewarding you. I asked numerous times if I could get guidance on moving to other business units and was basically told it’s all about metrics and that there is no alternative. However, even when you meet the ridiculous metrics in a month, it might be that the growth skill you wanted is not even hiring. So it’s like an endless cycle of MAYBE next month, IF you hit the metrics again. I definitely feel like there is a double standard for certain people. The back to back phone calls are exhausting and customers can be so rude. You honestly are just another number to this company.

Title: Good benegits/terrible upper management
View8: Good benefits The retirement department is amazing. They know their stuff. Especially retirement help desk
View10: They promote based on calls per hour now. They call them "automatic promotions". Basically, people prove that they're good at a job by how short their calls are (even if they're providing inaccurate information during that short time). Managers don't even recognize inaccurate information because they're not specialized on a specific function (ex. Retirement, high net worth, stock plan services, etc.) HR does not care about what an employee has gone through with a specific manager. They always take the manager's side, unless the employee makes a bigger deal about it constantly. The system they use to measure "calls per hour" is extremely flawed. It glitches people out of their status codes, which causes their CPH to go down. Management is aware of it, but does not take responsibility. They'll tell the employee to directly connect to their router, and that will minimize the disruptions. This is their solution, rather than changing the way CPH is calculated, or simply making CPH an insignificant measurement. Bonuses for the little guys may or may not come. You also might get scammed out of it by some loophole they find. For instance, they had a tax incentive going on that had an "attendance kicker" which meant you couldn't have any "same day PTO"... however, even for people who scheduled PTO months in advance, because some of it landed on a Friday or Monday, the system counted it as "same day PTO" , so those people didn't get the "attendance kicker" for that month.

Title: Great start, bad stuck
View8: Great training and support within the role. Company pays for training and SIE, Series 7 and 63 licensing. Management is generally supportive. Compensation and benefits are on par with other corporate companies in the same industry. Opportunities for other roles within the company.
View10: There is not much career opportunity where you are not on the phone all day. Know this going in. Management can be a stickler on metrics when there are many intangibles on calls. Shift schedule can be very draining with four 10 hour shifts a week. While most clients are generally very nice, regardless taking calls can be exhausting. There is a huge deluge of information which can be very overwhelming when starting. Even a year in, learning and breaking down certain financial concepts to clients in real time and resolving technical issues on the fly can be difficult.

Title: The worst

View10: I worst time with my new onboarding Staci always putting me down and saying I was. It going to pass! I enjoyed the company but not once did I meet with my branch team leaders and at home we had to study and study my butt bit my onboarding team never though I was working I was mico manage and lied too

Title: Great Company to work for
View8: awesome benefits, Great working environments
View10: Nothing cons about this company

Title: Great company. Exhausting role. Make sure you have a plan!
View8: Benefits PTO Variety in schedules Work-life balance Overtime is suggested but never mandatory Help desk to support during calls Training Onboarding Coworkers Advancement (to specialized phone roles)
View10: Unreasonable clients Repetitiveness Mental health can be at risk from an onslaught of mildly/moderately belligerent clients. Customer survey will affect bonus (Clients will score low for an error that is entirely outside of your control) Off-phone roles are minimal and highly sought after Senior management doesn't regularly interact with associate-level outside onboarding.

Title: Great Experience
View8: Fidelity is the best company that I have ever worked for. Managers truly care about the well being of employees all the way from Abby to my direct manager. The pay is above average and benefit package unmatched.
View10: None, Fidelity is a great place to work.

Title: Great place to work
View8: -Good management with great ways to make you grow -Always learning and advancing personal goals -Will work with you to move forward and advance your career
View10: -None that I can think of

Title: Great place to work

Title: Great company going down the wrong payh
View8: Great people Great pay Great work life balance

Title: Diversity & Inclusion is disenfranchising many
View8: Fidelity is a great company for many to start their careers and know the training will be unmatched. The benefits are generous despite the 5 year vesting schedule for the 401k. PTO is 23 days plus paid Federal Holidays for anyone under 5 years more for longer tenure. Many of the perks are geared toward a younger workforce so if you have student loans and want to continue your education, you will be served well by Fidelity's benefits.
View10: Entry level jobs are not a livable wage given the skyrocketing costs of housing and food in the Salt Lake area. It takes many grade levels of promotion to make much more than entry level pay. Luckily the benefits help make up for some of that but some people just need to be able to pay rent and eat as a priority to being fully vested after 5 years of service. Fidelity is growing at a very rapid pace and with all the diversity and inclusion initiatives it's leaving some groups without certain rights. There are no longer safe spaces for women to be able to deal with bodily functions in safety and privacy. The culture is so inclusive and refreshing but over the top which has also created a level of toxicity where some do not dare advocate for themselves without fear of backlash. Hearing the whispers of dissatisfaction over some of this makes for a fairly stressful environment and might be sewing deep seated seeds of division. There has to be a way to dance the diversity and inclusion dance without excluding wide swaths of the population.

Title: A lot to be desired...
View8: Great work environment with a lot of amenities.
View10: Had 5 different managers within 1 year. Management acts only in the interest of the higher ups and doesn't care about their employee's as people.

Title: Amazing company!
View8: Technology, compensation, hybrid environment, camaraderie from colleagues
View10: I can't think of anything

Title: Good experience, but only in the business sense.
View8: Competitive pay and great benefits. Hybrid work schedule (1 week per month in office). Lots of support in terms of training. A good place for people who like call center work. Gave me enough experience to move on to a role in a field that I want to work in. They are actively hiring unlike a lot of financial firms, which is a testament to the strong market position that they have.
View10: Soul sucking work. Customers have just gotten worse and worse regarding their behavior since I started working here. No assigned seating when working on-site. Upper and Middle management is very beaurcratic and unemapthetic. Expect any accommodations you try to make to take several weeks to be approved. Office politics are more important than merit in terms of career progression when aiming for roles higher into the organization. Very structured (which is both a good and bad thing). Not a good place for creative minds to prosper, especially early in your career.

Title: Great Time
View8: I didn't work there but need to do this to see some tips for a different job I'm applying to.
View10: See pros. They are the same pros and cons. Weird.

Title: Every company has pros/cons
View8: Good benefits, growth opportunities, ERGs
View10: Non flexible dynamic work weeks have been a struggle personally. They don't care how anyone feels about them. Instead of scheduling a "required" week, why not assign how many days you're required to go in a month with flexibility. As a recruiter- I can do my work remotely and it's been inconvenient driving to the office which means less productivity time to do my work. There shouldn't a strict schedule to follow. Mixed signals from upper management on expectations for dynamic work weeks. They boasted how dynamic work is meant for connecting , but then get in trouble for connecting too much? Doesn't make sense.

Title: Shallow Sales Role Marketed as Financial Planning
View8: -Mostly friendly colleagues and some nice perks. -Remote work setting.
View10: -Work is monotonous and unfulfilling. Not really financial planning but getting money in the door with shallow discussions of people's personal finances. -Hours can be horrible, working nights and weekends and 10-hour days. -Pay is below the industry and benefits do not make up for it. -Management carousel.

Title: Family Owned - Large Company that Feels Small
View8: -Employees are the shareholders of this privately owned company, so we aren't beholden to what other large financial institutions often have to worry about. -The business is very diversified, strong, and forward-thinking in our investments into new products, services, and fee structures. -They care about you! From the benefits they offer, to investing in your career growth by paying for your education and/or new certifications and skills, to encouraging mobility within and having the ability to jump around and try something new in another business area, among many other great perks. -The management team is great! You often work alongside midlevel managers to executives at every level and you are appreciated for your contributions no matter what level of tenure or seniority you have. This is due to our flattened hierarchy and humble culture that starts from the top down.
View10:
While the following may seem like "cons," they are actually understandable... It goes without saying that you get out what you put in, so you likely won't experience the following cons as long as you are actively growing/learning new skills and networking/volunteering with groups for new opportunities. That said, the "Cons" are:

-Base pay can be a little low, especially in your first couple years if you're not actively seeking new opportunities to learn new skills, network, or take on side projects. 
-Annual pay increases are small for a profitable company. To realize a significant jump in pay, you need to actively seek a promotion or jump laterally to another team or business unit. 

Moral of the story is, don't stay stagnant! But that goes for everything in life!

Title: real investment platform

Title: Fidelity review
View8: Great culture and top-notch training.

Title: Investor Center Great Place To Work

Must be working non-stop if you want to be successful. -Hybrid work available, but you will be much more successful in person.

Title: Great but Heavy Handed

The rest of my team are in different locations and are assigned different connect weeks. Little reason is given for the change, and there is 0 flexibility for swapping days. Can't guarantee that it won't increase to 50% in office for everyone(some teams already are).

Title: good company to work for

Title: Amazing company to work with for professional growth

Title: Pay is too low and they don't take care of entry level associates
View8: I learned more about finance than I ever would have known and they paid for training and certifications
View10: Lack of communication around a number of things is shocking, last year there was a 5k bonus but this year nothing and they didn't let anyone know, my whole team was expecting this and it didn't come. Pay rate is too low for the work you do and there is only the option for a promotion after you have been in your current position a year. Managers talk about caring but do not actually do anything to help you out, for instance I do not have a car and am being asked to come in a week every month and my manager told me there is nothing he can do.

Title: Toxic, toxic, toxic.
View8: Pay rates are slightly better than the industry average. The work is good resume fodder.
View10: To put it bluntly, the company doesn't know how to fix or even identify dysfunctional teams. It doesn't make a lot of sense. Fidelity is so large, they've been around for such a long time, and they are excessively worried about lawsuits and legal actions. You'd think they would have a plan regarding allegations of toxic team culture, they'd investigate the situation, and then they'd make some attempt to fix things. And yet ... no. TL;DR I found a different opportunity at another company and left as soon as I could.

Title: The remote prison

You can try to seek help, but ultimately, you are not equipped for success - There are 0 opportunities to network as every second of your day is completey dedicated to being on the phone
