Title: Silos, Senior Management has no transparency. Pay well below industry average. Nepotism.
View8:
-Benefits are comparable to other brokerage firms. 

-Workforce is starting to become younger

 -Free Coffee -Walking trails, onsite clinic, onsite fitness centers.
View10:
-This company relies on people fresh out of college who are entering a cuthroat job market, or older associates who are too invested in the company to leave. This is not a place for experienced industry professionals.

 -Management and hiring practices based solely off of nepotism. 

-Not publicly traded so the company's Senior Leadership has ZERO transparency. 

-Return to office policies made by out of touch senior leaders, and during hybrid we are at more than maximum capacity. Logistics of this have not been addressed.

 -Pay is totally made up and based on feelings rather than acheivement. It is substantially lower than industry average.

 -Bad behavior by management is rewarded, and those who abuse their team are promoted. 

-Onsite Cafeteria food, while subsidized A LITTLE TINY BIT is completely inedible and has given myself many people I know food poisining.

Title: Career Mobility
View8: RCS career mobility is a scam. They shuffle you through various phone roles and act as if they are of importance to the company meanwhile they actually offer no experience notable or worthwhile to a higher up position.
View10: Career mobility? Absolutely zero with RCS. Claims many openings, every only a few with hundreds of others competing, no increases in pay to keep up with inflation, lots of corporate politics to make it seem as if there is change and improvement to the RCS space with little action.

Title: Great pay, work-life balance, and upward mobility
View8: Great pay, work-life balance, and upward mobility
View10: There are some policies that are shortsighted and unfair, that lead to suboptimal outcomes for the employees, clients, and company as a whole

Title: The best career and company in the U.S
View8: Benefits, Location, Honesty + Integrity in the financial industry, Leadership, promotion and cultivation from within the company, respect company wide, and inclusiveness, charging stations for electric vehicles
View10: The walk from the parking garage to the building!!

Title: Best Company Culture
View8: The people you work with amazing. I’m a returning employee and the grass is not always greener.
View10: Relative pay to other firms

Title: Great company on paper, but lacking in action
View8: The company offers great benefits and has a pretty nice campus.
View10: The training here is subpar. My manager was difficult to get in touch with and the HR was incompetent. They say they offer endless support but their actions tell another story.

Title: Secure company, good work life balance, good culture
View8: Secure company, good work life balance, good culture, lots of room for new opportunities both promotion wise or moving laterally. The benefits are amazing, it's what keeps me at the company. The people are very chill, really easy to get along with mostly everyone.
View10: Base pay lower than industry standard.. UX designers start at $70k-$90k. No quarterly bonuses. I'm not currently making enough to get out of debt ironically.

Title: Great benefits
View8: Benefits are very good for my family
View10: Call center life is draining

Title: Help 401k participants plan for retirement.
View8: Supportive friendly management. Encourages growth and career development.
View10: Little to no opportunity to meaningfully increase earnings in the company. Better paying jobs seem almost impossible to get.

Title: I wouldn’t recommend
View8: Good Benefits. Culture is alright. It’s just the in office culture doesn’t fit everyone. Honestly, if they fixed the culture, I’m sure more people would enjoy working there. But it’s hard to keep an old school mindset with progressing world.
View10: Work from Home isn’t really work from home. It feels a bit forced and because of the culture associates don’t really feel empowered to speak up against it. The pay isn’t competitive. Vertical movement is really more like winning people over vs can the job get done.

Title: Great Benefits, Less Flexible Than Before
View8: Amazing benefits, they match 401k contributions up to 7%, tuition reimbursement helped me be free of student debt and acquire my MBA. I’ve always had great managers too
View10: Dynamic Working is uncertain and not flexible. Doesn’t work for everyone. I moved during the pandemic and now they make me fly in on my own dime every month to attend the in office week. My managers have no problem with me working remotely full time but they have no say on the situation. When they tried to fight for me to get an exception, it was shut down.

Title: Great team
View8: The structure of the Workplace Planning and Advice team is very thought out. Bonus potential is very good and very good benefits. Remote position
View10: Base pay is not the best. Tough to find next role in remote space as it is still new.

Title: I love Fidelity
View8: They want to help both employees and clients grow
View10: None so far and I don't foresee any

Title: Good first Job
View8: Great benefits, food culture, shared of the company
View10: The pay could be better

Title: Shady communication practices by senior leadership hurting employee morale
View8: It's a job that pays, not much monthly, but if you can keep your sanity until the end of the year, you have a chance of getting paid your market rate for your position with the annual bonus if you stay until the end of the year.
View10: Working at Fidelity was tolerable while fully remote. Then "dynamic" working started, where they forced employees to come to the office for 3 days a month, in the same week that they scheduled. Then a day or two after they closed the employee satisfaction survey, they announced that they were increasing that significantly starting in January. Suspicious timing to say the least. Why the need to go to the office? Remote working increased employee productivity. There is no need for all positions to be in the office. Yes, they have an exception process, but those approvals are far and few between, and do not cover all employee issues. I have a strong suspicion that come the new year, there will be a mass exodus.

Title: mid
View8: good place to start but very high attrition
View10: Felt like working at the modern equivalent of office space. People seemed to love working there but no one loved what they did.

Title: Good company, but feel like just a number
View8: Amazing benefits and culture within the regional center, they provide a lot of opportunities to network - mentoring, employee resource groups, events, etc. I've had really amazing managers while at Fidelity, the best I've ever had
View10: Glorified call center, you're just a number and the needs of the business always come first. I don't like that you're required to bid for PTO during some of the peak times. I feel like if you're on the call center side it is nearly impossible to break out of that

Title: Great company and culture
View8: Benefits, flexibility, and culture make fidelity a great place to work
View10: Mobility can be tricky if you don’t put in the time

Title: Overall great company to work for
View8: Great benefits. Good yearly bonuses. Great offices and amenities. Always room to grow and move horizontally in the company
View10: Pay could be better, but benefits balance it out. “Old school” atmosphere but getting better.

Title: Pay is not worth the role
View8: Easy role, decent work life balance. Management is solid
View10: The people you work with on the phones are often rude or dumb. The stats that are directly connected to incentives and bonuses are often uncontrollable

Title: A lifetime career
View8: Company culture is amazing, always trying to not side with anyone when it comes to politics, caring about social action, lots of giving back to the community. Clear ways to develop, enormous number of resources to learn and grow, career coaching, amazing benefits. Dynamic working between office and WFH. Awesome amenities including on site clinic and gym.
View10: Not the best place for people that prefer to work alone and not interact with colleagues.

Title: Good Place
View8: - Good Management - Easy work while I was there - Decent pay and nice people
View10: - They tell you there's upward mobility. It can feel limited - Work can be boring and monotonous

Title: Dependent on what Adviser you are aligned with
View8: If you have a great team and adviser you are supporting, its one of the best jobs at Fidelity. Communication is key and management likes you to take ownership of your results and tell them about successes and what you would like to be upskilled on
View10: If you have an adviser you are supporting that is disengaged or doesn't involve you, it can be hard to get enough work or compete with the other Planning consultants you will be ranked against for performance reviews and bonuses.

Title: Woke Serfdom
View8: Very few. The benefits are trendy. Decent time off.
View10: Weak 401(k), training is sub par, support for certain job functions is non existent, no real career paths (except get off the phones ASAP), lack of experience and skill with most managers, antiquated processes and technology, a lot of Woke cultural provisions, sub par compensation, ineffective organizational structure for dealing with customer requests and processing (The call centers are US based, but processing is oveseas), the Diversity and Inclusion area is non representational of the work force and does not hold much value, and the organization does not understand that its primary focus should be to be the best financial services organization versus a Woke culture factory.

Title: Very resourceful
View8: For any problems you may have or face, Fidelity has the resources for them. Team leader was available for any questions for majority of shifts.
View10: Very meticulous about their craft.

Title: It was okay
View8: Good pay and benefits, onboarding trainers are extremely awesome.
View10: Your job relies on you passing the Sie, series 7 and series 63. It can be a lot of pressure.

Title: Great company overall
View8: Great people, good overall benefits, never bored, innovation encouraged, privately held company yet large and established business enables Fidelity to invest in new ideas and its people and company to thrive,
View10: Work-live ballance not always the best, but It has gotten better over the years. Pay and culture may vary a bit depending on what part of Fidelity you work on. To succeed, you generally need to move to various groups within the company to grow professionally and to be considered for larger roles. This is not always the case, but even within the same company within Fidelity you should plan to consider that else be pigeon-holed.

Title: Good place for Innovation
View8: Best place to work with good employee benefits. The CEO is always innovates the direction for the employees. You can experience all the modern technologies to help you upskill in carrier One of the big privately owned company. The job involves lot of learnings through out your life time. Fun places to experience all the cultural parties goes all over the year. The biggest tech gaint's in the trading industry.
View10: I am happy working at fidelity. It all depends how you work for the company.

Title: Wonderful
View8: A ton of opportunities to grow and explore.  Benefits for both full and part timers. Good pay. Supportive crew and management. Tons of activities to engage and contribute in
View10: It’s a phone center job as their biggest role. That’s not everyone’s cup of tea. Micromanaging on the phones. Stingy about time off if it is not scheduled even if it’s an emergency

Title: Culture is amazing
View8: Everyone was welcoming, especially managers. Very helpful and want you to succeed. A lot of support to pass Series 7 and 63 exams.
View10: Customer Service heavy after 8-9 months of training. A lot of pressure and expectations. Micro-managed and a lot of monitoring. Hard to get promoted outside of phone roles.

Title: Great Workplace
View8: - Management helps/encourage every associate during licensing process - Benefits are great! - Very helpful team and they care about your success!
View10: - Licensing process is difficult

Title: I love working for Fidelity!
View8: Fidelity Investments has great PTO, Healthcare, and Benefits Package. They have remote role opportunities as well as onsite. There’s opportunity for careeer growth and progression.
View10: The base pay tends to be lower

Title: Company that Cares
View8: Amazing benefits and work/life balance. A company that puts people, and relationships first. That encourages collaboration, and constant improvement.
View10: I cannot think of any negatives. The Westlake regional center is amazing, new and improved.

Title: Lots of Flexibility with Remote Work
View8: Pros: Work from home 100%, Regular development time away from main function of inbound phone calls, and great benefits
View10: Cons: It's customer service and some days are better than others. Tax season is a particularly busy time of year

Title: This job has changed my life!
View8: With this job, I'm gaining financial understanding and knowledge that I can apply to my own life. For the first time in years, I have hope for the future. The benefits are unlike any I've ever had. They even pay my student loans! I've been here since May and I have yet to meet an unhappy person, myself included. You're not hired to fill the client services team. You're hired to start your career and they promote relatively quickly. I'm aiming to join the licensing team, since I used to be a teacher. It means a lot that I can use my degrees and experience.
View10: Licensing is HARD! Fidelity supports you through every step of the process and more of our employees passed the exams than most other firms who hand you a book and give you 30 days to pass or you're out. Your training period is long but you learn a whole lot and the company celebrates every milestone you reach.

Title: Mixed feelings
View8: Very good benefits, mostly remote
View10: Lots of work, you tend to work more when remote and weeks in office you’re always playing catch up on account of commute time. Work life balance can be tough.

Title: I was employed from 2015 - 2017, not 2019
View8: Great entry level job. Will receive great experience. If you are proficient with vba, and Tableau you will excel.
View10: Pay is low, mornings can be hectic because of the nature of mutual funds.

Title: Good if you can pass
View8: It’s a good place to grow your career IF you can pass the tests. But there is a lot of support to help you pass. Great benefits, great leaders. It’s a big company but I never felt like just a number to them.
View10: Everything is centered around the tests. Extremely stressful. No work life balance

Title: decent
View8: -work life balance - 401k - benefits - growth opportunities

Title: Great place to build your career
View8: Supportive and collaborative environment. Dynamic work arrangement supported by Fidelity’s commitment to invest in technology.

Title: Great job - no longer remote
View8: Great company culture Advancement opportunities Good training program Good compensation
View10: We are being forced back into in person work - I started working here as a remote worker during the pandemic and was recently told (without much notice) we are being forced back to the office one week a month starting in January - there is no flexibility in which week (you are assigned) nor is there the option to just do in office one day a week the whole month. This is very difficult as an involved dad - with commute I have to leave at 6:30AM and don’t get home until 6PM - working from home my day is 8AM-4:30PM. This change will be hard on my kids, as I will not be able to be as involved in their evening activities.

Title: Great Company, not excited about the push for back to office
View8: Great company to work work, surrounded by talented and driven people. The pay and benefits are good.

Title: Great place to work!

Title: Soar program
View8: Great people, great benefits, wonderful amenities in office.

Title: Great company
View8: Culture, benefits, opportunity to grow, leadership

Title: Vice President Level Roles

Title: Bad Unit, Great Company

Title: Good Company, Terrible Leadership/Mangement
View8: Great national backing, good training, and resources.

Surprisingly, a lack of understanding of financial concepts and strategies across the board, and emphasis apparently on communication or the appearance of intelligence rather than you know... Shockingly out of touch with many things, ironically opposed or maybe uninformed? of the CEO's vision, especially on new innovative asset classes. Probably shouldn't have expected much from a retail finance location, might be the place for you if your into the business of business, cronyism, networking, have other non-finance retail or sales experience or wanting to get a foot in the door

Title: Great Culture to Work with Benefits

Title: Stop dynamic weeks

View10: Forcing folks in that live too far away

Title: Manager WI PS

Title: Good pay and benefits for what the job is but you’re a robot
View8:
- Pay was good for what it was; received pay increase within 3-4 months to compete with other financial institutions. 
- Benefits and retirement plan (medical, dental, vision, 401k, stock program)
- 16 week paid training program (8:30am-5:00pm)
- some of the people you meet and community events etc
- good resume builder if you need to help build it
- diversity
View10:
- Once you are out of the training program you are 12pm-8pm ET. This seems okay at first and if you’re a night owl, but it wears on you. You can advance ur way to a better time slot but if you start a new role that’s the same sort of field, you go back to 12-8pm and have to work your way back up.
- Stats; you have to meet call criteria which some is understandable but then you have situations that they don’t train you on and your stuck ruining your stats. 
- You feel like a robot and are really just a number. Saying the same things over and over to every customer can get tiring especially some of them are super rude and impatient.
- a good manager and a bad one here affects ur motivation to do the same exact thing over and over again
- hourly salary; they tell you and send you an offer that it’s a salary position but are paid by the hour

Title: Great WLB, Not so competitive conpensation
View8: Great Work-Life Balance. Hardly anyone bothers post 4 PM on weekdays unless there's something urgent.
View10: Fewer growth options and well-established practices stop you from thinking out of the box. Not so generous when it comes to offering salary packages to employees.

Title: Great Company but can be a tough job
View8: Great benefits like retirement, healthcare options, s tudent loan assistance, and vacation. They pay well and do make you feel like they care about you. Also, Beautiful campus. Plenty of learning opportunities and advancement opportunities. If you are good with people and can brush off a toxic customer, like following a strict schedule, and can deal with a schedule that changes day to day, then this is a great job. I also made some lifelong friends there.
View10: Dealing with people's money can be difficult, and when it is over the phone, people can be very rude. Your time is constantly monitored by software. I didn't have a consistent break schedule, and I found it difficult to eat on demand. I don't deal well with toxic people, so it was a very stressful job. I also felt completely drained most days. Since there are so many clients and each have its own rules/policies, it felt like I took a 8-hour test most days. Most of the time I used my breaks to meditate from customers. But if you can handle that. This won't be an issue. My biggest issue was the software time management that tracked every second of your time. I found that really stressful. Not because I wanted to slack, but quite the opposite. I wanted to be perfect on time, and sticking to the schedule that changed every day was very tough. I'm a pretty smart, energetic, and confident person, but this took its toll on me.

Title: Excellent job, needs more direction
View8: Amazing work life balance, purely outbound dials, remote position (not all) and hands off leadership approach
View10: No direct path career wise, have to work on that on your own, can ask leadership but initiative is on you

Title: Great place to work
View8: Love this place don’t plan to leave
View10: Don’t have any so far I love it

Title: Great Career
View8: Great role with growth opportunities for those that put in the hard work.

Title: It is what you make it

Title: Great Company
View8: Benefits Flexibility Work/Life Balance Training Profit Sharinf

Title: Great place
View8: Good interview process met whole team
View10: Drug test screening not sure

Title: Really good place to work
View8: Benefits Environment People are great Management is super supportive
View10: None that I can think of

Title: Great culture and benefits
View8: The culture consists of managers that truly want you to succeed, and their support in helping you get licensed and learning the content to best clients is above par. If you do not know something you can always get help from other people around you. The benefits such as tuition reimbursement, gym reimbursement, 6% 401k match, and starting with 4 weeks of PTO are some of my favorite. The company supports the work life balance & managers encourage you to take time off. There are also a lot of opportunities to get to know your team with team outings; good thing that is prioritized.
View10: Large call volume can be exhausting & it is easy to get burnt out. Hard to move out of the call center.

Title: Amazing Benefits and Management
View8: All of my managers have wanted me to succeed and have worked with me on a great one on one level, making me feel valued.
View10: They hold out on giving bonuses so you’re always walking out on money if you leave.

Title: Glorified Customer Service Role
View8: Good office with cafeteria and standing desks.
View10: Dishonest job description. Promised career advancement that was not true. Micromanaged.

Title: Highly recommend
View8: World class benefits Developmental program Access to resources The people Enjoyable client base Highly competitive Equitable organization
View10: High expectations / standard of execution

Title: Great Company
View8: Benefits are phenomenal. 401k match is 7% , 10% of salary profit sharing contribution , affordable health and dental benefit , education reimbursement. 23 pto days plus bank holidays in first year of employment
View10: Only thing I could think if is the repetitive the role can become. You have to be okay with receiving incoming calls and make the occasional outgoing calls for appointments or cold calls. You have to find your own language and become comfortable to do planning at a moments notice no matter the situation

Title: Good place to work
View8: Easy to preform and get bonuses/promotions if you just listen to your manager and take coaching advice.
View10: Phone based role incoming calls. Some days are harder than others.

Title: Great Benefits, remote restructuring is a silo.
View8: Fidelity has awesome benefits! Paternity leave, Profit Sharing, Education Reimbursement, lots of PTO, and the Fidelity brand is well received by clients.
View10: Recent restructuring in the remote space has inspired me to leave this review. Fidelity is purposely siloing internal candidates. In the remote space, they stop announcing internal opportunities, instead only sharing this info with management (gatekeepers of you will). They have also increased the amount of roles that are external hire only. Roles that are clear promotions, can't even apply for. Many roles only have one path, regardless of what is promised.

Title: All good
View8: Remote learning and access was great
View10: Asked to work overtime a lot

Title: Just ok
View8: Remote work is a plus.
View10: Too much training to get certifications, and hardly any on your actual job. Thrown on the phones and just have to figure it out.

Title: Amazing Company!
View8: promotes changing job roles within company beautiful campus flexible work environment gym on site great benefits
View10: great workplace, no cons in my personal experience

Title: High net worth associate
View8: Great job training you. Flexible schedules and great work to life hours. Benefits are amazing
View10: the pay is low. its nice if you are 22 but if you have a kid good luck sticking around. Im pretty sure garbage men get paid more

Title: Growth for remote workers is nonexistant in the service side.
View8: decent starting pay, work from home setup and perks.
View10: The pressure of hitting consistent metrics for calls and ratios, breaks and times makes it a headache after months. They want to amass a massive customer service network, and promises of advancing even with 7/66/63/65 licenses are slow and always come with conditions internally. Was initially onboarded with the expectation that i would move into an advisor role, but after 10 months and still promises, it wasn't worth it. worst of all despite the high inflationary times, they do an annual assessment, and determined my pay would not increase. As a company I trust them with my money, but as an employee you're just a spec of dust. Despite making just under 60k in their high network service role, benefits are not paid for, so our family of 4 was costing me $600 month for insurances despite being healthy. Left for a job in fintech making much more with full covered benefits and better work/life.

Title: A. Implant that truly cares about people.
View8: Generous bonus structure, opportunity for growth and new development and the relationships made are unrivaled. True customer focused collaboration in approach to solve customer needs. Senior leadership is very approachable and offer guidance when asked. Not to mention an extremely easy to manage hybrid work schedule. I couldn’t recommend a better place for building a career and future.
View10: The pay is a little on the lower side Lots of acronyms to learn East to get tunnel vision in your own work Sometimes there are bottlenecks internally for internal team needs

Title: Excellent Pay, Benefits, and Training
View8: As much training as you care to take. Compensation that is tops in the area and in the industry.
View10: Geographically dispersed teams makes it hard to work effectively together in some cases.

Title: Good place to start but they try to keep you with benefits not salary
View8: Good benefits. Comp time is respected. 401k is second to none with match and profit sharing. Fast paced work environment if you like it. Vacation time was not frowned upon. If you are on the right team it could be a great learning experience. Great if you are working in a financial business unit.
View10: They pay you a lower salary than the competition but they compensate you with "benefits". This was reiterated by management multiple times. Other companies have good benefits as well so I didn't buy into that. Lots of hours for less pay. One year I worked 10 weekends and many 12+ hour shifts only got a 3% increase of income for 2021. Friends get promoted rather than hard working employees. If you are going to work for EI....run away....IT is not appreciated for their hard work. It will be a lot of hours with not alot of pay.

Title: Fidelity Investments - Maximize Opportunities
View8: Great benefits and they encourage mobility, meaning you can develop many skillsets and move to new areas of the company. It's a great way to maximize your potential and income.
View10: Once getting to the VP level, base pay adjustments are not automatic, even if you aren't near the "average" for the role.

Title: Okay -
View8: Bonus and long-term incentives very good. Solid work-life balance.
View10: Wide range of work ethic. Many people coasting, happy to get a paycheck and just stay around. Culture of passive-aggressive behavior inhibits even greater results.

Title: 23 year employee, 2nd stint with company
View8: Benefits, learning early in career.
View10: Likely the case with many companies today, but more focus on feelings and making sure they are diverse rather than focusing on getting the tasks done.

Title: good place to rest
View8: rest and vest for most of the teams working there
View10: no wroth / little growth depending on team.

Title: Best benefits out there
View8: 7% 401k match, pays 15k of student loan debt, excellent healthcare, profit sharing, 5 weeks of pto to start, hybrid work schedule—can’t beat it
View10: Truly none come to mind the benefits are great

Title: No Better Place To Work
View8: The community aspect of Fidelity is the main reason for my review. From my first day in office to now, I always feel welcomed and supported by every single person at Fidelity. The employee benefits are incredible and there is so much room for growth within the company in thousands of different directions.
View10: Huge company, so you have to put in a bit of effort to stand out.

Title: Employees are fantastic! The work is too hectic for me
View8: The environment is great! My colleagues were super supportive and very positive! I love the positive energy in the environment!!! You find some people here and there that are not so great. But you find that anywhere!! I promise you. I can say nothing but great things about the employees at Fidelity
View10: The work was too much for me. Calls were back to back. I didn't have enough time to breathe. You are micromanaged for everything that you do. I go to the restroom about 3 times a day. I exceeded my "off the phone time" because it exceeded over 7 minutes every day. I tried to go to the restroom during break but that's something I can't control. The entire obsession with metrix and numbers was way too much for me

Title: Great benefits
View8: Benefits - Fidelity offers the best benefits package I've seen in the industry

Title: Snr Software Engineer
View8: Inclusion & diversity, good pay, worklife balance, no long commute, bonuses
View10: Longer chain of command, in person office, should offer fully remote to some employees

Title: good company
View8: lots entry level positions with sponsored licenses
View10: must have Bachelor degree or higher to be promoted

Title: Always keep improving
View8: This is what Fidelity does well: -Benefits -Training -Inclusivity
View10: This is what Fidelity can improve upon: -Flexibility with communication styles. While branding is important, call language should not be so restrictive that if we get off the script a small amount, we don’t get penalized. -More breaks allowed -Managers staying on top of licensing in a more timely manner rather than having the employee (who is in extensive training) follow up with everything.

Title: Decent Career Starter

Title: Left due to poor manager

Title: Great place to start

Title: Great benefits; low pay

Title: Decent job, but phones aren’t for everyone
View8: Good benefits Pleasant company culture Have had great managers in my personal experience so far

Title: Data Analyst Review
View8: Benefits are great and amenities are very nice. WORK LIFE BALANCE is AMAZING (but also depends on your business unit and role). Company culture is also pretty good- emphasis on learning and cultivating your individual growth too.

Title: Great work environment!
View8: I love everything about working at Fidelity. From leadership to culture to work life balance it is an amazing place to work.
View10: No cons at all! Amazing place to work!

Title: Good company who treats employees well
View8: People tend to stay at Fidelity. Pay is competitive, if not necessarily top end. They value employees and genuinely want to make the employee experience rewarding and stable. There are a ton of great secondary benefits as well, such as student loan payments, retirement awards, HSA contributions, and a very generous 401k match.
View10: There is a lot of inertia at a company this big, especially when there is not much movement of senior leaders. The hierarchy is pretty top heavy and tends to be older, so there is a reluctance to try anything new. And it can be pretty political as there are groups of managers who have known each other and worked together for a long time.

Title: Fantastic Employer
View8: Great community, great benefits and culture!!
View10: No real cons outside of being a larger organization.

Title: Incredible company to work

Title: Great company. Great people. High standards

I've seen this happen with other companies but I sort of expected a bit more understanding at Fidelity. It is such a good company. I wish I had been able to make it work.

Title: I like my job overall
View8: Great leaders, good benefits, good tech. High moral standard company, strong mission statements, many career options, world class firm

Title: Great company and benefits

Title: Incredible company

Title: Excellent company

View10: None that I can think of.

Title: Room For Improvement
View8: The reputation and the benefits were great.
View10: Poor communication throughout the process. It took over a month to receive a response from HR's request for an interview. Once hired, it took 9 emails and a trip to the corporate office to get the I-9 processed because HR wasn't able to receive it (format had changed). The equipment for this remote position was received several days to several weeks late for 25% of the class. The training workload was unrealistic with the utter chaos that unfolded. Over 4000 people were hired within a few months.There was a lack of accountability and competency with the leadership assigned to me. The IT resources was unable to serve the quantity of employees hired within a very short period of time. The class size had doubled due to the aggressive hiring and the training was poorly executed.

Title: Fidelity review
View8: Love this company, very supportive, dynamic, and constructive. I learned most of my customer service experience from this role here. The training provided was super supportive and you were not alone in learning the company values and learning tasks. I am proud to represent fidelity. They helped me become very time organized and very efficient and effective in roles.
View10: Not what i want my career to be .

Title: Worth a try
View8: - They sponsor for Series 7 exam - Hire entry level
View10: - The inbound job is draining - Metrics and standards too demanding

Title: Good for start of your career
View8: Benefits Work/life balance Development Career mobility
View10: Low salary Not flexible with wfh High turnover specifically in FI Still got some old school dudes that don’t care about culture

Title: This company treats its employees and customers right.
View8: Fidelity is privately owned, and family-led. It’s values are based in the idea of helping people, by empowering everyday people to grow their savings and making investing more accessible. Care for employees is also a major focus and it shows in the benefits and pay practices. Many people stay for a long time because they relate to those values and the people are great as a result. Our CEO (Abigail Johnson) is awesome - she pushes her leaders to be on the cutting edge of research and employee practices, and prioritizes modernizing the company. The company isn’t afraid to invest in hiring and projects at times when other firms are contracting, but is responsible and prudent in running the business. Although there is room to continue improving in DE&I, the priority is clear and actually being lived out. Personal growth and risk taking is rewarded in one’s career, and test-and-learn / agile / scrum methods are common in many areas of the business. I’m extremely proud to work here.
View10:
Because everyone is so values-driven and the company is growing, it is easy to burn yourself out - there are always opportunities to grow and contribute. Leaders are sensitive to this and it’s starting to change (eg some leaders demonstrate more ability to prioritize or set boundaries), but the onus is still on each employee to manage. The upside is that this is a symptom of the company’s growth and hiring - a much better problem than the alternative. 

The pay is competitive and fair, and regularly assessed, but also structured in a way that is somewhat complex - so some employees leave or decline offers because they don’t understand the long term benefits and pay growth.

Title: Good place to start.
View8: Very educational cohort style training
View10: I left after 5 months because of the low pay, the fact they wouldn't reimburse my move, or provide me with a phone replacement (was on phone all day for the role)

Title: Career progression
View8: Industry leading work Good opportunities of Tech projects
View10: Beyond Director level, career progression and advancement is difficult, not necessarily merit based. Additionally, compensation is not competitive, well below industry standards, long term employees are at a disadvantage

Title: Pay alright, advancement opportunities dubious
View8: Great benefits and culture, fair pay

Title: Great work place
View8: Flexible Hours PTO Good benefits

Title: It’s okay
View8: Nice work environment Very helpful and welling to train
View10: They talked about all these opportunities for new positions but make it so hard to move to something off the phones

Title: Not sure it’s worth it.
View8: There are not many pros.
View10: Working at Fidelity was the longest couple of years of my life. Bait and switch interview tactics, revolving door of management (four managers over 15 months), fear mongering, low morale. Not a pleasant place to work. Wouldn’t go back. Wouldn’t recommend.

Title: Bait and Switch
View8: Great Benefits, Culture and people are amazing.
View10: When it comes to setting expectations there is lack of any of it. They ultimately trick you into thinking you get to rotate between these business units. But in reality it is a call center job. They have a new program out called the you program thats suppose to be all about transactional role, but if you dig deeper its still 75 percent phone calls. Fidelity get the best place to work because of the benefits, but its a smoke and mirror for how management and expectations are ran

Title: Investment
View8: Great benefits, friendly working environment, Great work life balance and flexible work schedule.
View10: Pay sucks but they think offering great benefits will make up for that. Repetitive work, Business units do not properly interact with each other to know what the unit work consist of so double work it sometimes done or correcting your assigned work because other business unit have messed up. I believe a lot of people are there just to collect a paycheck because they do not know the proper process of their work assignment so for many years I believe people have just got into their positions by just doing mediocre work. Networking will get you farther in the company regardless of if you know the work or not. Ancient Systems which affects a lot of the reason why most business units don't know what other business units is doing because they're working on different systems that do not interact together.

Title: Great Licensing's Opportunity

Title: Greatest company/firm/etc. I have ever worked for, even if things did not end exactly how I had wished.
View8: I was let go by Fidelity due to my inability to pass the required licensing exams that each onboarding client service representative must pass in order to advance their career in the securities industry (ideally to retire from Fidelity, a company known for keeping hardworking associates employed for long periods of time. One could only imagine how distraught I was to learn that I had lost it all because of the exam. I gave my all every single day and showed up on site despite the three day per month minimum requirement. I feel as though I tried and succeeded, to the best of my ability, to make a positive mark on the faces I saw at the workplace and put my best foot forward at this transitionary time in my personal life as well. This opportunity was a way out of a lot of troubling situations for me. I write this review, hence, to highlight the important truth and current state of mind I possess with respect to my former employer, for whom I have zero resentment or reason to ever say anything negative about Fidelity whatsoever. It was the greatest opportunity in the near dozen jobs I have listed on my resume, and kickstarted a career in the securities industry by inspiring me to re-register for the FINRA exams all by myself again. To everyone that gave me an opportunity at this incredible firm I say thank you, and with the experience I've gained and things I've learned, I will not still be at this company by the time I retire, but somewhere beyond the stars instead, as this setback has given me an opportunity - just like Fidelity did - to dream big in my career with a vow for hard work. #Fidelityassociate
View10: Like I said, no cons at all!

Title: Tax Business Downfall
Position: Licensed Sales Assistant and Financial Professional
View8: Great co-workers with like minded values. No micro-managing.
View10: In the last 9 years has bought a tax service. I understand the concept of finance and tax and we have an estate planning attorney-but the business on the tax side is run poorly. I have been told year after year that it will improve. It hasn't improved. Also just became an RIA and not sure it was totally thought through what all the changes and processes would be.

Title: One of the better firms to begin your career with and retire from!
View8: Great starting salary/hourly compared to other firms. Benefits are great, can't complain. PTO is good. Can roll over 40 hrs/yr. Hours are reasonable and predictable. Maternity and Paternity Leave. Offices are cozy and there's lots of fun things going on. Gym access and showers. Free food/snacks like every day. Water, coffee, expresso machine, the works! Onsite cafe and bistro. Most managers are people that you could hang out with after work; they really care about you and will work with you on life matters where they can. Robust career coaching and planning resources. You can schedule a sit down with the VP or whatever and they can mentor you, which is legit. The clients really love this company, too.
View10: Meritocracy based promotions at the lower end, then relationship and perceived experienced based at the upper level positions. You need people to know you, and you need to know people if you want higher positions. Have to come into the office more now, thanks to regulators. Not a place where you can make 7 figures+ as an advisor, and to succeed here you need to "drink the kool-aid" and do things the Fidelity way. If you are coming from another firm where you could make 5 figures a month from selling financial products and services, you won't make that here. If you are new to the industry and are looking for a place to start, then start here. Their product offering are cookie-cutter and lack customization and sophistication. This is great for the average investing customer. Great for the advisor looking to not have to think much. But this is not so great otherwise.

Title: Great Company to Work For.
View8: Fidelity is one of the most moral companies you can work for. Benefits are extremely good for the industry including 12 weeks of parental leave, 7% dollar for dollar 401k Match and 10% profit sharing a year. The job security here is also extremely high.
View10: Pay is on the lower end of the industry averages.

Title: Good company

Title: Stable company

Title: Hit or Miss.

Title: CONS and Pros of Fidelity Employment
View8: quarterly bonuses, yearly raises, great health insurance and other plan(s), profit sharing, understanding of leave of absence, allowed work from home during covid until 2022
View10: Management and above do not take concerns/needs seriously, employee relations do not take covid concerns seriously, no precautions taken against covid other than reporting (no masks, no social distancing, requiring employees to come into the office if covid reporting levels for the area are "reduced" even when they're still incredibly high), paid far less than local and national average by at least 7k+, the workload has increased with no end in sight, "multi-tasking" has been taken to unsustainable levels, stress levels of employees have skyrocketed since covid began with no relief, training for positions are lacking: too short, content is vague and outdated, trainees lack support from trainers, resources to perform daily job functions are conflicting and outdated, the interview process is incredibly lengthy, middle management is overwhelmed with the amount of work, middle management is also pressured by their superiors to ignore employees needs/etc to push company agenda

Title: Great Company Bas Position

Title: Current Employee
View8: Competitive Pay Work life balance is good

Title: Committed to Associate Engagement #Diversity
View8: Fidelity is a leader in associate engagement. We live Diversity and Inclusion. In 2022 we rolled out Neurodiversity resources. #ValuedAssociates
View10: No cons. Fidelity encourages us to bring our authentic self to work!

Title: Attention marketers….this is probably not place for you.
View8: Comp & benefits, work from home
View10: If you are a strategic marketer leader used to a sound omnichannel marketing program, I would look elsewhere. Most marketing teams here are treated like red headed step children, lacking tools & resources to achieve the most basic marketing objectives. It’s like stepping back into 1999. Don’t get me wrong - there are many really smart marketers within the company who know how and want to do the right things….but are blocked at almost every turn. This comes straight from the executive level - the people running the show clearly don’t get how impactful a funded, motivated, technically advanced marketing team can be. Especially interesting given the company is very intent on engaging the next-gen to fill their long term pipeline - not sure how they think they are going to get them without smart, data-driven marketing programs and the technology that supports.

Title: Great place for software development
View8: For a big, big enterprise company, Fidelity tries to adopt a lot of the modern business and development practices that you associate with smaller startups or tech giants like Google/Uber/Twitter/etc. They've been on a multi-year journey to embrace Agile methodology—there's still work to do there, but they've come a long way, and put a lot of resources toward making it more than lip service. They invest in cloud technologies like AWS and modern web tools like Angular, Node, etc. They even give you 1 day out of every 10 as a "Learning Day" to stay up-to-date or broaden your skills. Pay is competitive, and they gave an "extra bonus" last year beyond the normal profit-sharing, just because the company had done so well. Work-life balance is encouraged and respected, and PTO is generous. Most of all, I have no concerns about job security in uncertain times!
View10: They are a big company. Working for a small startup might be more exciting and adventurous (though some projects within Fidelity have that "startup spirit"). There's some inertia and levels of bureaucracy if you want to change a process or procedure. The huge size of the company means that you can have a totally different experience on a different project or division of the company.

Title: Company treats you fairly, pays well
View8: Great paid training, career development opportunities, fantastic benefits
View10: It's finance, which can be draining. Dealing with customers can be difficult since personal finances are so important to people

Title: Amazing company that keeps getting better

(They may adapt on this after feedback). Also base pay is sometimes a little low to industry, but the benefits package closes that gap.

Title: Not the same company
View8: Good benefits Avg industry pay. Open office environment. Work/life balance.

Title: Don't do it
View8: They give you $10 a day for lunch
View10: Some managers expect for you to be perfect at everything. I was told that everything needs to be perfect. The job that they advertised was nothing compared to what you have to deal with. Training is 11 weeks long and you read and watch videos. There are no dummy accounts so you can't practice unless it's on a live account. You really can't move up in a position unless you've been in your current one for 2 years. Our lunches are only 30 mins and granted you get 2 15 min breaks but its hard to unwind mentally on just 30 mins. If a customer writes a bad review on you whether it was the customer's fault it's on you. Also, we were just told in training that if we ask a team for help with a question and they give us the wrong answer and we tell the customer the answer, it's our fault. We'll get in trouble and possibly written up. They want us to "predict" or "know" that the answer the team lead gives us is right.

Title: Not Progressive
View8: This company is hiring in several areas and finally focused on digital communication.
View10: Despite its progressive talk, Fidelity management is wedded to old ways of doing things: demanding people return to the office 5 days a month (with more days to come) simply to fill office space. Some folks are driving an hour one-way to sit in an office where no one on their team works which means they drive into an office to still attend meetings on Zoom. Makes no sense! Also, don't believe the hype about Fidelity diversity and inclusion. Upper management remains heavily white women and men. Diverse hiring is at lower levels in expendable positions.

Title: Fidelity is an IT company
View8: Fidelity invests heavily in technology to ensure customer success
View10: The agile operating model went a bit too far, too many coaches, scrum masters and non-technical leaders driving technology capabilities

Title: Great benefits
View8: Benefits are superb, and continue to grow and add in. Generous leave time if needed. Great strives in the diversity and inclusion space. Supportive environment. Training is above average.
View10: I feel compensation is not as competitive at the base pay level. They offer bonuses/stock options but it’s rare to actually get them. The tenure is newer, a lot of tenured people have left so you are surrounded by newer associates. Along with pay, I don’t feel the company keeps up with inflation and rising costs. I’ve been there 8 years and still can’t afford to buy a home in my current housing market.

Title: Metric System and greedy management causes pervasive mental health problems in low level workers
View8: Decent pay, formal training, benefits
View10: Always compared to others and very intense productivity metrics, mental health problems throughout call center, apples call center does not use humiliation as a management tactic like fidelity

Title: Good Benefits, Terrible Management
View8: Benefits are great, training and licensing are paid
View10: You will be micromanaged down to the second by a computer once you’re out of training. It’s very strange because training and licensing is a very smooth process, but once you start working full time it becomes a draining call center role where you have no room to breathe. Management sometimes has no answers for you either for important questions and you’re just thrown into the full time role. Benefits are good but salary is low compared to other companies

Title: Good place to work
View8: The benefits package is really good. Fidelity really cares a lot about their employees and invests a lot into them. Even if the wage is lower than other companies, I think they make up for it with how much they give us benefits-wise. It is also a stable company and rarely lets people go, which is awesome to know that my job is secure. They also hire a lot from within, so there is a lot of room to grow in the organization.
View10: It is a massive company and that can result in things taking a really long time to happen. One especially annoying thing is how long it takes to get accesses. It makes sense that they want to be secure and whatnot, but it takes a long time to get things and sometimes if it is a once a year process then the access is removed after a certain time and has to be requested again when the team wasn't thinking it had to be.

Title: Great opportunities, if you can play the “game”

Title: Not Real Financial Planning
View8: Great benefits and 401(k). Somewhat flexible with work remote.
View10: Extreme micromanagement from branch leaders and market leader. They sell you on the fact that you will be doing comprehensive financial planning for Fidelity investors but really you are pushing sales tactics to put Fidelity investors in extremely expensive and mediocre preforming managed investment accounts and annuity products. Management cares way more about sales numbers and irrelevant KPIs than they do providing quality financial planning and doing what's best for the client. If you're a real fiduciary Financial Planner at heart, this is not for you.

Title: Join Fidelity, leave and then come back

Title: Great internship!

Title: Going in Reverse
View8: Pay and benefits are good 90% of the people are really great to work with and talk to My manager is very understanding and supportive You get incentive bonuses of $100 each week your work Monday and Friday and sign in on time. For peak weeks (high call volume weeks) you get a $200 incentive. There’s a $1000 bonus ($700 after taxes) for finishing training and another one after 6 months. There’s about 3 or so weeks of PTO and you can take voluntary unpaid time off too.
View10: They require everyone to come on site 5 consecutive days each month when your job can be done better at home. Imagine a room full of phone associates all talking at the same time. Not great for the customer service experience. They love talking about how they support work life balance, but ignore the fact the a lot of employees have to add 2 hours of driving time when going to the office. The 7% 401(k) match doesn’t start until a year after working here and even then you have to wait 3 more years to be vested. A lot of the stats they use to measure call success are not realistic. You can have 90% schedule adherence but if your wrap/idle time is too high (time you use to log calls or use the restroom) then they’ll focus on that. The surveys participants fill out can leave you a positive note, but they’ll label it as “Vague” If a call is transferred and the participant has a bad experience with the second person and fills out a survey, the survey reflects on you because you answered the phone first. Genesis (the system we use for taking calls) has a lot of problems with Mis- transferring calls which causes participants to have a bad experience which makes our jobs harder and our survey scores lower. The technology we use is VERY outdated. We have 2 different systems for doing rollovers/withdrawals. Depending on the type of transaction you’re doing determines which system you use. So it’s inefficient and time consuming.

Title: CRA

View10: Entry level position where networking is key to move up

Title: Good to work for overall
View8:
-competitive salary (47.5 a year, paid hourly) with little to no experience 
-a lot of pto (almost 5 weeks)
-quarterly bonuses. They’re fixed in this position, but variable based on performance when promoted
-a lot of promotion from within. It’s almost expected
View10: This department is open until 11, so you may not be able to work regular hours. The on job training is pretty arduous, especially if you aren’t licensed before the role (however, all training and studying during work hours is paid for) Hours can be long, and taking a lot of phone calls can get exhausting.

Title: CSA Salary

Title: Great company for career growth
View8: This is a large company and they encourage internal career growth. It’s a great place to start a career or make a career transition. They have great benefits, with quarterly or yearly bonus opportunities based on position, 7% 401k match, and 10% yearly profit sharing to your 401k. PTO is generous at 160 days per year with increased every 5 years. Culture is fairly relaxed, and work from home is 75%.
View10: Most of the time they hire people in at entry level and it can be competitive to move up the ranks. Most of the entry level jobs are comparable to a call center with specialized areas of expertise. Some of those roles can be very repetitive so there isn’t a lot of variety of work until you move into other areas of the business.

Title: Great company
View8: Great benefits and upward mobility
View10: Working on the phones can be stressful

Title: Solid Company
View8: Lots of room for growth and movement. Obtained my CEP, which was encouraged and learned an incredible amount. Lots of schedules to choose from, solid bonuses and company stock
View10:
There were times when managers rotated frequently. During a shift bid, I was one of the top performers who bid for a shift. I didn't receive the shift, when I asked about it and compared my performance to coworkers management said they'd get back to me. They then advised they'd made a mistake, but that they wouldn't correct it. We eventually found a compromise where I worked a different shift, but it was very disconcerting that I was told they'd made a mistake and then I had to push to get them to not simply say "Too bad". 

We also had a member of our team who practiced textbook "Call avoidance" where they would simply sit there and avoid calls forcing more burden on the team. When confronted, the employee admitted to it, but was given another chance. I knew of other employees who were let go for lesser offenses, so there were inconsistent standards at times. 

At the time I left, I had a new manager of approximately a month, and the senior manager spent the entire interview asking me about that manager and how they worked. I let the manager know that she seemed to have some sort of personal vendetta, she fired him shortly after.

Title: BEST JOB EVER!

Title: NOPE
View8: Benefits are pretty good PTO policy is very generous (it has to be or you're getting burned out fast) Coworkers are generally good people
View10: I found a review from about five years ago and it hit most of the points that I want to hit, so I'm using it as a basis here; it's discouraging to see that so little has changed with this role at this company in a five-year span. It's an indication of how absolutely oblivious upper management is to the situation on the ground. 1. Heavy volume of calls- there is NO pause between calls on many days. It's ridiculous to expect people to provide excellent customer service for an eight or ten hour shift when the volume is that heavy. 2. You will be micro-managed. Even if you're intelligent enough to make decisions that are best for the customer, you'll be told to do it according to the protocol, which a good deal of the time doesn't make any sense. 3. You will feel like a robot. You have to follow Fidelity's robotic call structure; miss any element of that and an excellent call becomes 'satisfactory' according to the judgement of "Quality," the Big Brother of Fidelity who evaluate calls. It is EXTREMELY demoralizing to feel like you have done an amazing job and that customers were happy with your service, but Fidelity is going to find a thousand things to criticize you on. 4. You are expected to know (or know how to locate) massive amounts of information. You will be asked obscure questions, and you'll have to sort through electronic encyclopedias of financial information to attempt to find the answer. 5. Customers get screwed over all the time. Somebody taking a $150 payout from their 401K has to pay the same $25 withdrawal fee as someone who's taking out $100K. Want tracking with your rollover check (Fidelity doesn't do direct rollovers)? You're going to pay $25 for that too. There are "recordkeeping fees" on most 401Ks. It's a racket.

Title: Fantastic place to work
View8: Company is welcoming to folks from all walks of life and has made strides since my hire to become even more inclusive. I feel more free to disclose who I am to work than I do family sometimes. My personal management has been engaging and transparent without overstepping to the "work is family" mentality, and gives me support whenever and however I need it. Work and personal life separation is achievable, even while still working from home, and the company has not pushed us to return past our comfort levels, which is refreshing.
View10: Any major cons I have would be purely circumstantial and wouldn't be a fair representation of the company. Nit-picking, I would say that sometimes company movement and adaptability is too easy, and there is a lot of turnover in some places that can lead to confusion, but it also leads to a lot of folks, myself included, having a longer tenure with the company and finding their niche.

Title: Financial Disneyland
View8: The most warm collaborative company I’ve ever worked at in finance. It’s not about the individual accolades but the team and organization. They make your growth and knowledge paramount. I just learned about the profit sharing and that’s a powerful benefit for retirement. I will never leave until I am ready to stop working and retire.

Title: Fidelity MADE is a SCAM!
View8: Decent PTO- you are going to need it, you will be burnt-out, I have had jobs with half the amount of PTO and not used all of it, I used every single day at Fidelity Paid Training and Licensing- They pay for your licenses and the time it takes to train for them, many people freak out during licensing and say how difficult it is, I found the time to be pretty good, you have most of the day to yourself to study with the materials they provide and then fill in the gaps with Zoom meetings, pretty different experience from when you get on the phones and are glued to your workstation because you never know when the phone will ring. Overall the exams are hard but I passed on the first attempt for each of them and didn't study a minute when I wasn't getting paid to do so. Having said that if you are having a difficult time with the material it may be a different story for you, also you will lose many co-workers during this time since they cant pass the exams. Our team was lucky and only lost a few but others had close to the whole team fail. If you can't pass the exams they often offer you a job with the 401k team but it is for lower pay and much higher call volume. Managers- Your experience may vary but every manager I had was very helpful and easy to approach Coworkers- Once again your experience may vary but I have had several teams in my time with Fidelity and they were mostly all good to work with Campus- This depends on your regional site but Durham has a very nice campus, with on-site cafeteria, albeit mediocre food, walking trail, very nicely equipped gym, Starbucks and ping pong and cornhole. In Durham's case it has some amenities you might expect from a tech site and that is because much of Fidelity's tech is centered in Durham, I have heard from co-workers in other sites that their campus is not nearly as nice and that probably has to do with the fact that non-tech at Fidelity are treated like second class citizens. Also you know what has many of those amenities, my house, so maybe don't force your coworkers to drive in so they can do the same thing they would have done at home but in an office, where it is louder and harder to hear clients Slow Season -During the summer months call volume slows dramatically and you may only take a handful of calls all day. It's not as great as it sounds though because you sit in ready for over an hour sometimes and you never know when you actually will get a call so you are stuck near your desk and if you have to go to the bathroom or get up for a minute you have go into not ready, do that too much and they are going to say you are avoiding calls and it will affect your metrics. Decent amount of off phone time when it is slow. - Not much to add to this one Benefits- This is the number one reason that anyone works for Fidelity, for the "amazing" benefits. While the benefits seem amazing at first, if you dig a little deeper they lose a lot of their luster. For example, the incredible match is only offered after your first full year with the company, in the meantime you get nothing and it takes a full five years to vest. The healthcare is pretty good but you are going to probably need it to go on anxiety medication, other benefits sound good but have pretty limited use, such as adoption assistance, commuter assistance that does not cover gas or vehicle payments but things such as public transportation, I don't know a single co-worker who used the bus to get to work nor if there was even one around and lastly, health reimbursement which sounds great but can only be used for classes and not equipment, so it covers Jazzercise but not weights or a treadmill. One benefit that was really great was student loan payments, which only knock on that was it was limited to 2k a year for up to 5 years. Overall the benefits are still really good, however Fidelity is run by smart people and they crunched the numbers and offering these benefits are cheaper than raising base pay.
View10: This first part only applies to those interested in getting into tech, so skip ahead if that is not you. Fidelity offers a non-tech to tech training program called Fidelity MADE, which sounds nice on paper and lures many to the company, however it is poorly run and if you do not check the right diversity boxes, you have no chance. It does not matter if you have a bachelors in computer science from a major state university, previous experience with the technologies they use, if you have had previous technical internships, if you have gotten a 100 on your first attempt on the pre-test, none of it matters because the number one thing they care about is satisfying a diversity requirement. Even the recruiter in charge complained that those running the program made them interview everyone that applied regardless of their qualifications and it set them back heavily. Ultimately it took them three and half months to send out rejection letters, a full month behind their schedule. When you get rejected its just a canned rejection letter that tells you to apply next time and continue practicing your technical skills, which is a joke because the interviews barely touch on anything technical and just a bunch of fluff, tell me about a time questions over and over, I suspect they did this so they could justify hiring blatantly under qualified individuals. This was not just me but several candidates with similar qualifications, the only similarity, our demographic. I wasted a full year before I could apply to MADE, practiced with the technologies in my free time and did everything I could do to prepare but it all was for nothing. If you want to break into tech this is not the way to do it. Future of work - They act like they are geniuses for coming up with the concept of hybrid work. There is no reason to have to go into the office when we worked perfectly fine remotely for over a year, but the billionaire boomer CEO thinks it is a great idea. At first it started as just three days every four weeks but then became five days every four weeks. I suspect they are going to go one week on and one week remote in the future but probably want to wait till after tax season so they can stomach the loss of staff better. The worst part about hybrid work is all the people who are only pay grades 1 or 2 can't generally afford to live near campus, so they have to drive, many well over an hour each way without traffic but all the higher ups do not have a problem with it because they get paid enough to afford decent housing near campus. Pay - The pay is mediocre and below industry standard. It is widely talked about how you can go to any competitor in the industry and make more money but the managers have to remind you how great the benefits are. I went up a pay grade and got to cost of living adjustments during my tenure and I barely noticed a difference. Schedule- Like working 8-5, well too bad because after training you will be moved to shift bid. You will be lucky to get anything before your 5th choice. The shifts start as early as 5am and go as late as 11pm so it is more than likely you will end up working odd hours. Tech Support - Fidelity's internal tech team is almost impossible to reach and it can take up to an hour to reach them, the digital tools that you have can be pretty hit or miss and some of them will just stop working randomly, so it would be great to be able to reach them. Also they are incompetent, when you leave the company make sure to get a receipt for your returned equipment because they will be hounding you to return it even though you already did. Client Obsessed - The company likes to say how client obsessed they are but I found this a joke. Very rarely does anyone at the company actually go above and beyond for the client, they mostly just tell you to let the client know you can't do something. Most of the people at the company are too worried about covering their butt rather than actually doing the right thing. Also it does not matter how great you are with the clients and how great your client survey scores are because how do you get promoted? By having enough calls per hour and if you are even a little under that, you are not getting promoted. You are incentivized to get the client off the phone as quickly as possible and if they don't complain it is good enough. Also I love how they say how client obsessed they are but this is the same company that is actively discouraging the use of mail in favor of digital, the clients who stuck with the company for a half century and helped build it into the billion dollar juggernaut today might not want to use a computer and they should not have to go through a lot of hopes to do so. It really won't even be a problem in about a decade since most of the clients that really care about the mail are in their twilight years. Promotions - The promotions are a joke when it comes to pay, you might get like a 5% bump in pay and a chance to make some more in bonuses. Also for auto promotions they only hire in certain departments randomly so if there is a department you want you will have to keep qualifying for them every single month and hope they are hiring that month and also hope you don't get a trade error because then you are disqualified for that month. Most people just take the first department they are offered rather than going through that. Any off phone openings are crazy competitive, they may have two spots open and get over 60 applicants because most people hate their phone role, so if you want off the phone good luck. Tax Season - During tax season, Feb-April you will be non stop busy and as soon as you hang up the phone another one comes in. I have worked in a restaurant for a long time and I was more physically exhausted after this job during the busy season than an active job like that. After spending all day talking to clients you just want to just sit there and do nothing and not talk to anyone, it is the most emotional and mentally draining time. Anxiety- Almost all your co-workers will talk about how much anxiety they feel all the time. This is not during the first few weeks either, we are talking about people who had been there for well over a year. The Sunday Scaries are real and you will probably get them bad. I ended up having to go on prescription medicine to help manage my anxiety and only got off as soon as I left the job. FINRA regulations - This one is not about Fidelity in particular but about the industry as a whole, FINRA regulations are very strict and require you to give a lot of personal information and limit outside business activities and amount of trading you can do in a quarter. Onboarding - The onboarding process takes forever with Fidelity and is pretty messy. The recruiter told me I had to get drug tested within a couple days but the place they wanted me to use was appointment only and did not have any openings during that time frame. Luckily they were able to reschedule but it was very inconvenient to have to panic that I wasn't going to have a job because I could not get the drug test done in time. Recruiters- Some recruiters straight up lie about the job and what it entails, one of them told my coworker that they mostly would be answering emails. The truth is it is a call center and we are not even able to email clients. How the job is advertised - Fidelity makes a big deal of being a financial professional and how you are going to have a series 7 job. The truth is it is a call center and you are going to feel like you work in retail more than working in finance, especially because you are going to be working retail hours most likely after you are done with training. There is a reason most of the people they hire have no financial background and come from retail jobs. The job itself - All this and I never even mentioned what the actual job is like , the truth is it is torture. One co-worker said it best when he said this job should be banned by the Genova convention, not only did I agree, I used those exact words to describe it to other people before. Surprisingly the clients themselves are not too bad and you even get some pretty pleasant and grateful clients but the job is a grind. Not only is everything you do monitored and recorded, it makes it difficult because you never know when the next call is going to come in. The best way to describe the job is like helping your grandma with her online banking details over the phone all day every day. Many of the people are technologically illiterate and almost everything has to be done on their end digitally. The simplest tasks like password resets and adding banking details can easily take over 40 minutes and wreck your stats. Also if you have to reach out to other departments many times they don't want to take the call from you or it can take a very long time to reach them. I have had to wait over an hour for the fraud department to fix simple issues, obviously the client is mad when you get back and the whole time your stats get destroyed. Many departments like fraud and transition services are chronically understaffed and as soon as you get a call that needs them you know you are not going to have a good time. As the client facing member of the team you are going to have to break a lot of bad news and hear some pretty tough situations. If you like waiting on hold and calling your bank's customer service, this is the job for you. Miscellaneous - The same time they required people to go into the office, they canceled the $10 lunch credit, I don't expect to get free food but the food was only worth it if it was free and I thought it was classless to cancel it at the same time as forcing people into the office more. Also no money for bonuses but a few days later we find out they are going to give a quarter billion dollars to underserved students. They virtue signal about diversity but the tech department is the least diverse place that I have ever seen. Wrap Up - Ask yourself why a company that has such "great" benefits, that brags about being voted a top place to work, has to spend so much on recruitment ads. The truth is it is a low paying call center and for every success story you see, there are dozens that washed out.

Title: Poor Experience
View8: The benefits and paid time off is pretty good.
View10: I worked at Fidelity for a year, if you don’t pass the test (SIE, Series 7, Series 63) you could be terminated. They don’t give you the options for testing up front if you have something going on in your life that could prevent you from passing. You have to research it, call HR, etc. I didn’t pass after dealing with many personal issues and was offered to apply elsewhere (WI, where the pay is less). They didn’t accept me after a year of work. You are a number to them, they don’t care about their people. The girl interviewing me was very young (early twenties) and did not have a personality to say the least. If you like being a number and answering angry calls all day for 20/hr this is the job for you! Personally, you can go work in a restaurant for a few hours and make more. In regards to the WFH environment, my manager asked to view my entire bedroom space where my desk is located. Is this normal? Seems very inappropriate to me. All together a pretty poor experience, lack of communication, lack of support.

I've seen they will chose their employees over clients.

You can never predict what will be asked of you and no matter how much training you get you are not prepared. I had so much anxiety in this role. A select few thrive in this environment, but most people really struggle.

Title: 4 years in
View8: Good benefits Great coworkers Goof work life balance

Title: Crazy making place
View8: Pay and benefits. Paid training.
View10: Fake bro/cool culture. Training begins with a lot of hot air about how *awesome* the company is, to the point where they seem to be trying to convince themselves. Lots of promises made about moving out of the call center quickly. So much sizzle, no steak. So much sizzle, many reviews here echo how leadership doesn't want you to really see that you are getting into a call center job. Fidelity does not allow workers to discuss pay, which is illegal. You have the right - by law - to talk about your pay. Company does not want employees who know their rights. They want fresh-out-of-college young people who they can bamboozle. My manager would pull people out of training to talk about shopping. She didn't like my objecting to that and became a bully. Don't trust anyone. They all talk to each other. Very cliquey, high school atmosphere.

Title: Surprising
View8:
I made a complete career change to work here. I was super hesitant to take the position since it was a pay cut to work here. However, the first 8 months are paid training for licensing. The culture seems fantastic in the office. Everyone seems happy to be here and there are a lot of perks, such as free lunches and coffee. I would say the reasons I'm staying here instead of accepting one of the MANY job offers I have for much higher pay in my previous field are:
Tons of room for growth - they make a huge effort to train people and move them around in the company.
Mentoring - it has been really nice having a manager that takes an active interest in me.
View10:
Low pay and it seems like pay doesn't increase a lot either as you move up.
Required overtime during the busy season.
Desk job on the phones - can be a bit of a grind feeling trapped to your desk
