Title: Grow career and skills - then proactively leave
View8:
Profit sharing is the best in industry - you need to stay 5 years to keep it
Career growth and training is excellent - as long as you know the right people
Tuition reimbursement is excellent
Remote work is very nice
View10:
Read "Think Again" by Adam Grant - Fidelity is one of those companies that does not encourage thinking outside the box. 
Being wrong is not a virtue, nor is humility. 
Egoism thrives at Fidelity. 
Not a safe place for questioning the status quo. 
Do not criticize the process. 
Its all about who you know and not what you know.
Skills development is limited. Once you hit the limit, hit the door on your own and look for a company that encourages personal growth, otherwise you might get stuck in your role with no relevant skills. 
This is a spreadsheet and numbers company, not a people company. 
Your experience is highly dependent on your manager, who likely did not even do your job.

Sky is the limit if work is the only thing that matters to you.

Title: Don't let the toxic positivity get to you
View8: Overall, Fidelity is a great company. I've met some amazing friends and I've loved all of my managers and leads thus far. Management can make or break your experience so its a blessing to have some that you really like. I came in apart of their new LAUNCH program, and the training and support during onboarding was superb!
View10: I've always had a gut feeling that things were going to take a turn for the worst after onboarding. It's not terrible, but you're tied to the phones for 8 hours everyday, minus any trainings you're subject to. That is the job we signed up for, but once you're actually doing it full-time, you'll start to hate it. At least I did. You get nice people sometimes, but the participants (people calling in) can be really entitled and annoying. It also seems like everyone is just as confused as you are. They preach about how the F in Fidelity is for flexibility, but it can quickly turn into organized chaos. Most of my training class is still confused about a lot of things when it comes to bonuses, PTO, etc. During training, they'll bring a ton of people in and host panels full of people that preach how awesome Fidelity is. They're not lying per say, but take it with a grain of salt. Go your own path and figure out if it's right for you. The CEO is also trying to make people come in 5 days out of the month (we do 3 currently) starting in January, and they only plan to increase the amount as we go through 2023 and onwards. She's getting a lot of pushback on it because going into the office is draining and a waste of time, since most of us can work more efficiently in our role at home. Salary is a bit on the low end, but they try to make up for it in "company culture" and benefits. Most of the benefits I honestly don't use so it would be nice if my salary was higher.

Title: good and bad

View10: going a little political and they are pushy about the vaccine. the office atmosphere is also VERY negative and winy. tough to just show up and work hard and go home without the micro managing culture to interfere. also the sales coach is VERY inexperienced and gets in the way more than he helps.

Title: Not terrible, but not good either for tech
View8: Very team dependent for any pros. Stable employment for the most part. Culture varies by role and team in the company too. If you're a developer or some other tech role, focus in on reviews only from those specific roles. Check the dates of reviews.
View10: Check Blind and Levels.fyi before anything else. Underpays a lot from tech industry norms, not a real tech company/fintech, not much developer work or real developer work for tech roles, the list goes on.

Title: Feeling regret
View8: Reputable corporation, base pay is fair to start, mostly good people to work with, benefits are good
View10: Originally was excited to join but almost immediately during onboarding I started to see the culture that was different from what was discussed during interviews. Feeling regret after taking this new job. You have to essentially sell your soul to work here, you have to hand over all your financial accounts and there are so many restrictions and requirements with what you can do from your accounts down to outside activity, to social media, and even access to your personal devices if you choose to use your personal phone for work. So many meetings, all are required to be on-camera. WFH here is so behind the times, they went from mandated 3 days/month during their “dynamic working” to now a full 5-day work week/month, boasting this dynamic model as some sort of super flexible way for their employees to work. Teams are spread across the country and even internationally, why must employees go into an office to take the same Zoom calls with their out of state team and managers? Dynamic working is a farce dressed up in an appealing package as if employees are considered first, when in reality this is a corporation stuck in micromanaging and sinking money into real estate for show when their talent can absolutely perform well and better WFH. What a blow to morale and how convenient this comes out of nowhere with no discussions with managers and after the pulse survey is complete. Onboarding is super overwhelming and stressful, it seems they have a structure with their training but you’re just thrown in with short deadlines and not much direction. CEO is very clearly struggling with adapting to evolving times and letting go of old ways. I could have dealt with some of these, even the original 3 day/month in-office work. But now I’m already on my way out.

Title: Fairly Chill (Sometimes too much)

Title: Culture Focused Business

Title: Life Changing
View8: *7% 401k match *10% profit sharing *Tax season bonuses just for doing your job *The tax-exempt market (TEM) division of Fidelity feels like a tight-knit community within the greater Fidelity ecosystem. *Have not experienced a notable degree of micromanagement in the TEM organization, which I hear can be a challenge in other divisions. *This company greatly rewards hard work and has provided opportunities that have changed my life. *Have been blessed with great managers who want to foster my long-term career growth. "Career vitality" is a major focus of the organization top to bottom, and it has proved to resonate for me.
View10: *You learn most of what you need on the job; baptism by fire. This can be a good thing though, as it forces you to adapt and learn quickly.

Title: Best company
View8: Great work culture, Benefits, Pay and managers that really are there to help you achieve your best
View10: No cons to speak of in my opinion

Title: Financial Planning
View8: Decent Pay. Nice way to gain experience. Great benefits.
View10: More room to make more money would be nice. Wish role had more to it.

Title: Good company

Title: Just don’t

Title: Large corporation with usual benefits and problems

Title: Great job

Title: Its OK

Title: Good Company

Title: Great place to work
View8: Fidelity is a great place to work. Benefits, culture, management, everything is top tier!
View10: No real cons to working here

Title: 401k Service Associate with other job exposure as well.

View10: Lots of phone time- easy to get burnt out if you do not use your PTO. You are very micro-managed in this role. Later down the line, there is room for more autonomy.

Title: Great Entry Job
View8: Incredible insurance and benefits offered

Title: Great work environment and benefits
View8: * Work environment * Paid for licenses * Decent starting pay

Title: Great for new grads
View8: Great paying job with lots of career advancement
View10: Taking phone calls all day can be exhausting

Title: Good experience and benefits
View8: Good experience and benefits. Fidelity will help you get licensed and does provide opportunities for growth. The benefits are excellent the pay is okay.
View10: Your micromanage right down to the exact words you say to clients. Everything is recorded and you are scrutinized on things that were totally irrelevant to the interaction. The metrics in which you are graded are blatantly unfair. The clients are demanding and rude. Oftentimes insufferable. This job can be absolutely draining.

Title: Bad Associate Experience
View8: Some good benefits, not many overall
View10: Leadership doesn't care about associate experience, just pushing numbers unethically.

Title: Overall good. Certain management immature.
View8: Pay is ok. Responsibilities are fair. Paid training a plus.
View10: Micromanagement is starting to become annoying. My current manager is way too nervous for the position.

Title: Why Fidelity
View8: I love the culture and the diversity.
View10: The only con I have is that the hybrid work schedule isn't all that hybrid.

Title: Great Company!
View8: People, benefits, pay, meaningful work
View10: We still have to show up to the office sometimes but the campus is really nice and we only have to go 1 week per month.

Title: Great training
View8: Has a very comprehensive 3 month training period where you get to learn the ins and outs of the job pretty well, has a great hybrid work schedule, there are also performance based quarterly bonuses.
View10: Might not be for those who don’t like call centers

Title: Poor Work-life balance
View8: The benefits are nice, they try to make up for a low salary but dont do much.
View10: The work-life balance sucks. You must be ready to answer your phone and in front of a computer screen for 8 hours a day

Title: Great training
View8: Great training, I learned a lot.
View10: Was a customer service job and dealing with the public is tough.

Title: New hire at SPS - Fidelity.
View8: Simply amazing atmosphere, everyone jumps out at helping when you need it. Management is always looking for ways to help develop your skills and grow, they do not hold you up in one position, great opportunities within the firm if you want to grow.
View10: None at this time, I will check again soon.

Title: Great company
View8: 7% 401k match, 10% annual profit sharing, generous maternity and parental leave, tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment. Culture is great, feels like family. Tons of resources and help for you to succeed in your role.
View10: Big company, so a lot is on your plate, can be overwhelming

Title: So bad I forfeited my sign-on bonus.
View8: Working at their startup incubator means you get to have the benefits of greenfield work while being under the wind of a large company.
View10: While the will to innovate is strong here, many roadblocks from the organization make that difficult. Trying to go outside the lines of their development cycle and infrastructure proves to be difficult. Many pieces of infrastructure for new fields were simply not available. I suspect that will be eased in the oncoming years.

Title: Good Benefits, and System
View8: Good CRM system. Efficient, and great security technology for clients.
View10: Immediate management can be to red tape. People in training treat it like high school. Emphasis is based on following rules, not results or problem solving.

Title: Wonderful company
View8: Excellent benefits. They take good care of their employees and do offer potential for growth within the company.
View10: Transition Services team handles a lot of responsibility and is paid entry level. I would recommend finding another role.

Title: Not a place for minorities or those looking for dynamism in the workplace
View8: Generous time off polices are probably the best selling point.
View10: Fidelity's claimed investment in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion is only an investment in rhetoric and propaganda, in which they incentivize every employee to post on job sites with false, pre-packaged promises of their "great" attributes of being a superior place to work. Indeed, my experience as a member of the LGBTQ+ community was anything but safe. Rather it was hostile in a workplace that was toxic as a whole. As a private company in which structural resistance to change is entrenched like an anchor, inclusive of pervasive nepotism, expect to be a pariah should you try to effect such change in the workplace. In their current state, I would not recommend anyone to join their team, until they can properly align their values with their soaring rhetoric.

Title: Technology organization review
View8: Good opportunities, large company with hands in every financial industry domain so you can get good exposure. Nice culture. Good technology stack
View10: A lot of red tapes to get anything done in time. If you work hard and deliver, you can expect to get burned out. Very uneven distribution of knowledge and large chunk of tech organization is absolutely unproductive

Title: Great place to start a career
View8: Great retirement benefits, a culture that is supportive and focused on personal growth, and coworkers
View10: Underpaid. It’s hard to make large wage gains without leaving and coming back as an external hire vs internal promotion.

Title: Great place to work for
View8: I'd like to work remotely.
View10: started as remotely, slowly getting everyone back to in office 100%

Title: Great until it ended
View8: Fidelity is a growing, thriving company with an interest in benefiting the customer and being the #1 leader in Retirement
View10: Fidelity looks out for its customers better than it looks out for its employees. Their goal is to just provide the ongoing market rate for employees instead of attracting and working to keep it's best employees

Title: Good for the first job out of college but will definitely dislike it after several months
View8: 1. Excellent benefits and lots of PTO days for entry level employees (23) 2. Lot of freedom during the day in offices. They could care less when you come in or leave or even if you play some video games in an empty meeting room or if you take your pet walrus on a walk.
View10: 1. Very low salary. For a resident of Rhode Island/Massachusetts, $70,000/year is surely not enough if you want a good apartment/townhouse and afford good quality food. 2. Very slow advancement for promotions 3. Tasks are very mundane for employees who are under 30 years old and without a master's degree. 4. Getting access to certain databases and tables takes very long. 5. Technologies that the company use are very outdated. 6. There is very prevalent ageism. I was 22-24 years old, and older employees opinions were always taken more seriously. 7. Obsessive compulsiveness with adhering to company standards, even in Microsoft Word documents, the specific dark blue font color had to be used for some columns. 8. NOBODY is open to creativity or new ways of doing things. 9. Company's median age is 45+. DO NOT work here for long if you're young. 10. Extremely cliquish. People almost always only hang out with others of their own team/squad/section or those they've known since age 6. 11. Very very vague performance evaluation criteria to the point where it feels like our evaluations are fake. Managers can EASILY twist the details of the evaluation form in your favor or against you. 12. Extremely terribly disorganized HR. I was called in for an interview for the June 2020 LEAP program in 2019, but little did I know that they already had filled up the June 2020 LEAP program a few weeks BEFORE my interview. But, they only told me AFTER I sweated through the 1-hour long interview. They told me this all ON THE PHONE and not in writing. Shady. They put me on a "waitlist" and gave me vague updates over the next several months. Eventually, they admitted me off the waitlist, but only after 8 MONTHS OF UNCERTAINTY.

Title: Good Benefits
View8: The Benefits were good at that time.
View10: Mismanagement in departments was evident.

Title: Please don’t work here
View8: Good health benefits, and possible bonus opps twice a year.
View10: Working here will not only damage your mental health, but if you have any health issues they will not listen to you about it. You are JUST A NUMBER to them. If you are not an over the top preformed they will drop you.

Title: Very unique role & career trajectory
View8: - Access to public company management teams - Autonomy / ability to build your own (internal) research franchise - Respect for WLB
View10: - Not great for a team/collaboration-oriented person - Lack of cohesiveness/communication a frequent complaint

Title: So many opportunities to do fun and interesting work
View8: Customer centered values, commitment to employees, strategic vision, commitment to investing for the future
View10: Poor prioritization framework, uneven leadership skills

Title: Great Benefits - No Mobility
View8: Great benefits and retirement; great company name recognition when applying to other jobs.
View10: They tell you there's mobility from the phones--there is no mobility from the phones. You get to move to another glorified phone position at best.

Title: Everyone is a corporate robot and sucks up to upper management
View8: Free granola bars sometimes in the office, horray!
View10: Everyone I've worked with has no personality. So much corporate language, no one has any personality, everything is always good and everyone is always "happy", and management is apparently always right and has the best intentions in mind. Fidelity also sends out surveys about everything but never listen to feedback. For example, they're making everyone go back to work even though no one does (although very few admit it to suck up to management). Gotta get back that "office culture", right? Upper management never answers questions in company meetings and instead gives vague, political-like answers. Pay is low and benefits are VERY average. Other companies offer so, so much. This place will suck out your soul and personality.

Title: Great Company
View8: Super good benefits, pay seems above average, company treats you super well
View10: Limited mobility outside of phone roles in certain locations, customer service jobs are always hard.

Title: Great Place to be part of
View8: Fun working environment, excellent team members, always feel like you are contributing to great things, awesome work/life balance, top tier benefits
View10: None that I can think of...

Title: Good Company, Bad People
View8: Pays well. Great benefits. Willing to make changes to remote style work opportunities.
View10: Bad management and promotion opportunities for people of color. They claim diversity, equity, and inclusion but privately do not back their public statements. This is a very East Coast mentality that doesn't necessarily work in Texas or other regions of the company. You will not advance with true input if you are black or brown. People stay because of the benefits. Otherwise, a job that you would definitely leave ASAP.

Title: Great place
View8: Super benefits right from hire date.
View10: Can be challenging culturally. That focus has been changing over the years.

Title: Stellar workplace for young professionals
View8: Due to internal promotion, management is typically someone who has spent more than a year in customer-facing roles and is highly competent. There's loads of room to grow, with career fairs held weekly in the office where you can network across the company. They recently started the Personal Investing Launch program, which gives those in service-based roles 10 hours a week to develop a growth skill set. The employee can opt for the growth skill set they are most interested in and can promote to a new role with relative ease thereafter. In the program, they also do resume and interview prep to help you transition to the next role (absolutely brilliant). Additionally, the benefits are ridiculously good. Who needs 12 weeks of paternal leave?? I couldn't be happier with Fidelity, they've been the best employer I've ever had by a long shot.
View10: Tax season can be very busy, and licensing can be difficult. Despite that, Fidelity is aware of these things and is very accommodating in terms of tax season and licensing incentives.

Title: workplace investing
View8: great benefit package, ability to work remotely.
View10: low salary and micromanagement. managers focus heavily on stats. You dont stop in a phone role, calls come in back to back and it’s draining.

Title: Glorified Call Center Rep
View8: It is a good role to gain experience with high net worth clients and build a solid foundation on the financial industry. Overtime opportunity and good benefits within the company.
View10: The role is nothing but a modified call center. Very schedule oriented, some managers observe every minute of your day and monitor your breaks/ wrap time online. Lots of micromanagement and little work-life balance with every single PTO request can be denied.

Title: Not for Remote Work
View8: * Great benefits package * Relatively easy work
View10: * Attempting to increase On-Site days. Not an advocate for remote work. * Pushy about joining company hackathon. Manager expresses disappointment to the employees they manage when they do not join.

Title: Fidelity
View8: Good place to start, good training program.
View10: Toxic environment. Overly focused on ESG will promote based on skin color and gender not merit.

Title: Glorified call center role
View8: Licensure, supportive management, and remote work for those who enjoy it. People were great, but no connection since 95% remote.
View10: Should not be a starting career for someone who paid for a bachelors degree in business. Extremely boring job and you’re sitting in a chair all day. Dealing with very old people and spend hours to just change a password. Nearly impossible to get out of the call center, but if you enjoy this then go at it.

Title: Great place to work but low total compensation
View8: People are excellent to work with Benefits are great (although don't make up for low base salary)
View10: Much lower base salary than competitors; even when taking into account added benefits (profit sharing, high 401k match, and shares), it's still below the competition Low merit increases year to year Career mobility isn't great given long tenure of more senior team members

Title: Fidelity Investments, great benefits, compensation but a fast pace no excuses work environment.
View8: Fidelity provides a very competitive compensation package but the benefits are best in the business. Benefits like a 7% 401k match plus 10% profit sharing is hard to beat. Medical benefits, loan repayment, PTO and the Charitable match are also unique.
View10: I worked at Fidelity for close to 20 years and the culture has shifted very dramatically to micro management, what have you done for me last week culture. In relationship roles your expected to produce unrealistic goals from existing client base while being compare to other reps receiving new clients with money in motion. Expectations presenting annuities is also concerning as a CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER. Too many good people leave sales and relationship roles to other roles in the organization due to burn out and which does impact the clients. FC roles are no longer a destination roles but rather a stop to some other role or outside the organization.

Title: Great Company but...
View8: Flexibility, decent pay, great benefits, strong career path, tons of learning opportunities. Is a great company in so many ways. Protect and services are superior.
View10: If you are a woman or minority go for it! Identity politics has become the way at Fidelity. I saw too many promotions and hires that were made based on gender or race instead of merit.

Title: Fired for Health Issues
View8: The benefits are good and the pay is decent
View10: They have extremely high expectations of all of their employees, they give no training for the emotional aspect of dealing with terminally ill patients/death/etc. And you never stay with one manager for long making it very hard to feel settled.

Title: Some better some worse
View8: Amazing benefits, Flexible work schedule, a job that cares about their people.
View10: Hiring outside of the company for higher positions causing tenured employees to stay where they're at.

Title: Great company
View8: With their tuition reimbursement I was able to finish my undergrad without any additional student loans. Great culture as well.
View10: If you don't like on the phone customer service you may be unhappy in the beginning of your time at Fidelity.

Title: Great company, poor management
View8:
- The company itself is amazing. The goals and intentions are clear and obtainable. 
- Benefits are second to none, even added extra relief PTO for Covid.
- Depending on the role, work from home is an option. But the FR role doesn’t allow for that.
- There are so many resources and learning opportunities.
- Your coworkers will always be eager to help you at any capacity.
View10:
- Management is more concerned on how well their profitable employees are doing, and taking care of them. They are more flexible and willing to bend for those employees.
- Micromanagement is an understatement.
- With all those learning opportunities, it’s still really hard to promote. You won’t promote unless the other people in your role are able to handle it themselves. Lots of people quit in this role because they can’t get licensed or the workload is a lot, so you’ll find yourself stuck in the role for 3-4 years (though they say 1-2 is average).
- They play favorites
- Moody managers that’s attitudes are just as volatile as the market

Title: Best Company I have worked for EVER
View8: Benefits are so good Pay is unreal Compensation is great Culture !!! Team member development is a huge focus
View10: Training is long Studying for your test sucks

Title: Fabulous firm to build a career
View8: Fidelity encourages mobility both within and across business lines. You can build a network and rely on it to help you solve problems, find new jobs and build your resume. The benefits are unbeatable.
View10: no cons for Fidelity investments

Title: Inconsistency is standard
View8: Paid maternity/paternity leave, profit sharing, 401k match, tuition reimbursement
View10: Micromanagement, inconsistent performance metrics, variable compensation is heavily influenced by manager discretion, variable compensation is based on total quarterly metrics completed rather than average daily metric for actual days worked. “Meaningful” PTO is emphasized but isn’t provided in actuality. If PTO is used, one can assume their variable compensation will be reduce for that specific quarter.

Title: Exceptional Benefits - Middling job
View8: Benefits are second to none. Culture of inclusivity is a foremost part of the branch identity/company identity.
View10: The PC is a Jr. Advisor position without sales metrics. If you want to be and advisor this may be a good track for you; however, if you do not wish to be an advisor, find another gig that isn't client facing. Generally speaking you need to hold 15 client appts per week every week.

Title: Decent pay, good company
View8: Great PTO and benefits. Good management.
View10: Average pay, only one bonus per year.

Title: Metrics Annoying
View8: Transparency in pay structure and benefits are fabulous, including health, vision, dental, 401k match.
View10: I wish I found the metric measured anything, but other than telling the company how quickly you can move to the next call, I'm not sure they do. Anyone who knows their job is quickly moved to another job, so most people are new and inexperienced and any attempts at building a "team" are sabotaged by the company itself. Pay is always tied to extra performance issues.

Title: Best employer I've had yet
View8: Pay is great, includes quarterly bonuses, rentention bonuses, referral bonuses, holiday pay, alot of holidays off, and holiday bonuses. Endless benefits such as insurance(vision dental and medical), perks for being employed there, they care about mental health, total inclusion, PRO LGBTQ, offers 401k, you get alot of support. You also have no limit in career development and can promote within quickly and they have a career hub for that. This places sets you up for success
View10: Due to everyone being trained by different teams, not everyone is trained the same. There for knowledge across the board is inconsistent in WI. Sometimes understaffed at times so calls are nonstop.

Title: Poor communication
View8: They have great benefits and pay is decent.
View10: They’re completely unorganized in the workplace investments department there is so miscommunication and lack of communication. Make sure you don’t have health issues because they will fire you while being on Fmla and gone on STD.

Title: Study
View8: Hybrid work environment is great.
View10: A lot of micromanaging forced on team leaders.

Title: Overworked
View8: You get to help people, tier 3
View10: Burn out, mandatory overtime, long hold times, under staffing, disconnect between employees and management, culture of fake positivity, promotions are not based on merit but connections

Title: Great place
View8: Wfh and benefits vacation time
View10: Micromanaged picky about every litter thing

Title: Amazing company, amazing growth
View8: Great benefits, great work life balance, lots of opportunities.
View10: Can feel stuck in the financial industry.

Title: Solid company
View8: Everyone is nice for the most part. The only way it won't work for you is if you do not like working in a corporate culture. I really enjoyed basically everyone I worked with.
View10: Bad politics, but this is common in every corporate company. I was fired in part because I worked from home. I worked from home as often as I could because I felt I was more productive. Then two years later covid hit and then some of my same coworkers worked remotely for nearly two years before coming back to the office.

Title: Salary caps for older workers
View8: Coworkers, Flexible work schedule, diverse responsibilities
View10: Caps salary around $63k for older workers in New Hampshire so your pay after taxes is about $2500/month. Average rent in Merrimack is $2000 or you can move an hour north and pay $1500 but gas/car expenses wipe out those savings. No overtime available and they never give cost of living adjustments. All promotions, even to a higher salary grade, come with no raises. Most benefits for younger workers. HR determines salary cap but they seem clueless on how expensive it is to live here. Utilities are doubling this year now, and inflation is surging so I am taking a huge pay cut every year. Disappointed that Fidelity is so cheap.

Title: Just fine
View8: Benefits Set way of doing things
View10: No upward mobility for part times

Title: Good WLB
View8: WLB is good in general (but depends on the team, of course). Lots of resources and opportunities to learn and grow. A very stable company with good culture (in general).
View10: At times, it can feel bureaucratic and doesn't have the agility of a tech company.

Title: Extremely Friendly Work Environment
View8: Fidelity is extremely inclusive, progressive, and a fun place to work. Everyone is willing to help whether you are on the same team or not. Lots of flexibility in your role and you can move around to different teams with ease to get a variety of exprience.
View10: Pay can be a little on the low end, but benefits make up for it.

Title: Decent Pay & Easy Work
View8: - Easy work assignments - Above-average compensation - Flexible time off - Generally friendly coworkers
View10: - Low compensation for tech roles - Slow technology adoption - Bureaucracy is particularly annoying at Fidelity

Title: College Grads Beware, this is a call center
View8: benefits, beautiful campus, work life balance
View10: During the interview process, they change the wording to make it seem like it’s not a call center, but it is. We take calls back to back and follow a strict schedule. If we don’t follow the schedule, then we get yelled at by our managers. I was in a post grad rotation program and our managers basically treat us like kids. It’s pretty cringey and not professional. I felt like I was still in high school going through this program and I don’t really feel much growth. I didn’t go through college just to be stuck in a call center role, getting berated by customers on the daily. I felt like I was lied to during the interview process, because they market this opportunity in such a different way. Just tell us straight up that this is a call center and not waste anyone’s time. Majority of the roles within the company are call center positions, so there’s no way getting off the phones. The one thing I don’t understand about this company, is that the pay is so bad, but people are still so enthusiastic about their job, getting yelled at by customers and being “customer obsessed.”It gives off cultish vibes. Anyways, it takes a certain personality to really like being on the phones and following a strict schedule with a timed 30 minute lunch.

Title: One step forward, two steps back
View8: Benefits like contribution matching are good
View10: Behind the times and regressing into stone age policies like forced time in the office, no flexibility

Title: Awesome Employeer
View8: - Best Work Culture ever - Excellent Benefits -23 days PTO to start - increases over time
View10: - It is still a call center, so if you aren't able to do that kind of work it just wont be a good fit.

Title: Answered incoming calls about current account inquires
View8: Great communication from managers and team members. Very flexible hours, easy to take vacation, all to set your own schedule
View10: Don't really have any cons

Title: could be great
View8:
easy to get in through customer service and phone role
decent pay to get out of other lower paying industry. 
decent benefits package 
upward mobility available
there are a lot of people who have been with the company for decades and love it.
View10:
self paced training which basically teaches you the bare minimum. 
a lot of trial and error, you learn by making mistakes everyday. 
a lot of research while having time constraints 
its a lot of work. and it can take anywhere from 3 months to a year to stop feeling like a ball of anxious mess, 
theres a certain level of fear mongering that is used to make sure you do the job like they want you too. probably not best if you already struggle with anxiety. it will definitely kick it up a notch... a couple notches. 
they calculate more stats than you can even think of. these stats will be thrown at you daily and you will be asked to explain every bit if its out of the desired window. bonuses and pay increases depend on that. 
if any of these feel like pros to you then it may be the right fit for you.

Title: Great company but needs a little move focus on current employees
View8: Fidelity is a fantastic company, they really take care of their people! From the start of the pandemic, it was a smooth transition to WFH. Even now they provide support and resources to all of their employees.
View10: It's not as easy as they say to move around, it's about who know. I've worked at the company for 10 yrs. Yes, I've moved around but it wasn't easy, especially when it comes to being paid my worth. I feel like that is something that needs to be worked on.

Title: I love what we do for our customers and working with great people!
View8: Benefits, PTO and the people!
View10: Forcing specific time to be in office

Title: Great workplace! makes you feel you are valued!
View8: -Best workplace environment. -Smart team members. -Fidelity puts employees first and makes sure you have an environment to grow. -Great employee benefits.
View10: Base pay could have been a little better.

Title: Great Org Depending on where you are
View8: Strong Company that will last
View10: Your experience of the company depends on where you are located. Some states are treated better than others. I wouldn't recommend NM as the environment and opportunities there is questionable. Partners in other states have a better experience of working for the brand

Title: Fantastic Benefits
View8: Pays you to get your license
View10: Call Center - lots of calls starting off

Title: They are who they say they are
View8: Great benefits and bonus opportunities
View10: Can be extremely stressful during peak seasons. Frequent internal changes but that's kind of expected for a financial company.

Title: Great experience, company really cares about its employees and customers.
View8: Great benefits, company is always improving things
View10: Big company, you can get lost or have to wait for promotions

Title: Amazing place to be comfortable
View8: Planning consultants have great work life balance, great compensation. Best job I've ever had.
View10: NOT A PRODUCING ROLE! If you are looking to be comfortable PC is the way to go

Title: Abby J for President.
View8:
Casually getting a 10% base bump recently and bonus payouts through the roof? They said this day would come, but here we are. Paying us to not only stay, but bring in top talent. 

Thanks Abby J. Really though. I make an impact every day. Nothing means more if you're honest with yourself. Always doing what's best for the client. If you work hard, you will be compensated.
View10: One bad manager out of the 4 others that truly changed the trajectory of my life. Still keep in touch with previous managers. It takes you by surprise when you get a mediocre leader because the bar is set so high. Crush it and you'll be out in no time. Not a place for entitled individuals or those who don't work hard.

Title: Great Company
View8: Pay, Benefits, Training for licensing
View10: None I can think of

Title: Overall great place to work
View8: Genuine people. Great pay. Fun place to work. Management truly cares about employees and wants to see people excel.
View10: In an effort to always make things better, systems that work well get changed often.

Title: Career
View8: Plenty of avenues to pursue career wise, lots of upward potential, and great support system generally speaking.
View10: Compensation does not feel true to market. They also sell promotions and job changes on "potential" instead of compensation. I recently capped out the current path, and had limited options of what to pursue next. I had to accept the "potential" sales pitch, and took a hefty pay cut. They would not even match current income with the job change even though it was discussed as a "destination role" and promotion.

Title: Great Training
View8: *This company will give you great client services training applicable to all financial service roles! You can learn so much here in terms of financial education that you can get branch to many different roles and companies in finance.
View10: They run a tight ship.

Title: Strong Program
View8: Good training and exposure in investment research for recent college grads, coupled with strong branding. Some asset classes offer strong performers upward mobility and chance to get promoted to career-track analyst roles.
View10: Nothing comes to mind at the moment.

Title: Good employer
View8: Great employee benefits; financially sound company
View10: Manage by consensus which holds back some innovation

Title: Not Like It Used To Be
View8: You were proud to say you worked at Fidelity - still am. However, it's not the same company. You felt valued and appreciated. Not any more.
View10: Constantly finding ways to reduce salaries. Never have experienced a company that often offers early retirement so they can weed out the older generation for the younger, less experience and inexpensive talent. If you're an older employee and decline the early retirement you will eventually be laid off. Not the same company since Bob Reynolds left.

Title: Lack diversity
View8: Flexibility Close to home Good training program
View10: Stressful Unfriendly Over worked Lack diversity

Title: SaFe Scrum Master

Title: Under the Veil
View8: Learn Finance, Good starter Job, Updated Offices
View10:
Fidelity leaders grind their workers to no end (you will be burnt out quick). Plan on taking 70-100 calls a day.

No work/life balance. Fidelity preaches Work/Life Balance while also requiring you to work mandatory overtime the second you get licensed. 

Benefits are only good if you stay with firm long term (Schwab's 401k vest starting day 1, Fidelity requires you to stay for 5 year). 

Pay is lowest amongst other firms. 

You can be most talented candidate for promotion, but if you don't fit the firms "Diversity and Inclusion" efforts.... a less qualified or not qualified candidate will fill the promotion (If you are a white male good luck).

Title: NOT THE PLACE TO WORK IF YOU ARE A SINGLE PARENT
View8: Decent pay and sponsorship for licensing.
View10:
Lack of consideration for single parents who work from home with children. 
If you upset management in any way they will turn their back on you. 
Management should be more considerate and truthful. 
If you use your PTO too soon, but dont go over your limit, they will look to terminate you. 
If you fail the exam one time they will terminate you. 
If you have to take care of your child they will terminate you. 
You put in so much effort and time to study for the Series 7 and if you fail they will look at you badly. 
All in all, if you have a child and are a single parent and think Fidelity will understand if you have to help your child....they WILL NOT and will terminate you if you are a great employee who does their job well.

Title: Depends on team

Title: Disappointed after reading all the good hype
View8: The work is extremely easy . They have good benefits 401k and profit share. They have everything at the company that you can think of as far a technology, so lots to learn for entry level people. Has a decent corporate culture that encourages a good attitude and free speech.
View10: Fidelity lacks technical leadership as a whole and does not value it! They value attitude over all else which means they hire people they like and contract out technical folks. They are not lean and Agile, lots of bloat and middle managers. The environment is extremely political and they accomplish very little. It's extremely hard to get anything done with all bureaucracy, meetings. Lots of non-technical folks blowing hot air and not enough GOOD developers. 90% of their developers are not employees but contractors and turn over is very high. As far as fulltime employees go, Fidelity hires low-level tech folks who have a good attitude but lack experience which further exuberates and compounds not getting things done. Lots of silos and teams that only care about themselves, Cross team communication is probably the poorest I have ever experienced in my career. To add to it all, folks regularly switch teams and so you lose people you trained and you have to start over again. As a whole, in my opinion, it's not a great environment to write and test code in. Everything is always breaking and getting things fixed takes days not hours while your whole team is idle. This encourages idleness and apathy.

Title: Bad job but difficult to rate.
View8: They license you. You will think about this experience in future jobs and feel relief that you no longer work here. This job is probably more attainable than the vast majority of others job in "finance".
View10:
Ultimately the job title is "Customer Relationship Advocate", so I can't fault Fidelity for being dishonest in anyway during recruiting. However, if you are a college graduate looking for a job, even if you failed other interviews, do not take this job if you want to enter a job that is A) financial and/or B) analytical.

Firstly, Fidelity will advertise the SIE/S7/S63 as a good way to begin your career and potentially jump to something else later. These licenses are required from a compliance standpoint, that is the only reason they require you to take them. These licenses will not land you a job as an analyst or impress anyone who actually knows what they are. If you are only joining to take these exams, I advise against this.

Close your eyes. Do you want to take phone calls all day every for the foreseeable future, with the only promotions available being other roles where you get a slight pay bump and take phone calls all day? This is your life after finishing licensing, and if you're like me you will be put on a 10-hour shift against your preference. 10 hours all day every day of talking to customers is not going to make you very desirable in any actual finance or analytical job.

This job is 97.5% customer service and 2.5% finance. Some might argue it is not finance at all, the most sophisticated thing you will do on a daily basis is place a stock order for a customer who is too lazy to do it themselves. You will get trainings on concepts that most customers understand through internet articles, or you will be trained on proprietary systems, nothing you can even place on a resume to show you as a desirable candidate for when you will want to leave.

This job is basically an office version of a factory assembly line. The second you finish a call you're onto the next, there is no opportunity to extend to any meaningful project that will help you get out of the perpetual call center. The job is designed to keep you working for them in a call center, they already licensed and trained you so this is most profitable for them. 

The only person I can see who would like this job is someone who worked in call centers in the past and sees this as an upgrade since they can call themselves a licensed broker etc.

For anyone who wishes to have career advancement outside of customer service or potentially their wealth management branch (you will start off a brand new role, continuing to do calls all day every day and maybe after 3-5 years get promoted to a branch), extend your job search and look elsewhere.

Lastly, the reason I put "difficult to rate" in the title is because I might seem naive for giving a poor rating to a customer service job since it doesn't offer promotions into analytical or financial jobs. But ultimately I can't give this job a good rating whatsoever because everyday was dreadful; never-ending phone calls with no hope for meaningful advancement.

Title: Not an expert
View8: Benefits, especially the help repaying student loans and paid parental leave. Up to 7 percent match on retirement contributions. The medical premiums cost more than my prior jobs, but other benefits cost a bit less. A lot of reviews on here are complaining about the base pay. For me, it's nearly a 50 percent increase over my old job in a different industry. That's not a raise, that's life changing. There are also opportunities for bonuses. I am going to be allowed to mostly work from home for a lot longer than I was led to believe during the interview process. It's totally okay if we'd rather go ahead and work onsite every day, too.
View10: Inconsistent support - my onboarding coach didn't work in my role. They clearly want me to do well and can coach on if I am hitting certain points when interacting with customers, but they have pointedly stated that I'm "supposed to be the expert" in my role. When I reach out to my team for help while assisting customers, I only get answers to the questions that aren't part of our specific role. However, I'm not going to be trained in that specific role until at least 4-5 months on the job. I'm willing to stumble blindly through an adventure of learning alongside our customers, but many of them don't have time for that, and me not knowing what I'm doing yet is leading to a poor customer experience for them. The headsets provided for working from home aren't compatible with the onsite phones, so that was an unexpected learning curve. My coach strangely seemed perplexed that I didn't know how to operate the call center equipment already on the first day of calls despite never having seen or used that equipment before. It is extremely difficult for clients to hear me clearly, and often vice versa, due to the background conversations when working onsite. Being able to hear clearly is the top reason I'd like to continue working at home. Some of our customers are intentionally cruel. There are rude customers everywhere, but I've never cried during work every day before.

Title: Not for those who want to be excited about a job or make a single connection in the workplace.
View8:
Very clear on corporate culture. 
Updates from superiors (CEO, etc.) multiple times a week.
Will pay for your licensing if you’re in a licensed role.
Pretty easy to get vacation days approved.
View10:
This is not a job for someone who can’t sit in the same chair, staring at the same computer screen for 8+ hours.
Working from home is miserable, but working in the office requires either weekly testing and tracking or the vaccine. 
I’ve never felt so lonely at a company, even though this is the biggest company I’ve ever worked for.
I barely even know my manager’s first name, that’s how disconnected everyone is.
I only lasted one month after I finished training because the job isn’t rewarding in the slightest.
Be prepared to get yelled at or called incompetent at least 5 times a day.
Don’t expect more than minimal support from any supervisor.
This position should pay much more than it actually does. 
During onboarding, they make it seem like you can move around as much as you want, as quickly as you want, and your manager will help you advance however they can, but that’s a joke.
By the end of my shift, I’m exhausted and can’t even build up the motivation to make dinner.
EVERYTHING is scheduled. You get two 15 minute breaks - one in the morning and one in the afternoon - and a 30 minute lunch, but you may not be eating lunch until hours after any normal lunch time should be scheduled. And you don’t get a say on that either.

Title: You must look at the total compensation package
View8: Fidelity provides paid training to obtain your FINRA licensure, the have outstanding benefits from day 1. The team I was on was awesome, we all got along -- we all tugged on the rope together in the same direction, the team was diversified, and I believe everyone felt included and had a voice. We were project managers, agile, scrum team, analysts, -- it was very rewarding & challenging work.
View10:
There is high turnover, once in a Financial Rep phone role it is hard to break free -- HR and mgt sees you only in that role even though you may have obtained your masters. There are lots of departments and opportunity -- unfortunately there are walls and barriers that prevent freedom of movement from retail phones to a branch, workplace savings, or institutional. 

I was lucky and got to move into non-phone roles within the organization and enjoyed my job tremendously and felt I was finally making a contribution to the company and helping our clients. 

Project management, analysts, scrum, advisors, problem resolution, FMR, is completely different company and greater opportunity than Fidelity phone roles -- do not believe you can take an entry level phone job and quickly transition into non-phone roles -- people do get stuck in phones -- still you'll have a good job with good pay, benefits, and obtain your Series 7 license. After a year or two you can apply directly for the job you want, there are some great jobs at Fidelity.

Title: Only dedicated need apply
View8: If you’ve got what it takes, this can be a great career. Beware, this is not meant to be a job that you only do for a year or less. Choose this job if you’re ready to commit to a career that is going to be very long-term, or even lifelong. The amount of effort, and commitment that you will need to put in during your extended training is the kind of commitment that will have you rearranging vital portions of your life if you wish to be successful. They will warn you ahead of time. He does warnings. They’re being serious. If, however, you can make it through all of this you’re going to have gainful employment at an excellent rate of compensation for the rest of your life. There are also a few employers who treat their people as well as Fidelity.
View10: The work can be incredibly difficult, and even mindnumbing. The extended training is grueling to say the least. While the support is there from Everyone around you, what the average person will need to give up for several months will be substantial. You will lose friends, you will upset your family, and you will likely encourage great amount of stress during this time. Licensing is very difficult time.

Title: Depends on the role
View8: Benefits are really good. 401k match, profit sharing, health benefits. All great. Pretty generous PTO, especially after you have been there a while. The base pay is okay.
View10:
Fidelity can be great. It depends on two things: what department/role you are in, and your manager. My major complaint about WPC is that people who play the game and burn through calls get promoted and those who spend time with clients don’t. You are not encouraged to spend time and plan with a client. You are supposed to get your tool clicks, uncover assets and send a referral to a branch. It has developed a culture of work 12 hour days to get your numbers, or cut corners. 


Also, they required mandatory overtime on Monday’s and Friday’s for over 6 months. Demanding total flexibility from all reps and continually asking for more, more, more. But good luck using your PTO. Some managers will act like you are stealing PTO hours from their own bank when you ask. The “COVID relief days” they offered were total BS as well. Their policy stated you could use it for anything that required “flexibility” during the pandemic. However, most managers would only let you take it if you were sick COVID.

Title: Call Center w/ Lack of Promotion outside of that
View8:
Pros: 

-All of the managers/ colleagues are generally very nice 
- Work doesn’t come home w/ you 
- Several bonus incentive opportunities
- 4-day work week option 
-Tuition Reimbursement/ Student Loan Repayment
- Gym membership Reimbursement
- Constant Overtime Availability 
-Good resume builder
-Sponsored to get FINRA Licenses
-Work from home
View10:
CRA ROLE: I graduated with a Bachelor’s in finance last year (degree not required for role) and I took this job b/c they advertised being able to become a licensed financial professional with FINRA. My professor indirectly tried to steer me away from it but I was naive. I sat in on a seminar and was really impressed with how happy everyone seemed. I thought getting my foot in the door I would be able to easily navigate and move on to a more technical skilled role. Boy was I wrong… The CRA role is the lowest of the totem pole you can be on. They try to make you feel like you’re not working in a call center because of licensing and the culture but you really are. You take inbound customer service calls. You get trained and have to assist with a magnitude of differing requests such as the status of paper work or educating/placing trades for clients in margin. It felt like I was getting paid so little to know SO MUCH. You are also expected to work chat function several times a week and manage multiple chat conversations at once. 

The busiest times are Tax Season and the end of the year for RMDs. Summer is the slowest— you most often stare at the screen all day with maybe 5-6 calls your whole 8 hour shift. 

PERFORMANCE/ PROMOTION: You are graded on the criteria of the call model & grading is inconsistent. Additionally, the anxiety you feel when you get calls and don’t know what to expect is difficult. A lot of the clients are older and can be rude when they don’t get their way. You have to help them navigate the website which sometimes can take up to an hour. Clients receive follow-up surveys in 24-48 hours after interaction and if you get a 6 or lower it counts as a 0 towards that metric. A lot of clients are unhappy when they don’t know what they are doing and you get the blame for it instead of allowing you to support and expand their knowledge. Weekends are also tough working b/c a lot of supporting business units are closed on the weekends which results in disgruntled customers and call backs (also, a metric your performance gets graded on)
Fidelity allows auto-promotion when you reach certain call review scores and call metrics. They are just other call center roles with a $1,000-$2,000 yearly salary pay increase. After tax is an extra $50-80 dollars per month. Do not be fooled do the math. 
 
TRAINING/ SUPPORT: You will go through a total of 8 months of training. A lot of information to know. Difficult to retain as you will not be practicing skills daily. If you have a question about a procedure or process managers tell you to contact the Help Desk. Crazy b/c you depend on them to measure and assess your performance but they don’t know the job role specifics. 

Overall, this job left me feeling hopeless and unmotivated. I feel like they should be more transparent with what the job function really is. It is not just about becoming licensed and being a financial professional b/c the clients don’t see you as that, they see you as a customer service representative punching bag. Call center work is not for a lot of people, really think about if this is the type of role you see yourself in permanently.

Title: Life Changing Career Decision
View8:
Excellent Training, Outstanding benefits, Healthy work/life balance. Amazing tuition reimbursement. Great place to launch a career or facilitate a career change. 
Jaw-dropping 401(k) match and profit sharing. Best career decision I ever made! I am eternally grateful for the impact Fidelity has on me and my family. Transparently, my financial future will be dramatically and positively different because of my career at Fidelity. Very proud to tell others where I work!
View10:
The only con I have is that Fidelity is more focused on hiring externally than promoting from within. Much of this focus is due to recent cultural and economic events (i.e., 2020). From a business perspective, I understand the desire to capitalize on available and diverse talent but not at the risk of frustrating and overlooking your highly qualified and tenured associates. There is a simmering frustration among the ranks and will soon result in sizable attrition if not addressed. 

For example, I am the most credential and skilled associate of my team and keep getting overlooked for a particular role. The individuals that are being hired into this role are under credentialed and/or have less experience. It is the most frustrating thing in the world! For the first time in my tenure at Fidelity, I have started proactively looking outside the firm. It genuinely PAINS me to think I may have to join a competitor to advance my career and compensation.

Title: Toxic Culture
View8: Fidelity is well known for their great benefits. Although their salaries tend to be way below what other companies pay. It's a great place to start, get your certifications, and then go somewhere else where they'll double your pay. This is what most engineers were doing at the time I was there. After I left, I doubled my salary at another firm.
View10:
I worked at Fidelity from 2018-2019 and found it to be one of the most toxic cultures I’ve ever experienced in my 20+ years as a professional. 
I worked in ECC where, although being a highly technical BU, the Sr leadership (at the time), promoted several non-technical people into leadership positions. I worked under one of these, a woman (HJ) who had a knack for hiring and promoting underqualified people, thereby creating a situation where they needed to be “protected” and would be loyal to her. This included promoting an individual from QA to a PM role with zero experience, as well as someone from the event planning dept to a Dir level leading a UX team. 
The situation was so wily, that at one point, this PM (LV) held several meetings to explain to our highly experienced UX team “UX Strategy”. She’d done her research on Google. I wish I was joking. Later, she would hold “UX Strategy” meetings that only included the one UX designer and a young woman whose role was designing PP decks for leadership (SJ). She insisted on defining herself as the UX Researcher, even though (you guessed it) she had no experience doing research and never actually conducted any research. But she was really good at gossiping, slandering, and keeping VP abreast of BU gossip.  I wish I was joking. These people were not only unqualified and unprofessional, they were MEAN.
The PM for this team created a corrosive and toxic environment; she battled constantly with the PO in front of the full 20+ team, deliberately excluded key players from meetings, showed open aggression in smaller meetings, bullied several individuals, and was just a hostile aggressive person in general.
There was another individual promoted by this VP who not only lacked in technical or leadership skills, but was one of the most badly behaved individuals of the entire team (MVH). She led a team of several people and had the emotional IQ of a 13 YO girl. She also bullied members of her own team, behaved in a hostile manner, openly threated team members, and acted appallingly. When new leadership came in and there was a reorg, she kept her position but lost her entire team. That should tell you all you need to know about Fidelity. The fact that all these people are still employed there is insane.
And make no mistake, the behavior of this group of women was endorsed by their own leadership (HJ). They knew they could get away with it and they did. Tactics included: mobbing, bullying individuals and teams, open aggression in meetings, withholding vital information, excluding individuals from specific team meetings, openly threatening individuals, slandering those who refused to play their game, and even firing those who refused to fall in line or pushed back.
Many associates complained to both HR and the Chairman’s line about this group of women, but the only sense we had that they were taking any actions was when HR executives showed up to an offsite event. But you guessed it, nothing happened. HR exists only to protect the firm. If there are no lawsuits possible, they don’t care.
This “leader” is now a VP in PI and continues her abusive, toxic behavior, as well as promoting only those who show their loyalty to her, as evidenced by the woman she just promoted to Director. In fact, all these women still hold positions at Fidelity. They may be scattered across the enterprise, but it’s just a matter of time until VP brings them all back onto her team and it all begins again.

Title: Changing for the worse
View8:
Benefits
Remote work
Great place to start your career. Get out and get paid more after.
View10: Have worked here for 6 years in 3 different locations. Management has gotten worse. I used to think “Wow. The management really cares about advancing my career and helping me” that tune has changed. It’s become a corporate boys club and full of toxic negativity. You have to leave the firm and come back to get any type of promotion or pay increase. They don’t hire from within they literally have jobs that say external hire only. What kind of garbage is that? It’s a boys club so if you’re a female in this finance world, good luck. Management is fake and can’t be real with their employees like they used to. They have to drink the corporate Kool-aid and give everyone corporate BS answers. Fidelity has started to care so much about money that the client experience is going to the way side. I used to love how client oriented we were. They are changing everything to be about money and how do we make the most money and work the employees the hardest.

View10: - The base pay is lower than the market, making you reliant on your end of year bonus to bring it in line. - Raises are low unless they come attached with a promotion. - People tend to work at Fidelity for a very long time, which makes it difficult for new talent and ideas to come in and mix things up. - Fidelity loves to pretend its a tech company, but does not have the technical talent to back it up. This causes there to be a lot of "flashy" things like containers and microservices, but not a lot of talent to utilize them fully which can make things worse than traditional architectures.

Good focus on inclusion and overall work environment.
They care about the success and retention of their employees
Career growth opportunities
View10:
Work/Life balance can be tough with a high pace and even higher expectations
Big company with a big hierarchy
Success is overly dependent on intracompany relationships often grounded with tenure in the company
While extending your career and experience is highly encouraged, transitions and upward mobility can be challenging.

Title: Fantastic company to work for!
View8: Employee friendly Customer focus Strong values and principles Well grounded in facts

Title: Good company with good people
View8: The benefits are good, the people are nice, and the company does try hard to take care of the employees. 7% 401k match dollar for dollar and full health care coverage on day one. 25 days of PTO for first year employees.
View10: A lot of people working from home so it is hard to get to know your coworkers. A lot of time on the phones, but I would say 95% of the clients are nice. You have to pass your Series 7 & 63 pretty quick, they let go a few coworkers for not passing on the first try.

Title: Why didn't you refer this plan participant to a nearby Fidelity Investor Center?
View8: Financial planning tools are effective, if you slip up and actually provide real financial planning to the plan participant. Less than all of the participants are rude and ignorant. You'll always be able to ply your craft because there is always a queue of participants to speak to. The Fidelity RSP 401k match is strong and, coupled with 10 percent profit sharing, makes it very easy to save a lot of money for retirement. So you'll only be poor during your career and not also in a long retirement.
View10: Fidelity wants Workplace Planning and Advice and its Workplace Planning Consultants to refer opportunities to the Investor Center. That's the job. Say whatever you need to get the referral and you'll advance in your career. Any personal ethos of Do what's Right will be compromised in WPA. The answer to everything, everything, is refer the opportunity to the Investor Center. Also there is no way that compensation for Fidelity phone roles is materially-higher than any industry average.

Title: Fixed income
View8: retirement contributions is a nice benefit
View10: care about new hires more then tenured employees for raises. New managers are hit or miss with being power hungry and micro managing you. Been here 3 years and have had 8 different managers

Title: Company review
View8:
-great work/life balance
-good company culture

-great programs/clubs to join and network
View10:
- no cons that I can think of rn

Title: Fidelity
View8: Healthy benefits and pay profit sharing
View10: Management will micromanage and push

Title: Good experience

I hate that one month cost me my entire career, and my manager did not try to reach out at all.

Title: Job fell short of what it was advertised as

After I left, others had shared similar experiences and they changed the required company HR trainings to 1 hour max.

View10: Licensing can be difficult, but manageable if you’re willing to put the work in.

Title: Great Place To Work So Far
View8: Working fully remote from home as an Investment Solutions Representative. Enjoy the no work commute which means more time to spend with my family. Great benefits.

Title: Felt Like I Was On A Treadmill
View8: Benefits were above average and communication was usually clear.
View10: Most days were spent working overtime just to stay on top of things and overtime was always expected/asked. Working six days a week of at least 9-10 hours a day was the norm. Constantly felt understaffed and most days felt like drowning. Help by management was always promised on the horizon, but after being told that for two years, it was clear nothing was being done. Requesting time off around the Holidays like Christmas was done by a lottery system and, because of that, I missed Christmas with my family for three straight years. I have friends working at Charles Schwab and TD and they have shared their experience was nothing like that.

Title: Good starting point

Title: Fidelity
View8: Benefits, work life balance, work from home
View10: Pay is lower than other firms Rich in benefits but cheap in salary potential Metric focused - pushed hard

Title: Call Center work
View8: Decent pay, ability to work from home.
View10: Still a call center job at it's core with unrealistic measurements for associate performance. Bonus pay also unfairly measured. Management is only in contact with you for reconstructive criticism and not usually available for customers that request to speak to a manager, for that you are on your own as an associate, and that usually affects the customer feedback that affects your bonus. Title: Lots of bureaucracy and need to be willing to brown-nose to get ahead
View8:
Good pay & benefits
Stable company
Does provide a valuable service

Very bureaucratic - lots of layers

Title: Strong Community, Weak Pay
View8:
- Strong community
-Good job security
- They hire from within before outside, and there are always opportunities to move laterally. Which is encouraged every 3-5 years or so. 
- Many employee resource groups and support programs. 
- lots of networking opportunities. 
- If you want to gain a certain skill or a certain license, management is usually pretty good at finding a way to let you grow skills, even if that means you will leave your current team. Again, they are big on lateral moves.
- A much more relaxed environment compared to other high-stress brokerage firms.
View10:
- Depending on your position you can be working very long hours. ( Ie Tax season or "giving season" will have you working 8 am-8 pm)
- The pay is lower compared to other brokerage firms. 
- Pay is dependent on seniority, not ability. It's incredibly frustrating to be a top performer in a team, but know you make significantly less than a senior team member, who does not perform well. ( you will get raises but you won't be lifted up to the pay level of a person who has been there for 20 years and has grown complacent) The best way to get raises quickly is through lateral movement and negoation. 
- It is very difficult to get a management position, simply because the company is so big, there is always a large pool of applicants to compete against. 
- Many times when people leave, instead of hiring a new person, they pile that job on an existing team member, but will not raise that team member's pay. Just the expectations. 
- The quality of your manager makes a big difference in your experience. Sadly good managers get promoted and move on to better things, and then a novice is sent to replace them. Great for the managers, bad for the senior team members.

Title: Great for entry level, not if you have actual experience
View8: If you’re getting into the industry and can’t find anyone to hire you this is a great place to start. They at least offer benefits and a salary. The sales training is good and you’ll be exposed to HNW and UHNW clients to take with you when you leave in 2-3 years.
View10: Constant micromanagement around numbers. Calls, appointments, plans, sales pitches, etc.  They say that you are running your own practice but watch every move you make and tell you how to interact with customers.  When I tell other actual advisors what Fidelity does they think it’s criminal, they’re selling cheeseburgers and calling it steak. They want to be the largest RIA in the country but this isn’t it.  The investment management arm of the company (Strategic Advisors) is the RIA. This job is trying to use their watered down planning software to convince customers to buy managed products.  FCs are encouraged (read: compensated) to send the relationship to strategic advisors when it’s closed. This is nothing like a real RIA, trust me I’ve worked at two boutiques. Look no further than the WAS program, where FCs refer clients to actual financial advisors and boutiques. The longest tenured FC in my office was about 3-4 years. Some advice for job seekers, this should be your last option, try to get on with a real RIA first.

Title: Decent
View8: Great benefits, decent pay, work/life balance
View10: Too much emphasis on hiring managers with soft skills, not enough emphasis on hiring management/leadership with actual experience in the department they're managing.

Title: Stuck on Java
View8:
* More than enough PTO (23 days + 5 days covid/family relief time)
* Deadlines are reasonable for epics and sprints, low stress to get work done on time
* Pay is pretty good for RDU metro area
View10:
* Stuck on Java as the primary language. Reasoning for that is legacy code integrates more easily, and they know they can hire for Java. But recent graduates like myself probably don't like using it as much as Python, Go, etc.
* Slow to lay out concrete details for return to office

Title: Good place to start
View8: It’s a healthy work life balance culture and a great place to get a start in the industry
View10: You can get an increase in pay and job quickly but you do hit a ceiling at a certain point

Title: Great job, potential burn out
View8: Great training, benefits, and overall support
View10: Metrics based doesn't work for everyone - if you can hit your goals you'll get promoted, but if you can't meet your goals you might get burnt out

Title: It’s all about the metrics
View8: Nice people, good training, good benefits
View10: No matter how much they romanticize making a connection with clients, what truly matters in this role always comes back to metrics. If they can’t measure it, it doesn’t count, and you’re only as good as your metrics say. It’s relentless and offers little autonomy and a ton of scrutiny and micromanagement. If that’s not your thing, this isn’t your place.

Title: Call Center
View8: Great support amongst higher-ups Many opportunities with enough networking and effort
View10: No cons, the job was simply not for me

Title: Very stressful
View8: They train you Health insurance starts day one
View10: The management hovers over you Micromanaged to the point they might as well take the call themselves Cared more about numbers of call than the quality of the call They time your lunch break and bathroom breaks to the minute and ‘ding’ you if you are a minute off the phones Staff are nervous to even go to the bathroom when needed!

Title: WPC
View8:
- Decent pay
- Good benefits (very long vesting schedule for some)
- Pay for training/licensing, although Fidelity does have a big problem of reps leaving after being paid to obtain the licenses
- They are currently promoting reps very quickly through the WPA department
View10:
- Taking phone calls all day long (the majority I had would message you within 5 minutes of not being on the phone, but that could help obviously vary with locations/managers)

- Very high turnover. My team had 5 different managers within 6 months. Reps also leave very quickly to get off the phones. The company really has a plan in place to make their reps stay in the call center as long as possible. Bonus payments are structured to make you feel like it is just close enough to stay for a little while longer. Also a year requirement of work after you obtain your licenses before you can move to a branch role (which are very competitive, and typically are outside hires anyways)

- Extremely sales oriented, but a lot of the clients think we are service. Be prepared for awkward calls where you and the client have completely separate agendas. Instead of servicing the clients need and moving on to help the next, the company would rather you run them through their retirement tools. These tools can be beneficial in some instances, but they are extremely general and many of these clients have recognized that they don’t help much. Seems the department is only here to promote these tools. Only goal on every single call is to take the clients need, acknowledge it while basically ignoring it, run them through the retirement tools so we can gather outside assets, and then set an appointment with a branch so they can move those to Fidelity.

I understand there are plenty of roles similar to this, the only difference is that a lot of the hiring managers at Fidelity do not warn you of this. Multiple reps on my team and I had this same experience.

Overall, this role and the constant phone calls will exhaust you. I would recommend looking elsewhere first if your goal is to get into financial advising. If necessary, this can be a decent role in the short-term.

Title: Awesome company!!
View8: I’ve been here for almost a year and waited until I had “seen it all” to post a review. Fidelity really cares for their employees, what they say is VERY true. We get bonuses on top of bonuses just by working and doing what we’re supposed to be doing. Amazing PTOs about 23 days for all associates that have been here for less than 2 years. Amazing health, dental, vision etc etc the standard basic benefits but what really got me was how much they invest in you as an associate. I’m truly blessed to work for such a great organization!
View10: Micromanaging can be a problem however, as to be expected if you are on a phone role. May feel like you are “stuck” and stagnant at a role but in the mean time I am seeing lots of employment opportunities to move around. It may take a bit longer for you to move around and the pay may be below average for the same job elsewhere but the benefits package are for sure to be top notch all around.

Title: As advertised
View8: good management, PTO and benefits available right when you start. Work culture is good and most clients on the phone are easy to handle. If you already have a finance background this is a easy step into the field and can net you a life long job within the company.
View10: Expect to be tested on Series 7/63 within 3 months of starting role. This isn't a permanent position until you pass these exams and failure means losing your job.

Title: Amazing Company, Pay Tradeoff
View8: Fidelity has amazing benefits, is seriously one of the best companies to work for in terms of work/life balance. You manager actually push you to move up in the company and want you to succeed.
View10:
You trade extra PTO and an amazing company culture for a little less pay than the rest of the industry and the sales roles don't really have commission. 
If all you care about is money maybe not the right place, but if you want somewhere you can grow and enjoy your life APPLY!

Title: Fast paced, great career experience but watch for management issues
View8: Holistic Retirement and Investment Planning and Guidance, access to specialists, industry leader in tech utilization. You will get top notch experience here. Incredibly high level efficiency. Other advisors and specialists are overall great people with team-oriented mentality.
View10: Pay, high stress level, work hours can easily spill into the evening, very high level of expectation including weekly meetings, planning interactions and proposals (more than double most other places). Management may also make assurances and not follow through or even backtrack. Without other specifics, HR and Management were competent overall but among the worst I've ever worked with and I will not say why here. If the company allows or endorses this management type I would stay clear.

Title: Great Company

Title: Great Company
