Title: Fidelity Will Ruin Your IT Career With a Smile
View8: The benefits package is above average.
View10:
Fidelity will destroy an IT carrier.  

They will work you to death on out date tech that won't do you any good outside their doors.  

Manager's are immune to repercussions for their actions. While employees are expected to follow very high standards of conduct.  Discrimination of all forms is common and well accepted by HR.

If you are going to work for Fidelity make sure you fall into a category of person your manager likes, or they will destroy you with the full support of the HR department. 

You also better make sure you don't have kids to take care of, or turn 40.  I worked there for a decade and no one ever retired by choice.

Title: Best in the biz (its the biz thats the problem)

Internal systems are a nightmare, its a Frankenstein mishmash of all these old in house systems that don't play nice together and are not very user friendly. Also training is rushed adding an un-needed degree of pressure to new hires already working a difficult job.

 And the job no matter how good everything else could be is a tough tough job. It takes at least a year to get any good but once you pass your "trial by fire" and give it 100% this can be a very rewarding career especially for someone like me with no college degree.

Title: Not worth it

Title: Micro managed for minimum pay

Title: Best place I've ever worked

- As a CRA my entire job was answering a nonstop stream of phone calls
- While the training program is nice, you will NEVER fully be trained or prepared for what calls you may receive. 
- There is a massive variety of calls you may receive, which can leave you juggling a client, researching a solution and reaching out to other departments to find a solution.
- Once training was done I was put onto a new work schedule that ruined my work/life balance. I tried for multiple months to get a new schedule but since I was a newer employee I was never able to get something a bit more accomodating.

Title: High stress
View8: Good pay and benefits are provided.
View10: Almost every metric imaginable is tracked. This is an extremely stressful work environment with no down time. The extra money I receive from this company is offset by medical expenses to manage my anxiety and depression I’ve developed since working here. You will be continually told that relief is coming in the form of more employees, but for three years this has yet to happen to counteract turnover. If you want to take 6-8 phone calls an hour, be insulted daily by clients, work mandatory overtime, and develop crippling mental health issues, this is the company for you.

Title: Very Corporate
View8:
Work life balance
Pay/benefits 
Paid time off
Great 401k match and profit sharing 
Decent resources for training and development
View10:
Can be substantial micro management from the branch leaders in the investor centers. 

Investor centers always seem to be understaffed creating a strain on other roles. High turnover. 

Substantial concentration on metrics that drive your performance bonus with no consideration that some roles get wrapped up in service when their role responsibility doesn’t not include service and their main metrics don’t credit any service work.

No real autonomy to follow your own planning process. Their process is all by their book which can sometimes feel non genuine when working with clients.

Title: Unrelenting Work Environment
View8: Many very talented colleagues and depending on where you work you get to do very interesting work. Internal information and learning resources are great.
View10: A ceaseless grind. Nervous, risk-averse, fear driven work environment. Restructuring and layoffs were constant. Success is entirely in the hands of your direct manager, so while it depends on who your manager is, largely the culture reinforces doing what the boss says and being very cautious about expressing any alternate perspectives. Many people have been there for years and the inside club can be defensive of their turf. You are encouraged to not think of compensation and instead the 'total value' of the package, but never-the-less, I found overall pay to be below market.

Title: Management only cares about metrics and fails to look at bigger picture.
View8: -401k match -Tuition reimbursement -decent work-life balance -trauma bonds built with coworkers forged friendships that will last a lifetime
View10:
-Very political environment with lots of nepotism. This allowed many undeserving and incapable people to become management.

-True competence and hard work was noticed by managers, but rarely actually rewarded. Only numbers were considered important, and these metrics were easy to manipulate if the employees lacked integrity. If you wanted to succeed, you had to be prepared to cheat in one way or another.

-Complete lack of mobility between departments. Many employees joined the company because they were told that it was possible to transition to analyst work. When they became eligible to move departments, they were mysteriously kept in customer service (even if they worked very hard and networked well in order to be able to leave).

-Constant changes that made your job more difficult without any additional pay or thanks. This was a never ending flow of additional responsibilities handed to us.

Title: Bias work environment
View8: Amazing insurance and time off benefits , managers are great to work with, employees are nice and friendly
View10: My biggest con is around covid and others may see it as a plus. However, “equal opportunity employer” is not true. If you’re vaccinated, you get extra time off the phones, free lunches in the office, development opportunities not given to those not allowed to go into the office. Whether you have medical reasons or not to not get the vaccine. It doesn’t matter to them, you will be treated less than equal which does impact career development because you don’t have the same opportunities given to those who are vaccinated.

Title: Enjoyed my 21 years, left at the right time.
View8: Good Technology and tools, Brand Name. Good benefits.
View10: Behind the curve at times with products offerings. Hiring based on diversity, not quality of applicant.

Title: Better than the service industry, but still service
View8: Lots of assistance offered to get you licensed (SIE, series 7, series 63). Inclusive culture is pushed (don't expect everyone to be that way, but at least they try to make it welcoming). Better than minimum wage. Opportunities for growth.
View10: UNDERPAID! This role requires you to live within 100 miles of Fidelity, yet they do not pay enough for a person to afford to actually live by themselves near Fidelity which is absolutely shameful. It is like being in a minimum wage job except with better pay (though, like I said, still underpaid). You get limited breaks, you are expected to clock in ten minutes early each day, it can be difficult to use your PTO. The customer's rate us on a 7 point scale, but the only acceptable score is 7 points. If you get rated a 6, that is considered failing. This role is very challenging and directly customer facing. There is a lot of pressure because you are dealing with customer's money. Fidelity throws you right into it, I did not feel ready to be moving money for customer's on my own but you just gotta do it. It is great that they sponsor you through the licensing process, but it is really easy to get burned out by their pace. Then, if you fail, prepare to be "let go." It is a FINRA rule that licensed employees cannot work from home full time without an exception process that Fidelity is not interested in participating in (it would require them to inspect your home office so I can't blame them for not wanting to do that). We can WFH right now, but will be forced to go in at least part time once it is deemed safe. Fidelity is really pushing for people to return to the office, lots of pressure to participate in "connect weeks" which is where you volunteer to go back to the office. They send you a lot of free stuff but most of it is junk. Like cheapy backpacks/mugs/merch you didn't ask for. I am putting this as a con because even though it is nice to receive free things and in the moment it gets you feeling part of the group, this practice has to stop. It is not good for the planet to keep producing useless junk.

Title: Sane, humane, a little slow

View10: Most of the company adjusts slowly to change. If you’ve got an “I want to see my work have impact right away” mind, you may be dismayed. But the caution, overall, is prudent and reflects conscious deliberation. If you can work at enterprise speed, it’s a good place, but you’ll lose your mind if you’re a sprinter.

Title: The Green Machine
View8: Great company with lots of opportunity for advancement and career changes with god benefits, and good pay. Plenty of great people and some pretty awesome financial industry leaders. It's a privately owned company so if they want to pursue something they don't have to get the stock holder's buy in and they allow the employees to provide input on a lot of the process and employee engagement improvements that are currently in place. Overall it's a very dynamic culture constantly changing.

Title: Great Company for the Ambitious and Energetic
View8:
Lots of pros! The pay, the perks, and the people are all great. Fidelity has tried really hard to support employees during COVID, through extra paid leave specifically coronavirus-related, counselor-finding services, fun activities and food provided for people who are willing to come back into the office part time during virus lulls.

Fidelity is also working hard on diversity-and-inclusion, and on making sure employees' voices are heard from the ground up. The company supports outside volunteer efforts and onsite environmental initiatives. You can feel good about working for a company that wants to do good, not just do well.
View10:
Most people are hired into Fidelity at this position. It's a pretty rigorous process, from submitting the application through multiple interviews. Once you're hired, there are two potential hurdles: first in learning the job then in doing the job.

Oh, the learning process! Even entirely online as it has been since the pandemic, it's kind of fun. There are get-to-know-you activities with your newbie group. But there is also a LOT of information to absorb, and it doesn't let up for months. First you learn the Fidelity systems, then you go through licensing training. You must pass the licensing exams to advance within the company. From hire, this all could take 4-6 months. Yes, they pay you the whole time. Once you're licensed, you alternate more Fidelity-specific classes with actual customer support for a few more months before you settle into full time on the phones. After a few more months of that, you may start applying within the company for new skills and new roles, your options being more self-directed.

So, the cons: the pace of learning is set to warp speed, be prepared! Realize that while you're learning you cost the company quite a bit. It's a lot of stress, but they'll want to push you as fast as they can get you to go. And once you're on the job, well, it depends. Some people like inbound phone customer service, or at least don't mind it. Fidelity customers are usually quite pleasant really. But especially in the busy months, from maybe November through tax season, they can spend more time on hold than they like, which makes them cranky. There will be constant pressure from Fidelity for you to make each call as brief as possible: they will measure both your customer satisfaction stats AND your calls per hour. It can be hard to balance the one against the other. And, this is the job: call after call after call. There are breaks, of course, from weekly team meetings to personal lunch and break time to refresher education. If you can continue in the inbound phones roles long enough, you can eventually get promoted out of it if you choose: perhaps 1-5 years, generally?

Title: Overall Excellent Company
View8:
Job security, Work-Life Balance, Great Benefits, From my experience excellent managers that work with you and do not add unnecessary stress

For many roles, you will have great job security and be extremely well-compensated compared to other companies in the industry doing the same role.

I will say that they do have a vested interest in taking care of their associates and I do feel more valued than I would in other big-name companies.
View10:
-Does not sponsor you for licensing unless you are in a role that requires it.

Overall most of the cons can be applied to any big corporate organization.

-Job growth and ability to be promoted within is definitely there, but I have seen some people become stuck in their roles if they stay too long or do not develop skills to move onto the next position. 
- In addition, moving up to management can take quite a while. I have seen it happen within the company, but a large number (especially an overwhelming number of upper-level management) either left the company and came back or were recruited externally. However, this is something that can be seen in almost any company you go to. 

- From the above my experience with management has been great, but I know on some high-intensity teams (such as sales or fund management) can have more stressful managers, but I have not heard anything terrible to note.
-Career center is just incapable

Title: It’s a marathon from sign on to sign off

It’s a marathon! From when you sign on to when you sign off it’s call after call after call… and they monitor you on everything. 

To give you an idea on the difficulty of the job. A new higher class might consist of 20 people. By the time you factor in getting licensed, trained, and then on the phones and go out one year… the quit out rate will have been 75% that’s 3 quarters of a class. 
It’s a tough job and for those who apply and can make it good for you. I lasted five years and left once I was fully vested.

Title: Tech divisions lag the market in tooling, processes, comp, management, leadership, dev experience.
View8: The benefits packages are fully-featured and health insurance is affordable. The best perk of Fidelity is the 7% 401k match and the 10% annual profit sharing; 17% contributions to your 401k overall each year. The work/life balance ends up being very reasonable - it would be uncommon to work a 45-hour workweek more than a few times a year. 40 hours is the very common norm.
View10:
Fidelity does not use public cloud, which has many negative side-effects; they attempt to replicate that experience with older, internal tooling which dramatically slows developer velocity. For example, engineer's ability to access compute resources is blocked by request processes. Libraries are all subject to a security review which can take a small number of weeks if requested with priority, or many weeks without. Licenses are purchased by a remote requisitions team with a similarly slow resolution timeframe. Releases are produced manually, there is no continuous deployment. 

There is no universal devops/platform team, squads maintain their own services. 
This self-sufficiency produces isolation, practically and socially; process standards and tooling varies a fair amount between them. There is no architecture team or unified technical leadership group. Each squad has their own tech lead and that's it.

Pay for engineers lags the market, targeting approximately 80-100% of the market rate. There is no option to acquire equity. "Chairman shares" are offered to top performers, but those are simply 2-year vesting cash bonus - not actual equity. Anecdotally, the very talented engineers remain due to not knowing their own market value. 

The manager-to-report ratio can vary wildly, 50+:1 in some cases, offering virtually no manager facetime or development opportunities to members of those squads. The daily routine of managers and directors is primarily comprised of liaising with customers (other business units) rather than anything related to developing their engineering teams.

Because the tech groups service internal business units, customer requirements are often poorly defined, change frequently and are conveyed verbally to product managers over calls. Oftentimes a change will be reverted due to a customer's whim, not the functionality of the feature itself.

Leadership is adamant about working from the office and will not support remote work post-covid.

Leadership has frequent messaging about undergoing an agile transformation, yet none of the shortcomings described here are eligible for reevaluation. The remaining set of factors that can be changed are virtually meaningless in impact.

Talented top-level leadership want to lead other business units which are revenue centers (all are financial business units) rather than cost centers, so the tech groups end up with a steady rotation of SVPs (the head of the tech group, equivalent to a CEO elsewhere) every 1-2 years. 

In short, the engineer experience at Fidelity is stable, yet slow, uninspiring, and poorly-compensated when compared to the broader market.

Title: Good benefits and pay but micromanaged

Also your bonus is mainly based on customer reviews but customers will use the review to complain about plan rules that you cannot control. So you will receive a lower bonus for simply doing your job, and stating the plan rules.

Title: Unhealthy environment
View8: The people, the benefits are great
View10: The higher the leadership closest to the top, the more close minded and attached to old school culture they are, trying to force everyone into outdated thinking.  They will also lure you into new roles and lock you down without being honest about what the role really is.  You get “used” as a vessel to push upper leadership personal motivations and accolades, while slowly being quieted down and eventually silenced.  .  It’s just a bunch of senior leaders trying to outshine each other and get their name on something even if it’s not best for the employees.  Will get overwhelming associate feedback in surveys about wanting to work remote and will only tell you about the one comment from someone who wants to be in the office and then try to gaslight you into believing it’s the majority opinion.  Leadership will “threaten” that you’re luck the President is giving you any flexibility because she would prefer not to and force you to give up all of your flexibility if you don’t agree to work in the office sometimes.  Kind of like “ you’re lucky to get anything.  Don’t push your luck or she will take all your toys away.  The culture was going in an amazing direction the past couple of years.  But in a very short time it’s gone backwards and more toxic than it’s ever been.

Title: Great Company! Why look anywhere else?!
View8:
-Respectful, Inclusive Workplace! Fidelity encourages anyone to bring up to someone you trust about something someone did or said that made you uncomfortable and Fidelity has no tolerance for inappropriate and disrespectful behavior! 

-Since COVID 19 hit 99% of this company works from home! (This position allowed working from home 2 days out of the week before COVID happened.)

-Work from home but not alone! Excellent technology giving you all the tools you need to be successful and feel connected with you coworkers and managers. 

-Flex time! With this position getting one planned paid hour off a week. ( i.e Getting off at 4 instead of 5 on Friday and getting paid that hour. What company does that? 

- VERY STABLE! When companies during COVID-19  are laying off people this company is hiring.  Most businesses get busy in the summer while this company gets busy in the winter.

-Free  Essential Health Insurance

- Job Advancement! The Career Center is dedicated in giving you resources for job advancement where the people associated are there to help you obtain a job you want within Fidelity. 

- Plenty of other Pros!
View10:
Call center work is repetitive. 
(You have to really fish for cons to find them with a great company like this)

Title: Data scientists go elsewhere
View8: It pays well and the benefits are good.  There are women in leadership positions.  For tech people at least, fairly flexible.
View10:
Oh where to start.  I worked in Fidelity labs.

The so called culture of "speaking frankly" and "taking risks" is 100% a lie.  You can speak as frankly as you want as long as you're saying what your manager wants to hear.   You cannot innovate.  My manager incorrectly considered himself an expert in the fields of every person on his team and never accepted any opposing views.   All the data scientists on my team quit.  No one reached out to us.  Nobody cared.  Take this warning seriously.

Title: Benefits are the only reason I’m there
View8: You won’t find a company with better benefits. We had an unprecedented busy year and the job sucked more than usual. The company responded with doing an overtime incentive program where you could earn not only time and half, but another $25 per hour on top. In addition, they are rolling out another bonus, on top of the performative bonus we already have, for those who simply passed their license exams within a certain time frame of their hire date. In addition, we get 18 days of PTO, paid holidays, and this year, we got 40 hours of COVID Relief Time.
View10: The job itself is not fun and can be stressful. When we were busy, we would deal with angry clients every single call, and take about 4-6 calls and hour for 8 straight hours. It gets tiring and extremely repetitive. I also personally do not like staring at a screen for that long.

There were other people who didn’t even pass the SIE the first time but still kept their jobs! How does that make sense? It makes no sense to hire people, invest this time and then simply let them go when it’s a call center job..I legit was doing the job while in training. No suprise so many people quit even after passing all the exams. They hype themselves when it’s just a call center. DONT kid yourself. Also I understand it’s a financial firm but they are very intrusive in your life.

Title: Several Things To Consider
View8: There are several things to consider when start a job at Fidelity. The optimal situation is when you’re earlier in you’re career. Fidelity will help develop and manage career for the long term. Great benefits and retirement package (except the 5 year vesting requirement on 401k).
View10: Fidelity isn’t the best option for mid or late career scenarios. The pay isn’t as competitive and promotions are based on bureaucracy and not efforts. Work life balance is horrible in technical areas (80 to 90 hours a week is not uncommon), the on-call competition is below the industry standard and cell phone reimbursement is garbage. There is a passive aggressive expectation to work long long hours but take time off. The internal application process for careers is insulting and garbage. There are employees who applied for 100’s of jobs with no response or feedback.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View8: They're flexible with scheduling if you have a life circumstance that justifies it. Decent pay, they raise salary slowly based on the current economy. Hasn't changed much for this role in the last 15 years from what I have seen. Good benefits for people with families and medical expenses.
View10: I went through the hiring process three years ago with about 30 people. A bunch left during the first year. I've interviewed several times with a 20 to 1 ratio for applicants vs. positions offered. Everyone that stayed made a lateral move within the company. They changed positions but didn't get a bump in pay. A lot of promises and motivational meetings are given on career mobility, but most can't move anywhere easily. Climbing the ladder takes years. For most, it takes a lot of education, experience, and exceptional stats. I saw a guy with a CFP, 3 years of financial advisement experience, a degree in finance, and excellent testing/current role scores lose a job to a woman with 1-year furniture sales experience. He couldn't move out for a long time. I've seen that happen to several people where the promotions were not fair based on diversity hiring. Qualified people get passed up frequently for diverse applicants. I worked with several people that had multiple years of financial experience and a few that had MBA's that didn't move any easier than people in their 2nd year of college. Experience/education/certifications don't help very much. Lots of people apply for every job. If you're not at the top of performance, experience, diversity, education, and in some cases popularity, you don't have a great shot at moving around here.

View10: - Sometimes low pay for what you do, depending on the position - If you move from Workplace Investment to Personal Investment you might have to start back on the phone services and climb up

Title: They’ve been pretty good to me.
View8:
7% 1:1 company match on base plus bonuses. Contribute up to 50% of bonus to 401k & they will match up to 7% 1:1 there too.

Tuition reimbursement 90% if you pass your classes with a C. Masters degrees converged at 10k per year if you major in a relevant field.

Flexible time off without fear of reprisals.
Stay employed even in lean economic markets. 
Fathers get 3 months of parental leave for new borns.
Adoption services.
Concierge services for those who want to plan that special date or marriage proposal.

Paid child care by the firm on days they need you if come in if another sight is snowed by request. Discounts on other days at approved sites.

Night time Differential pay at 5% for folks who work past 6 PM. That increases to 20% for those who work past 8 PM of your eligible based compensation per hour. 

Christmas bonuses 2 to 3 times every five years. Usually 1 pay period awarded. There have been other types of incentive pay depending on call volume to encourage us to not cancel auto OT when applied awarded in cash, stock grants, one day off, Fidelity cash for merchandise, etc.

No weekend requirements for those supporting workplace roles. Personal investments roles may have weekend hours depending on the job.

More Telework is available due to Covid19.

Real career development exit here. Some managers are better at this than others. I’ve always felt that they’re pushing me to take up the next challenge. Even at times when I wasn’t ready to move up or just getting complacent.

Fun stuff at call centers. Choose any of these clubs: Women in Leadership, Aspire, FidVets, FinTech, President Circle, Leadership Summit, etc... they always have something going on for you to network and use to move on up. It’s up to you to hustle and play the game.

Pre Covid19 we had hot air balloon rides, dragon boat competitions, BBall breaks, volleyball teams, zombie nights for Halloween, BBQ competitions, ice cream socials, team outings, camping trips, visiting chefs at some sights, team potlucks, free food and I’m talking about the good stuff NOT pizza. You can definitely gain major weight at certain sites.

No worries because some sites have a full service gym w/ personal trainers, classes, and nutritionists.

 At Our sites we got the choice to take a walk and discuss our development plans or monthly business results around one of the many nature trails.
View10:
Bonus metrics change a lot.

Managers depending on the site location change a lot in the call centers for sure.
 
Will push you hard to keep up with the ever changing metrics in order to stay relevant if you want to get promoted. Only to hire a guy off the street to the branch with 6 months of car sales experience, no degrees in the field, and has to still get his S7 & 63.

You have a better chance of jumping a few slots to get to where you want if you work at Fidelity for 1-3 years. Quit; then work elsewhere for 1-2 years only to come back to Fidelity.

Serious issues at to many of the branches when it comes to hiring women, professionals with ascents, or they may serve in locations with above average demographics or immigrants without one person in the branch that can speak their language. These folks tend to have small to midsize size businesses. They horde cash and don’t have someone they trust to reach out to them. However, executive management is aware and working on making the hiring process better. I can tell that change is happening. It’s not HQ more so the mindset of the financial industry at the local levels. 

Management feedback for the interview process can be largely lackluster. Heard from other top performers that the feed back was non existent or borderline suspect. Being told to smile more during the interview or joke more at team meetings is NOT productive feedback for a job interview. Especially when they seem to selectively provide this to certain “types.”

Healthcare plan is average. Family plan is 3k high deductible. They do give you $1500 per year to your HSA to offset that high @-&:?:?’ Plan. Prescription med and co pays prices were higher for me than my previous employer.

Pay is actually lower than the national average for a license professional.

Title: Nepotism, Lies, Onliviusness
View8:
COVID so people could wfh because it’s a waste of company resources to have office space for a job everyone’s doing just fine at home. 

There’s a lot of really kind and good people at the company. They’re the one thing that makes it good. This is specific to lower level employees, not any form of leadership.
View10:
I wouldn’t know where to start. 

Abby Johnson attempting to create the cult called Fidelity is failing and outflow at the firm is coming. They’re anti-fiduciary approach will cost them majorly with the CFP Board.

 They take no feedback from employees with knowledge of this and other things that are unethical and would violate even Reg BI.

Recruiters will tell you that unless you have a CFA Level I upon graduation from an Ivy League school , or you can never be an analyst. After LinkedIn review this is not true, and I cross referenced who didn’t qualify for those “standards” I found those not from Ivy League had some nepotism within the company, generally at a VP or higher level 

This east coast bias here is incredible. Call centers everywhere else-with about 1/5 the pay of anyone in Massachusetts. 

I don’t recommend this firm to anyone. They’ll preach a holistic happy fun approach- the reality is nothing close. 

Abby Johnson just because you were born into the most successful mutual fund company- does not mean anyone should worship you the way it’s demanded from the top down. It’s actually pretty pathetic you feel the need to plaster your own quotes and face everywhere. 

Best of luck to all those who dare enter these jobs. Congratulations to those who’s dad bought them an Ivy League education and nepotistically raised the wealth differential in this country. Fidelity is the epitome.

Title: Cult
View8: Get your licenses and leave
View10: Drink that koolaid or else you won't last. This is an absolutely miserable job, manager was completely incompetent and was an absolute joke to watch her interact with other leads. Denied first time off request after 5 months of working. You're not going any where, once your're on the phones there is absolutely no movement. The internal technology is from the 1980s. I would never hold my money at this place and no one ever should. Fidelity definitely writes their own ratings because there is simply no way people give them such good feedback. The training program is actually horrible in covid conditions, if you need extra help good luck in a zoom class of 300 people. If you're a college grad and think this sounds like a good start, simply don't do it, you will have your soul sucked out of you 6 months into your career.

Title: Will keep employees as temp workers for years
View8: A lot of company parties, lunches, etc. The schedule can be flexible for college students. Big Christmas party at the end of the year.
View10: They like to pretend like it's a friendly and great work environment; however, there is a lot of micromanagement and very few opportunities to advance. The work environment is not culturally inclusive and temporary employees are treated poorly. Temporary workers are expected to do the same job if not more than full-time employees and are told if they continue to do their job well, they will get hired on. Management will activily encourage you to apply for new permanent positions, only to hire a friend or family member from outside of the company. Permanent employees are giving annual bonuses every year, sometimes double for performing great that year, while the temporary employees, whom worked beside them the whole year gets nothing but maybe a free lunch. Their hiring process, specifically in the Covington location is severly flawed and unfair to the people who believe they will eventually get hired after working their for several years.

Title: Fantastic Company
View8:
Fidelity has amazing benefits - 10% profit sharing after 1 year at the company, 18 days PTO for new hires, 7% 401k match with five year vesting, low-deductible health insurance coverage, maternity and paternity leave. They are a very generous company, and they give employees great work-life balance. You will only bump into more financial benefits the more you work there. 

The company is also genuinely high integrity. They structure their company with customer obsession as the main goal. I enjoy making clients happy, and I go to bed feeling good about my work at night.
View10: Fidelity is a good company for someone wanting a corporate job. If someone is extremely entrepreneurial, they will probably feel somewhat trapped or undervalued at Fidelity. Fidelity has a process they want employees to follow, and sticking to their process is key to long-term success.

Title: Less Than Ideal
View8: - Good pay - No micromanagement - Learning days - Encouraged to move within company
View10:
The LEAP program has been terrible. It is essentially 4 more months of college after you graduate. Lots of hand-holding and forced classroom-style learning. Instructor-led training is mostly a waste of time here.

High chance that you will be working with an outdated tech stack after LEAP. You may also be placed into an unfavorable role with little to no technical mentorship and with minimal transferrable skills. They will try to tell you that Fidelity is a "tech company that does finance" but this is not the case.

In short, not a great place for new software engineers. If you have another offer, I would highly recommended considering working elsewhere

Title: Great place to work!

The company has made a strong effort to put its people first; the benefits are stellar. D&I has become a top priority as the firm continues to display a strong social consciousness. Technology groups across the company have embarked on a sweeping Agile transformation. The idea of constant improvement is alive and well at Fidelity. It is a great place to work.
View10: There are no major Cons to report. All large companies have challenges. Does Fidelity present some of these? Sure. The difference is that management is receptive to feedback, and reasonable responses and appropriate action are often provided. No company is perfect, but nothing major to report here.

Title: Where college degrees die and anxiety is born.
View8:
Generous 401k match
Reasonably priced insurance
Flexible PTO
Positive company culture/values
They hire pleasant people
So many perks and benefits I literally cant fit it all on here.
View10:
Ever ask yourself "How can I simultaneously destroy my career prospects and waste my expensive college degree?" Well then , Fidelity Investments in Jacksonville has the perfect job for you! 

First, it's a call center people...through and through. You will talk to dozens of people on the phone. Every...single...day. Eventually, that "ding!" sound of a new call coming in will haunt your dreams. Most people don't last more than a year. You can either go the sales or service route. If you go service, there is very little room for advancement. In addition, if you move into whats called a "High Net Worth" service role, you will be responsible for a HUGE range of knowledge and actions without commensurate pay. One call could have you rushing to get a complex option trade placed within minutes of market close, while a pushy day trader berates you, and the next call could be spending an hour helping a 90 year old man reset his password as you bang your head on you desk asking "I went to college for this?!" If you go sales, then get used to working long, awkward hours and having your success defined in how many more calls you can take than the next guy/gal. 

The coupe de grace (ATTENTION ALL RECENT COLLEGE GRADS): None of the jobs they offer in Jacksonville are real finance jobs. They're just customer service/sales jobs parading as something fancier. Even the "Financial Advisor" roles are just sales, albeit well paying. Also, call center jobs are only marketable to other customer service careers. Having a call center job on your resume will actually HARM your chances of landing a job in world of ACTUAL finance. So, before you go thinking "I'll just work here for a year or two to get something on my resume"....DON'T DO IT.

None of what I just said should reflect poorly on the company itself, because Fidelity is a great company in terms of culture, mission, and values. That's undeniable. The problem is very specific to the extent of their operations in Jacksonville being call center based and that these are very stressful and career-limiting work environments. Consider yourself warned!

Also be on the lookout for training new hires while keeping up with the regular workload, there is high turnover in the group.

Title: Fidelity Clients with $10MM waited for 50-200 minutes to speak to me and were never in a good mood
View8: I got paid on time
View10:
This is, despite the description, a hard core call center job. But, because its Fidelity, the clients wait for 50-200 minutes or more to speak with you, they are, as you would expect, not happy by the time you speak with them. (These are the clients filling out your survey, and only PERFECT surveys count). The queue of clients to speak to is endless. Over time the bad attitudes and angry people yelling at me wore me down and I lost 15 lbs, because skinny anxious and depressed, and essentially sacrificed my personal self to chase my professional goal to move to a different job where the clients don't wait as long. However, the rhetoric and promise of changing jobs, the date keeps getting pushed back. Now they are refusing to do internal promotions, due to the egregious client hold times. This is a LOSING TEAM. Go join a winning team. 

If you don't live there already, you have to move to the city to WFH

No real team atmosphere

Clients yelling at you and disrespecting you.

In the words of management "this is the bottom of the company"

In the words of my former manager "this is the hardest year at the company, and this is the worst version of the hardest year at the company ever"

Except, this year is different, because the company is literally NOT PROMOTING the loyal employees who worked through the hell of December-March.

If you call Fidelity this upcoming December 2021, you will experience an unacceptable hold time of at least 70 minutes, and you will work with someone brand new and incompetent.

Since I joined, my class of 30 people, about 14 have quit or been fired for yelling back at clients, or failing their Finra exams.

Again, I cannot emphasize enough, this is a LOSING TEAM and the teflon-covered management give you lip-service about the future getting better, yet the carrot gets pushed farther and farther away.

Even in this terrible environment, when my peers got only 40% "perfect surveys" my record month was 91%.

I have been asking for help since January to get into a different role that fits my background and skillset.
Now, I have other companies offering me jobs that pay more than 2x the $48,000 at Fidelity.

BYEEEEEEEEEE

Title: Customer Relationship Advocate
View8: Outstanding benefits package. Very positive corporate culture.
View10:
Ever ask yourself  "How can I waste my finance degree AND make myself less marketable at the same time?" Well, have I got a job for you! Sarcasm aside, let's just be brutally honest here. COLLEGE STUDENTS/GRADS PAY ATTENTION!!! Unless you plan to become an advisor (cough...salesman), most of the jobs you will find in the world of personal investments/brokerage services are going to be a CALL CENTER JOB! This is just the nature of the beast, yet something that your career counselor at college probably wont tell you. Call center experience is only a marketable skill to more customer service jobs.  I have worked at Fidelity for several years and can honestly say that I feel I have wasted years of my life doing something I have grown to absolutely despise. Dealing with customers on the phone is a life-draining experience. So let's bring it back to Fidelity, shall we? Would you like a real-life sample of what your job will consist of as a "Financial Representative" or "Customer Advocate" at Fidelity? Well, say no more!:

8:00 a.m. - Distribution check request.
8:10 a.m. - Hour long password reset with 90 year old client. (College degree hard at work!)
9:10 a.m. - Distribution check request.
10:10 a.m. - Help client find tax form online. 
10:15 a.m. - Why wont my debit card work?
10:25 a.m. - Why wont my credit card work?
10:35 a.m. - Complex multi-leg option trade.
10:45 a.m. - 30 minute password reset with 80 year old client. ( I went to college for this?)

Now rinse and repeat this for 30 calls a day, day in and day out. Not exactly what you pictured yourself doing with that shiny, expensive college education, is it?
Look...I could go on and on about other details of the job (particularly the wacked-out survey questionnaire Fidelity bases a large portion of your bonus on) but I'll leave that for some other disenchanted soul. Here is the bottom line...if you want to do sales, that is great for you and you will find many career opportunities at any brokerage firm, including Fidelity, and you will make a great living doing so. However, if sales is not your thing then I highly suggest you look elsewhere.

Title: The definition of Gamification of the workplace.
View8: Do not need any investment knowledge.  Can be promoted simply due to "needs of the business".  If able to stick around for 5+ years, will be able to keep the 7% 401k matching and 10% yearly profit-sharing payout.  Great for recent college grads who have not developed professional workplace habits.  VERY hands on approaching to coaching and development; multiple people always providing career advice.
View10: Some of the lowest pay in the industry.  Previous experience is not respected once hired on; only benefits prior to being hired when qualifying for roles.  Micromanaged down to the smallest detail.  As the title of the review says, gamification of the workplace is in full swing (look it up if unfamiliar; may not be suitable for all individuals).  VERY negative attitude towards competitors.  Upon resignation of the firm all previous connections will instantly dissolve.  Senior management uses smiles and positive speeches to squash any and all critiques/feedback of existing processes.  "On-loan" roles are overused in order to keep from permanently funding very enjoyable roles.  Lower management uses toys (slinkees, pom-poms, hello kitty candy dispensers) to "encourage and motivate" their teams while in the middle of tax seasons.  Overall, very immature and unprofessional work environment.  Attrition is a constant battle that is verbally ignored and spoken against.

Title: Fast food of finance
View8: Great benefits, great coworkers, clean campus,
View10: Managers only manage up. Pay quickly stops after several years to a grinding halt, even with stellar reviews. Most of these positive reviews are from newbies who are the only ones fidelity invests in. After a couple years, trust me, you'll be begging to get out of their militant and lack of resource style. Managers know nothing about your role, as Fidelity typically hires managers with no knowledge of the role as they believe managers are their to "manage" and not need be experts at the technical aspects of the role. With that said, where do you go for guidance? Glad the police, fire department or pilots aren't hired Fidelity style. Who is the go to contact if your manager doesn't have a clue about the day to day of your job? Being a manager is a great deal at Fido as they have zero accountability and throw you under the bus if need be. I've been there 7 years and have a rockstar performance record, so this review is not in spite, rather it's just reality. Get in, get your license and experience on their dime, get out. Was a great employer years gone by, but as Ned once said "Our employees are our biggest asset" has not been heard in years and years. They burn you out, WANTING turnover, just to hire somebody for half your salary.

Title: Strong Company
View8: Great pay and benefits. Good company culture.
View10:
Learn to get good at office politics! Constantly feel like you're on the hamster wheel. Some of the offices have excellent leadership but some 
are surprisingly backwards.

Title: Great company with pockets of terrible management.
View8:
Great benefits for employees. Salary+Bonus+Annual Profit Share+7% dollar-to-dollar 401k match.
Contractors treated well in most groups. (I have been contracting the last few years)
Durham NC location is pretty casual. Business casual dress with jeans on Friday. Relationships with management have always been casual side.
Some groups work with offshore resources and get to travel to other countries.
Some groups are in flexible work arrangement situations. Some people work from home much of the time. Even in other groups, you generally can work from home if needed for personal reasons from time to time.
View10:
Base salaries can be very low, especially when you get promoted to the next level.
Some groups work in crowded arrangements because leadership will not support any official work from home arrangements.
Lack of oversight on Directors and Vice Presidents with direct reports. A bad apple can really tear a department apart. 
Review process is not individual. People are stack ranked and there are quotas on high ratings. Even if you have 2 star performers, only 1 can receive the most excellent rating. The process is truly not individualized.
People provide reviews for employees they have had very little interaction with. Can get very personal.
You will have to change departments to earn more money as annual merit increases are often nominal.
Your career is in your hands here. You can not depend on any management or HR group to help guide you in advancing your career.

Title: Not What I Expected
View8: The pay and benefits are great for the Albuquerque area, they also offer some amazing perks to inspire you to make choices.
View10:
Fidelity does not practice what it preaches.. You are told when you are hired and during training that customer service and advocating for the customer is the main goal.  That you should "own the call". However as soon as you are on the phones, you are told that once the customer is handed off to what ever dept ,  you should not be involved anymore, that you should not make too many outbound calls to the customers because we are an inbound call center , I do not consider this owning anything.  The procedures and resources are time consuming and cumbersome.  Your computer is prone to freezing when you are in the middle of a call because of all of the resources you have to have up,  and yet you can not say anything about your computer not working properly. 
  Fidelity has compassion as part of it's mission statement , yet most of the procedures could not possibly show less compassion for the customer if they tried.  In short I feel like I was lied to about the position I was hired for.   
   Management shows favoritism as well as cliquishness, and though everyone appears to be friendly it is surface only.  You never know what management expects or what they are in charge of  because it changes constantly.

Title: Just okay
View8: I love my coworkers, they are truly nice people to work with. Fidelity has excellent benefits - medical, dental, 401k with 7% percent match (though you have to be there a year to get match and work 5 years to be vested), quarterly bonuses on performance and profit sharing. I truly love Fidelity and what they stand for. I just hate the role I'm in.
View10: The role just sucks, especially if you work nights because they never hire enough people to work late nights so people can wait up to 10 minutes just for a password reset! It's a call center so it's constantly taking call after call and people can be too needy or hostile because they can't treat their retirement account like an ATM. You have to be in the role for at least a year to even be considered for other roles though it will just be another job on the phone all day. Also your calls are graded all the time and depending on your manager... it's a miracle if you do anything right on a call. Some people call in to get a balance and just because you didn't get the persons life story doesn't mean the call was "inconsistent". Metrics are so whack.

Title: Positive, fun and challenging
View8: I would say that the best part of working at Fidelity are the benefits and the culture. The benefits are unmatched for New Hampshire (I would imagine the same for Florida, Kentucky, Ohio, Colorado and Utah but I'm not 100% certain). The culture is awesome. Lots of positive people and I've definitely gotten my share of great managers that like to promote within. I believe that management culture does trickle down and inspire new and up-and-coming managers. Being positive at this company will certainly get your far. I tend to be a naturally positive person who is extremely driven. That speaks volumes.
View10: It's stressful at times. The pay could be a little better, but it's not horrible by any means. I still feel like upper management is slightly disconnected to what we have to do vs. industry standards vs. their expectations. Lastly, we have an internal feedback board we can utilize to provide customer as well as coworker feedback, however the time frames from when the research of a project starts to when it completes can be well over 1 year. For a multi-billion dollar company, I'm not sure if that is truly acceptable.

Title: Decent compensation but all advancement is purely political.
View8: Compensation is comparable to other large financial services companies.  Benefits used to be among the best in the industry but that has fallen in recent years.
View10:
In my department advancement, whether in the form of formal promotions or stretch assignments, go only to those with contacts at higher levels.  Midlevel managers routinely tell subordinates that they believe the subordinates deserve advancement but that none is available unless the subordinate can figure out a way for senior managers to take notice.  Senior managers don't believe this is a problem because they see promotions going to the people they know are good.  They are oblivious to how many good people work there that they don't know.  That is because people rise to the top at Fidelity by managing up, not managing down.

There are two types of senior managers.  One is the Fidelity Lifer who understands how to play the game.  Don't try to change anything, don't take any chances, figure out how to not get your finger prints on anything that might fail and know that after 20 years you can retire extremely wealthy.  The other is the short timer who comes in from another company expecting to get things done.  They take chances, they get involved in new projects that take the company in new directions and they are the first to be blamed when things fail.  These people rarely last long.

Title: Great company

Title: Portfolio specialist
View8: Great benefits package and a large company so lots of opportunity to grow. You can advance quickly if you have ambition. The retirement benefits alone make it worth it. 10 percent profit sharing...Seven percent 401k match. You can expect to make over 100k as a portfolio specialist which is decent and is truly under 45 hour work week. They are rolling out things like16 weeks paid maternity for women and 6 weeks paid for men. The best thing about the job is you do meet life long friends and work with a ton of amazing people.
View10: They are old fashioned. They don't have a work environment that inspires creativity.They have call models and sales models that they want you to stick to "to make you successful"...they actually focus more on those models than educating about the products they want you to sell...it can sometimes make you feel like a robot and clients pick up on it. They measure performance a lot by things that don't really make business sense and have particular buckets they want you to fill. If you can get past that aspect of the job it can be a nice career.

Title: The Tea:
View8:
If you get a great manager they will help you grow and push you to do better. There is a lot of opportunity for growth.
Having the market knowledge was my favorite part.
It’s fun to help
Ppl along the way.
View10:
For Cei metrics they only count sevens. Which is ridiculous for the reps and it leads to getting burnt out quick.

Also back to back phone calls will get to you after a while so find ways to connect with the customer. And make up little
Competitions for yourself and your team. ( I did that a lot for
My team) it helped us improve and have fun. 
There are some managers who do not practice company values. I had three great managers. They were so amazing! Then came Angie who was sexiest and racist and I have no idea how she held on to her job for so
Long. ( she has no idea what she was doing. And she was handed a great team and she made sure it went to crap) she’s now gone from the company. But it caused me
To leave the company wayy before I planned on it. 

So reach out and build a network! Also don’t stay in one place for too long. Seek to grow!

Title: Fidelity sucks for me, will it for you?
View8: Job security. For the most part it takes a lot to be laid off or fired.  Benefits are good, which include profit sharing, access to HSA/Health Flex accounts, etc.
View10: You won't get any significant raises unless you make it your priority to move departments when you can. This requires you to apply and search for internal jobs constantly, which I have seen work for some people. To sum it up, there is no autonomy in your job. From the start, they want you to buy into the "Fidelity Culture." However, they have the money to spend to be a successful company - at least for the short term. So if you want job security this is the place for you. If you're looking for autonomy in your job and play an active role in the company you work for, I suggest you look elsewhere.

Title: Good Company if You're in the Right Team
View8: Decent Salaries, great bonuses, great benefits, insane 401k matching, and generally fun coworkers. Fidelity tries to figure out what makes their employees happy - for example they recently started helping with student loans which was incredible. Certain teams have great dynamics and click really well with each other. There's a ton of diversity, so you get interesting perspectives from everyone.
View10: They tend to promote people based on who has the loudest mouth.  They also have a streak of hiring incompetent people and then moving them around instead of firing them. There are politics abound in most of the upper management and they try to obfuscate everything from lower employees. It is difficult to move around in Fidelity. I tried several moves, but kept getting blocked so I ended up leaving.

Title: One of the best employers in the DFW area

Title: Great benefits but low salary
View8:
You can’t beat the company match on your 401k, profit sharing and the retiree health credit.  Plus if you choose the high deductible health plan they give you 1k towards your HSA.
Other: good nice people/ coworkers. Some work/life flexibility depending upon the job.
View10:
No matter how many times employees tell them that Fidelity pays lower salary than other companies they always say it’s comparative to the current market, and of course they tout all the benefits. For some tenured employees the benefits package keeps them there but younger employees don’t see it that way and just want the base pay.  I was an employee for over 12 years and always felt I was underpaid at the base salary.  They don’t seem interested in retaining hard working, SP rating employees who execute on the work. You have to be a superstar to be recognized.
Other: so many layers of approval to get to any type of decision, lots of group consensus needed.
Career oops: they are all into talking about mobility right now but it seems to be towards more younger employees to keep them engaged.
When jobs are eliminated: it’s almost always people age 40 and above. You can have a department of 80 people and the people getting laid off are always above 40.

Title: Great benefits, but leaders can make it tough for new hires to thrive and grow their careers
View8:
Great and caring people all over the company if you can find them for your network.
Premium health insurance and superior overall benefits.
Employee Resource Groups for connecting with other employees.
Opportunities to volunteer with local charities.
View10:
Pay is lagging and not competitive or calibrated by location (no cost of living increases and most Director level salaries don't change year to year for multiple years).
Meeting-heavy culture...lots and lots of meetings.
Have to wait 1 year to participate in 401K.
Tenured employees (15-20+ year) are mostly unwilling to change or transform the way they work, or be influenced by new thinking.
Career growth is limited for back-office employees and most job requisitions require you to live in the geographical area (TX, NC, or MA) in order to be considered for the job.
Lacking leadership skills at Director level, VP, and above creating a micro-managing culture and toxic work environment. 
HR is passive in giving employee support and really only advocates and acts upon anything for the benefit of the manager and company.
Way too many Executives and layers of management.
Spending or investing via your Fidelity checking and 401K accounts are monitored by your manager.
Year-end bonus and performance evaluations are 100% subjective with manager discretion to give you 0% bonus.
Diversity and Inclusion is not a top priority for Fidelity, although they have taken steps to address some the gaps, but could still do more.

Title: Good place to work

View10: Pay is a bit below competitors

Title: Tenured Associate
View8: Great benefits, coworkers are awesome, if you weren’t a college grad you could have a good job with great benefits and pay. Often in areas where there aren’t many other good jobs. Upper management wants to do the right thing, but often dies in the middle.
View10:
My biggest issue is with middle management. If associates don’t want to go into sales, the only other option is management, which is often not a good fit. You’d have managers who just weren’t “people” people, who would be leading a team of 20+. Managers also have the ability to make or break your career. They control your pay, bonuses, reviews and even promotions. I don’t believe one (possibly inept) person should have control over basically your life. Favoritism runs rampant, which is awesome if you’re a favorite, sucks if you’re not. I had many managers, some who loved me and would mentor and promote me and sing my praises from the rooftop, and then others who gave me very low performance reviews (how is this possible?) 

They’re just SO HUGE with so many different business groups that people wouldn’t know what jobs are out there. Sales or management was all people knew, wish there was more transparency so people who aren’t fit for mgmt wouldn’t go into those roles. Upper management initiates also die at the middle management level due to their inertia and stubbornness.

Title: Great way to enter financial advisor career

Title: Highly political
View8: Decent salary. Good benefits. Some coworkers that can share your values about doing big things. A company that prides itself in conservative investing contrasted with technology and first-to-market product and services.
View10: A highly political company with unknown employee measurement and hidden scores. As a senior person in my position you get to know the skill set that is important for your job. When you do outstanding work you soon realize that advancement Is not based on merit but who you are aligned with. A company that is interested more in protecting management with an emphasis on the org chart and less about the work itself. Constant internal battles and intentional reorganizations. An internal employee goal program that ignores how you want to grow as an individual instead focusing on how a manager wants you positioned. If you get a good manager that focuses on the work it can be a wonderful place but soon there will be a reorg and and you will find yourself having to pay more attention to the political back channels and less on your passions and skill set. Politics is extended externally as well with profits spent on preventing governmental "regulation" but internally a love of regulating the employee. Highly protectionist from the top on down. This protectionism even extends to internal technology where systems in place are more about what management wants rather than what the employee needs.

Title: Very corporate culture, great benefits and pay, lots of bloat
View8:
Excellent 401K matching, but you're not fully vested until you hit your five years. Very good pay and benefits. 

Culture depends on the division you're in -- I used to work in Strategic Advisers, Inc. (later rolled up into Asset Allocation) and the majority of the people that I worked with in that group were incredibly nice and smart. I'd heard not-so-great things about some of the other divisions at Fidelity, though, so I counted myself fortunate. Compared to the other floors in my building (245 Summer St), my floor was relatively casual and the floor plan was more open -- large half-cubes instead of the cube farms at the Smithfield, RI campus. Because I worked on a floor with portfolio managers and other members of investment management, we also got nicer drinks in the fridge.

I also had a very kind and nurturing manager and a good team.
View10:
Even within the division that I worked in, there were a few deadweights -- people who had made it to middle management after being at the company for 15+ years and were really just complacent and there for the paycheck. Those people were always a drag to work with; fortunately, I was able to minimize my dealings with them and usually partnered with the research and investment teams, who were filled with smart, driven people.

One other con was that it IS a big corporation, so change does come fairly slowly, and there are constant re-orgs and re-branding initiatives, which can get a bit difficult to keep track of. It can also be hard to get things done in an efficient manner because there are always a million stakeholders on each project.

Title: Great place to gain professional experience out of college!
View8: The company was a great way to gain professional work experience in a corporate environment. The company places major emphasis on customer service, and will reward its employees for meeting SLAs, daily metrics, and going above and beyond to drive customer loyalty. Also, the quarterly bonus potential,  employee match for 401k, and profit sharing is amazing! Plus there is plenty of overtime for those who desire it.
View10: Call Center Environment can be very stressful and is not for everyone. Employees have to go through too many avenues to find answers or confirm information, which can effect the employees call handling time and as a result can damage the employees daily metrics and bonus potential. Lastly, has a "Not what you know, but who you know" culture and as a result, the opportunity for growth within the company can be slow if you are not a Fidelity socialite!

Title: Hoping I retire here
View8: The benefits are neck and shoulders above everyone else. Great quality of people to work with. CEO that looks out for all of the employees. Great work life balance. Really rewarding profession.
View10: With anything customer service, there's bad with the good because anyone can walk through the door. Fidelity is really large and is always adapting so you are constantly learning new things.

Title: Great Company, Tough for Creatives

View10: Their internal departments are extremely confusing, and it can be hard to plan a career with them. Especially as a creative, there aren't many internal opportunities and their internal hiring process is lacking.

training is very helpful

Title: Good luck!
View8: The people and how you can move up on the corporate ladder in this position
View10:
I'm not a negative person but this topic makes me so angry so 

Compensation: The base pay (at least for my role) is way too low for what I do. 

Job: My job itself is manageable but stressful at times already. When people leave, they put that person's job on other people, with no raise or any acknowledgment of how the person's doing. The job you add on, you may not even be qualified for under in the industry. Also, they add on useless tasks to do (that other locations don't do) just for no reason at all. We have all of these tasks to do with no extra pay or help from higher management. The higher up people do not even know how to do the jobs we have which I can say from my experience here for sure.

Customers: some of the clients are absolutely absurd. they come in asking for things and you try to help them and give them caring honest answers and they dont care. it just adds on to the stress.

Company: During the pandemic they've put completely unrealistic protocols that do not make the clients happy (not being able to walk in places). Although I understand it's important to be safe during the pandemic, other companies allow it, so why not here? This just makes the clients very angry, more than already about their needs, and they go off on us service reps as if it is our fault. We take the heat. When we present it to a manager they do not care and tell us to try to resolve it more. If it escalates too much to a manager then they just blame the company and seem not to care. 

P.S. If you have a fidelity account and need help, do NOT call the service number because there is a 1% chance someone will answer in the first 10 minutes.

Title: Used to love it here
View8: Opportunity to work with current technology and very smart people.  Lots of industry respect. Great vacation benefits.  This is where you'll get the experience that will allow you to write your own ticket.  You'll also become a subject matter expert as you get deeply immersed into whatever technology you support.  If your job doesn't require being on the phone all day, most managers are flexible about when/where you work.  Discounted trading/money mgmt  is a nice perk.
View10: Recent layoffs affected many of the most effective employees.  Every group is down to bare bones and every employee has become a single point of failure.  They are also firing people for things that have nothing to do with job performance.  Most of the great benefits that used to exist have been taken away which now means most employees are underpaid compared to other companies.  Severe consequences for minor screw-ups. Everyone is looking for someone to blame.

Title: Seemed like a great place but...
View8: I was offered a great salary and benefits.  The hours seems reasonable and not ever having to work weekends seemed great
View10: I went through the entire hiring process and was made an offer, went for drug testing , fingerprinting and to have a badge made . On a Monday before class started I mentioned I was pregnant . On that Tuesday I recieved a call from hr asking question regarding my pregnancy , on Thursday I recieved a very rude call stating they were withdrawing my offer due to "unspecified concerns that came up during background check" even though the background portion had already been completed and passed long before... There's no doubt in my mind that they changed their mind due to my pregnancy , which Im pretty sure is illegal. I'm very disappointed , I was looking forward to this job and wasn't even expecting a maternity leave from them, I was back at my current job when my youngest was only 6 days old. There's nothing in my background that should've kept me from getting hired , per their rules that I looked over carefully. Whatever their reasons, I know that my merit and experience more than qualified me for this position , and my character has never been questioned, especially by an employer or associate. Their loss I guess.

Title: branch representative
View8: The benefits are generally good.  Job security is above average
View10:
I want to set everyone straight on this company.  
This is a financial sales company, not a financial services firm.  The goal year in and year out is to maximize sales at the cost of providing true financial planning services to clients and developing relationships.
Book sizes are over 500 and by nature, representatives have little incentive to interact with current book clients unless there is new money coming in.  Reps are constantly not following up with their own clients because there is no incentive to stay true to a relationship model.  The planning is a masked service, run by computers and over complicated pieces of marketing material.  When each "solution" for a client is a fidelity managed account, you start to question what actual planning you are really doing.  If I client does not want a managed account, there is barely anything you can do for them, besides show them how to research on their own, defeating the purpose of a "guidance" appointment.  Management is constantly looking at ways to better the years previously at the cost of the reps and the clients.  More appointments, more phone calls is the name of the game.  It is impossible to keep a relationship model when this is the driving force behind it.  

If you want to provide financial planning guidance in a more meaningful way, it is best to join an RIA, which is where fidelity is losing most of its staff to anyway.

Title: Great company depending on manager and department
View8: Worked there for many years. Experience varies depending upon your manager and department. Positive, supportive.
View10: Layoffs happen regularly. Positive environment especially if you have a strong manager.

Salary, benefits and work environment.

ALWAYS feel Fidelity has my back!
View10: Let's face it - work is work but Fidelity truly makes one feel respected and valued.

Title: 5 stara
View8: I liked people i work witj
View10: No cons i liked it

Title: Great place to learn the industry and get trained- then you should leave
View8: Really good training, their sales process is taught to other firms but they do a great job of driving the process home. Best benefits in the industry and they are now offering flexibility to work from home. They will pay for your licenses and CFP. You can learn as much as you want to learn, plenty of resources available for you.  Great place to gain experience.  You'll never have to cold call for prospects.
View10:
At the end of the day your job is to sell a managed solution to the client by giving the illusion that you are actually doing financial planning for them.  The turnover at the branches brings down client satisfaction. It is definitely a what have you done for me lately type of place. Monthly business reviews can be brutal for people who are not producing. 

You might have managers or trainers that have never been in your seat, or could not cut it so they transitioned. Makes it difficult to have them coach when they have not done it. 

 You make just enough money that its difficult to leave, and they do that on purpose. My advice for people is to get your certifications and a few years experience and then look elsewhere before you start making so much that its hard to leave.

Title: Great Brand-Name But Caveat Emptor
View8: Industry leader in many ways with one of the best brand-names in the business. Fidelity at the top of your resume or anywhere on your resume gets you noticed in the marketplace. It's a private company instead of public company so it's not pressured by the Wall Street quarterly earmings mentality, and that's a HUGE difference-maker in a great way. It's a well-capitalized company and they spend a lot on technology; I've honestly never seen anything like it. Some very smart people there, too, and some of them were even nice. Fidelity has a variety of businesses within the organization and people do move around.
View10: A lot of uncertainty from the top down, and most rank-and-file employees feel very out of the loop and not very empowered. Restructurings and management changes seem to be arbitrary and tend not to improve things; it almost feels like someone's tinkering with things because they believe they need to do something but they're not sure what. The people at the top are absurdly over-compensated and they don't spread it out as much as they could and should -- more employee ownership would be a great step. The people on the "inside" of the fund management shop, the core business, seem insulated and out of touch, kind of like a bunch of Roman senators.

Title: "Lions led by Donkeys"
View8: Privately held, lots of smart people, good benefits
View10:
"Lions led by Donkeys" - I'm stealing this phrase from Rodger Lawson, who mentioned it during one of his briefings. 

During this time of unprecedented change, it seems the place has become even more political and bureaucratic. Personally, I think Rodger Lawson is a much needed shot-in-the-arm for the company and has done much to infuse new leadership at the top. However, the next few levels down are in turmoil and disarray. Political infighting, turf wars, back-stabbing...it couldn't be further from the goals and objectives that Rodger laid out when he arrived at Fidelity. I think he would be stunned if he knew the truth about how some of his senior leaders were making decisions during the recent waves of layoffs, how good (but "non political") talent was being purged from the company, how things were being done more for "optics" than actual results. There are still many S and E level VPs in the company that need to find some religion...or seek other pastures.

Title: BEWARE!!
View8: They allowed workers to work from home.
View10:
Where do I start? I spent a decent amount of time working at Fidelity. Overall, I would say it’s not a great company to work for at all. From my observations, many people have gotten stuck in this company, and it’s drained the life/soul out of them. For starts, many full-time and contractors (Fidelity TalentSource) are underpaid for the amount of responsibility on them. Many people are very unhappy here, but their soul has been trapped here way too long. They don’t know how to leave; all they know to do is stay around and complain.

Racism is obvious in this company. After the murder of George Floyd and many others, there was a lot of lip service from upper-level leaders and money donated to non-profits, but the core of this company has not changed at all. It’s racist!

Human Resources and Recruiters for the most part are awful. I think this is one of the MANY reasons why they don’t attract quality candidates, let alone keep them exceptionally long. Speaking of that, turnover is HIGH.

The leadership is really what makes or breaks an organization. The leadership here is awful. I met with a Senior Leader about issues with a product that they oversaw, and they admitted it was problematic and had obvious issues. However, since our meeting nothing about the product has improved, it’s only gotten worst. Do companies think by ignoring constant issues/problems that they’re just going to float away?

I conclude by saying, proceed with caution. Don’t let the nice buildings, benefits, etc. fool you. Once you get in, you will soon realize it was a BIG mistake coming here. You deserve better in life, STAY AWAY!!

Title: AFA
View8: Career mobility within finance function Work/life balance
View10: Low base salary Work (depending on group placement)

Title: Fidelity - Leadership
View8: They take care of employees with pay and benefits.
View10: Large institution, hard to get things changed quickly. Sometimes there were shifting priorities and fire drills to put out.

Title: Financial Consultant
View8: As mentioned, great benefits. 7% match and 10% profit sharing. If you do 7% your going to be putting away 24% of your total pay into retirement which is great.
View10:
Their Portfolio Advisory Service (PAS) is the key product along with annuities that you are pressed to sell. They train you really well on how to overcome the objections of Clients. You get paid 0.07% or 7 basis points for every dollar you put into these products - JUST ONE TIME - there is a tiny bonus based on Retention. The worst part is that every one in the Financial Consultant role knows the product is terrible and underperforms consistently by 1.5%-2.2% on a yearly basis. If you work here, prepare to exchange your conscious for your paycheck. 

Management will talk trash about you after you leave, there is no loyalty. You will work with 400 Clients, the best Financial Consultants don't develop deep relationships with Clients because you don't have the capacity to do that because you must sell about $36 million a year at a minimum in their garbage products.

Title: Inconsistent Values
View8: Abby Johnson, the CEO, is awesome. She repeatedly beats the drum of providing a great customer and employee experience. Some of the best benefits in the industry. Between its low cost platform to invest and its fabulous benefits, Fidelity sets the bar high.
View10:
The only concern I have with Fidelity is that it doesn't do enough to root out managers with direct reports who violate its values. The lack in accountability of its managers isn't unique to Fidelity. Yet, it's disappointing considering it sincerely strives to standby things it espouses. Everyone knows who these bad actors and bad apples are. Members of their teams can't move away fast enough to other teams, departments, or companies. 

Though the company allows them to punish or push out struggling yet sincere frontline employees, it does little to recognize that these ineffective managers are better at managing up to their bosses than lifting up their teams. Just recently, I saw a manager who was recently promoted to an enviable post who has a seriously horrible reputation. He is a poster child of everything I mentioned and is one of the worst managers in the building.
