Title: Mixed bag - very political
View8: If you are lucky enough to land with a secure, mature manager you will have many opportunities to exceed at your work.  Confident managers excel at training, advancing, promoting their subordinates into better positions.  They advise, challenge, critique, encourage and correct your work and presentations in a productive, positive manner.  They look for opportunities for their subordinates.
View10: If you are unlucky and land on one of the insecure manager teams you will go nowhere.  Expect no directions, no clarifications, no assistance with projects and tasks assigned to you.  Expect no contact from these managers until your yearly review, then expect the worst possible annual review where you will be blamed for all of this manager's short comings.  You can write a rebuttal to the BS in your review, but that rebuttal will never get looked at and you're left with a tarnished reputation, no raise, lousy bonus but - gosh - at that moment, your manager sure looks happy!

Title: Mixed experiences based on department, managers do not heed management guidelines, and coworkers hostile to newcomers
View8: Excellent benefits and if you happen to be young enough to have a family there is quite a bit of flexibility regarding needs relating to school, etc. Some organizations reward proactive employees well and goals and expectation are clear and consistent. This is a company that strives for continual improvement in most areas and works hard to reward employee engagement.
View10: Depending on the job and organization, management communication can be poor or non-existent. There is virtually no on-boarding for new hires and new hires are treated badly by colleagues. You have to have a very thick skin and be willing to stand your ground in the face of some rude treatment. The environment can be quite stressful and some department management seems almost proud of the level of stress. When interviewing be sure to ask about the group's culture rather than the whole company's culture. Performance reviews can be problematic with some management teams. Most divisions require mangers to work with direct reports to establish goals and objectives. Some groups ignore this requirement and reviews can be based on the opinions of co-workers rather than on actual substantive performance measures.

Title: "Active Trader"
View8: Vacation, 401k match, insurance, Licensing
View10:
Fidelity caters to new hires. They are like comcast: Throw the world at you if you are a new employee, but the people that have worked here and put their time in, and actually contribute to the company are rewarded with the opportunity to do more work.
 Every benefit is designed to get people in the door.  New hires got a  12% bump in pay, plus a signing bonus of $2500.   I have worked here for almost 10 years and I get to do my job, the help desks job, and the new hires job, and don't get so much as a thank you. Too much middle management that has no idea what goes on on the phones.   Work is not challenging.  Roles are not defined. Who does what... No one knows.  
Meet your sales number? Here's a Snickers bar.
Pay is low.  
I'm sure that there are some people that enjoy their work, but in the Active Trader  group, the morale is low, attitudes are awful, and suggestions are ignored.
Work site is in a horrible location- every time you go outside, you are accosted by homeless people for money.  Building is not owned by company.

Title: LEAP Associate Software Engineer = Grand Opportunity
View8:
Within the LEAP Program as an Associate Software Engineer, you get trained for roughly 12 weeks. After this, you'll have dedicated project time where you work on a real project within Fidelity Investments. A great plus is, you get paid during training. You'll learn things such as front end, middle tier, and back end technologies. You are basically getting equipped for your future role within the company. You work closely with your manager and they'll try to find the best role for you. Ie, if you want to work more on front end(html/css/angular), they'll try to find the best role for you. 

Trust me, as a recent college graduate, this program is unreal. It truly is a gateway to success for your Software Engineering career. It helps you get your feet wet, and feel the least bit comfortable to get off to a good start. 

Here is a list of Pros:
- 401k match (7% at 100%) + ~10% profit sharing (Ie: its ultimately 17% 401k match)
- Student Loan Assistance (Up to $10,000) 
- Great networking along the way (You are in classrooms with recent graduates just like you. Great life long friendships and connections were made!)
- Learning Front End, Middle Tier, Back End Technologies (The general ones Fidelity uses.... and no, these aren't legacy software technologies)
- Learning coding concepts/design patterns
View10: There aren't really any cons. You are getting paid to learn(say what?). It is what you make of the program.

Title: Very friendly work environment and well paid
View8: Benefits - 100% match on 401k up to 7% of salary. 90% tuition reimbursement up to $10,000 per year if business related and very simple to get reimbursed- no run around. Can apply for new position every 6 months to a year. Management is very supportive of employee growth and input. The firm is very accomodating when it comes to rearranging your schedule for unexpected emergencies, anything related to your children or school related matters.
View10: The one downside is that most of the positions within the company are either  based on sales as some form of your compensation and performance review or the positions are assisting customers on the phone regarding their accounts and investments. There are occasionally positions that are non-sales and non-phone based such as marketing, accounting, etc., but very rarely are these position entry level. They typically require several years of experience and a  degree. But is you start your career in an entry level position on the phone or sales and get your degree while working you still don't qualify for these positions because you lack the experience and there is not a way to get that kind of experience (in non-sales and non-phone based positions) without leaving the company and gaining the experience elsewhere first.

Down to the decimal?

Title: Trading Execution Rep. - Active Trader Services
Position: Trading Execution Representative - Active Trader Services
View8: Good basic market mechanics, personal finance, and trading training. Learned basics of retirement and brokerage accounts. Great FINRA licensing program. Paid to study.
View10: Joke managers who are less educated than most employees. Joke clients that think they are big shots because they trade 200 times a year in a $20k account. Management makes employees think they are actually making an impact on the business when they actually have no control whatsoever. Your bonus is 99% based on customer surveys which you have NO control over. And your manager has the authority to subjectively slice up the bonus pool based on who they like and do not like ( I did fine in bonuses, it is just a terrible way of handling it). Your variable comp as they like to call has very little to do with your overall performance. The Active Trader group has this allure of being a specialty group and close to an institutional trading desk, when really all it is is another phone site job. You just have to be a bit better at handling jerks on the phone and entering trades timely and accurately. Pay is very low, and exit opps are NON - Existent. It is nearly impossible to explain what you did in ATS to any future employers. Other than sponsoring to sit for the Series 4 exam you build zero career equity. Job and company is absolute joke, unless you are unmotivated and content being another # like most people who work there.

Title: Overall, good experience. Wish secular environment was better

Title: Stock Plan Associate
View8: Fidelity has some great benefits: student loan reimbursement, good health insurance, they pay for your licenses etc.
View10:
You are on the phone ALL DAY LONG, dealing with mainly irritated old people.

Fidelity tries to make it seem like their is "a ton of career growth", but really it is just customer service phone job after customer service phone job.

They move you around to different departments to make it seem like you are being "promoted", but really it is the same old crap.

I worked in the Stock Plan Service group in SLC, and was excited to find a career path I was interested in.... Only to find out that Fidelity's generous $10k per year tuition reimbursement policy doesn't apply to you getting THE ONE CERTIFICATION THAT IS 100% applicable to your job. 

You wanna know why? Because everyone who gets it leaves for way higher paying jobs elsewhere. Of course, Fidelity will never tell you that's the real reason.

As soon as I found that out, I started shooting my resume out to competitors in the industry. I easily received multiple offers, off the phone, for way more money. I suggest you do the same!

Oh, and Fidelity does this really cool thing called "loans". Basically they promote you to a higher position, give you more work and responsibility but don't pay you any more money. How generous of them, right?

Title: Great benefits, but two steps behind
View8: Benefits are fantastic. 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing dump. Great health plan. Lots of vacation. Job Security. Great place to begin a career in Sales/Financial Planning. Great customer focus (in terms of interactions and handling issues). Great Integrity. One of those companies where it would take blatant action to intentionally hurt the client interaction to lose your job.
View10: Middle to Upper Middle management are pretty unqualified. When there is a problem with a system or process the resolution is to take down a list of everything that's broken, sit and wait to see how many customers complain about it over the course of 1-3 years, then prioritize funding to fix the issue, then make a video about how terrible the process is and show it to all of the employees in some sort of a backwards way to show their great problem resolution technique, and then maybe after 2 years its fixed. Meanwhile, front line employees have to constantly make excuses to clients and maintain a "can do" attitude.

Title: The Financial Representative is technically like a Pledge to a Fraternity/Sorority you have to swallow your dignity.
View8: Benefits, great training, company gets you up to speed fast, helps attain licenses.  Can pay for further schooling.  This is a great job to enter right out of college.  The pay is good enough.  Just get out of it as quick as you can, as it beats you down once the aura of the new job wears off.
View10: You are responsible for the whole office even though you typically are the least experience person in the office.  It's a great way to learn, but also a great way to have employees above you dislike you if you make a mistake.  The position can be quite demeaning as you order lunches for associates above you and will be treated like a secretary on numerous occasions throughout the week.  You are ordered around more so than any other employee in the office.  You are responsible for the whole office, but all the other employees are responsible just for themselves so you can get pulled many ways at once to keep people happy and of course, this typically will not help you be happy.

Title: "F is for flexibility"
View8:
Excellent benefits, great mobility into other positions if working in call centers to turn an "okay" base pay to solid. Top of the line training for licensing should your role require it off the bat, or sometime down the line.

The workplace culture is excellent- every single manager I've had is excellent, and that's likely a result of trickle-down from *their* higher ups. Willingness to accomodate work from home is an excellent push, as long as you're okay with online training.
View10: Certain products like the one I work with currently very much feel like they're on the backburner when it comes to updating resources, educating customers, etc. It makes a call with an insane hold time even more distressing, and just leads to more OT asks. I've had the term "F for flexibility" thrown around more times than I can count. Having covid PTO is great, but the distressing air of the call center floor makes associates feel almost guilty for not doing OT, nevermind taking days off during "peak season", which, since the pandemic, has been virtually every day. I love what I do and I love assisting customers- but beware, if call center work is exhausting to you, it's going to outweigh most pros I'm giving here.

Title: Great place to start
View8: Fidelity Investments is a great place to start your career. I started right out of college 2 years ago and the starting salaries are competitive. Plus, you get amazing benefits such as dollar for dollar match on 401K up to 7%. In addition they give you 10% of your salary for profit sharing at the end of the year. I have worked with a lot of very intelligent people that challenge me everyday to make me better. I enjoy the challenge because if we aren't helping each other improve and to learn new things a job can get stale very quickly.
View10: While the salaries are competitive at the beginning the raises are almost none existent. And, to get a promotion is even more difficult. If your looking for somewhere to grow quickly then Fidelity isn't the place for you unless your lucky. Also, there is a lot of politics involved in this company. You will see coworkers move past you that are terrible at their jobs (borderline clueless as to what is going on), but network very well and talk to the right people. This can be very discouraging to those who actually try and work hard. Because, at the end of the day your picking up their slack and they're reaping the benefits.

Title: Great benefits....career advancement revolves around sales
View8:
- Incredible benefits package, excluding paid vacation time
- On-site management teams have always been understanding of personal situations or need for time off on short notice
- Great opportunity to learn the industry
- Very customer friendly environment and great brand recognition
View10:
- Too beaurocratic - front line employees are asked to provide feedback to upper management on ways to improve but little is acknowledged, much less acted on
- Upon hiring they promote career opportunity, and even managers state career developement is something they want to help out with, but unless you want to do sales and/ or be tied to a phone doing different levels of customer service, very little career growth exists unless you have the right connections
- Compensation seems to be appropriate for entry level jobs but does not keep pace as you do move through the company
- Severe disconnect between upper managment and front line employees
- Contracting expectations - they promote world class customer service as being the number one priority in this particular role, but great interactions are rarely rewarded, and sales are what most non-base pay compensation is tied to

Title: Takes care of employees
View8: Experience varies widely based on groups. On the tech side PI is one of the most modern whereas FI is stuck in the early 1990s. My group is excellent and for Fidelity we are on the cutting edge. Work life balance is great - in general the management is very flexible. There are politics but a good manager will shield the developer from this. If you can prove your valuable by innovating Fidelity will take notice - if you do nothing new then you will stagnate. Base compensation is on the lower end of what a developer could make elsewhere but the wide array of benefits, especially the contributions to 401k (7% match and generally 10% profit sharing) are unheard of. Senior management seems to have a clear vision of what they want but the execution on it by middle management is variable.
View10: So much of Fidelity's tech is old and maintaining, enhancing the existing systems and building new capabilities requires lots of investment which up until the year the company had been pouring money into. In my opinion some of this money was wasted on buying expensive vendor products from the likes of IBM and Oracle that could have been done without paying for a license. Another issue is Fidelity still hires too many useless contractors and unnecessary project managers.

Title: Low Pay - Great Benefits - Degrading Culture
View8: The benefits are definitely pros. 401k matching up to 7%, tuition reimbursement and medical are all noteworthy benefits.
View10: Your pay will be low unless your are in sales. Service used to get paid well if you worked your way to the top, however, Fidelity recently restructured variable compensation and top performing reps are taking up to a $10,000 pay cut. While they cut your pay they are asking you to do twice the work by consolidating roles and drastically increasing calls per hour expectations. Expect to  handle complex problem resolution on matters like alternative investments, international wires, or incorrect cost basis research all while taking 7 calls per hour.  You will get paid around $50,000  for practically handling every aspect of service for all clients and financial consultants who very likely know less than you but get paid over twice as much. In summary the pay is low, the goals are practically (now) unattainable, job security is not the best.

Title: Great place to work.

Title: A big company with big company pluses and minuses
View8: I worked for Fidelity in two stints lasting a total of 12+ years on the IT operations side.  On the whole I was treated very well, but it was about what I put into it.  I felt that I worked hard and was rewarded (promotion and $ wise) appropriately.   As with any big company, your success is very dependent on your supervisor and how they choose to treat their staff.  But I always felt that if you worked hard and performed well, you got what you deserved.  Benefits are very good and I felt I more than compensated fairly for my work.
View10: Fidelity by nature is risk averse because of its reputation and that is also it's biggest issue when it comes to innovation.  Fidelity, for all it's lip service as a leading edge company, is behind the curve on technology and is working to make strides in cloud services and robo investing services to keep up with more innovative companies attempting to steal the millennial generation market.  In addition, there is no real accountability within technology operations (including the need to really measure performance against budget) so there is a lot of stagnation among long-time employees and in  management.  Fidelity moves very slowly on re-orgs and layoffs after telegraphing changes are coming, leaving employees in limbo for long periods and impacting productivity.

Title: Great to start
View8:
They have great training
Great work life balance
View10: They are the worst with their promotion metrics. I was performing in top 1% of the company 3 months I dropped 1 month and the used it as an excuse not to promote me up. If your a person of color as well there is no diversity at the the maagement level besides one woman of Asian heritage. Expect if you are white to be promoted even though you're not the most qualified for the role. Expect to be accused of being bad on the phone when you did everythign you did for a client yet they give you a bad rating for the 1 hour hold time they waited to talk to you, and the best part is then the company will use that against you to screw you out of your bonuses saying you didn't do a great job. Of course, there is no way to throw out the ones that that were just an upset customer and not your fault. We were told they didn't have money for raises then they cut their commissions and magically found a way to still give us a raise. They do not do any cost of living adustments so expect to live harsh while some people live comfortable in other states. So pretty much expect to be disregarded at this company they don't care about you.

Title: Four stars for the company, two stars for the job.
View8:
The people that make up this company are really great and not only care about their coworkers, but the surrounding community as well. I made life-long friends here.

The training teams were very helpful in helping my entire new-hire class pass our licensing exams and the information I learned has been very helpful for my life in general. 

My managers seemed genuinely interested in helping me find the right job internally--ironically this helped me realize that my dreams lay outside the company.
View10:
At its core, this is a call-center job--8 hours on the phone (or more). The information you discuss with clients is more complicated than other phone jobs, so you'll be relying on internal information systems since you can't know every little policy or acronym.

There's little time to breathe between calls at certain times of the year.

Meetings and coaching get cancelled all the time right when you're ready to take a break from the phones. I really could've used some help to improve the work I was doing.

Title: Great Entry to Financial Services
View8: Great scheduling options, great benefits, training, and especially coworkers.
View10: Call center - always on the phones, expected to take a certain number of calls per hour, no matter how much the caller talks.

Title: An amazing company
View8: Client and employee obsessed, with a wonderful diverse work force
View10: I truly have nothing bad to say

Title: Good people hamstrung by micro-managing senior management who won't make tough decisons
View8: Solid pay, decent work-life balance, excellent benefits. The people at Fidelity are smart, friendly and uniformly desire to do the right thing.
View10: Terrible disconnect between senior management and the people below them. Poltiical maneuvering among senior leaders is widespread, a result of C-level unwillingness to set direction clearly or resolve conflicts decisively. Company culture is consensus-driven - often from the bottom up in that individuals, groups and teams are left to work things out themselves - and when issues among teams arise that cannot be resolved below the SVP level, they remain unaddressed and left to fester until things get bad enough that someone senior HAS to step in, usually with more fallout than would have been necessary if the problem had been addressed earlier. There is a serious blind spot when it comes to recognizing the limits of consensus-building and the fact that leadership by directive is sometimes necessary.  Micro-managing is common, and far, far too much time is spent on producing presentations and reports.

Title: Awesome Company
View8: Benefits, culture, flexibility, remote, upward mobility
View10: The constant change of management. Good for managers because they are being promoted. Difficult for teams because we have to get used to new leaders all the time.

Title: No longer a good place to work
View8: Benefits are very good. Lots to learn. Can be a good place to establish a career.
View10: Fidelity was a great place to work in the 90s but that's all changed. There has been a great deal of pressure on the employees since at least 2003 to perform. Review ratings are absurd. You can literally perform with absolute excellence all year and still be rated average...after all the managers are all under pressure to meet the numbers and submit ratings within the allotted quotas. So...it the whole department had a banner year don't think the whole department is rewarded...this would never happen and it's grossly unfair. You're expected to suck it up and move on...until the next layoff then you're gone. Who needs that!!!

Title: Financial Service Rep
View8: Open 24/7 so that gives you a lot of flexibility.  Great benefits! 6 weeks fully paid parental leave for males and 16 week I believe for women who had a baby.  Tons of overtime opportunities in tax season.  Low stress, pay is great for entry level.  401k match and profit sharing totals to 17% a year (profit sharing 10% and 401k match 7%) managers want you to do well, flexible breaks and lunches, flexible with school schedules and family schedules, Fidelity all in all is a great place to work!
View10: It's a call center, at least you get paid well.  Sometimes you feel like a operator transferring calls. Bonus is effected by how your team does as a whole.  They make a lot of changes throughout the year and you need to be on your toes to keep up with all of it.  Colleagues can drag you down by being negative about their job.  Customer experience surveys are a very big factor in eligibility for larger bonuses and annual raises.  You can take thousands of calls but 30 surveys can make or break your eligibility for a raise. Some other small things, but this position is a call center position it's not always easy but definitely a good starting job to get you comfortable with the lingo and customer facing position.

Title: Lateral Mobility , if you play the game.
View8: Benefits are pretty good, profit sharing.
View10: Worked here in many roles over 12 years. Culture has changed dramatically in last 5-7 years. Terrible team leaders that bully anyone under top 15-25%. They play favorites with people who are probably cheating the system. Was planning on retiring here, but getting older here is a death sentence.  Unethical mgrs who are puppets manufacture reasons to push you out the door. No respect for tenured reps and managers are usually just associates that couldn't compete. Blind side associates with nonsensical stats if they don't like you. Call review scoring lacks consistency. Returned to work after STD for surgery and everyday was a new nightmare until terminated without much evidence and treated like a criminal. Becoming pretty standard way of thinning out tenured reps. Loved this company and mgmt. in the beginning. Made a lot of good friends. Mgmt. now just worried their stats and look the other way when cheaters don't even care to keep their stats within reality. Very toxic and political environment with unbelievable micro-management pressure , if you're not cheating and getting these mid-mgmt cretons promoted. It's viral all the way through to senior mgmt who are conceited, entitled, no talent bullies. No loyalty among thieves either. Most jump ship with a title and leave their wreckage behind. AVOID THIS COMPANY. It's smoke and mirrors your first 5 years.

Title: Fidelity, from an insiders perspective.
View8: The people who work there are friendly and have an interest in the markets and business in general. They have a wide array of shifts to choose from. Managers manage effectively, thats not to say they are good leaders, simply they encourage working hard as well as smart, they provide feedback in a timely manner. Their benefits package is very top notch. The profit-sharing enables them to have a great benefits package from computer purchases to gym memberships and quarterly bonuses. Their lack of accountability to shareholders makes their business model more effective and gives them the incentive to work hard for the benefit of the customers
View10: being paid hourly and not being paid for lunch, therefore one must give up 9 hours a day to work an 8hour day. If you're not working in corporate, you're answering phones. Also their new hire training teaches the fundamentals of their systems, they dont teach anything stock related, the closest thing you'll get to learning how markets work is through the series 7 exam and talking with colleagues, but even they are somewhat clueless. Lastly, Fidelity, being a conservative company severely limits employee investing, for instance, any position thats considered bearish is not allowed.

Title: The big green line
View8: They have spent billions on the brand, and it worked, they spent billions on the tools, and they rock, the products are cheep and won't hurt anyone unless you lie to them in the sales process.
View10:
!Its a big company and if you are not aware of how you are perceived it could possibly hurt your chances to move up. This is not anything different from any other large company. To the people complaining about how they were passed over or done wrong, so sorry for you but getting ahead in life is about more than just how you think you did at your job, your bosses have feelings to and if you don't make them feel like they made a good decision (At any company) you will not get ahead. 

In terms of the people in call centers and computer programming roles, well it is probably tough to stick out from the thousands of other people, but it is still a great company and they don't really expect too much of you from a performance standpoint so why complain about it. Just do your job and try to improve.

Title: Great and efficient company. Very pleased so far.
View8: Tremendous brand-name industry recognition. Even though it's a large Co with a lot of layers of management it's actually very nimble and efficient when it comes to finding solutions for clients' needs and that keeps clients and customers satisfied.  The company spends a lot of $$ on innovation and technology and it's refreshing to see how it keeps clients' needs above everything else. Client is #1.  Benefits are great: 7% co match in 401k (dollar for dollar) and also a 10% Profit Sharing (on average) after 1 year of service. HSA contributions, plus incentive performance awards are above industry average. The culture is very conservative but they do respect all people no matter the associate's  sexual or religious background. Last but not least, the company is very committed to integrity and compliance standards so it stays out of negative headlines and it's extremely well run.  It's been a great place for me to work here and I'm very pleased to be part of this organization.
View10: Very large company so it's hard sometimes to get a lot of visibility and may feel lost without proper mentoring.

Title: ﻿"Very tough and political
Title_URL: but you will learn a lot and be very marketable"
View8: Pros
View9:
- Tremendous brand name that helps your work have a big industry impact
-  Privately held company - doesn't worry about quarterlyy earnings
- Great resources to accomplish whatever you need to do
- Opportunity to grow for younger workers
- Excellent salaries and benefits
View10: Cons
helpfulness:
- Very tough and political organization. To be successful, you will have to be a strong corporate politician
- Not a very friendly place for older workers. The benefits and HR strategy focus on making Millenials happy while managing out older employees.  Fidelity is a great place to start your career.
- Privately held company - Since management isn't exposed to Wall Street pressure, they are slow to change.  For example, Fidelity has been a slow follower in developing online trading, launching an ETF business, creating passive investment products, and developing a robo-advisor.  The company is not innovative. It seeks to copy initiatives from other successful companies.
- Senior management is not willing to take risks. They are so well compensated that they have nos insensitive to put their lifestyles in jeopardy. 
- The company is very large.  Projects and product development have become very bureaucratic.
- Dogmatic commitment to active management.
- Products are too expensive and have seen erosion in their competitive position from companies like Vanguard

Title: Financial Associate
View8: The company is a good place to start a career
View10: You are working in a call center

Title: Financial Representative aka "this is not a sales job but it sure as heck is"
View8: There are many positive aspects of working as a financial rep at Fidelity Investments. Even though it is a call center job with stringent metrics and every move and word measured and recorded, it's not horrible. The pay is above average and so are the benefits. The standards are transparent. Not the easiest to meet but no smoke and mirrors except in one respect. When I was hired I was told that this is not a sales job. I was told that is customer service. Told the same thing in training. The truth is different.
View10: After about a month or two on the floor there began to be a lot of pressure to discuss about people increasing their contributions and trying to get them to speak to licensed representatives. We the "guidance" as a plan benefit that is a feature that doesn't cost anything but we're really selling the additional Portfolio Advisory Services that costs additional. Regardless of whether it is a good plan, and I do believe it is, I still feel it is misleading I also feel misled about what I signed on for when accepting the position. I said in the phone interview and in person interview that I did not want a sales job.

Title: Overall working at Fidelity was good.
View8: Great way to work your way up if you are fresh out of college.  Bonuses are higher in fin'l services than other places and Fidelity will pay you quarterly bonuses plus profit sharing bonus.  Fidelity teaches you how to ask questions in discussions w/ clients so you can better understand who your client is and what solution fits best. Good career path for goal driven young people as they can become managers.  Recreation room with video gaming system and ping pong tables. Company loves to hire internally for regional offices.
View10: Unfortunately to excel you simply have to take more calls than anyone so you can outperform in your metrics.  A 45 minute discussion w/ your client about how best to invest his/her money is a stat killer.  Big focus on pushing people to 'do it yourself' online. I've been in fin'l services for 9 years...young managers aren't good managers. Fidelity does allow people to become managers when they are not skilled enough to do it. As a seasoned outside person who started with Fidelity, their max starting salary to outsiders was $45k...below what seasoned people make.  Phone center will always suffer from the need to have people adhere to their schedules 'on phone' times.

Title: Relationship Manager
View8:
- Great 401k match @ 7%
- Good Medical-- FSA for low deductible & HSA for High deductible plans
- Annual fitness incentive to help pay for gym membership or exercise equipment
- Computer reimbursement (% of $ spent up to a certain amt.)
- Fun team building events and outings with colleagues

Good company with opportunity to learn about the industry and get licensed. 
Offsite training is excellent.

There are a lot of intelligent and friendly people. Actually, I'd like to add emphasis --there are a lot of genuinely good natured, friendly and pleasant people working for the company.
View10: There are claims of an opportunity for career growth, yet there's a disappointing air of bureaucratic BS and a bizarre expectation of gender roles. A heavy concentration of women work in entry-level and support roles and are blatantly treated as if it's the "natural order". It was disappointing to see smart and qualified women being promoted less often than male counterparts and even encouraged to remain in their current roles.

Title: Financial representative
View8: Good training program, private company with good job security
View10: This is a call center and you will be on the phone ALL DAY LONG.  There are no jobs in this co.that don't require you to be on the phone all day long regardless of the job title.  Benefits are great if you can stay for the 5 year vesting schedule which 90% of the people don't bc of burn out.  That's why the benefits are great bc no one ever vests so they never get paid out.  You get 1-2 hours off the phone per WEEk....not per day.  Eventually you can't take being on the phone anylonger and you either leave or get burnt out which effects your performance.   Pay is lower than industry average and the main goal of all 1000 employees is to get one of the 50 or so jobs that don't require one to be on the phone all day.  These non phone jobs rarely come up and competitive is fierce.   Decent job for first time out of college person looking to gain experience and then leave.  Also, everything is based on phone metrics so keep your headset on and don't drink much water bc that will require you to go to the bathroom and hurt your phone metrics.

Title: Design lead
View8: Fidelity is a great place to learn how to be effective in a huge organization. When I worked there, the company was eager to show off its design group--we were allowed to wear jeans every day and had very cool hexagonal cubes, because the company wanted to showcase the fact that creative people worked at a financial institution. There was also a full usability lab, which is rarity in any industry.
View10: It was really easy for people to do very little work. Inefficiency was literally built into the design review process; I had to run every finished design by a designer--a Fidelity veteran, natch--who might have half my skill level, despite their years of experience. I left because I knew that I wouldn't learn anything there, and my skills would inevitably get stale in an environment that lacked innovation. The management was just getting excited about Flash at the time, at the moment when the industry was moving toward abandoning it! Additionally, diversity was a problem. Fidelity had very few non-white/non-Indian people, at the time, and I don't think anything has changed. One buffoon of a manager (white) thought it was hilarious to spout "ebonics" at every opportunity. It was cringe-making, at the very least.

Title: Financial consultant
View8: Great place to start, learn the ropes and prepare for a career.  Phenomenal benefits/ 401k profit sharing.  Leads tee'd up for you. Great tech. Nice office. A lot of resources to learn and get better. A lot of nice people in branch offices. Easy to close business.
View10:
The longer you work here, the less you'll like it.  They micromanage you on everything, literally.  How many meetings, referrals, toa's, managed money, annuities, flows, mutual fund sales, how you say hello and goodbye to a customer. Non-stop meetings with "coaches", who are either people who never really did sales or did it for a few years here and ran for the hills to get out of the branches.  Some branch managers require a debrief with their consultants after every meeting.

The elephant in the room is that they have good products but we are constantly forced to push PAS which is their worst product.  

It's cookie cutter, they want every client to have a managed account and an annuity.  You definitely can't think for yourself, or help clients in unique ways- everything is run through a computer template. 

There is way too much garbage meetings to do any real planning for people.

Title: Good Company
View8:
Good training program
They care about their employees
View10:
Difficult to move out of your business unit
Everything seems to be phone related

Title: Meh
View8: Resources, benefits, people, industry leader
View10: Middle management is completely worthless

Title: Indifference and Abuse
View8: I made some friendships while I was there. Everything related to my actual job was horrible.
View10: The upper management all sort of do there own things and have their own expectations, creating confusion throughout the company. I don't think Abby really has control over some of her subordinates. Site management changed every year that I was there, adding to the confusion. Team managers have entirely too much power and there is very little recourse given to appeal their decisions or seek redress of grievances when they act in an inappropriate manner. The pay is well below industry standards and while you are able to make lateral movements within the company, moving up is EXTREMELY difficult. Pay raises rarely keep up with inflation and while I was there our variable comp was changed making it impossible for anyone to meet the new standards. My pay went down a couple of thousand dollars per year as a result. HR is not responsive and negligent at times. I went an entire year without insurance because I was somehow disenrolled in the plan that I signed up for when I got hired on. HR knew that this mistake had happened and it was documented in their system, but they didn't do anything in time to correct the problem despite my contant pressuring them. The company became even less invested in its employees during my time, essentially turning from a somewhat tolerable work experience into just another high turnover, turn and burn call center.

Title: Pays well, good benefits, not a good work culture
View8: Pays well and has good benefits
View10: Still old management, not a very exciting place to work

Title: Good, not great.
View8:
Licensing program
Supportive
Down to earth
Steady pay
View10:
Non-transparent
Stuck in role
Glued to your desk

Title: Lost it's Way
View8: Fidelity has a good brand and most of the employees are smart and want to do the right thing. It is nice that it is a private company with huge wallets which allows them to invest when the market (stock or job) is down. Good place to work out of school and get some good experience by moving around and trying different roles. There is also a student debt benefit which is good for anybody that can leverage it. Due to their volumes, they will continue to make lots of money.
View10: They have flattened the organization as part of the "agile transformation" and expect you to make lots of lateral moves (forget climbing the ladder unless you are very junior). They have pushed out most of the good senior level leaders or bought them out via VBO. They are catering to young workers who they can pay less and shuffle from one group to another.  Leadership is not engaging or inspiring.

Title: Amazing company & benefits, not enough flexibility
View8: There's always something new to learn in the job and being customer oriented was something I appreciated about the company. In addition, having a 7% company match and profit sharing component in the 401(k) plan was a great benefit. They also encourage employees to develop their careers so your job is never at a standstill.
View10: Since some jobs have you working in a contact center type of environment, there are a lot of months where call volume can be busy and it can be exhausting taking care of so many customers in a span of 9-11 hrs each day. In addition, you're set on a schedule (could be working an evening shift until further notice) and even though you might be working for a minimum of 8 hours, it can still be exhausting leaving the workplace at 8:30 pm closer to 9 pm on a Friday with hardly any other employees working with you during that time as well.

Title: Career or Next Stop
View8: Overall, very solid company with great benefits, opportunities for promotion.  Fidelity has multiple locations so there is potential to move around.  You can get in contact with the top easier than you'd think for a large corporation.  The old saying was you never get rich while at Fidelity, but because you worked there you will be rich.  I think this is true because of the incentive programs between annual bonus opportunities which can be a substantial amount of your income, phantom share program that pay out every two years and their profit sharing that was their year in and out.
View10: I thought that Fidelity got a little too big and struggled to find out how to structure itself to succeed.  It seemed like we would go through 3-4 organizational alignments each year.  It's not that it's bad, but they never seem to be able to stay the course with their decisions.  It really depended upon who was leading the charge.  Current senior management is more about the bottom line as oppose to prior leadership.  Prior leadership still looked at growth opportunities and current leadership wants to maintain and not necessary grow the business unless it is an EXACT fit or match.

Title: Active Trader Services Representative
View8: Benefits are great - 401K match is 7%, and heath/dental insurance are top notch.  Great cafeterias in the offices.  Some of the nicest coworkers you could hope for.
View10:
Getting promoted from this department is next to impossible.  This used to be a 'desirable' destination, with the potential to advance one's career.  No more.  They care less about the front-line folks helping clients, and more about 'stats.'  Your breaks are timed/measured, the length of your calls is measured (long calls = baaaaaad,) and getting promoted outside of the department takes an act of congress.
Management, in general, is a bunch of glad-handing guys and gals.  You seldom see managers let go/demoted, even if they are consistently poor performers/coaches.  This leads to a lot of stagnation, and little room for advancement (unless my manager would take the initiative to seek a different role or retire, which hasn't happened in the 5+ years I have been there.)

Title: Once a great place to work, but things are changing......
View8: Fair pay (not exactly up to industry standards, but OK) and AMAZING benefits!  Health insurance, life insurance, many discount benefits through a number of vendors (Verizon, etc.), great short and long term disability insurance and of course a decent retirement plan.
View10: When it comes to advancement at Fidelity the mantra is, "It's not WHAT you know, but WHO".  Your skills and experience mean very little when it comes to advancement.  To get ahead you just need to be friends with the right people.  It matter more who you play golf or poker with than what your experience or expertise is.  And it's starting to show in the quality of the firm.  As is the compartmentalization of duties and leaving major decisions to each units management team with very little oversight.  This has created a few sandbox bullies who have been allowed to run roughshod over their particular departments without any ramifications.  So weigh your options carefully if you're looking at applying at Fidelity.

Title: Used to be all about the customer
View8: Great benefits package, decent pay, great colleagues, various shift schedules to choose from, quarterly bonuses based on personal results. Great intro job to finance, and Fidelity will offer opportunities to move towards your finance-industry-related work, even if you have little to no experience. You MUST understand that this is a call center job, however. As such, your job is to take X number of phone calls each and every day, day in and day out.
View10: What used to be all about the customer experience has, over the past few years, heavily diverted into a metric-based environment. This leaves associates "kicking the can" down the road to the next associate who can help better, leading to a terrible customer experience, simply because associates are watching out for their KPIs. Poor KPI results will result in heavy-handed "coaching" sessions and absurd amounts of micromanagement.

Title: Highly Recommend
View8: - Work environment - Job Growth
View10: - Salary on low end - Co-Workers

Title: Great company and benefits
View8: Fidelity makes it possible for many employees to work from home, especially due to COVID-19. They continue to expand benefits every year.
View10: It can be a challenge to move between departments

Title: Excessive Turnover
View8:
Great benefits
Green Offices
Best health coverage for your money
View10:
No vision plan (for a job where you stare at a PC all day)
Excessive turnover
Management really does not listen to anyone but their closed circle of people
Egotistical Trainers
Low Wages
Manipulating statistics to make metrics
Lying to associates
Training is not as good as represented.
Trash talking associates who did not make the cut
Who fires their associates when they are driving their cars home?

Title: Challenging work, but 0 support from management when needed.
View8: The work was challenging and you learned something new on a daily basis.  There was plenty of room for growth and development within the role.  There was such a sense of satisfaction doing the analytical work and keeping the client satisfied with Fidelity's record keeping of their HW benefits.
View10: No work/life balance.  No support from management.  You are set up for failure if you are passionate about your work.  If you're good at your job then you are loaded down with the work of other employees that don't do well in their roles.  You are then given an impossible amount of tasks to complete in a deadline that will not be met, and you're given little to no support.  If you don't mine working 65 to 75 hours a week in order to keep up with the workload then this will be the place for you.  However, if you do not enjoy working weekends, holidays, cancelling vacations, etc. for work on a constant basis then look elsewhere, because management will really look down on you for not sacrificing everything to meet their impossible expectations.

Title: This place is horrible
View8: The PTO benefit is really nice, as well as the Student loan benefit. Only thing with the PTO is be careful of how you use it if you plan to leave the company, because they will make you pay them back once you leave.
View10: Open door policy is a lie. If you’re a minority keep your head down and do your work. This company lies about everything and makes up their own rules that goes against their written policy. If you are faced with a discrepancy, chain of command does not help. Managers are very controlling and seek to sabotage careers if they could. Micromanagement is very real in this workplace, management will yell at you in front of others and back each other up to make you look “combative”. Constant changes, no resolutions for errors the company is making. So basically you’re taking the brunt of the heat from clients all day. The pay is horrible, the managers try to make it seem like your raise is a lot, when in reality at most the raises won’t raise you above the $40k threshold. The company isn’t for the best interest of the client don’t believe that I’ve seen so much where Fidelity does things to hurt the client more than help them. I can write a book about this place. Don’t waste your mental health here and it’s a lie if you think that upward mobility is possible. I had a manager try to make sure I didn’t desire to be a manager because she didn’t want me trying to “take” her job.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View8: Great culture and benefits. Many opportunities to learn and grow. The best people!
View10: Large company where you can sometimes get overlooked if you aren't actively working on progressing in your career.

Title: Get out of the box
View8:
Good 401K/Profit Share
Educational Reimbursement
Friendly atmosphere
Good location for traffic/parking
Company is very clear in communicating job responsibilities within each role
Great place for young person to start/get licensed
View10:
Job Performance and experience have little or nothing to do with advancement. Most promotions go to younger less experienced reps and those that have "branded themselves"  properly. IMO the "Brand" they seek is someone that never questions anything and is perceived to have a clean slate that they can mold to do things as they say "The Fidelity Way' . My new employer values my experience and sees it as an asset rather than a liability.

Most opportunities are lateral and involve little or no pay increase 

They are so concerned with everyone staying within their predefined roles that customers get passed to 3,4, even 5 people just to get a 401K rolled over. Along the way each rep is charged with getting some sort of lead.

Title: I'd work at McDonalds or D'Angelos over this place (and some current employees have according to their resumes)
View8: It's impossible to get fired, but other than that there is not a single pro that comes to mind...how can there be pros when you have 7 long hours of customer service calls.  It's literarily call after call from clients who are pissed off and only call in because they have a problem.  Maybe flipping patties and making sandwiches isn't such a bad idea, huh?
View10:
The managers get paid to keep their reps in the call center aka prison.  You do not want to do a life sentence at this place because you'll wake up in 20 years and still be taking 7 hours of phone calls and making 40k a year.  There is no advancement at all!  This job will not help you get your foot in the door to move through the company...it will get you in the door to move from phone center job to phone center job to phone center job aka lateral movement with new job titles and more annoying clients.
This place hires photography majors, geology majors, heck even people without a college degree, so if you have a finance, accounting, or econ degree, look elsewhere if you want to start a real career in finance or any business field because this place is like a kindergarten for adults (why else are the walls painted mac n cheese orange, sun yellow, puke green?

Title: Easily the BEST run financial firm I've worked for.
View8:
I've worked for Scottrade, T. Rowe, and a couple others and this is by far the best run company I've worked for. You meet and work with the sharpest people and business partners. The exposure to products, investment strategies and financial planning subjects provides a Graduate level education in finance. 

Who your manager is makes a difference as far as culture and our is AWESOME. And for such a massive company, they are extremely aggressive with innovation and rapidly implementing changes to drive success. Top management really knows what's going on in the field and is nimble in providing solutions. Fidelity's value proposition and products often sell themselves so driving business is very easy. A FC role is highly coveted so if you can land it then it will fast track your career at Fido as its a gateway role to many other career paths.
View10: Multi asset class managed account performance.

Title: Call Center Representative: Great Coworkers, Somewhat Unpleasant Work
View8:
Wonderful, kind coworkers. 
Wonderful people in upper and lower management.
Some of the customers are the sweetest people you will ever speak with.
Really understanding and accommodating for disabilities (mental and otherwise!).
Great CEO.
Room for Growth.
View10:
The same problems as most call center work: 
The call center should have a more regular office-like environment and employees should be able to take their time with customer cases-- including necessary off-the-phone time (such as faxing, e-mailing, and account maintenance) without having to jump through hoops to do so.
The customers can be difficult to deal with and really unkind. Most people will be reasonable, but each day there are bound to be at least a few calls in which people are truly frustrated and you just have to have a thick skin about it or find another job.
Like with any job, there is always one manager who is very difficult to deal with. In the case of where I worked, this team manager ended up making the majority of her team quit because of her attitude. I'm lucky that I was placed with one of the other, excellent managers instead of her.

Title: Overall
View8: Great benefits across the board
View10:
Lower salary but overall comp
Is comparable

Title: great benefits
View8: great benefits, class A company
View10: too many of middle managers

Title: Good place to start
View8: Quality coaching and experience. Very redundant though.
View10: Fidelity’s call center revolves around Micromanaging. A good place to start but look toward a branch as a career goal.

Title: Nice benefits, good place to start, but opportunities may be limited
View8: They offer a good benefits package, including a 401k match of 7% and annual profit sharing which is normally 10%.  The health and dental are also good.  High deductible health plan with annual company contribution may be good for those without a family who are in good general health.  Good place to get started in the industry and get your license.  Also good foundation for your personal investing and retirement planning.  Some schedule flexibility, 4 weeks vacation after 5 years, and good place to meet people, for friends and romance.  Know a number of people who met their future spouse here.
View10: As it is a very large company, it can be easy to get lost in the shiffle and pigeonholed into limited opportunities.  You can also feel like you are just a number at times.  Individual talent and superior work performance is not always properly recognized and rewarded, it seems too often that cronyism and politics are more important for advancement.  Too many levels of middle management, often staffed by people less talented and motivated than those the are "managing"- a key point, as there seems to be too much managing and not enough leading.  In recent years, occasional layoffs are also a concern.

Title: Good Company for building up your retirement money
View8: Great Benefits. Fair Salary. For very good to excellent workers the annual bonus is nice. They provide 4 weeks vacation after 5 years on the job. Excellent 401K match at up to 7% and annual profit sharing at 10% of base pay or salary plus 3k yearly for a medical retirement account. They also have other benefit perks. They provide flexible work hours that take family issues into account.
View10: For at least the past 6 years advancement opportunities were limited. Merit raises have been meager. Due to cost cutting, departments are not budgeted fully (over the past 10 years or so) and goals of individual departments are not aligned to the corporate goals (except when it comes to cutting costs). This misalignment of goals causes friction and completion between departments.  Management is more top down as the company matures. Management tends to value, in all ways, those they consider superstars and "Outstanding" while ignoring the hard workers who come in every day and keep the company moving forward.

Title: God Awful Toxic Sweatshop
View8: There are no pro's to this job
View10: Everything, forced OT, low pay, managers do not care about you. back to back abusive callers all day. 12/16 of my class quit within 6 months

Title: Great culture - hard work
View8: Great teammates, great client offering
View10: Culture driven to perfection - work life balance not where it needs to be.

Title: Good Company
View8:
Good benefits
Good life/work balance
Good culture
Excellent training 
Paid licensing
View10:
Below National average pay
Less opportunities than promised
Takes a long time to move up

Title: Great company
View8: Company is great works with your schedule decent home life balance
View10: The technology is somewhat outdated and could use an update

Title: Great Company
View8: I love the company and the benefits
View10: really big and hard to find the right person to get questions answered

Title: Define Contribution Representative, working in the call center managing retirement plans
View8:
They sometimes give free food when you have to work overtime.
They REALLY care about the customer.....(not so much the worker)
View10:
There is mandatory overtime during the months that there is high call volume, i.e. January is when they send out 1099 R forms, customers call in for tax questions as well as statement questions. This is the time that the only way to get out of working overtime is to obtain valid permission through the program director. The overtime is 11 hours.
Another con is the phones are constantly ringing there is no break between calls as soon as the caller hangs up the next call is already through and you have to be ready.
If you want a job outside of the field you are in you have to wait a year to get to a different sector.
There are so many goals they want done on every call, you have to maintain a relationship with the caller, ask protruding personal questions of why they want to take out money out of THEIR 401ks, you have to get a guidance opportunity in where you feel like a seller, you have to get a PCC in where you talk about how much they are putting in their 401k...etc, etc. the list goes on, you have to get so much done in one call, every call.

Title: Hard work
View8:
1) 10% year end profit sharing (added to 401K account) and 7% 401k match
2) Stability of company
3) "Always learning" mentality, constant weekly coaching meeting to ensure we are on top of the market
4) Good pay if you can perform well (only speaking for branch positions ie VP Financial Consultant / Financial Consultant)
5) If you are new to the field the Fidelity call centers is the perfect place to start. Fidelity will license you, train you, and help you find the right department/branch to work in. Fidelity is big in promoting internal candidates.
View10:
1) Increased stress. Due to Fidelity's business model to constantly bring in new business we are focused on bringing in new business all the time. I never take full lunch breaks and leaving at 5 PM makes me feel guilty. 
2) Hampster wheel. There is no means to the end.  Managing a $1B book ensures you may get $50 - $60k a year in "residuals/trails" at Fidelity while at a wirehouse a $1B book may generate $1MM + in residuals/trails
3) Long hours. If you are looking for an 8-5 job, working at the branch sales level isn't for you. Work/life balance is tough.

Title: Overall like the company but major issues in some areas that need addressing
View8: Great benefits and pay. Senior leadership is wonderful, and so are the values of the overall company.  Many resources and benefits provided to employees including profit sharing, bonuses, training, tuition reimbursement and career development resources available.
View10:
Difficulty in advancing, it is a lot of who you know and are network with less of the skills that you bring.  Don't count on advancing unless you spend a lot of time networking with the people/ groups that you are looking to move into. 
Culture especially in the call center can be an issue. A lot of office politics and harassment issues that get swept under the rug by management.  Some are addressed appropriately (if HR gets involved) but there were numerous occasions I have seen management quietly sweep issues under the rug, discourage people from calling HR to protect other employees and things like people getting promoted after sleeping with their boss.  While this is not every area and all departments was something that was observed by myself and others in the many years we worked there.

Title: Great firm to work for!
View8:
Complete compensation package.
The company thrives on work life balance.
View10: No cons at this time.

Title: Terrible Employee Experience
View8: Hi pay, great benefits and 401K/Profit Sharing match
View10: Politics, Everything moves slow, Out of touch leadership - HR thinks they run the business

Title: Great Company
View8: Forward thinking, smart colleagues, opportunity
View10: Overall lack of transparency into reorganization decisions

Title: great place to start a career
View8: the culture is great and fidelity has great learning opportunities for people who want to grow and learn in their position.  the people are nice and the food is good at fidelity.  i like my co-workers and they promote a team atmosphere.  if you work hard you will make money but sometimes you have to be politically able to rise up in the company.  the work life balance is good and you don't have to work overtime unless you want to.  it is the type of job that when you leave the job and go home you don't have to think about anything.  i like that.
View10: sometimes the work can get routine.  you get in this rut and you just process things for other people.  the customers can be angry at times, especially in a downturn market.  sometimes the clients can be annoying as well but that is just the way customer service goes.  sometimes the bonus structure is very team oriented that if you are on a bad team then you can kiss a good bonus goodbye.  if you are on a good team then i guess things would be better.  sometimes meeting numbers can overtake doing quality work.  the company is putting in place a lot of systems that check closely what each person is up to.

Title: Stable and still a good place to work
View8:
Private company provides stability, and strong values allow true customer focus. 
Rocket-paced growth of the 90's has been replaced with slow growth and stability. 
Consistent organizational improvement. Sr. Management has improved over the last 10-15 years - the bad ones leave and the good ones stay are rotated through different areas.  
Although challenging personalities and work goals exist (as they do anywhere), respect and professionalism wins over personal ego at this company.  
Very good benefits, excellent 401k match, but health cost have risen substantially in past few years.  
Average employee tenure has risen substantially due to high retention rate and slower growth.
View10:
Long tenure in many areas limit promotion opportunities. 
Salary less than some competitors (but offset by benefits).
Management positions tend to be stretched thin, so expect some long hours.  Definitely some gaps in HR defined positions defined and business duties required. 
Salary growth has been non-existent since 2007. 
Hourly positions tend to have seasonal overtime which can be quite high.
Historically has been known by customers as a 'many-headed Hydra' due to independently managed business units and departments (this is changing due to customer focus).

Title: Painful Management
View8: Okay if you really need a job. Some departments can be very good. It all depends on the management. Decent benefits. good money management for employees.
View10: Overall very antiquated Vision and Resources. They overspend on garbage tech and cluttered interfaces and workflow. Very wasteful processes and time management. Depending on the department and manager it can sway to very, very micro management environment. Favoritism, politics. Managers and Directors with zero people and management skills. When people die at their desk and leave or take time off for stress, that's a big problem they need to address.

Title: Great experience
View8: Learned alot along the way. Great benefits.
View10: Management not always the greatest.

Title: Ned Johnson is no longer in control of this company.
View8: If you want to be a low paid phone drone, Fidelity is the place for you. If you love being treated like dirt and feel that management should rightfully walk all over their employees, Fidelity is the place for you. If you have no ambition other than to make a paycheck and go home frustrated every day, Fidelity is DEFINITELY the place for you. On the other hand, if you are an IT Professional who places value on their contribution to a company and would like to feel that your efforts will be rewarded, Fidelity is a place you should stay far, far away from.
View10: Ned Johnson no longer has anything to do with the day-to-day operations of the company and consequently the goal of the current management is to take the company in the complete opposite direction to that which it was once directed. IT is now considered a low priority and the emphasis on using technology to stay at the forefront of the financial industry is a thing of the past. No new equipment, move as many jobs overseas as possible, reduce the technical staff to a shadow of what it once was, bring in the head choppers, and generally shift the emphasis to the sales force is Roger Lawson's method of running the company (into the ground).

Title: Good for financial services.
View8: Good 401k plan and profit sharing.
View10: Compensation lower than full service brokers and RIAs.

Title: Great caregiver moany
View8: Salary and bonus and benefits package
View10: Long hours fear of layoffs.

Title: Good Place to Work
View8:
Great Benefits
Good Coworkers and Managers
Like the CEO
View10:
Poor training at higher levels
Basically Sales position

Title: Deceitful Management; Reckless Decision Making; Terribly Inefficient
View8: Pays is fair and when bonus and profit sharing is funded - compensation is fair.
View10: This company is horribly inefficient. Senior management changes frequently and with those changes is always a reorganization and change of strategy. Fidelity chose RTP in NC as the home for their $100  million dollar new facility and planned to add 2000 + jobs. They started off strong - bought the land, moved hundreds of folks down from Boston and then pulled the plug and decided they would rather operate in TX and other parts of MA. With hundreds of families making a committment to relocate for the company, leaving family, selling their homes in a bad housing market and taking losses on the moves and home sales - most that relocated were laid off before their 1st year finished in the 'new' location. Folks that relocated without a relocation package paid thousands of dollars to get to NC for the company - and the company decided to change strategy and then laid these same 'committed' employees off. Many folks made personal sacrafices for Fidelity - and the company just hung their employees out to dry. Very deceitful company - provides little information to the employees - and what is communicated is mostly not accurate/honest. The culture is highly politicized and very back-stabbing as the company has so many layoffs everyone is always trying to make the other guy look bad in hopes of saving their own position.

Title: Lots of opportunity for those who are hard workers and not afraid of change.
View8: I was able to grow into a career in software development, thanks to in-house and on the job training and opportunities.  The size of the company affords a great benefits package, with tuition reimbursement, and a variety of health plans, 401 K etc.   Because the company has so many different areas of business, employees can gain experience in different business units via internal transfers, and grow their career within Fidelity. Different areas almost have different business "personalities." The company also welcomes back any "alumni" who had left on good terms. There is a commitment to excellence and integrity to their customers.
View10: You will never work so hard!  Underachievers need not apply. If you don't like change, don't work at Fidelity!  (however, some people enjoy change, so this is a pro, not a con!)  Business units reorganize, individual jobs transform.  Depending upon the business unit you work in, there may be lots of bureaucracy or it may resemble a start up - this is why Fidelity is hard to generalize about.

Title: Financial Representative
View8: Great benefits (one of the best really!) the company trains you very well to get you licensed. This is a great place to start (but don't stay long)
View10: Fidelity is one of the lowest paying company in the financial industry. They start you at $38K. I have been offered $20K - $30K more doing the same for other companies. The quarterly bonus is a joke. If you are a decent rep you can max you bonus really fast. The company does not care if you have post graduate degrees--you will not advance for being better educated and prepared then the next guy. Also, the company has this weird mentality to promote women. If you are a woman and want to advance fast, apply here. Management will hire less qualified women over qualified men just because of their gender. I have seen friends who had 3 years experience or more apply for a job, and management will hire a girl who is still going through full trader training. If you are looking to get paid three times as much, get trained here and apply at Moran Stanley or eTrade. Fidelity does not seem to understand I cannot pay my mortgage with a class A medical insurance.

Title: Stable but bureaucratic
View8: Good work life balance despite being a financial company.
View10: Bureaucracy and lack of tech talent in senior management.

Title: Great culture
View8:
Work culture
Ethics
Flexibility
These are the advantages of working here
View10:
Work-life balance
Salary
Especially salary could be much better.

Title: Be ready to compromise your values...
View8: Base pay not so competitive, but generous bonus plans more than made up for that.  Good place for recent college grads to start their careers and get a solid foundation of experience.  Beautiful facilities, great design, and lots of art.  Lots of opportunities to participate in classes, seminars, information sessions, etc...both in person and online.
View10: Everything is communicated via 50+ page Powerpoint documents that no one reads beyond the 3rd slide during meetings. Annual increases are tiny or nonexistent, although the HR documentation indicates ranges for double-digit increases (dream on).  Some execs are reassigned to lead departments in which they have no experience and are clueless about strategies and issues.  Overall, they are very slow to take action on toxic performers, which causes turnover of  the solid performers who can get jobs elsewhere and not have to deal with the grief caused by the toxic colleagues.  Sr. leaders ask for feedback and suggestions, but rarely act on honest input - it's easier for them to manage the status quo.  Although the ongoing mantra is about ethical decisions and behaviors, I personally encountered an environment where confidentiality was breached and bullying was evident...the sr. exec chose to look the other way.

Title: Great job
View8:
Amazing benefits
The company truly values the employees
View10: The CRA role can be very busy

Title: Good retirement plan but pay and corporate values lacking
View8: Great profit sharing, 401(k) , match programs. Good training for someone new to the business
View10: Not easy to advance into management. More “who you know” then “what you know”. Pay is lower for such a large successful privately owned  company . Since Abbey had taken over most of Ned Johnson’s responsibilities, the company that was truly “ doing what’s right for th client is doing what’s right for Fidelity “ philosophy is out the window and it’s all about cutting costs and do more work with less support.

Title: Great Employer
View8: Salary, management, guiding values, team members
View10: Sometimes a little too fast-paced.

Title: Run Far away
View8: Benefits and education that's all
View10:
Branch micro management 
More worried about clicking than helping clients

Title: Overall, a great company
View8:
Amazing benefits - 401k (100% up to 7% matched), profit sharing, medical/dental, paid holidays, paid vacation, gym membership reimbursement, tuition assistance, student loan pay off, ability to work from home in many departments/roles...  I could go on and on!

Great work environment.  Nice facilities. Great culture.  Awesome folks to work with. Management  was wonderful.
View10: In my department  (Learning & Development), there are constant changes and reorganizations, thus leading to shifts in teams and eventually lay offs.  Fidelity is a chronic  "reorg and then lay off" company and I experienced it firsthand after being with them for 11 years, along with many others in my group - some with long tenure and even more with incredible talent.  Since the owner, Mr. Johnson, stepped down and allowed his daughter, Abby, to take over, so much has changed and not in a good way.  It is really unfortunate.

Title: None
View8: Financially solid company, Great benefits
View10: Continues to Purge the elders

Title: Great Place to work
View8: Great benefits and always room to grow.
View10: No issues as of yet.

Title: Alright
View8: Decent pay and remote work
View10: If you don’t pass the series 7 you will be fired

Title: Poor management
View8:
-Office Space
-Technology
-Support of Call Centers
-Good for someone looking to start their career and obtaining securities licenses 
-Benefits are okay - not as good as some companies but not bad either
View10:
This is a job - not a career.  Your role and upward movement with this company is dependent upon your relationship with senior management. It has little to do with the amount of work you do or your contribution to the organization. 

Extremely political atmosphere - most employees are afraid to raise concerns due to repercussions from senior management. There are some very good managers within the company however locally, our managers were very unprofessional and morale within the office was very low as a result. High turnover within company as a result.

Title: Retired after 20 years, Personal Investing side
View8: Private company.  The Johnson family is committed to the company & its clients. Reputation for innovation, eye toward the future, investing in latest technology and not afraid of shaking things up periodically. Great benefits. Great strides in opening up transfers to other Fidelity lines of business for employees wishing to transfer.
View10: Seemed to fall behind in leadership recently,  allowing competitors to jump in and grab credit for lowering commissions, other mgmt fees,  introducing  lower cost robo-advisor platform.  Mgmt did not tolerate and ushered in environment of encouraging change in all levels of organization.  Tone however seemed to be directed at older, longer term employees being labeled higher paid, against change and holding back career of younger workers.   I reluctantly accepted Fidelity's voluntary buy-out (VBO) sensing I would regret it down the road.

Title: Revoked Offer
View8: The employees dressed nice. (Read the Cons)
View10:
DO NOT EVER APPLY HERE. They could not care less about you as a person. They revoked my offer Today, a Friday and I was supposed to start on Monday. This is right before the Holidays and they knew about my current situation that a family member has CANCER. Not just a sickness, CANCER that I am paying OUT OF POCKET FOR. When they ran a credit report they found something that I didn't even know about, total around $4000. DID NOT KNOW IT WAS THERE. This happened on Wednesday. So I call the collections agency at their request, settle it, give them the information that things have been taken care of and they tell me today that my offer was still revoked. THEY DON'T CARE ABOUT YOU. They will screw you over, spit on you, and laugh about it. SERIOUSLY. The Recruiter did not care one cent. Now I'm completely screwed, no job, cancer, and bills. Oh, yeah! Happy Holidays! 
P.S. I have several friends who use them for their accounts and they will be closing them because of what they've done in this situation. And I will make sure this is all over my social media. This is REAL LIFE. I was COMPLETELY SCREWED OVER.

Title: Fidelity
View8: I think Fidelity is a great place to start your career. Their benefits are really good and affordable, and they have very generous PTO and 6 weeks paid paternity leave for men. I have read a lot of reviews about there being a lack of movement. I can honestly say that I could see that being an issue for some people. In my own experience Fidelity rewards being ambitious. A lot of people here have been in their role for a very long time and become jaded. Be ambitious,  take initiative, and it's not that hard to move up here. Comparitively there is a lot of opportunity here, if you miss out on that you have nobody to blame but yourself. Not to mention every manager I have met at fidelity seems to genuinely care about advancing your career. Quarterly comp is nice. Working from home is a other nice part if fidelity, but this also varies depending on your function.
View10: The salary is the worst part. You get quarterly compensation which is nice and can be a lot depending on your function but they rarely budge on raising your base pay.
