This is used as an excuse to not raise your base pay when you move around. Also, this is a call center job so not specifically a con to fidelity but these type of jobs have their ups and downs.

Title: Great company
View8: Compensation benefits facilities great people
View10: Lack of diversity at all levels. From the board to mgt

Title: Amazing Company Culture
View8:
Great pay.
Fair Vacation time.
Great Benefits.
Plenty advancement opportunities.
View10:
No merit raises. 
Only way to receive raise to move departments.

Title: Best job ever
View8: Awesome everything, literally changed my life.
View10: Nothing, absolutely nothing. Perennial in every way

Title: Know Your Management
View8: Fidelity is a strong company with a streak of independence allowed by private ownership. Good product recognition. Solid and very conservative with respect to financial responsibility. Many opportunities for career growth, change and diversity if you are able to adopt the culture. Good availability of resources including career education. Better than average compensation and benefits.
View10: Your success at Fidelity will depend largely on the ability of your manager to steer you within the maze and to protect you from the political environment. Don't stay in any one area/unit/department for too long as you will become "type cast."  This is not a paternalistic environment; do not expect to be taken care of. This employer typifies the characterization of the "disposable employee." They have a reputation for re-organizing every six months. This is, if not literally, virtually true. You must be very flexible and not cling to the past. Upper management is currently (May 2010) in a state of upheaval that has been ongoing for perhaps 5 years. Continuity and vision is lacking.

Title: Challenging work, decent starting pay
View8:
1. Starting pay is at or slightly above market rate.  Total compensation package including bonus, profit sharing, and 401K match are relatively good.
2. Many benefits including 7% 401K match, computer purchase assistance, inhouse gyms, excellent facilities, subsidized lunches, etc.
3. Relatively lax work schedule heavily dependent on manager.
4. Challenging fast paced environment built upon a foundation of chaotic reorgs.
View10:
1. Year over year pay increases, as well as promotion-based pay increases are way below market.
2. Benefits are being cut as a cost-cutting tool.
3. Seasonality of work results in very slow down periods and very chaotic up periods.
4. Promotions are rare; must be aggressive to pursue career growth.  Inhouse promotions substantially smaller pay increases than external candidates.  Very very illogical promotion system.
5. Technology is the bane of Fidelity.  Too many platforms that do not sync with each other resulting iin a plethora of manual processes that will inadvertedly crash one day!
6. There are so many process people; decisions take aeons to execute

Title: FPCMS
View8: The benefits are some of the best in the industry. The 401K match, profit sharing, bonus opportunities, student loan payments, etc. No firms currently come close to matching that level of benefits. They offer a lot of career paths and do a great job at hiring internally.
View10: With all of the job growth in the DFW metroplex, they are starting to struggle with talent retainment. There have been a few retention packages offered, but they are not working. FPCMS in WLK has gone through several leaders. The decisions made at times seem to contradict the firms values. The current leaders have their select few chosen ones, who can do no wrong. However, it is apparent that they have their own form of nepotism. They will force out people who may block their people from getting promo'ed. This has happened time and time again. People are taking on roles that they lack the qualifications for, just because they are favorites.

Title: Anxiety Inducing
View8: The pay and benefits are supreme. There is room for growth, but you have to actually like finance.
View10:
There are tons of metrics to adhere to, and managers are controlling. Let me be clear, you are not micromanaged, you are controlled to the point that you cannot get up to use the restroom. 

You will be berated if your computer does not work, as if you are supposed to fix that. 

If you bite back, your managers will gaslight you into thinking that you are the problem, not the super bizarre environment that they have created.They will ask you, if you are only "there for a paycheck?" The answer is yes, because they're only "there for metrics." 

The environment is not collaborative, and they will use you up until you are done. They are not dumb. They know exactly what the average associate's shelf life is(a manager told me so), and they will coldly and callously move on. 

I have seen world class people, get eaten up and swallowed alive. When you quit, you will be given a box and literally pushed out the door.

Title: It started out great and has slowly declined as management has changed.
View8: Benefits are good, pay is pretty good also. Trying to move in the right direction at the upper management level. The message from upper management is very inspiring and motivational.
View10: Micro managing employees to the point that it inhibits daily job duties. The inspiring and motivational message from upper management gets lost in translation by the time it reaches the field. Middle management does not want you to think that you have a secure career.

Title: Good first job, but there are drawbacks
View8: Good benefits to regular full time and regular part time employees in terms of medical, dental, and vision- the higher coverage plan has a higher cost passed onto the employee. 401k plan available with matching.
View10: In the Albuquerque site, favoritism runs rampant. Managers play favorites with staff and will ignore employee concerns, this problem extends up to directors as well. Also, Albuquerque is excluded from the profit sharing benefit that ALL OTHER SITES enjoy and pay is low for the job. They will try and convince you the pay is appropriate, however, compared to other call centers it is lower starting by far. To be clear, this is a call center job, while it may have different ways of doing things, metrics are the only thing a manager has to use to grade your performance. If your manager doesn't like you, they can find a number of ways to get rid of you.

Title: Need better recruiters and training.
View8: Good hours, great pay, no working weekends.
View10: I was recruited strictly for my customer service skills.  I was concerned about metrics such as call times, call quota, and surveys and asked clear questions about these issues.  In the face to face interview, I was very mislead.  I was told the main focus was on customer satisfaction, and this was not true once I was on the floor.  Our training about the subject matter was excellent, but we received almost no training on the complex and multiple computer programs.  There was no hands on training of the system.  This lack of training on an absolutely vital part of the job is why I had to leave the company.  Also, many times we asked a manager or mentor a question, we were told something that was later disputed.  There was no consistency regarding information.

Title: Financial Customer Associate
View8: Good work/life balance, opportunities exist, the 7% match and 10% profit sharing 401k bonus are very nice, too. It is a company that is slowly but surely seeking to improve the work experience. My managers have been awesome, too.
View10: Most of the opportune moves are lateral, Fidelity takes it's sweet time on paying bonuses and raises, it is a call center job and if you don't enjoy this type of engagement, opportunities are severely limited. Not many jobs here that allow you to critically think, but rather answer questions. Most co-workers treat this as a job, rather than something they enjoy (though this is not true for all)

Title: 4 years and counting - So far, so good.
View8:
I started as an IT contractor and was offered full time employment.  Great benefits,  work from home,  good people.    The word on the street is salaries are lower but that has not been my experience.  My salary is average for my position.  The bonus and benefits more than make up for any shortcomings.  Yes, you can make more money elsewhere but for me, we are talking 5%.

Technology is older but not ancient.  There are opportunities to learn new technologies but are slow to move.
View10:
It's a big place, so there are some politics and bureaucracy you must learn to navigate.  

Too many "true believers" outside the I.T. group. .... it's almost cult-like among the managers and directors.  This is not unusual as good jobs in general are hard to find and people outside I.T. do not have the same opportunities as I.T. folks.

Recently went to new "open office" layout and it sucks big time.   If I didn't work remotely 3-4 days a week, I would not last.

If you are an I.T. professional, your skills could become dated if you are not vigilant about it.

Title: Very Disappointed
View8: None that would out weigh the cons
View10: It all begins with job satisfaction, people in general tend to do jobs they enjoy and are passionate about even if pay is lacking, but fidelity has clearly missed the mark. A volume based discount broker call center where even team leads (managers) are frustrated with leadership. Upper management is not there to help build a profitable successful environment but make sure numbers on spread sheet are met. 95% of the people I worked with actively are unhappy with their current job and only stay so they can get their 5 year vesting. I’m truthfully dumbfounded at the lack of communication with management down to reps. I’m disappointed to say I wasted so much time at the company and missed valuable opportunity actually being able to advise build relationships. This company the last two years had tried to put a square peg into a round hole and has lost a lot of talented people. This will continue to be the trend because Fidelity is slow pace when it comes to change. Culture there was absolutely horrible with people just struggling through daily life and I hope those who read this can take this as a warning! Unless you are absolutely desperate or doubt mind being an un valued easy replaceable cog in the Fidelity machine you can do so much better..

Title: Excellent Company
View8: Competitive salaries, great benefits, flexible work schedule
View10: There are no cons to list.

Title: Highly Political, Layoffs Often, No Job Security
View8:
Very good competitive compensation and benefits package.
Interesting and challenging work.
Reasonable work demands in most departments.
View10: Fidelity is highly political.  Basically no matter how high the quality of your work is, if you are not "liked" especially by your direct manager you will not be around for long.  Department and company reorganizations are often and many.  It is during these times you risk falling out of favor and run the risk of frequent job eliminations. Once you are out of the company due to a layoff or job elimination you are pretty much out forever - unless you have a contact manager that will hire you. There is no job security no matter your position or length of employment.  Fidelity will never win any best places to work awards but the they pay well.  If you are looking to be loved, respected, or for a friend - buy a dog.

Title: Depends who you are/who you know- things change daily at Fidelity.  Depends on which manager will implement it.
View8: Starting pay and yearly merit reviews based on performance Lots of OT.  The company match is 7%. You also get profit sharing.  Health and college reimbursements. Company discounts to many companies - just say where you work and most of the time you get a discount.
View10:
Heavy volume call center - can’t sip water between calls. Didn’t hire enough people to fill in after many took the voluntary buy out package 6/2017. 
You’re expected to know everything that has changed and is changing and not all teams are unison in the messages that is announced.  Branding - it’s huge - it’s bologna when you don’t even get a chance to get to know that person- and they don’t forget it no matter how many years have passed, what hardships you have been thru, and where you are now in work life.  Fidelity allowed for managers and interim manager to bully associates.  Managers have their clicks.  You will get wrote up for using PTO when your truly sick.... depends who your manager is!  You will get accused for something you didn’t do- bc your acting manager says you did- won’t pull the call up but purposely stops the audio to say call avoidance calls for immediate termination and I was escorted out.  I transferred the caller to another associate and I never disconnected!

Title: Great place to work!
View8:
Very friendly
Great practical projects which keeps you engaged
View10: None at the moment while working

Title: LOVE!
View8: Management, Coworkers, Work/Life Balance, Culture
View10: A lot of information to process

Title: Excellent Pay but Political Organization with  Lots of Hierarchy
View8: You are working along side very smart, capable, and engaging co-workers.  This is a company that is generally focused on doing the right thing -- for customers and employees.  They do this because they are  proud of their brand/ heritage.  They protect their reputation vigorously.  Be prepared for change:  The organization is constantly reinventing (or improving in a Kaizen manner) itself.   Heavy focus on technology.  Fantastic benefits package.   Reasonable work-life balance.  Coming in as a new employee will feel like you are drinking from a fire hose:  a lot will be thrown at you in a short amount of time.  Hang in there -- it is worth it!
View10: Its a very political organization with lots of hierarchy.  Senior management doesn't always listen to the feedback they receive from employees.  While things change frequently, the changes are typically from the top (and not in response to employee feedback).  Some of the politics are a pain and there are always the 'management favorites' (you will find that in nearly every large company), but you will be well paid for your efforts.

Title: Excellent Place to Work
View8:
Good benefits, Good Pay.
Management listens to suggestions and cares
View10: Nothing to say here now.

Title: Great company for savers!
View8:
Outstanding company retirement benefits
Solid company brand
Positive external reputation
View10:
Leadership aspects 
Culture challenges
Mechanistic workflow

Title: Conformity Culture.  Innovators and Fast Movers Stay Away.
View8: The firm's client service delivery is second to none.  Abby and her team have recognized that the culture is slow and have attempted to make changes over the years.
View10:
Legacy leaders point to minor wins as progress.  Small thinking and high school culture wins, and friends are rewarded.   Medium bets are avoided for less risky career steadying choices.  

The Voluntary Buyout program targeted legacy leaders over 55, while giving opportunities to legacy leaders...over 50?  A clear message was sent.  What sense is there waiting for higher positions at Fidelity if you are in the first half of your career.

The same leaders drive the same mediocre results, and continually keep positions in the firm.  Repeated service model and strategy changes cannot change the mediocre managers leading each team. 

Leaders in the business with finance backgrounds do not bridge the gap to "innovation" in products, they can measure but are not creators.  Always concerned that if the market tanked, I wouldn't be able to sell products at Fidelity's prices with the cost structure so heavy.

Title: Fidelity Investments: Retirement playground for washed up executives.
View8: Challenges. If you like to be challenged, there's many opportunities. Start a project, then half way through it 'poof' the people you were working with are gone, typically replaced by inexperienced Indian speaking low paid H1B candidates. Salary is ok, but don't expect too much in the way of a raise.
View10: Executive Management is a revolving door. Fidelity is the place where 'executives' like to end their days getting highly paid to put their 'stamp' on the company. Almost like clockwork, every 5 years or so, executive management changes. Then the newest group of executives start their own slash & burn program to make the company more 'productive'. Once they've finished this wonderful task and decimated the various groups they declare victory, collect their huge bonuses, and turn things over to the next group of bean counters. Fidelity is coming apart at the seams because there are so many chiefs and so few indians left to any real work.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work, but the environment has become much more intense recently.
View8: The benefits are great. I have had a long career at Fidelity and been able to develop my knowledge of the 403(b) & 401(k) business. The clients I work with are great. Most of my collegues are top notch. There is a great deal of focus around data security and customer privacy. Fidelity has a strong balance sheet and is convervatively run. I think that senior management is positioning the company to be profitable for the long term, which means that the future will be bright.
View10: Recently there have been a lot of changes at senior management level. This has caused a great deal of uncertainty about the future of the company. My department was moved from the northeast last year to Texas, and I am not sure what career opportunities will come up in the future. Financial services right is an industry in turmoil. There is another round of layoffs coming in the 1st quarter.

Title: Fidelity Investments is a good place to work for someone who expects as much out of the company as they put in.
View8: Fidelity offers extensive growth opportunities to those individuals who display talent and a drive to succeed.  In most cases the managers are very understanding of family and personal time needs, coupled with an expectation that everyone is a professional and will make their hours up as necessary. Fidelity also offers excellent benefits packages.
View10: Depending on your position, there can be an expectation of working well beyond 40 hr work weeks, though that is not a consistent occurence.  Occasionally Executive Management may have plans in the works that are driving changes organizationally, but which not all employees are privvy to at the time, and which can then make some of the organizational changes seem inappropriate (at that time).

Title: Benefits are great, but NOT worth it.
View8: Great benefits, help with student loan payments, reimbursement for health/fitness things, gym on site, awesome coworkers, fun environment overall, great company match on 401k plus profit sharing, good health benefits, generous paid vacation time, very detailed training, nice salary with quarterly bonuses
View10: No mobility within the company, managers are completely fake and act like they care about your career development but really don't care at all, they blow smoke up your you know what and make it seem like there's a lot of opportunity, but that's only true if you've been with the company for 5+ years, unfair treatment of employees by upper management, immoral conduct swept under the rug, ridiculous expectations, micromanaging

Title: Just a Cog in the great machine
View8:
-Benefits
- Flexibility
- It honestly is a good place to start but dont plan to stay for too long
View10:
- Fidelity views all of its employees as easily replaceable. This was emphasized when Abby Johnson and Kathy Murphy said in the most recent town hall that because they always have so many people come back to Fidelity it doesn't really matter to retain them.

It's a good place to start, but there's only so much growth with in the company

There is no way to change things at a decent pace. In my role my manager knows there are issues with how things are run, our director is also aware of them, and the site GM has some knowledge. Each level agrees with our issues and agrees that present solutions make sense, but that they have no power or ability to do anything about it.

Title: Benefits Specialist
View8: Great Co-workers for the most part.
View10: Poor pay, over working employees, no  job security, management is terrible. it's about who you know there fore most of those who are friends of team leads or management received positions, are then trained by those who have been there for years only to be rewarded by witnessing those they trained get back to back promotion. Mind you seven years of working with the company and most ( mainly of ethnic background) are just getting their first promotion. I was there 7 years was give great feedback during review time but managers always found a reason not to give me a raise ( I received on raise the entire time I was employed). One made up reason given when my manager spent a min tripping over her words to think of what to come up with was that she heard I spend to much time in the ladies room (of course it was not true but it was good enough for her to justify when I again would not receive a raise) Most of my managers were up north therefore  managed at a distance and visited maybe every three months per year. I could go on and on but over all I would not recommend anyone in there right mind to work there ...at least not in the benefits department. I had enough of being used and overwork and constantly being told I was doing great here is extra work, but not receiving compensation.

Title: High Net Worth
View8: Overall, I was extremely happy with my experience with Fidelity. I chose to move firms due to issues I had with my site and my role, not with Fidelity as a whole.  I felt that the pay was reasonable, but any gap was more than made up with the incredible benefits. 7% 401k match, 10% profit share, 10k of student loan payoff (after only a few months in the role!), and great health and dental insurance. The people are friendly (for the most part) and I had a great relationship with my manager.
View10:
The HNW role could be extremely frustrating at times, to say the least. We were fully licensed brokers, but the majority of my time was spent doing password resets and distributions - I'm not sure why the firm would pay our licensing fees only to have us perform repetitive tasks any (unlicensed) customer service rep can do. Dealing with the general public is trying - people will call in and scream/curse at you over something you had no control over. To be fair, most conversations weren't negative but the really bad calls could ruin your entire day.

There is little opportunity for career development (outside of sales) and a large bottleneck for leadership/management positios.

Title: Workplace Guidance
View8: Flexible work hours, tuition reimbursement, respectable café, lots of career development.   Slightly higher salary for a call center for the area but much lower than the national average for licensed reps.  Heck, it's lower by 10-15k base pay locally.  Co workers are nice and the building amenities (Gym, Stress room, walking desks, basket ball court, ping pong,horse shoes, etc..)  keep the day moving quickly.
View10:
If you're in a license role you almost have to leave ABQ to advance.  The ABQ hub opportunities have maxed out. Denver or Jacksonville might be better places to look into for above normal growth opportunities.  Low pay compared to the national average. No profit sharing but other sites get it.

Location is not ideal.  They should have put this hub on the westside of town.
Hard to get good quality scores for a while because each manage score card was so different.  Fast tracking fokes and nepotism in play.

View8:
flexible 
competitive 
growth
development 
strong leadership
View10: difficult to move positions internally

Title: Good Company Toxic Culture in Finance
View8:
- Good retirement benefits
- Decent pay
View10:
- Preferential treatment & resources for full time MBA grads
- Political culture / who you know to get ahead

Title: Mixed bag
View8: Great compensation, very good benefits.  The company is privately owned, so you are not constantly worried about the vicissitudes of the shareholders and whether it's an up or down quarter.  Don't get me wrong, they very much care about making money, but it's not the same grind as a public company.  Their eyes are focused on the customer as the one to please, not the shareholders.
View10: There are really great organizations within Fidelity, but there are also some organizations that are horrible.  Where I worked before I left they had no management skills.  EVPs would have a tantrum at meetings - yelling at the attendees.  They nitpicked everything, and never showed any appreciation when you completed a project.  Other cons include the fact that you have to have all your investments at Fidelity or jump through hoops for compliance.  You also cannot mention that you work for Fidelity on social media.  You have to have all your political contributions and volunteering activities preapproved.  I guess that's standard for financial services, but it's still a con as far as working environment.  It's hard to know where they are going with the Merrimack site.  They keep moving the technology jobs to North Carolina.

Title: Great company
View8:
Great understanding people
Management takes care of people
View10:
Low base salary
Things can move slow sometimes

Title: Great opportunities if you are a self starter
View8: Good management of the Employer services part of the company meant it was a great place to work in IT. Many opportunities to shine but it required hard work and you need to be a self starter. If you want to gain skills in running projects, managing up or down and overall leadership, FESCo was a wonderful environment.
View10: Other Fidelity business units are not as well managed, if you do not work in a group with good leadership you may have a different experience altogether. Security is tight, you will go through extensive background checks and must adhere to the companies many policies. As with any large company, there is a reasonable amount of red tape and paperwork to get anything done. Internal IT services in this company are particularly inefficient.

Title: Great company to work for.
View8: Fidelity offers plenty of opportunities to grow, and rise in the ranks.  Their benefits are one of the top reasons to stay at Fidelity.  They really value their employees, and try to make sure they are being taken care of.  Their pay is good, although not the best out there.  They don't require you to work as many hours as other investments firms to make more money.
View10:
Fidelity has certain career paths are that almost set in stone.  There isn't a whole lot of deviation from what they've outlined as the path you need to take to move upward.  It would be good if management would recognize the efforts in other divisions, and reward those that are doing well with opportunities for advancement.  
You almost have to work quite a bit of overtime in order to stand out as a top performer.  There is no 40-hour work weeks for the successful there.  They do pay OT however, so the pay is nice if you have the time to work the extra hours.

Title: Flawed Employee Compensation Structure
View8: I worked at Fidelity for 6 years as a Client Service Manager in IWS. Overall, the job is challenging and rewarding but offers little flexibility in terms of how you structure your day. You have 30 minutes for lunch and be prepared for blackout periods for vacation during seasonally high volume periods (i.e. December and April). Regardless of the experience, credentials and skills you bring to the role, you will still be managed like a $10/hour customer service rep. In my experience, don't look to your manager to provide career and professional development, that is up to you. Lastly, depending on the level you are hired at (i.e. 25, 27, 29) you will not be eligible for the full, advertised bonus. This is the great unspoken fallacy of this position. Your time, effort and sacrifice will be rewarded by giving up a portion of your yearly bonus to subsidize the more tenured client managers on the team.
View10: Lack of flexibility, bonus "bell curve", adherence to high customer service levels at the expense of human capital, increasing micro management

Title: IT is treated as an expense, not as an investment.
View8: There are a lot of very smart people working in the IT area here, and it's been a pleasure working with them.
View10: There are also a lot of very lazy people working here who have adopted a "cover my butt" attitude.  Taking risks and initiative is actively discouraged by multiple layers of middle management who are afraid to be on the "wrong side" of a senior manager, so the safe-but-inadequate decision is preferred over a better solution which entails some risk.  Too much paper-pushing and red tape in getting things done.  HR & Management like to crow about paying "industry average" salaries, which to me seems like a way to guarantee you'll only retain "industry average" talent.

Title: Great company to start a career
View8:
- Managers that care about your career and personal development
- Great benefits - dollar per dollar match to 7% of salary in 401k - Having a ROTH 401k was a great attraction for me
- Currently growing - Opportunities to move into your desired career path - Great for people who get hired on just to get in the door with a less desirable position 
- The company is big on following the kaizen philosophy
- The company is moving a lot of positions from Boston to Westlake - Great growth opportunity as many of the Boston employees do not want to relocate - Not having a state income tax was probably a driver for the move
View10:
- Your desk moved frequently, within 6 months my team/department has relocated within the same building 2 times - I think they do this as it is the only way some people clean their desk
- Slow moving changes
- Lags behind industry changes - Needs to move faster with offering of ETF's

Title: A Cesspool That Sucks The Life Right Out of You.
View8:
There's a roof on the building, so you don't get wet when it rains. 
The knives in the cafeteria are not sharp enough to slit your wrist if you feel the urge.
View10:
It's culture of lip service, where you're not exactly telling lies but close to it. 
The pay is horrible. I was paid $20,000 under the industry average. 
It's  a political game from Day One.  If you want to get anywhere, you'll need to invest in a set of knee pads.

Title: 'Changing but not in the right direction'
View8: Lots of good people, friendly culture, great benefits, great campuses with nice scenery and amenities. Interesting and challenging work to grow your skills.
View10: Low base pay, hard to get promotions, in a cost cutting mode, decreasing work/life balance, cafe food not that good

Title: Phone Center Trader
View8: Probably the best training I've ever been through. I was hired on w/o my securities licenses and spent the first few months of work studying and in the classroom learning the Fidelity systems/culture/etc. (white getting paid). They hire great people, so everyone you work with knows their stuff and is enjoyable to be around. The company is extremely generous (10% of salary profit sharing bonus every year, fantastic benefits - I even got a $100 xmas bonus 2 mos. after being hired). If you're looking to get into the securities business this is a great place to get your licenses and cut your teeth.
View10: This is a phone center job. Your schedule is 100% set for you, down to the 15 min breaks before and after lunch, which is understandable, your job is to answer the phones. Most of the day you're not placing trades for customers but doing some sort of account maintenance (pw resets, IRA distributions, sending them forms, etc.). Everything is tracked and monitored (again, understandable, just be aware before you take the job). After training when you're on the phones all day you don't see much of your coworkers, it's mostly about talking to customers at your cubicle/desk. The job becomes very monotonous quickly.

Title: Good Start Gets Boring Quick!
View8: They pay for your licensing training and pay you a decent starting salary. 7% 401k match after the first year and 10% profit sharing on your second year.
View10: This is where your dreams go to die. You answer phone calls all day long 24/7. You feel like a robot with going over the same questions over and over again. Even at the prestigious higher roles you are still only offering two cookie cutter solutions PAS (Portfolio Advisory Service) and Life Cycle Funds both of which have mediocre performance. As a Financial Solutions Rep we aren't even allowed to sell the product on performance. Why else would you hire someone to manage your money other than performance? The people that sell it don't even know what the performance is and its so hard to find you eventually give up. If you want to be paid a lot to be a robot selling mediocre products this a great place for you.

Title: Great place to work, but its not a technology company like they believe...Software Engineer - Leap Hire
View8:
-Great retirement benefits
-laid back environment ( my business unit no longer has a dress code )
-great set up ( 2x 24" monitors for everyone )
-other benefits are really great (maternity/paternity leave was increased, tuition reimbursement, college loan help)
View10:
-pay, team quality, manager quality, and the projects you work on differ enormously between business units and groups within those units
-too many managers with little to no technical experience making technical decisions (my boss still thinks git and github are the same thing)
-managers seem to make decisions that please everyone vs making the right decision
-hiring process was terrible, my technical interview consisted of the following questions:
        1) is javascript a subset of java?
        2) how would you write an SQL query.
        3) what is a class?
        * this sounds awesome until you realize how dumb you could be and still get hired if this is all the knowledge you need

Title: the best place to start your career
View8:
- great benefits
- flexible work schedule (depending on your team, you could have the opportunity to work from home)
- lots of training opportunities
- a culture that encourages career growth and movement
- no dress code, definitely a relaxed company that's focused on what matters: the customers and the services
View10:
- some benefits take up to a year to kick in
- base pay could be more competitive
- leadership expects folks at the team level to be agile, but they don't drive agility amongst themselves 
- there's little communication among upper management to each other on what their teams are working on to prevent duplication of efforts... you could probably find 3 or 4 tools across the BUs that do the same exact thing

Title: Fidelity has good compensation and benefits, but can be very bureacratic.
View8:
There are a lot of different areas of the company which allows for a lot of opportunity.  You can spend many years there and actually experience a number of different careers.  Unfortunately, it takes a lot of personal career management and "political" savy to get the opportunities.  

Fidelity is very innovative in their use of technology.  They have an amazing technology research center where they are constantly are looking to improve their systems.
View10: Very old school culture.  If you haven't been with the company for at least 10 years it feels like no one listens to you.  There is also a very strong aversion to change, you hear things like "this is the way Fidelity does it" and "Ned (the Chairman) likes it to be this way".  Unfortunately, I think people are afraid to question the way things are done.  Also, it is a large (50k employees) private company that is mostly family owned, so trying to drive change is almost impossible.

Title: Long timer - been through the good, the bad, and the ugly - things are getting better.
View8: Great benefits. If you work for the right manager and are smart and diligent you can make Fidelity work. You need to put your networking skills to work. Fidelity weathered the 2008 rather well considering others in the financial services sector. Fidelity puts a lot of stock in personal integrity and doing the right thing for the customer.
View10:
The company has grown a lot over the years and now is bureaucratic. It is hard to be heard and get improvement ideas through the system. There are many roles now that are high throughput and that can be hard on the people.

There is a lot of talk about investment in technology, but it does not seem to be focused on the right technology and there are decades old back-end systems that badly need some upgrading.

Title: Worst Professional Experience Of An Otherwise Productive Career
View8: The Pay was good compared to the S. Ohio / N. Kentucky area as a whole. Benefits were good as well.
View10:
As has been stated in various reviews on this site, if you are too intelligent, attractive, or bring sound business experience with you to the role, expect to be shunned eventually if not immediately. In the S. Ohio/N. Kentucky region there are not many opportunities, even for college graduates so its easy to scare the majority into conforming into whatever management requires at the time. Where else can they go? This was true even before the world blew up.

They will hire minorities but they expect them to be docile, weak and just smart enough to do what is asked of them. No matter how smart you are, if you are a black male you have little chance of making any real progress. Of course there are the "tokens" to make things look good on the surface. Once a manager even sent out an email to his team that had a Martin Luther King speech in it that said the Negro was still not free. Imagine that in this day and age. This kind of behavior is condoned in Covington Kentucky.

Title: They should change their name to Infidelity
View8: Decent pay, decent benefits, workable facilities. It is difficult to find another fourteen words to meet the requirements of this posting.
View10:
Good old boy type of culture there. 
If you are the type that enjoys getting credit when deserved, you can forget that here, but they will let you know if they don't like something you are doing. 
Too much fraternizing with co-workers going on, and not just hanging out (Holiday Parties are for employees only, this is where a lot of the Infidelity comes into play).
If you are relying on your merits to take you places, you can forget that here. It's all about who you know and who's jokes you laugh at.
Too many double standards (what is good for one person, is not good for the next even if they are suppose to be a level above you.)
Middle management needs to be thoroughly investigated.
They throw around the VP title to anyone; deserving or not.
No promotional opportunities unless you know someone.
HR is a joke; not really a support system and they are somewhat difficult to reach.
Fear is often used to try to get you to conform or become friends

Title: Great people and working environment.
View8: People are professional and they care.  Leadership is excellent and C level executives are very in tune with what is happening in the business.  Open environment where ideas are encouraged.  Fairly conservative and cautious company which means quality triumphs over speed.  This means you actually have time to think and do things right with less pressure to simply deliver.
View10: Not a performance based company.   While they claim to be,  monetary reward system tends to be socialistic with little distinction for a person's productivity. Much of compensation is tied to 401K as opposed to cash in pocket.  Will know more on this once I've gone through the bonus round.  Once you get hired in you are fairly well set since they tend to steer away from terminations, rather they look first to place people in another position.   This makes it challenging for managers who are dealing with performance issues.  But even with this, the vast majority of people are top notch.

Title: Get Licensed, and get out!
View8: The best reason to go to work for Fidelity, is frankly that they will hire anyone, from any background, and fully pay for the employee's FINRA licensing.  The testing program is top-notch.  And the campus is very nice, although you will never see it because you will be shackled to your cubicle.  If you are lucky, you may be near a window.
View10: Management at all levels really gets in its own way when it comes to getting anything accomplished.  The sole purpose of your team manager is not so much to encourage, motivate, or lead, as it is to make sure every second of your day is accounted for.  This micromanagement is the main task of your supervisors, who can be very creative at coming up with reasons to charge you with errors, which in turn keeps the bonus and raise levels down.  So basically, when you are given errors for actually helping customers, it comes to a point when the employees just don't care anymore.  Everyone only wants to meet quotas to keep their job.  And this comes at the expense of the clients.  fortunately, I was able to move on to bigger and better things, and have the microscope removed from my rear end.

Title: Investment operations manager
View8: Good benefits package, good place to get foundational experience particularly in an entry level role. There are some great people who you can learn a lot from if you end up in the right spot!
View10:
Large company with lots of office politics and red tape, even at times folks engaging in group think. As you move into management this becomes increasingly frustrating. Decisions often are made at the top without involving those in the weeds who know details, ending up with a lot of poorly executed strategic decisions and frustrated frontline managers and associates. 

The work life balance is not always as true as advertised, particularly for those who don’t have kids. 


Salary not always up to par against the industry/ market.

Title: Used to be better.
View8: Benefits, some good managers, work/life (depending on your manager).
View10: Many poor managers, only "horizontal" movement - forget promotions.  Many employees that are just not qualified are put into positions (often of power).  Everything is a secret.  Who you know is key.  I tried for 4 years to get into this company, when it finally happened, I was so excited.  The benefits were amazing, the perks were fantastic and everyone seemed happy.  Shortly after, they restructured, brought in the car salesman (ax man) and it has all been down hill from there.  Took away the pension, didn't even grandfather people in - absolutely ridiculous, changed benefits, rules, compensation, and basically took the "You are lucky to have a job" attitude towards the employees.  Lay-offs, RIFS, "site strategy" (which is how they now hide lay-offs from the press).

Title: If looking for a "career" look elsewhere
View8: Good work/life balance, most of the people were very nice want to see you succeed. I think my experience was a problem at the branch I worked in rather than the whole company.
View10: Terribly run office, clear training structure not in place, letting one nasty angry employee affect the culture of the whole branch. Management did not have an effective way to deal with a problem employee. I was hired with all my licenses and 4 years of experience into the financial rep role to eventually move into a sales role (after 9 mos to a year). After 3 months I had been repeatedly told by management that I was not filling the role "effectively". I received almost no training and was expected to not make a mistake. The job is not hard but being "written up" and receiving "warnings" for every mistake caused a lot of issues. They did not use me for the talents I had, I started looking for other employment within 60 days of starting. I have worked at 100% commission and was less stressed out than here. Basically I was a scape goat because the manager could not stand up and lead the office.

Title: Cares about employees!
View8: I honestly love my job.  I'm so grateful for the opportunity to work for a company that truly cares about their clients!  Providing excellent customer service is absolutely necessary and we take it very seriously. Fidelity strives to hire like minded individuals that create a positive work environment.  They review their salaries to make sure they are staying competitive and there's plenty of overtime opportunity. The benefits are great. Tuition reimbursement, 10% profit sharing, 7% 401k match, health reimbursement (gym memberships), etc.  They are very lax compared to other companies when it comes to using sick time, last minute vacation, and changing your shift to accomplish a better work/life balance. Fidelity is very open about upcoming changes within the company with all levels of employees.
View10: Not so much Fidelity as it is the industry we work in but tax season (leading up to the tax deadline of April 15th) and distribution season (retirees requesting their minimum required distributions before the end of the year) can be incredibly draining.  Last year we were slammed and it made for a very long couple of months.

Title: Great Benefits, Good Company to work for
View8: I worked for Fidelity for 5+ years as an Administrative Assistant for a Sr. Vice President.  I thought the quality of the employees was outstanding!  It was very different from my last company, when someone said they were going to do something it was 50/50 if they would follow through.  At Fidelity I would say 90% of the employees actually do what they say they are going to do.
View10: As for the Cons, a lot of the employees came from Boston and they are not as friendly as people here in Texas.  When I say that I mean, I said "hello" to people for months it seemed like before they actually started responding back to me, "hello".  Quite a few people relocated from Boston to Westlake and they were all close friends. That made it tough as a new employee.  On the positive side, once they go to know me they were great friends!!

Title: Good Luck
View8: Very easy and money just falls in your lap cause of the brand name. Easy competition for the stack rank. It's fairly new so it isn't micromanaged yet but it is trending that direction. More relaxed than other roles in the phone site.
View10: The compensation is much less than what it should be for the money you move in and service provided. Confusing bonus structure that is constantly changing and bonus is dictated by manager entirely and not by production and stack rank so it can be very bias. In reality the stack rank is pointless cause 2nd place can get a bigger bonus than 1st. It is starting to become more and more micromanaged. It has become more of an efficiency role instead of quality even though the main point is sales and not service. Very unorganized part of the company. It's a little niche compared to the rest of the company so there is constant change and no one including directors know what's going on in the future. Also misrepresented growth opportunities. They say they are expanding and you can promote to the more prestigious phone role or into the field however when one of those spots is vacated they backfill it with two people in this role instead of replacing. So be prepared to be stuck.

Title: Great Company But It's Still A Call Center
View8:
- Good base salary
- 401K + Profit Sharing are good
- Nice co-workers (obviously anecdotal here)
- Quality cafeteria on site
- Lot of potential career paths (but it's hard to get off the phones)
- Work/Life balance is very good
- Usually a lot of overtime available (at least in the spring)
View10:
- Terrible Bonuses (Overall pay is inline with the industry but Fidelity has a higher amount of base, which is not necessarily a bad thing)
- Training is below par. Most new service representatives have no clue what they are doing
- Business units are very isolated 
- There often seems to be a lack of direction by mid/upper management
- There is always a weary feeling that another round of layoffs are going to come back

Title: Great Co-Workers and Growth Potential
View8:
- My co-workers are amazing people. Everyone is very friendly, outgoing, and generally positive. I look forward to seeing them every day and miss them on the weekends!
- The training is bar none. They give you extensive training to pass the Series 7 and 63 exams, making it almost impossible for you to fail, and every new skill set you master is accompanied by at least a week of intense training. 
- The work environment is very pleasant. My desk is very spacious, the break rooms are well stocked, and we have huge windows with views of the mountains.
- If you're willing to work hard and network with people, the growth potential for your career at Fidelity is unlimited.
View10:
- The pay is less than it should be. Considering the complexity and responsibility on our shoulders with all the regulations and rules, we should be paid much more than we are.
- Some managers exhibit favoritism towards employees who are clearly incompetent at their jobs but are likable people.
- The micromanaging of your schedule is obnoxious, but it's pretty standard in a call center environment.

Title: Great company but no loyalty to their good employees
View8: Great pay, benefits, bonuses, PTO.  Great opportunities exist if you're the right kind of people and you can avoid the RIFs.
View10:
Training is pretty much non-existent - it's sink-or-swim when you're thrown onto a project.  

We're told it's easy to move around and try new things within Fidelity to progress in our careers.  I never found this to be true.  When I applied to jobs within the xxx division, I was told by the internal recruiters that the hiring manager was looking for candidates who had xxx division experience.  It didn't matter that I had over 10 years of valuable experience in Fidelity with plenty of other transferable skills.  How is someone supposed to get the xxx experience if you're not given the opportunity?  

Way too many re-orgs and RIFs with the loss of really good people. This leaves others to pick up their work when employees are already overloaded with their own work.   

Frequent changes in  managers leads to inconsistent annual reviews and constantly changing goals. It's difficult to know what one has to do to get promoted.

Title: No Growth, Bad Compensation
View8:
Interaction with several areas of the company, including portfolio managers and traders if you work in FMR, FIMT

Best 401k match when compared to other Fund Management Firms.
View10:
Based on my experience in the IT Department. No growth, impossible review system. you are also subject to "common judgement" by others who don't know you nor have ever seen your work. Always a chance of your job being outsourced to their India or Ireland locations OR you being asked to move to Rhode Island, North Carolina or Texas. 
Most Product Managers are incompetent and have only been promoted because someone got laid off or quit for greener pastures.Almost impossible to get promoted by merit/hard work.

HR also reminds people that Fidelity only pays 75% of your worth in the Market Place. So the base salaries are quite low.

Big push to move low level employees into the next step on the ladder. People at senior/principal levels just stay where they are whether they slack off just enough or put in some quality hard work

Fidelity has never won the Boston Business Journals best places to work for award ever

Title: Great benefits, easy to burnout
View8: Amazing benefits, understanding boss, comprehensive training, learn a ton on the job, frequent bonuses offered, always overtime, 529 clients typically nicer, opportunities for growth, tuition reimbursement, affordable healthcare/HSA, great 401k match, work with intelligent self motivated peers
View10: Super easy to burnout, it’s been so overwhelmingly busy clients often want to vent or treat me like a punching bag. High expectations on our stats that feel impossible to achieve with it being so busy. Bonuses are based on these stats. Feel isolated working from home, sitting at a desk, and not being able to communicate with peers since I’m always on a call.

Title: Dissatisfied in Cary.
View8: If you can keep at job at Fidelity, that woud be a "pro"
View10: Fidelity use to be the BEST place to work and the most respected company in the industry.  To have Fidelity on your resume gave you the advantage over the competition.  However, that all changed in 2007.  The company culture, benefits structure and management style changed suddenly and negatively impacted clients and employees.  The company has considerable market share and has been wobbling ever since, trying to determine a direction to steer, go public, sell businesses piece by piece, not succession plan, etc.  I blame Roger Lawson for the down turn, but perhaps that was his purpose.  In 2010, the company still  has no clear direction and their current employees are not high the mgmt's priority.  The constant state of layoffs and restructure proves a detriment to moral and productivity.  Where is Ned?

Title: Big on Vision and Teamwork, Small on Compensation
View8: If you enjoy a team environment working with other highly motivated and intelligent individuals, Fidelity is a wonderful place to work.  The company survives on a high level of commitment from its employees, and has been incredibly successful as a result, even posting record profits during the worst recession of our time.  Particularly during the first couple of years out of college, Fidelity can be a rewarding and educational place to work.  Most people consider FIdelity a good training ground for better jobs in the industry that pay a decent salary.
View10: There are countless opportunities for advancement, but Fidelity has done away with most opportunities for actual pay raises.  All job opportunities are positioned as "Stepping up and contributing to the needs of the business", with vague promises of "potential merit increases" which never come to fruition, or "increased bonus opportunity", which likewise never comes to fruition.  Raises are only given for major job promotions, such as from manager to director, and even then they are minimal.

Title: Always on the phones
View8: Benefits are outstanding, management is very respectful of employees, more ethical than other companies, and flexible with schedules if notice is given in a timely manner.
View10:
No advancement. It's all lateral movement. Hard to go vertical.

There were a few situations where individuals with consistently outstanding numbers never got promoted to positions they earned. I personally knew such a person and from speaking to him it was due to some issues with his manager.

Very family / religious environment. This can be a good or bad thing depending on your personally situation. 

When I was there, Fidelity implemented a terrible business plan which made service's function more like sales. It was done by making certain metrics, one is evaluated on, excessively high for sales like responsibilities. By the time I left, these metrics had been adjusted to more reasonable numbers. However, the service department still had a major roll in bringing in new money, without any compensation other than miniscule quarterly bonus.

Way to many metrics. You never know where you stand. I excelled in certain areas but average in others. My manager evaluations always made me feel like I was doing a bad job.

Title: Great company
View8:
-Amazing training
-Great benefits package, 401k, tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, HSA
-Salary took a turn for the better last year, however it still is very low for the job done
-Open comminication with managers
-Team players
-Great atmosphere
View10:
-Controlled, call center environment that sucks the life out of you. 8 hours on the phones, only 30 min lunch and 2 fifteen min breaks
-When you are hired, you are promised a career path, but it is hard to get out of the call center right away
-Not allowed to apply for jobs within Fidelity outside of the call center, before reaching 1-year
-Late night shifts until midnight, hard to get an earlier shift
-Impossible stats to reach, they only want you to be out of your phones for 6% of the day. So if you need to used the bathroom and it takes lonner than usual, you are already havint bad performance. 
-There is no time to use outside of the phones for customer resolution
-Work-life balance not balanced

Title: A lot of travel, low pay, but great experience.
View8: You learn a ton about the clearing and custody business. You are one arm of the full implementation spectrum, but it allows you client facing opportunities as well as exposure to all levels of management and different departments. The experience, knowledge and exposure are the biggest advantages to this job
View10:
Travelling can be extensive. Each implementation is at least 1 - 2 weeks (including the weekends) and it's not uncommon to go from one to another. Some implementations are scheduled and promised by upper management to the client, for 10 - 12 weeks. There were many instances where employees would travel from a 2 week conversion to a 4 week conversion to another 4-6 week conversion back to back. 

I don't know if the pay grades were appropriate for this sort of commitment to the employees.

Title: No movement out of Call center
View8: solid benefits and bonus, was able to get Series 7 +63 after a year
View10: You take about 80 calls a day, Managers are not helpful and make the job even more stressful. They care more about customer satisfaction than they do employee satisfaction. Under payed and over worked. Expected to work overtime hours and shamed if you opt out. Don't work here. my mental health is still recovering from this sweat shop of a call center. They rant about how great their benefits are (7% comp match) which would be good if you made more than what they pay. The calls suck, customers are incredibly rude. No flexibility on hours and not very understanding on leaving early. I would not recommend this role to my worst enemy. I left on my own terms and met some really good people their but everyone is miserable because the job is ..... also don't expect to use this as a 'foot in the door type' because once you're in the call center there's no movement out. I was their for 2 years and got promoted within the call center but never once met or saw anyone get an opportunity that didn't involve answering the phones. Look elsewhere

Title: Merrimack Call Center: Worst job I've ever had!
View8: Nothing, unless you're a masochist.
View10:
Big Brother is watching EVERYTHING you do.  All phone calls and all computer use is recorded, timed, measured -  Anything you say or do can and will be used against you.  Metrics for everything and anything - Did you leave for break on time? (doesn't matter if you're on a call with a client);  How many and how long were your bathroom breaks?;  Constant coaching of what you said on calls with clients.  If you're not perfect, you don't get a raise.
They want drones, not humans, you're expected to say the exact same script every single time, no matter what.  They should just have employees monitoring calls from clients and push "Button #27" for the script for that question, "Button #92" for script for this question...  As soon as you hang up from one call, the next call is coming in, virtually non-stop the whole shift.  I'd be surprised if they don't run out of people in the area soon to fill those jobs - they've burned out so many and/or fired so many for miniscule infractions of their rules.  Doesn't matter how many 'Kudos' you got from clients that were happy with your assistance.

Title: Find the right fit for you
View8: You will meet some phenomenal people at the company. You will also have pretty solid access to people/education that you would have to pay for elsewhere
View10:
Boy are these people good at telling people what they want to hear. We were all told (by the president of a business unit) that pay would not be negatively affected by an operating model change. I know multiple people who's salaries were adjusted down.

Upper management is extremely patronizing. Though they attempt to cover it up there is very much a culture of "Mommy/Daddy knows best" when it comes to making decisions. This thought process is extremely embedded into culture there; so much so that despite a huge organizational change, my team's day-to-day work is still prioritized by a person who is two or three pay grades above my "boss". 

They also say that career mobility is something they encourage. In practice, getting in tough with internal hiring managers is laborious and conversations are often derailed by administrative interference. 

If you do work here, do your due diligence when vetting who you'll be working with. It's easy to get with people that drink the Kool-Aid.

Title: Great benefits, too much office politics, no concern for employee's mental health
View8: Benefits are great. Work environment is casual. If you like investing and financial industry, you might be happy.
View10: Though the possiblity of starting in customer service and growing into other roles is highly used as a selling point in the beginning, it is nearly impossible to actually do it due to the office politics. Layoffs or forced resignations have become the norm- they are always trying to do more work with less heads. Finally, if you have any kind of personal crisis, it's fine for a day or two. but if it affects your mental health and ends up causing long-term issues...good luck! You'll likely be PIP'd out of there in no time.  As for the work/life balance they are currently advertising, the flexibility is a joke if you have a family. Yes, it's flexible for the young, childless demographic, but if you need true flexibility, steer clear!

Title: New leaders across firm changing the culture
View8: I loved the people I worked with at Fidelity - smart, creative, hardworking, fun.  Most people care about the customer and work hard to provide great service.  Operations and Technology groups had many talented individuals and middle managers, but lacked a cohesive strategy and strong SVP management.  I had excellent training opportunities and career progression.  Fidelity was a great company for the 15 years I worked there.
View10: With the overhaul at the executive levels from 2007 onwards, and the revolving door of external hires at the highest levels, the frequency of organizational and strategic changes became intense.  Major layoffs took place in 2008 and early 2009, due in part (but not entirely) to the market turmoil.  The whole financial services field has been downsizing, so think carefully before you apply for a job at Fidelity if the stock market is still very rocky.  Be prepared to manage your career and build a good network.  Have a "Plan B" ready in case you get laid off.

Title: Fidelity offers a wealth of opportunities and potential.
View8: Very good pay and benefits.  Opportunities for growth.  Tired of your current position?  You can move on without bad feelings and still maintain your seniority.  Interesting and enjoyable co-workers for the most part.
View10: Commuting from Metro West into Boston is like working a 2nd job.  Work-life balance is something they try to say they are all about.  I suppose it depends on your position.  As a cube dweller.... flexibility is not really an option.  Constant change in roles and management hierarchy is difficult for some people but is the culture at Fidelity.  You learn to deal with it or move on....

Title: Progressive promotions as knowledge grew and flourished from my entry level position and beyond
View8: Best benefits I have seen and researched throughout the industry. Work/life balance is encouraged, and the programs provided by the firm are abundant.
View10: The promotion opportunities are not direct, they promote more of a 'lattice' structure. Best advice is to be involved in projects, extra tasks, etc. this opened several more doors and expedited my career with Fidelity.  Some of the leadership is quite weak and the politics can outweigh the actual business at times, unfortunately.

Title: Fidelity is all smoke and mirrors.
View8: Very nice facilities, excellent licensing program for new brokers, great health and 401k benefits
View10: Where do I start? The unnecessary micromanaging? The months of brainwashing? (They force you to watch countless hours of internally-produced videos during new hire class on why Fidelity is the best company you'll ever work for...). The secrecy of everything, including the breakdown of the bonus structure that is supposed to make your miserable job worth it. They make you feel bad for hating your job while at the same time putting under unmanageable working conditions. I had to work 10 hour shifts with a 30 MINUTE lunch, and if I took 1 minute longer than that, I got a threatening email from my manger. SERIOUSLY? I could go on, but there's so much that I could say about this company. Do not work for Fidelity unless you are desperate and have nowhere else to go. I've worked in call centers before, and this, by far, was the worst experience I've ever had.

Title: Great company to work for, but with call center setbacks
View8: Great benefits, pay is decent, and staff is great. They will sponsor you and ay you to study for the series 7 and 63.They have CFP programs if you want to go the sales route as an account executive.  Management actually really does care about employees, and listens to their suggestions and ideas. This is a baby call center opened in summer 2013.  There is good potential for promotion, however, only in client facing roles.  In other words, it is a call center.
View10: It is a call center and it is hard talking to people for eight hours a day about their finances.  Clients are often old and sometimes senile, often needing help online or setting up transactions. The work can be stressful.  It is busy year round and expect to take calls all day, with maybe the occasional meeting or coaching hour to break up the day.

Title: Workplace Planning and Guidance I
View8:
Great benefits
Student Tuition program
HSA
Profit sharing after your second full year
100% up to 7% of 401k match
Pays for you to get Series 7, 66, 9, 10 licenses
View10:
Managers use fear tactics to drive numbers.  
Pitch that the role is to help plan retirement but it's honestly just a sales role where you strive to put clients assets in IRA's and brokerage accounts.
Call center environment
Outbound calls are requested by the participating companies but to the customer, it is just cold calling.
Due to the industry fears, target date funds are pushed on everyone without access to the management service so there's no actual financial advising or RIA work.

Title: Stressful Work environment, fast pace
View8:
Decent pay
Nice co-workers
Advanced technology
View10: Licensing is absolutely draining. Don’t expect to have any free time. If you’re new to the industry make sure to do some pre-studying to stay on track with the class. Fast pace. If you don’t feel comfortable with the material and you’re not sure if you are going to pass; do yourself a favor and start job searching. Retakes are not promised even if they make it seem like they are.

Title: Wonderful place to live a well-rounded life
View8:
The work-life balance, benefits, and compensation package are the best I've ever had at any companies. The culture is collaborative and not stressful. There are many senior leaders that are women, including many that have young children at home, which I believe helps set a great tone for work-life balance.

Given the business is privately held and family run, I've found leadership to demonstrate more long-term and strategic thinking compared to large publicly traded companies. There is a desire to deliver today and plan for tomorrow.

Over the last few years, there has also been an earnest push to keep pace on rapid innovation with the rise of fintech and operate under agile principles. People do value pace over perfection and speed to market, but there is still a ways to go to truly be agile.
View10: Like many large companies, it can be bureaucratic and slower moving than I'd like (although better than most of the large companies I've worked at). Some individuals are motivated by self-interest and politics and kissing up can trump business results.

Title: If you are debating between this company and another -- GO THERE!
View8: It's a job and pays the bills.  That is what I can say about Fidelity.  It USED to be a good place to work, but things have changed there dramatically.
View10: Very condescending, little or no advancement if you are female with children or an ill spouse.  They treat you like dogs because they know they can in this economy.  Best friend comes home in tears - lecherous treatment of women in the finance side of the business.  You have to be gorgeous and LIKE that kind of attention, or male and have little or no encumbrances.  They are turning all of their business over the India.

Title: Truly best company to work for in financial services
View8: You might hear "call center"and cringe but the Fidelity regional center are absolutely amazing. I've been with the company over five years now and couldn't imagine working anywhere else. Casual dress, awesome cafeteria very low cost healthy options, the Westlake location is on a nature preserve so there are awesome walking trails to use during lunch or breaks. Lots of windows and natural light. The best benefits like 28 days PTO once you're fully vested. I'm making a great salary that in a career I feel I can stick with forever.
View10: Be ready for change with technology (which I also see as a plus). The new system you're learning will probably change again in 3-5 years. If a review for Fidelity is negative honestly they're probably in the wrong role. It can take a while to navigate to a dream position within the company (five years for me), but work hard, dress for the job you want, and you'll get there! Not a ton of work from home opportunities.

Title: Customer Relationship Advocate/Full Trader
View8: Some good benefits, good people to work with.
View10: Constantly monitored by stats that are glitchy at best and downright dishonest at worst. Bonuses, reviews all based on these overwhelming stats where every thing you do down to your bathroom breaks is monitored and used to stack rank you. Policies are constantly shifting, trying to move and learn and grow is often stifled. I have applied for 3 or 4 different sales positions, and I can only assume because I am a woman, have been turned down for every one of them, even though my misleading "stats" were good. These are the only ways to make a decent salary. They change your role, requirements and expectations constantly, usually to save the company money, and then spin it is something AMAZING! It's laughable. It's been a decent job overall, but the last year has been disappointment after disappointment.

Title: CRA role review
View8: Great and honest company that cares about its employees and it’s clients. High pay and numerous bonus opportunities through out the year. Extensive benefits package. Fidelity wants to help you succeed and grow in your career!
View10: The Customer Relationship Advocate position itself is the most draining role at Fidelity Investments. It has the most turnover, not because of Fidelity, but because you are a customer service agent via call center that services over 10 types of accounts, and you’re a stock broker. You deal with about 50-70 clients a day and 90% of them do not understand their accounts and/or the stock market. Because it is a call center, every minute that you clock in is accounted for via statistics.

Title: Great company
View8: The benefits are generous, including tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, 401k match and profit sharing. Fidelity has a robust licensing and training program for new associates. The focus on employee success and well-being is a top priority of leadership, especially during COVID.
View10: Like any job, there are little annoyances and parts that are less desirable. Like, chasing down time card approvals every Monday morning. Don’t you want to get paid? This list of ‘cons’ will be different for everyone. The pros greatly outweigh the cons. Sometimes I have to take a step back and remember that!

Title: Sinking Giant
View8: Privately owned, provides flexibility. Great benefits but getting weaker. Good individual technology, blackberry, laptop, etc. Lots of smart, hardworking people there. Well known name, brand recognition. Morally responsible people for the most part with minimal backstabbing.
View10: Ownership has let too many outsiders come in and has not protected internal employees. Many top leaders have been allowed to leave. This is completely opposite their prior approach. People have to work very hard to succeed with little reward or recognition. 55-60 hour weeks are not uncommon and are expected. Management does not prioritize and simply jump from one focus to the next with no continuity. They do not allow an idea or effort to develop and show results. Refuse to ask the hard question and demand results. They are drowning under the weight of their own size and becoming more bureacratic by the day.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to begin a career in finance, however you'll be burned out in a year!!!
View8: Fidelity has excellent industry training, will pay for the necessary security licenses such as the FINRA Series 7 and Series 63, and provide on going training through out your tenure.  I learned more in a year and half working at Fidelity, then I have at any other employer!!
View10: Heavy Micro-Managing, Bad Work Schedules, High Turnover Rate, and Bad Compensation.  Do not plan on working for Fidelity more than one to two years, because you will become burned and stressed out.  The work environment is high stress with little reward or compensation.  Plus, you will have to follow strict hourly work schedule which includes only two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch (This is monitored to the minute...literally)!!!  The work environment does not allow for one to build relationships with your fellow coworkers, because you will be on the phone non-stop dealing with customers, and plan on taking between 85-115 phone calls in an 8 hour period.

Title: My Honest Opinion, longtime FIIS worker.
View8:
This used to be a wonderful place to work. Now, even through staff may be all highly competent, you will be ranked on a bell curve. Expect layoffs every year. It is highly competitvie internally and lots of favoritism.

Check rank on the Country's Companies For Working Parents list -- it will not make the top 50% is my estimation.

Due to employees not moving on frrm Fidelity no one was getting promoted. To resolve this issue and to ensure all the competent highly paid workers were shown the door to make way for new and inexperienced people to come on board, Fidelity was able to save lots of $. This does happen with many compnaies, and finanical services was hit hard in the past few years. However, this started before that economic crisis.

They work you hard which is fine. Just don't expect to be fairly rated, and don't count on the bonus coming through. 

Great place several years ago, but now it is cut throat and highly political.
Other firms seem to be paying a lot more than Fidelity.
View10: Be prepared for change all of the time and "ride the wave." Ther eare many layoffs, reorgs, and other stressful changes.

Title: This USE to be the Best Place to Work.  Now, not so much
View8: You are surrounded by smart people and will learn a lot.  You will most certainly get experience that will translate to any other financial services firm in the world.
View10: They have everyone at each others necks now for survival.  What use to be an environment of constant improvement and making things better for investors is now an every man for himself environment with everyone worried about saving their own skin.  It is tragic what has happened to the once premiere investment firm to work for in New England.

Title: Bean counting company driven by metrics
View8: Bonuses, decent benefits, large company with lots of other job opportunities, health-conscious environment with fitness center, healthy meals etc.
View10: Too many metrics. Rep performance is measured every which way. Working under a microscope is discouraging.  Every new management regime resets expectations. Result: two steps forward, one step back. Latest focus is "being efficient" aka doing more with less. Lip service to Work/Life balance. Business needs come first. Company is largely segregated: Lots of India natives in IT. Blacks, women, the elderly in Phones. Promotion is based on who you know which means company loses some high potential employees who don't know the right people and don't see any growth potential.

Title: Financial Service Representative
View8: The benefits are great and the campus is beautiful
View10: They reel you in with the great benefits and the pay sounds good at first, but after training is over they throw you to the wolves and you’re expected to know everything single thing they never taught you. Once you’re in the call center, it’s impossible to get out, even if you’re the top performer on your team. They emphasize work/life balance but be prepared for a guilt trip and lecture if you ever need a sick day. Everywhere outside of the call center seems to be run so much better, people here are overworked, treated poorly, you can’t even take a sip of water between calls most days and if you do then your numbers are penalized. Managers ask you what career path you want to be in but then do absolutely nothing to help you get there. HR is a joke.

Title: Business Analyst
View8:
Working at the Durham office had its perks that start with the beautiful campus which had an on-site gym, lots of walking trails, decently priced cafe food and solid office space to work throughout.

Benefits are very good but don't expect too much of a work/life balance.  Fidelity didn't innovate/realize early enough to understand the changing employer landscape which has cost it a lot of turnover.  Around when I left there was a large effort to catch up to and implement changes from market leaders in employment statisfacation/culture.

I enjoyed a lot of the mid level management during my tenure, but never really found upper management to be helpful.
View10:
-Lots of change within to reduce spending which also reduced employee perks
-Too many folks that do the bare minimum and are showed favoritism by management
-Upper management rarely meets with their associates below, unless they meet quickly to announce something
-Pay is below market average
-A lot of interim positions open up, but not many full time positions are opened internally
-Tons of legacy systems you have to work with that are 15+ years old

Title: Burned out
View8: Benefits are good and building is nice.
View10: Position consists of taking relentless inbound calls. There is no time in between calls and you’re pretty much hooked up to the computer all day. The metrics they want you to meet are almost impossible to follow so employees purposefully transfer calls to keep metrics low.
