My Manager criticized my calls so much at one point I realized there was nothing I could do to make him happy. Mistakes are to easy to make even if you are laser focused all day. I found a new position and was walked out after putting in my two week notice. They are paying me but i was unable to say goodbye to anyone so it looked like I was terminated after being walked out by my manager which wasn’t the case. Employees complained of being burned out constantly and management does nothing. It’s sad cause the employees are wonderful people who deserve at least 5 seconds between calls to stretch or take a sip of water but upper management doesn’t notice at all. I couldn’t take it anymore

Title: Bad experience
View8: My co-workers are what kept me there so long.
View10: Management is a joke.  They were extreme micromanagers and very cliquey with each other.  They made it known who they favored and many deserving associates couldn't progress in their roles simply because they weren't favored.  You have to take your breaks and lunches at the exact times they schedule you for (which differed every day) and if you got stuck on a call and went on break late, it would negatively affect your numbers - which ultimately decided your bonus.  This place is a sweatshop.  You are expected to take non stop calls your entire shift.  There is no break in between calls so you aren't even left with time to make notes on the customers accounts you just spoke to - as soon as they hang up, another call immediately comes through with no choice to decline the call.  On average there is at least a 5-10 minute wait  for customers to get through to a representative.  Customers are already aggravated by the time you speak to them - it's like the company sets you up for failure.  They clearly need to hire more people for the role.  The turnover rate is so high because employees are so unhappy.  Glad I'm out of there.

Title: Like most very large companies, it's very hit or miss.
View8: Fidelity is actually a bunch of smaller companies. If you're in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you're going to have amazing benefits, great pay, even free Cokes, Izze's, and cappuccinos in the break rooms. If you have a good manager, the sky could be the limit when it comes to advancement and opportunities. They do generally take very good care of their people.
View10: If you're not in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you wear the badge, but don't necessarily have the good pay or benefits, and you can expect to pay dearly at the cafeteria. Fidelity's companies are VERY siloed, so if you want to advance from one group to another and don't know someone there, or your manager doesn't have strong connections, you are actually at a disadvantage to outsiders trying for the same position. If you aren't under a good, well-connected manager, expect to slave at your current role forever.

Title: Good company - feels underpaid
View8:
It’s a very, very easy job. 
There are a lot of hidden benefits like working from home and high PTO. 
Laid back office life
You’ll get dank karma on reddit with all the free time you spend on there at work
View10:
Feels slow paced
You’ll feel like you’re making 10-20% less of a salary than other firms in the feel
Depending on your department, you’ll work on old tech (software developer working with c98 standard and python 2.6). It leads you to have to redefine the wheel often
Standard 3% raises if you’re lucky
it takes your bosses a while to dole out new work. You’ll constantly find your 2 week sprints have two projects that will take you a max of 1week to finish.
Some days you reach the bottom of reddit and you feel like you’re in high school detention 
On the job experience of the systems you work on is given out painfully slow. 3 years in and I’m finally understanding how the system works

Title: Sub-Par Management and Work/Life Balance
View8: Colleagues; Cafeteria; Benefits; Licensing Process
View10: I left Fidelity Investments due to my manager and the position itself. I was a Customer Relationship Advocate (fully trained and licensed) and each day on the phones was anxiety-inducing. I did not feel properly trained, nor did I feel comfortable answering a ton of questions on margin balances, options, etc., and despite that, I was not supported further. Just about every day, I would get yelled at by clients, and yet nothing was done. There were also very few breaks from the phones, and I woke up each morning dreading work and realizing just how miserable this position was. At one point, I had to go on a medical leave and I think I went 5 weeks without hearing from my manager. He did not respond to any of the emails I sent to him, he did not check in on me, and generally, he seemed to care very little about the associates; instead, he was very focused on the metrics instead. All of this contributed to a sub-par experience.

Title: All in all, a good place to be.
View8: Fidelity puts a ton of resources into training and is absolutely all about doing the right thing for the customer.  They do a good job of attracting professional people who are willing to help.  There are plentiful development opportunities and networking opportunities in the form of employee resource groups.
View10: Politics.  They vary by business unit but they can range anywhere from a nuisance to absolutely noxious.  Yes, I understand this exists in pretty much every place, but there’s a long-standing impression that people tend to get ahead based on who, rather than what, they know.  The higher-ups also tend to play favorites and it becomes fairly obvious who those are and are not.

Title: Financial Representative
View8: Good Training, Great co workers, good benefits, good entry to financial knowledge
View10:
At the end of the day, it's just a call center. There isn't that much room for growing despite it being a finance company. The job itself is not finance related, so unless you develop your skills outside of work, you can't really move away from the call center.

Managers aren't that helpful. They will spend time trying to coach you on things that might not even matter, or might not even work. They will tell you they will look for opportunities for you, but you are on your own.

Required to stay at your role for 1 year.

Long term for vest/match to go through

Company values high metrics, regardless of how you handle your job. Good Metrics = good benefits, even if you don't do your job correctly

Lots of departments to work with. Very messy and your metrics are dependant on other people doing their job properly.

Lots of favoritism on the office.

Don't leave the position until after 1 year if you don't want to pay the bonus back.

Title: Will hire anyone  willing to work for their wages with  access to very confidential information!
View8: Nice working environment.   Great countryside -campus atmosphere!   Great eating areas.  Nice parking garages located far from buildings.
View10:
Have to be related to someone or willing to manipulate the supervisors.   Most
employees have access to all account holders information in the privacy of their homes.    Screening of  personnel before hiring seems short.   This company seems to hire  inexperienced people to handle millions of dollars worth of accounts.  I have never seen so many  confused  people under one roof.  The company  keeps increasing responsibilities and nothing else.

Title: Great 1st and 3rd place to work
View8: Unmatched Benefits package.  7% 100% matched 401K + 10% profit sharing dumped into 401K annually  (=24% into 401K each year).  Annual bonus for most positions.  Company values are truly top notch and I trust the company to always do the right thing for the customer.
View10: Great benefits offset the low pay but benefits don't pay your bills.  You can move up fast but hit a ceiling very quickly.  In line promotions not an option for most positions.  Almost impossible to make real money without bouncing around from job to job or leaving and coming back.  Company is very cost sensitive right now so there is a lot of anxiety about job security.  They claim to be very flexible with work from home arrangements and a more casual atmosphere, but the traditional must be in the office attitude still exists for most roles.

Title: Be careful not to think outside the very small box
View8: They offer excellent medical and educational benefits.
View10: Working at Fidelity will be frustrating for anyone who likes to think for his or herself.  In the call center, you are considered close to a trained parrot, and the only value the company recognizes is your ability to regurgitate the same lines over and over.  Even after considering very carefully how to word certain items with customers, a management intern with weeks of relevant experience who has very little understanding of your job will listen to your calls and tell you exactly how they want you to speak to customers, down to exact lines of text that won't work very well and will cause you more problems with customers.  Thinking people will hate this.  Work is very boring and rote.  The tools provided to get the job done are poorly designed, and can hurt your call statistics.  You will be assigned a queue for a specific pool of customers, and some are far worse than others.  This too will affect your statistics.

Title: Absolutely BEST Employer I have EVER worked for!!
View8: Superb management who are engaging and truly care about the future and current success of the employee. Very competitive compensation package including salary, bonus, profit sharing, retirement health funds, 401(k) match, education contribution match, fitness reimbursement, computer reimbursement, and MANY MANY more! Fidelity's health, dental, and life insurance offerings are PHENOMENAL!! Family type environment run by a family from the top down. Excellent opportunities to move globally and into other job types and businesses. Fidelity is a highly diversified corporation with abundant options. Depending upon the position, many teams offer flex-schedules, including working from home. Training is available in areas both inside and outside of the employee's current role enabling them to grow in areas they are interested in.
View10: Interviewing can be challenging depending upon the role you are applying for. Also, if you do not have work experience or financial industry experience, it may be difficult to get your foot in the door.

Title: Work 12 hours a day till you get fired .
View8: Computer equipment purchase program. Discount on healthy eating options. Wellness center on campus. 10% profit sharing. On campus fitness center(family members are not allowed)
View10:
. 15% lower salary then industry average.
. No work life balance.
. You need to have a very good relationship with middle management to get good bonus and hike.
. Lay offs are very frequent, recently they laid off many due to bad planning of the management. Incompetent upper management with no visibility for future (not even for 3 months).
. Unnecessary works imposed on you to impress superiors of your boss.
. No training , no support to do your work.
. They manipulate teams at will without any transition plans. 
. Hard work and success is never acknowledge or celebrated.
. No fun activities or team building activities.
. Many a time no place to sit, untill recently (after they fired many people).
. Very mechanical work environment.
. Only one boring party in entire year on Christmas that to you are not allowed if your are a contractor and families are not allowed.

Title: Vice President -- Financial Consultant
View8: Overall a very good company with great benefits and potential career growth if you are willing to move across the country, depending on your business unit.   Also, this is a great company in which to start your career.
View10: Very large organization with business units in all facets of financial services to the point that, in some cases, they compete within Fidelity for the same business.  In the branch network, the employee needs to be very careful about the manager of the branch.  There are some managers that are not equipped to deal with people.  The one I worked with tended to treat everyone like they are small, errant children regardless of age and/or experience.  I had worked in a different business unit for a number of years that had very qualified managers who knew how to manage and motivate adults .

Title: Not for young people
View8: There are some good people there but that place is not somewhere for young people especially if you want to learn and grow. Advancement is not something that happens much and promotions forget about it. People have been in the same roles for 5 years or longer with no promotions. Culture is old and many older employees do not value young people and see them as threats to their jobs. A lot of managers should not be managers as they do not possess the true qualities it takes to be managers. They are trying to make changes but a lot of employees are unhappy and leaving.
View10: Management, advancement, promotions, salary, mobility

Title: Very good place to start a job, tremendous place to establish a career.
View8: Very easily to be promoted within the company, as long as you excel at your previous role.  Challenging enough to keep you interested until you master that role, at that time there is opportunity to move along.  Benefits are unmatched compared to anywhere!  7% match on 401(k), 10% profit sharing into 401(k) each December, quarterly bonuses, health packages, fitness reimbursement, almost fully paid advance degrees (i.e. MBA).
View10: It can be monotonous at times.  Initially, you start out on the phones as a Customer Service rep.  As long as you aren't a screw up in that role, it's easy to move along to others with more responsibility.  It is very much an inbound call center, however, training there is very good.  Still good education when it comes to market knowledge and very, very good licensing training (7, 63, 66... possibly CFP pending on how far you move along).  I have no experience in branch roles.

Title: Overall a good company with good training, nice people, and pleasant environment.
View8: Chance to earn some small bonuses during the quarter and at year's end.  Company would show appreciation by catering food for employees from various restaurants during tax season.  Obtained Series 7 and 63 registrations.  Worked with a good group of people.  Learned a lot via training and by being on the phone all day with customers from all 50 states.  No take home work.  Able to leave the job behind each day at market close.
View10: Worked was mundane.  Even as a Trader, one is stuck in a cubicle all day with a headset on shagging phone calls.  Listening to abusive and ignorant customers gets old real quick.  Little room for advancement.  Company is big on looks.  You won't land an Advisor position in one of the retail investment centers unless you look like a Ken doll.

Title: A decent place to work if you are patient and don't expect to progress quickly...or at all
View8: Benefits are decent; Management supports work-life balance; Tuition reimbursement program; Intelligent people; Upscale place to work, Modern building with amenities
View10: Bonus has never been what I was promised at the beginning, it is controlled by upper management who do not know and work with the lower level employees. They are more concerned with controlling their budgets, rather than rewarding and developing talented people. Difficult to get interesting and challenging projects, management is guarding their turf and does not delegate. Which is understandable, considering the constant threat of layoffs. If you are eager to advance, have varying assignments, get exposure to high visibility projects and rise quickly on the career ladder, this is NOT the place for you...unless you have really good connections and/or a senior exec family member. If you are, however, content with 9 to 5, easy, mindless work, go for it.

Title: Finance
View8:
You can define your own career path. 
Some of the people are good and inspiring.
Investment in new hires / first time employees  (time, rotational programs, benefits and wages / equipment) is good - but they ignore more "seasoned" team members.
Values and mission as defined are good (just not always followed)
View10: Promotions based on whether you are liked and mostly internal to each business unit. Push in some areas of finance to keep to lowest common denominator for quality and creativity which is demoralizing to those of us pushing the envelope. My managers (VP and SVP level) only worried about their own jobs - and they lied to protect themselves at the expense of their employees.   Plus - do you really think someone with 1 - 3 years experience can replace someone you pushed out with VBO ?  the rest of the team were left holding the work and failing.

Title: OSG OVERTAKEN BY MINDLESS HUMANOIDS!!!
View8: Gain experience in the financial industry. Good pay and great benefits.
View10: At Fidelity Investments there are too many politics. I thought I was in the novel "Catch 22" but instead of the book being set in WW2, it's set in Corporate America. Some of the most asinine decisions I've ever seen, including those in movies and on TV, were made at the manager level. Too many layers and layers of middle management who don't really have a function other than to attend meetings and self-promote. Some of the managers even make the associates complete manager reviews for them.

Title: Slow moving company with great benefits. Not ideal for software engineers.
View8:
Great work life balance.
Above average benefits.
Good company image and demonstrated success.
View10:
Comparatively low salary. Fidelity claims it is competitive but it isn't.
Does not understand technology. 
Slow moving and not very many opportunities to build a resume with marketable skills.
Career advancement can be heavily based on the politics of your team.
Very lax interviews causes many of your fellow teammates to be incompetent and unable.
Lots of offshore contracting going on. This means you'll be getting up early to talk to your offshore team and hating doing it since of the probable communication barrier.

Title: Drains you
View8: The people you work with, and that they pay you to study.
View10:
This job will literally drain your life, you're answering 30-40 phone calls per day. You're graded on your CEI (customer survey) and your CPH (call per hour), which sometimes you get surveys for calls that is not your department (wtf 401k calls).

Promotion is not based on your CEI and CPH alone, they will promote you if they like you enough. Good luck on getting a manager that you'll get along with, some of them don't care (looking at you Lauren, coming in at 11am and leaving at 3pm), and some are so obsessed with stats that they'll work your until you die. 

Oh you're putting in overtime? That's great, we're expecting you to, who cares if you don't have work/life balance. 

Stay away from this job if you can get anything else. Don't believe it when they tell you 'oh here is a Ping Pong table you get to use', or 'you can sit anywhere you'd like', because they're too cheap to build their own place, and they're overcrowding this office. 

P.S. you better drink that koolaide.

Title: Unfortunately more cons
View8: Good name to have listed on a resume, good benefits if you're able to use them, good food on site.
View10: Passive aggressive managers who are simply looking to gain top awards for themselves and drive metrics and stats. Zero time to actually utilize the benefits that are offered. They tell you overtime isn't mandatory but you need to have a valid reason to opt out and then if you do opt out, you receive emails asking you to reconsider. High expectations and low direction from many managers. Stuck in one role for 1 year before the possibility of ever moving around within the company.

Title: Okay, for a call center.
View8: The company has a great work-from-home opportunity for a lot of roles, the health care plan choices are pretty good and are affordable, and there are a lot of options for schedules, making it easier to balance work/home life.
View10:
The pay is not comparable to other major investment firms, and it doesn't keep up with cost-of-living increases we've seen in the Denver area. 
There is also a big difference in what some managers bring to the table versus others. There seems to be a 50/50 spilt between managers who show up, coach their team, and support their associates and those who, frankly, don't. If you get one of the managers who doesn't, there is no opportunity to switch.

Title: Graveyard of ambition with better than average benefits
View8: Parking,  Coffee, HSA, nearby trails.
View10: Management is only interested in one thing,  and no one knows what it is.

Title: Not a place to work Long Term
View8: Its a great stepping stone in your career, they do have a flexible work environment depending on where you work, Boston is hectic and down sizing all the time whereas North Carolina folks are more laid back and slow. Ample parking space in North Carolina
View10: Very little professional growth if you towards the bottom of the totem pole, very high turnover rate and employees are constantly playing musical chairs with regards to cube assignments or reorg in the company. Some professionals are given too much power and run the place like total dictatorship. Would never want to work here again nor would I want to invest my savings with this firm. Loyalty, reliability and professionalism has no value here.

Title: Great place to start, but move on
View8: Fantastic benefits, above average compensation, great co-workers, and lots of professional training.  Great place to start a career, but not a place to work for ever.
View10: Fidelity does believe in its employees.  I experienced it multiple times, they only believe in their name.  On the surface Fidelity appears to value its employees, but in reality they have no loyalty to its workers.  That will only become apparent after 5+ years of working for them.  The pay offset the negative aspects of the company.  You would think that there is room for advancement in such a large company.  However, that is not case.  The Pros do out way the cons for a period of time, 5-7 years.  After that, take your experience and move on.

Title: Not a bad place to work, and so much potential to get better in the future!
View8: Fidelity has a very competitive benefits package, and good opportunities for training and extending your knowlege of financial services.  There are lots of opportunities for working in different departments during your career.  The average tenure of Fidelity employees is quite long - something like 10+ years, so you could build a long career here if you want to.
View10: Management is out of touch with market direction and needs, and technology personnel are viewed as "overhead" or an "expense" and not really an investment in the future.  There is a tremendous amount of bureacracy and layers of removal between the customer and the people actually doing the work.  Having "fun" at work isn't really a priority, eveyrone walks around with their head down hardly cracking a smile most of the time.  It's all business, all the time, but a lot of efforts being duplicated and /or wasted.

Title: Great company, good opportunities when the economy permits
View8: This is a great company to work for. Smart, caring people (for the most part), great benefits, lots of extras, beautiful facilities and great managers (for the most part). This, at least my department, is pretty laid back and it runs very smoothly. Low stress job.
View10: It is still a cubical farm. There is a lot of corporate non-sense that you have to put up with. There are still some unqualified, and not-so-great managers who sneak in to their positions from other companies. Hard to move up right now of course w/ the hiring freeze and the economy in general. We just went through a reorg so it was very unfun to work here for the last few months, but things are getting back on track now that the panic has subsided a bit.

Title: Great career jobs with layers of bureaucracy
View8: On-boarding process has plenty of Kool-aid to drink (aka. "we're amazing and nothing wrong") that gets you excited for your new job, Plenty of movement during certain periods of the business cycle, lots of cross training, great retirement benefits and health plans, investment in employees, pay is great, clean, bright work environment.  Perfect for a long term career employer.
View10: Leadership is sub-par, upper management is extremely disconnected with the front line representatives and doesn't enable mid management, lots of politics, office culture seems inauthentic, very low flexibility on work schedule, forecasting always off, talk about providing best customer service in industry yet not providing tools or hiring sufficient staff, extremely restrictive of employee trading (no "bearish" positions, very hard to qualify for upper level options trading) due to policy not regulation, few rewards for service reps - mostly available in sales.  Very hard to effect any real change.

Title: Amazing company!!!
View8: I am so lucky to work for this company, and no I’m not sugar coating it, it’s actually awesome! We are going through a pandemic right now and I feel so appreciated and valued. They have gone above and beyond to make this transition so much easier, not perfect, but it felt effortless. The benefits even prior are unmatched, you come to work but folks care about you and you leave work feeling like you made a difference. I haven’t been here but a few months and I’ve already moved up! Your career is what you make it, so you must be proactive and go after it yourself! Also, managers treat you like an equal and genuinely want you to excel!
View10: Overtime can suck, and you sometimes question how to move up, but you are never alone in it!

Title: Don't expect to think for yourself in the 401k department
View8: I like the benefits... the 401k matching and fitness money is great.
View10: You get knocked off on call scores for insane reasons. They expect you to follow a script and be able to click through a window that tells you how to do your job as well as help the customer at the same time. Transactions that I know like the back of my hand take two or three times as long because I have to read through the "call flows" and sound like  a complete idiot to the customer. I have to read through them to make sure I don't miss some inane bit of information that I have to tell the customer that really does not have anything to do with the transaction taking place. I have seen employees who have been with the company for a long time let go or on last warning because they know the job so well using this tool slows them down.

Title: Once #1 mutual fund industry leader now slowly decenting to the middle of the pack
View8: The money and benefits are excellent.  Salary, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Shares, Life Insurance, company match in 401(k), etc.
View10: Performance is not always valued.  Mediocre resources can flourish and even excel if they are liked by senior management.  Pay for Performance is not managed well.  New Senior Leadership is cutting staff based on money not performance.

Title: Excellent place to begin a career
View8:
- Generous compensation: overtime is available (and expected during tax season), company match is great if you stay with the company for more than one year, quarterly bonuses that can be up to 200% of goal provided you hit your metrics.
- Licensing training is next to none and you will be very prepared for your daily work. Great way to build knowledge of finance.
- Lots of chances at upper mobility as long as you are willing to work for it.
View10:
- Working on the phones can get a little dry after a while. Management seems to be aware of this though and they are attempting to improve employee experience.
- What you are able to do for customers is limited as a function of your position in the company. Thus, until you reach a higher position, you don't necessarily get to do a lot of the fun things. This can also lead to customers feeling like they are getting the run-around.

Title: Horrible, like a cult
View8: great licensing program, thorough training
View10:
Micromanagement 
Stressful work environment
Poor Morale

Title: Pleasant at times stressful. Limited ability to help clients efficiently and a glass ceiling after 2yrs.
View8: Benefit structure is great. It's a safe place to work if you're just looking for a starting place to work, and you are content to grow a career somewhere else.
View10: work environment is placid, juvenile management techniques, limited respect for capabilities of employees. Employee morale and attitudes are negative qualities. Lower level management with limited to no brokerage and finance experience. Get the impression that the organization is afraid to take chances and people are afraid to put it on the line.

Title: Working in IT at Fidelity will be the death of your career if you are a true Tech Person
View8: Generally competitive salaries and good benefits.  If you are very good with Technology no one is likely to ask questions as they wouldn't want to reveal how little they know themselves.
View10:
Fidelity is very political and top heavy.  Over 25% of IT people have titles of Director or above, however this is not because of ability, it is because it is the only way Fidelity can retain staff.  These people would not cut it at technology companies where engineering and merit are central.

In order to accomplish anything at Fidelity, you must have countless meeting with many groups of people, most of whom will not understand any technical aspects of the discussion.  Instead decision makers will rely on people with inflated titles whom they believe to be technical gurus, but who are simply the best at appearances and politics.

Fidelity is extremely title, appearance, and politics conscious.  Your actual ability to innovate, be creative, or lead is secondary to these factors.  If you are a true lover of technology who wants to learn and grow, then you should make every effort to join a proper technology company.  Avoid Fidelity at all costs.
It

Title: Great place to work if you are in the right role.
View8: There are a lot of very challenging, rewarding, and lucrative roles within the company.  If you find yourself in the right business unit at the right time Fidelity can be an amazing place to work.  While base salaries seem low, if you are in a role where you are compensated on performance (commission, cash bonus, stock awards) you can find yourself making a great living with a great work / life balance as compared to the rest of the industry.
View10: Entry level and back office employees are not paid very much and are not eligible for many of the performance based compensation incentives (stock awards, cash bonuses etc.).  This means that if you find yourself in the position of being dependent upon one of these people to do your job, you are frequently greeted with either incompetence or apathy.

Title: An Old, Tired Company that Needs Improvement
View8: Good benefits (profit sharing, 7% match for 401k)
View10:
Its an old, tired company that is way too top heavy.  Particularly with senior managers who have been around for 10+ year and seem to be in "coast mode" and are out of touch.  In my specific group there are twice as many managers as there are actual employees (developers, analysts, QA, etc.).  This makes for a politically charged  environment.  Promotions are based on who you know and how long you've been around instead of how good you are.  

The opportunity to move up in the company by moving on to other groups within the company has recently been removed.  You can still transfer, but it must be a lateral movement (ie: they won't pay you more for doing more, and any type of promotion is out of the question even though they'll expect you to do the work of people with a higher job title).

Title: Ethical, customer friendly and employee friendly company
View8: Great emphasis on continuing education for Financial Consultants,.  The company always emphasizes creating financial plans that puts clients in a better situation according to generally accepted principles of financial planning.
View10: It’s best to join the company young and completely buy in to Fidelity’s view of how financial plans should be drawn up.   Those with a tremendous amount of external experience may struggle vs those who completely drink the Fidelity  Kool Aid.  There is almost no flexibility or creativity among Financial Consultants.  If Fidelity we’re managing their business 100% according to plan, it would not matter at all which FC you worked with because every single one of them would offer you precisely the same solutions.

Title: Every Minute is Timed - Customer Relationship Advocate
View8: - Wonderful benefits (specifically retirement/retirement planning) - Everything has a process (not enjoyable for me, but a pro for some) - Overall culture from top down was positive
View10:
- Dissonance between corporate culture and frontline culture (find this in many large companies though)
- Micro-management built into phone-based roles (every minute must be accounted for on computer) 
- Difficult to move laterally (plan on sticking in your initial-role or something comparable for several years)

Title: Cookie Cutter Metric Driven
View8: Health and Welfare benefits are good
View10: Talent Acquisition stated the C Suite recognized they needed diversity of ideas and to recruit experienced leadership and talent from other financial firms to get some fresh ideas vs. homogeneous atmosphere they have. Well their entire 10-20+ year Team Leader and Manger level folks that arrived at the firm in their 20’s and are still there aren’t on board. They want you do it “this old way” or you just don’t fit their metric driven, hourly only, completely micro managed way of doing things. It was promising in the beginning, but in 15 mos. it was obvious the firm has problems. They touted Agile ways of doing things, but that wasn’t really what was happening.

Title: I love this company.
View8: Fidelity investments has phenomenal benefits. The healthcare premiums are fairly low and provide full coverage. The firm matches 7% of your 401(k) contributions and adds annual profit sharing money which is a percentage of your salary. The quarterly bonuses are quite nice too! There are many other corporate perks/discounts as well. I like the fact that I work with young professionals that range in age, sex, and race. Everyone at the firm is very charismatic. I've been there for 6 months now and I can easily see myself retiring with Fidelity. I honestly can't think of anything bad, especially since there is PLENTY of room for advancement/growth.
View10: It can be tough to advance (change roles) if you are an introvert. Moving around in the company happens by shadowing others, so you better show charisma and the drive to take control of your own development. Many of the roles require communication skills, so if you don't feel comfortable with public speaking then this is NOT for you.

Title: Good company, middle management doesn't have a strong backbone
View8: Fidelity is a family friendly company.  Most executives / directors / managers work with employees struggling with family hardships as much as possible given the employees responsibility level.  The benefits are very good as compared to companies in general.  Certain positions are able to work from home.
View10: Being a large company, getting things done has way too much red tape.  The company is not nimble.  Systems are very complicated and that doesn't allow for quickly adjusting to market conditions.  Goals set at the executive level do not translate to all divisions with the company.  Most promotions are about who you know, not based on merit and experience.

Title: Retirement Solutions Representative
View8:
+Benefits are top notch (7% match, 10% profit sharing, great medical, dental, student loan repayment program, tuition reimbursement program, paid family leave, new parent leave- the works) 
+Ability to be promoted quickly. Company is large- plenty of options
+Focus on promoting from within
+Focust on technology 
+Some employees are bright and talented
View10:
+Complete lack of transparency 
+Company is so large there is very little opportunity to affect change
+Low base pay, total compensation is dependent on bonuses which are liable to change on company whim 
+Regional centers are under-appreciated
+Layoffs are poorly communicated 
+Branch locations are understaffed 
+Lateral moves do not result in compensation that could be achieved as an external transfer 
+Some employees are complacent and jaded 
+The Kool-Aid is THICK

Title: Great Company with some downsides
View8:
Opportunity to try different careers. I moved around from a contractor to full time then moved into 5 other types of positions within my 19 yrs at Fidelity.
Great benefits. I was able to use adoption cost benefits, PC purchasing 3 times, continuing ed assistance, fitness reimbursement, etc. while there.
Last job with Mondays off and remote work from home one day was great!
View10:
Company is downsizing and relocating workers in an ongoing basis for the past 4 years. Folks that relocated to NC found they were laid off soon after. 
They used to RIF in large volumes but appear to do 100 at a time now to go under the radar of media. 
They do have a great severance package though for those with many years.
Recently it's been more difficult to climg the ladder due to cost cuts.

Title: Don't waste your time.
View8: Fellow employees are great. The business casual environment is a nice touch even allowing jeans on certain days. The benefits are well above average and can rack up a nice retirement if smart and utilize all outlets avaiable. Always drawings and contests happening on the campus which produce gift cards for the winners. I surfed the net to kill time on slow days.
View10: The work itself is mind numbing and employees are micro-managed to death. I had at least 4-7 people telling me 100 different things to do at any giving time. It is nearly impossible to succeed giving the matrix they must use to promote; meaning there is no rhyme or reason to it, they throw a dart at a board. They don't have a problem training you in different aspects of the job but only so someone else that used to do it can take a nap. Everyone hates the place that works there and thats all they talk about, all the time. If someone messes up, everyone gets yelled at for like 2 months. Gets old.

Title: Fidelity was an extremely challenging yet rewarding firm to work for over the years
View8: Fidelity compensates its employees well and provides an exciting and challenging work environment.
View10:
1) Constant re-organizations make it difficult to make change initiatives stick within the organization.  Each new leader wants to dismantle previous leaders work and rebuild in his own vision therefore some employees choose to not embrace change because they know they can wait it out until the next re-organization.  

2)  Mid to upper management his very political and tend to focus on their own personal agenda's versus doing what is right by the firm which frustrates the people who truly want to do the right thing.

Title: Strong reputation but future is concerning
View8: Great brand name with a wealth of clients, albeit quickly aging. Unparalleled technology and integrity. Exceptional brokerage platform for the self directed investor. Excellent preparation for career in financial services. Privately held by the benevolent Johnson family.
View10: Very robotic, little room for personal expression. Template driven environment that frustrates top performers. Production pressure in insurance and managed money accounts. Proprietary offerings carry high fees and below average performance. Politics and finger pointing on the rise as competition erodes asset base. Product offering does not resonate well with sophisticated clientele.

Title: Hard work and skills don’t matter
View8: Benefits ..... that’s all I can say
View10:
Hard work and skill doesn’t matter. All based on favoritism so all you gotta do is kiss their butt. If you apply in a phone call center, expect to stay there and rotate between different call centers for the rest of your life. Only opportunity they offer is different call centers. Two 15 minute breaks, one 30 min lunch and they choose when you take it. YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT AT EXACT TIMES . They recently made it so that you can take it 20 min before or after . Break feels like 5 mins and lunch is 10 min cause the lines are sooooo long in the cafe and it takes time to get your butt up off your prison cell and walk all the way over there sooo technically you got 5-10 mins to shove the food in the mouth. Easy to get burn outs and forces you to do OT or else you’ll look bad and lose that opportunity for progression. Flexibility my butt! they give you a list of unattractive hours that is available and you just gotta choose from it.

Just avoid applying for phone call centers unless it’s your last resort.

Title: Borderline discriminatory management. Mediocrity at its worst!
View8: Nice campus, free coffee, free parking. Quarterly appreciation event with cupcakes and games.
View10: No career. Politics counts for 90%, which hurts the evolution of projects and deliverables. Improvisation, lack of leadership skills, and management that plays favorites, not with those that contribute the most, or who do the best for the company, but those who kiss the boss's behinds more often. People will often take credit for your deliverables, and will also blame you for their mistakes and snafus. Performance reviews are a joke in all areas of the company, and the employee has no chance of refuting the facts. Management is often clueless, and worse, it often lies about status of projects, impacts, deadlines, or deliverables. Everybody is a VP. The less degrees you have, and the more bs you can talk, the better.

Title: Premium Services Rep
View8: Great benefits, ample opportunity for growth
View10: Fidelity has a reputation for chewing people up and spitting them out.  There's a high turnover rate and you're typically either there for a very short time or for years if you can cut it.  During my lengthy multi-year tenure, Fidelity's focus went from a very high level of efficient customer satisfaction fading into higher and higher efficiency to the point of rushing people off the phone if they had no outside assets to consolidate.  Higher level management tends to be aloof as to the customer and employee concerns/issues that reps are having to face daily on the front lines, oftentimes blindly making decisions with no idea or regard as to the unintended consequences that negatively affect employees and customers.  Advancement is based on merit to a degree, but company politics and who you know is much more important despite management's efforts to thwart this.

Title: Good first job
View8: Benefits, office perks, decent coworkers. Good job to have straight out of college, but they definitely throw you right into the role so be prepared to work with little to no guidance.
View10: Work life balance can be difficult for this role because you’re expected to be the first one in & the last one out. You basically do everyone’s busy work & you don’t get compensated for it. The role has evolved a lot due to COVID, you’re basically doing the relationship manager role just without the extra pay. I worked in an investor center so you won’t be micromanaged, but it’s hard to do anything when you don’t know what to do. Clients can be hard to work with. If you’re not looking to get into sales don’t even bother. They advertise how quickly you can be promoted within the company but it’s harder than they make it out to be, doesn’t matter how long you’ve been there.

Title: Awesome Place To Work!
View8:
I worked here for over decade, and I really enjoyed my time here. I remember the day I got hired as a temp. My world changed, and I was so excited to start my new hire training class. The people at Fidelity are top notch from the security guards, to the cleaning crew, to the executives. This company is ridiculously good at finding the right people who fit the culture and help others grow.

My manager had flexibility where required, and demanded excellence where necessary. I was never unsure of expectations because of the constant feedback loop, and I always strived to do the best work possible because of it. In my group, we had executive leadership involved as well, and even though I was a lower level employee, they were fun, respectful, and always treated me like part of a very important team. I couldn't have asked for more from Fidelity, and I was sad to leave.
View10: I honestly never had any issues here that weren't my own fault (and I had a few for sure).

Title: It will just be another large corporation when Mr Johnson retires...not a good thing.  He's the backbone of the company.
View8: The benefits and pay are equal and/or above it's competitors.  Everyone takes pride in their work and they want to do the right thing.  The tenure is high.
View10: There's very little job stability...layoffs have been happening every year in certain areas.  Not sure why, we're swamped with work and the company continues to make a ton of money.  That is a good thing, but they need to cut in certain 'other' areas instead of the same area every year.  Some of the old leadership must go.  The new leadership I believe is strong.   Maybe they will help breakdown the walls between the groups so we can get a lot of work accomplished.  They also need to get rid of the 'good old boy network'...there's a lot of talent in the organization, but they can't get passed the 'clicks'.  This is very unfortunate.

Title: Fidelity used to be great but is now just good and hopefully stops there.
View8: Fidelity supports work-life balance and has excellent benefits.  The work is challenging and mostly interesting.  Fidelity has a high degree of integrity and is a place you can generally be proud to be associated.
View10: Fidelity is a large, lumbering organization that is going through significant change.  This can make for a challenging work environment.  Processes to get day to day work completed are often cumbersome and inefficient.  Decision making is often decentralized and requires buy-in from many different organizations.  Strategic decisions seem to take excessively long and sometimes waffle back and forth.  This makes execution of the strategy much harder than it needs to be and sometimes nearly impossible to meet required time frames.

Title: Great if you have never worked anywhere else and do not plan on working anywhere else.
View8: GREAT for young people just out of college looking to get their feet wet in the Financial Services Industry.  They give plenty of support to new and untrained/inexperienced employees.
View10: If you have EVER worked outside the firm before joining, you will be extremely surprised at some of the cultural differences.  You really have to drink the kool-aid and conform if you want to stay happy.  Really nice people, yet the firm is in a distinct identity crisis about who/what they want to be.  They can't seem to get passed the notion that if you want to have a "relationship" that means relationship, not buy  our products (proprietary funds, managed accounts and annuities)

Title: 529 College Planning Representative
View8: American Fork Team:  Great team and awesome manager.  The company and employees are fun and expect to make at least a few life long friends.  Fidelity uses great technology to make your job easier and your team will support you a lot when you're new.  This is not a sales job, they used to push a lot for leads and sales, but have really changed over the last few years.
View10:
After you know your job, expect to be bored.  It becomes super easy and you'll find that Fidelity does not value the Utah office.  The only career advancement will be on the phone, but your pay will stop topping out.  The best advice is, to get a job at Fidelity, then have them pay for your MBA or other schooling, then move to another state to work for Fidelity or find a job someplace else.

Builds your resume, but does not really give you many marketable skills.

Title: Stable, established technology-heavy company
View8:
- Long-established company
- Numerous business units offer a variety of lateral transfer opportunities
- Not one of the "bad guys" of the financial world
- "Fidelity nice": a culture heavily focused on comity and professional behavior
- Excellent compensation and benefits
View10:
- Probably the most hierarchical management culture I have ever experienced. Management evaluates ideas largely based on the pay grade of who submitted the idea.
- In the technology space, change is excruciatingly slow. Initiatives flow almost exclusively from the top down.
- Performance reviews are based solely on the feedback of your manager, so a poor relationship with your manager (or an indifferent manager) will doom your career.
- Underperforming employees tend to stick around in their current positions (making life difficult for their team members and customers) rather than being nudged into other roles.

Title: Very conservative and respected, reputable firm can improve in compensation department as an I-Management leader.
View8: Reputable firm. Leader in the MF industry. Very conservative business platform and compliance/HR department that constantly modifies policies and procedures in order to avoid heavy risks and excessive business expenses.  The company has very driven and intelligent individuals that strongly believe in a team oriented work environment. The branch work environment is much different than the phone sites where customer service is provided to branch representatives and clients.  Business processes are heavily outsourced by department functions and organized according to a customer service phone tree.  Overall, the only improvement to be made is in the compensation area and the technical development available to the representatives working at the branches.
View10: Business platform is too large and departments are outsourced; created as phone sites versus subject matter support staff to advisors. Financial advisors are too reliant on software and not enough technical (financial) development is promoted by the company in certain areas.

Title: It is better than a punch in the face.
View8: The money, especially bonuses in my experience exceed the market.  The base salaries are about on par.  There are a lot of good benefits beyond 401k and health care.  There is supposed to be a work / life balance at Fidelity, but like so many other things, it is very inconsistent from manager to manager and business unit to business unit.
View10: The company has institutionalized the acceptance of failure at worst and mediocrity at best when it comes to IT Projects.  As a software professional, it becomes frustrating to work furiously at solving every type of issue besides the technical.  Front line managers are ill equipped to manager software professionals, they are either bad developers promoted to the point of incompetence, or just do nothing know nothing MS Project jockeys.

Title: Good place to start a career
Position: Customer Service Associate II - Tax Exempt Division
View8:
Company does value all employees, very family-like atmosphere, your benefit package is awesome regardless of your position being "entry-level" or management. 
Personal development is highly encouraged- If you dedicate yourself to be successful in your position you will be reward faster than you think ( Fast growth potential - Even if you start in call center)
Work/life balance very important to company 
Very impressed with the level of integrity and emphasis on importance of customer service, 
- you will be very successful if you come in everyday eager to go Go above and Beyond - 

**Everyone seemed happy, excited, and coming in with a  smile every morning**
View10: As a Company, there is not much one can say that isn't positive, they value their reputation very much, you can be very proud to be an employee -

Title: Brokerage Representative
View8: Nothing good other than the benefits and pay, but depending on the department you work for, that doesn’t matter.
View10: Managers could be oblivious on how they treat they’re employees. Will put underachievers ahead of the hard workers. It’s tough to find a department with a good work environment. Sometimes the department you work for, will leave a bad taste in your mouth about the overall company and leave. Sexism plays a part in whether you can grow or not, but if that’s the case, find another department, and fast. Idk how Fidelity can allow sexism managers to be where they are. I’m sure there are other departments who actually value they’re employees but some who don’t care.

Title: Fair Comp System, Not Great For Career Analysts
View8: Pay system is pretty fair and straightforward. A lot of busy work, but great access and resources.
View10: Clique-y and clubby. A lot of Fidelity people socialize together as well as work together. Good if you like that sort of thing. PM driven. They have never gotten a career analyst role integrated into the system. Analsyts can burn a HUGE amount of cycles holding pro forma meetings that deliver no insight. Great access, but "water water everywhere, not a drop to drink" in terms of being able to really drill down into your companies in person.

Title: Institutional Trade Support
View8: It is a very fast pace role with hundreds of phone calls and trade issues need to be addressed on the daily basis. Such environment is good for a entry level individuals who would like to establish his/her career in trading. The team that I worked with are fabulous individuals with great industry knowledge and years of experience.
View10: Since it is family own, you really have to play politics well to survive and move up. There are individuals in the management team that are really not suitable for their roles while others that are really capable got ouster after losing the political fight. Also Fido's salary is kind of lag behind the industry, so do expect getting paid a little less than the peers.

Title: Great place to work but......
View8: Competitive salary and can provide great experience. I worked in several different groups including workplace investing, brokerage operations and technology and have been very happy working in my current role.
View10: Focuses too much on younger talent instead of looking at those with experience. work/life balance is good but can be detrimental if you want to move up. People without families are able to participate in after work socializing and are able to mingle with senior managers whose kids are grown up. As a result, those of us with families tend be left behind those who are single and can go out and drink with the V.P.s and get moved ahead.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work, but could be limiting in career growth
View8: Outstanding benfits package, beautiful campus, professional atmosphere, good work/life balance, challenging projects, and Fidelity gives back to the community.
View10: Arbitrary performance review and bonus review ratings.  As a regular worker you are very unlikely to see the E (exceptional) or O (outstanding) performance review ratings, those seemed to be reserved for managers and connected people.  While many get promoted, they are usually "in-line" promotions worked out with existing managers.  If you post for a higher level position on the internal job board you are unlikely to get it.

Title: Nothing lasts forever
View8: The first 8-10 of my 16 years were good.  Work was challenging but rewarding.  New ideas and approaches were encouraged.  Teams of talented, hard working professionals defined the company.  Employees were told that they were the number one asset.
View10: Too much focus on process and too little on work that added value to the firm.  Offshoring and dumping people in Texas has eliminated nearly every tech job in Boston;  any honest audit of the 'site strategy' will show that it has been an ill-conceived disaster.  The costs are much higher and very little is getting done.

Title: Fantastic, everyones very kind and hard working. Food in the cafeteria is great and reasonably priced. Well managed.
View8: People as well as the opportunities to change roles within the company. Everyone here seems to work hard and their are few shortfalls with the benefits that we receive. It has personally led me to grow as an individual as well as gain valuable experience in the financial services industries. I personally feel lucky that I had the opportunity to work at such a wonderful company and hope to continue my career here for years to come.
View10: Can be stressful with the workload, half the time it seems like your in meetings receiving work than you are actually doing work. Will have to work late hours a lot to make up for the work you could not complete during the day and sometimes you are working 60 hour weeks to keep up with the demand. It is manageable but it can lead to stress, less sleep and worrying. The paycheck does make up for this however as they are a company that does pay pretty well.

Title: 10 year veteran
View8: Privately owned company with huge market-share.  Fidelity still keeps the customer-first approach and believes heavily in creating a great job-experience for it's employees.  The benefits are good and they seem to be continuously looking for ways to improve upon the existing benefits package.
View10: Fidelity isn't known for being the highest paying employment option.  They know that the trade-off is that you get a better overall day to day experience working here than you might working for a competitor who might pay better.

Title: Financial service rep
View8:
Great paid training program to pass 7 & 63 licencing exams. They pay you to study and train you well with an extremely high pass rate for the exams. 

Continued training and development is very good. 

A lot of good benefit programs like loan repayment, computer reimbursement, bonuses, 6 weeks of paternity leave, a lot of other random benefits that are great.
View10:
Very restrictive on personal trading. If you like to trade in your own account they restrict the number of trades you can do per quarter to about 60. This might not matter to some people but for others it is restricting. 
They limit you to long only positions in your personal account unless using it as a hedge. You can short index ETFs. Again this might not matter to some people but could be restrictive if you like to trade.

Overall it is a very mundane job. Some people love it and it is a great fit but you are tied to a desk and a phone which did not work for me.

Title: Representative
View8: Team managers are great but have a limited voice. Everyone is nice that you work with , but nice does not pay the bills.
View10: When you have three financial licenses and have been here for a few years you still make less than almost anyone you know, especially in the financial industry.

Title: Fidelity has Lost it's Way
View8: good benefits, good place to work right out of school (resume builder), opportunity to move around if you are not sure what you want to do with your career
View10:
They have bought or pushed out any decent leaders that knew how to lead, inspire and engage people. The focus now is on young, cheap talent and  "mobility." Forget about climbing the company ladder, they expect you to move around in lateral jobs like you are interchangeable pieces of a puzzle. ( I am on my 4th manager in a little over a year without even changing jobs). 

If you have more than 10 years in the workforce, I would not waste your time here as it will be a dead end.

Title: Workplace Planning & Guidance Consultant
View8: I enjoyed autonomy, I created my own schedule, although certainly certain goals had to be met. I was paid a salary, plus a variable compensation, which was largely derived from my activities, so I had a better chance to drive my own success.
View10: For my region, a huge amount of travel was required, which took much of my productive time. This was often not the case with my peers, whom I was ranked against. Certain employer events would also cause flows of assets beyond my control. They attempted to capture this in the goal setting, but that was done so far in advance that it was certainly not an exact science. The travel time made it very difficult to have much of a personal or social life as well. I often worked 12 hour days, and then spent the evenings doing all the paperwork and entering notes into our tracking system, so it wasn't unusual to have a 14-15 hour day, then have to catch a plane to another location and do it all again the next day.

Title: Top Tier Company
View8: Fidelity Investments is one of the top company's in the financial industry.  The firm's focus on workplace atmosphere, collaboration, career growth, benefits, and work-life balance make one of the most rewarding and enjoyable employer's.  Fidelity also regularly hires third party company's to conduct employee surveys, and that feedback is taken very seriously.  I say this because I've seen senior management respond to areas of improvement with meaningful and relevant changes that enhance the working lives of Fidelity's associates.
View10: The usual large company drawback's apply.  If you're looking to work on the most cutting edge technology or explore ways to disrupt industries, maybe it isn't the best place to work.  Although Fidelity focuses on innovation strategies and new markets, it's size means that change does not come quickly, for the most part, as there are many processes and controls wrapped around existing models. There are also significant regulations to which all players in the financial services industry must adhere, which is fine, but learning and adhering to those regulations limits flexibility.

Title: Enough fooling around - time to start focusing on the business at hand and your employees.
View8: Benefits and the employees in the Human Resources services company are great to work with.
View10: Constant distraction of reorganizations and reductions in force. No clear direction in the Human Resources Services Company. While this Fidelity Company is over 10 years old they are still trying to figure out who they want to be when they grow up. Opportunities, career advancement, salary increases and bonus are based on who you know not job performance. No consistency in roles, employees in team leaders and managers positions play the same roles with the same and in some cases more responsibility as the Directors and VP's but without the same salaries, title and bonuses potential.  Employees continue to pay for the sins of poor decisions made by Senior Management team by way of continued reduction in the merit increase and bonus pool to make up for financial losses incurred  by poor decisions.

Title: It once was a great place to work.  I'd stay away for a while until things shake out one way or the other.
View8: There are some very fine people who work there, and the environment is professional.  Many projects are well funded, and they take a long term approach to projects -- so you usually have what you need to get things done.  There is a commitment to integrity.  The benefits are quite nice.
View10: The management seems to have lost focus and is spinning around creating turmoil and fear. There is a lot of internal strife and politics.  Groups are set up to compete with each other, and this causes in-fighting.  They compete with each other, and loose focus on competing with their external competitors.  I think Ned lost control of the company, and it seems to me that the family cares more about their assets than about the company.  It's a family biz, and the family comes first.

Title: Great place to work, but you will get burnt out easily
View8: Fidelity really has the name brand recognition in the industry. People generally respect Fidelity as a whole. They also have a very good benefits package, and between a 7% 401k match and profit sharing, they take good year of your retirement account. Also, with Fidelity being a privately held company, they have a little bit more flexibility to do what is right for the employees.
View10: I have come to find that it is a very micro-managed company, where management really is not in tune with what is happening in the real world. With regards to work/life balance, there are too many times where you need to take your work home to get to know the materials better or study for a presentation, and there is definitely not enough time off. There is also too many worries about "perception is reality", and you always have to watch who takes notice or looks over your shoulder.

Title: Once a good company to work for but now it is just a sweat shop
View8: There are a number of different jobs, so you can move around and gain a lot of knowledge about different practices, procedures, environments, etc.
View10: At one time Fidelity was a premier company to work for but over the past 5 or 6 years it has gone in the toilet.  There is no longer any loyality to anyone, no matter how much knowledge they have, how beneficial they have been to the company, and their peers.  It is all about the bottom line and if you were paid too much, look out you may just get axed.

Title: Decent and Stable Place to Work
View8:
-Portrays a good image of how it cares for employees. 
-The profit sharing and match for the 401k is outstanding and the work environment is decent. 
-Stable job environment, do not like laying off employees.
Fair amount of time off for vacation and maternity or paternity leave.
-Clients are sometimes good and sometimes bad to work with.
View10:
-All jobs are very much dumbed down, verymuch top-down management.
-Gradually increasing benefits cost to employees, next year, health care costs will rise substantially.
-Very limited upward growth for higher paying rep based jobs.  (> 75k)
-Very, very political and favorite rep driven. Managers are notorious for promoting best friends
-Easy to manipulate the "system" and get credit for stuff reps don't actually do.
-Feels like people are treated as "human capital" and not assets to the firm.
-Higher education does very little for you. A college degree is all you need and lots of people don't even have that. 
-Very little innovation and slow moving. The 1000 lb Gorilla.
-Very much a CYA environment

Title: Overall, its a great company to work at - if one is looking for stability.
View8: The company is extremely customer focused. The management team is always trying to re-invent themselves to ensure they remain competitive.  The firm is also employee friendly and has the power to weather the economic ups and downs with minimum impact to employees.
View10: Change is constant.  Career growth prospects are extremely limited.  Anyone who is looking to move up the ladder will find it takes many years to get a promotion. In the past 5-7 years, the company's focus on cutting costs and improving productivity has resulted in fewer people working a lot more with no significant improvement in compensation. This is not a company to look at if you are looking for a 9-5 working day.

Title: Great Company, Incompetent Lower Management
View8: Absolutely great company to work for and great atmosphere. Best retirement benefits and 401k in the industry. Great place to cut your teeth and learn. Tons of opportunity. If you enjoy investments it's a phenomenal place to learn.
View10: Awful and I mean absolutely awful lower management. Do not recognize talent whatsoever. Production means absolutely nothing. Initial management are the employees who couldn't make it in what they actually wanted to do or just wanted to be lazy. Upper management is extremely smart but lower management is very petty and very likely to be as young or younger than you when starting. Fight your way through it and it is very rewarding but it can burn you out initially. Just realize you will be above them soon.

Title: If you want to be happy in the workplace, avoid this company
View8: If your just out of college, might be a good place to kick off your career
View10: Ok, where to start. Politics, rules this company, if for some minor reason they don't like you from the outset, you can forget about moving anywhere from your current role. Middle mgmt consistently talking badly about their employees. Pay is terrible, upward movement is slow and only to favorites, regardless of how good at the job you might be. The role itself didn't bother me as such, I knew what I signed up for (client services) its just all the BS that went with the role that finally got to me. Turnover rate was ridiculous, I started training in a class of 25, within 12mnths over half had left.  Oh and you will be micromanaged to the second.

Title: Too much change at the top
View8: Good benefits package.  Company was in good shape financially until recently.  Friendly people.  Involved in lots of charitable orginazations.  They have a nice Xmas party and do lots of things for families such as the Big Apple circus and the books fair.  If you need to travel for the company, cuh as going to India, they are generous on expenses for the trip.  Relocation packaages for people going to NC or Texas were good.  Working from home is something that seems to be available to most people.  Bi annual meetings with Sr management attempt to give you info about whats going on but they are usually a waste of time.
View10: Little to no room for a promotion.  Tiny raises for the masses.  No recoginition for doing a good job, unless your a major kiss a..  Poltics and lots of it.

Title: I really hate to say this but the people at the Smithfield, RI campus are not that nice ...
View8: In my role, the work / life balance seems to be good. Nobody bothers you. Very flexible. Corporate seems to be doing a great job.
View10: Training seems to be inconsistant. Nobody seems to be on the same page. The people are not friendly and can be jerks at times, arrogant and cold.

Title: Corrupted and Greedy - Culture is gone
View8: Good Branding for Resume; Diverse Product Range; Well Known Company; Decent technology Implementation to keep up with the current trends.
View10: Corrupt Managment; Cost Cutting at expense of Employees; HR does not hire quality personnel; Cheap wins always over value; Minimum investment into employee development; Inexpereinced managment without knowledge of industry or expereince managing employees

Title: WONDERFUL place to work!
Position: Director, Senior Client Service Manager & Project Coordinator
View8: Since it is a private company, we benefit from autonomy and under Abby's leadership there have been quite a few changes that positively impact employees such as paid time off is now pooled so you have many opportunities to take time off as needed.  Since there is such a large pool of talented employees, we each have access to a large network of people to help us grow both as individuals and as employees.
View10: Large size can be difficult to navigate at times, but all you need to do is network and ask for recommendations on who to talk to.  Work from home/remote opportunities are limited, which makes inclement weather work days a real challenge.  Employees have to endure terrible and risky commutes as they have no other choice.

Title: Great Benefits
View8: Benefits are top notch, there are few that can beat them. The number of days of is crazy compared to most other companies. All technologists are eligible for a bonus. The pay is good. Depending on the business unit you end up in will determine your work load and the type of work you will be doing. Flat company structure.
View10: They try to pass themselves off as a technology company that happens to be in finance, for the most part they try quite hard to maintain this image. Unfortunately, they, like all other companies in the finance field, always seem to slow try something new. Managers are overloaded with work and meetings, making them hard to reach and at times completely out of the loop, this also causes problems with guidance, and mentorship.

Title: Not a friendly place to work
View8: Benefits are good, location is nice.
View10: They promote people to management that don't have any empathy or soft skills and favor their "friends" reporting to them.  If you go in "new", you are an outsider and very few people will make an effort to be your friend or help you.  Very clickish, like high school, groups of people who have worked together a long time.  I had 3 managers in 2 years.  There's no consistency in leadership.

Title: Fair
View8: Salary is lower than industry standard, but made up for by benefit packages and little perks (fitness reimbursement, computer assistance, etc.) Great place to learn the ropes of the industry, sales techniques, etc.  Stable company, constantly changing internally to evolve with economy or client investment demand.
View10: I am in customer service so I've been getting burned out by the demanding customer expectations and Fidelity's policy that the "customer is always right".  I notice the sales roles have experienced greater pressure to fulfill goals due to the economy.  We have been short staffed for a long time, and they are slow to fill the roles (either internally or externally, and competition is FIERCE) puting added pressure and stress on the remaining employees.

Title: Amazing is an understatement!
View8: The benefits are incredible. Fidelity offers great 401k plans, corporate perks and impeccable developmental programs, this company is such an amazing place to work. People are very supportive in this organization and genuinely want to see you grow. Networking plays a big role at Fidelity, its all about who you know when it comes to advancing to the next step in your career so the more people you meet the better.
View10: The Talent Acquisition folks can be unpleasant at times even to internal hires. I have also heard from a few friends that working in the phones suck so if working in a call center isn't in line with your career objectives then I would encourage you to stay away from that area and actually find a position within other divisions.

Title: Sr. Manager
View8: As a ~20 year employee holding a variety of positions, the quality of people has always been outstanding. I've worked for (and with) some tremendous talent, and I've had the opportunity to lead some great people. I've also developed relationships that will last. Fidelity offers great benefits and the work environment and amenities are 2nd to none
View10: The work culture and expectations have become increasingly demanding and it's not uncommon to see e-mails (and sometimes phone calls) at all hours and through the weekend. Senior Teams are under a great deal of pressure to perform, and as a result, Fidelity feels more like a machine and less like the community it was 5 or 10 years ago.

Title: Good for short term experience, then move on
View8:
- Good student loan repayment system
- Gain some insight into the health and insurance or 401k business
- Good 401k  plans
View10:
- Rarely promotes from within
- stagnant wages (raises are not granted based on performance but by the starting competitive wages for call centered)
- Management will have your back one moment then throw you to the wolves the next
- No real ability to do anything besides take calls
- everything is monitored and you will get into trouble years down the road for any mistake
-  No translatable skills
- High turnover (about half do not make it past 1 year, one person in a class may last long enough to be vested after 5 years)
-  Did I mention that they do not promote from within, there is no upward mobility

Title: Product Management
View8: Lots of training opportunities, many different career paths, many niches, many locations, good pay and benefits, and awesome retirement benefits!
View10: Bureaucracy. Different cultures (silos) within the firm. Too top heavy (VP and above). Bending over too much for millennials. If you are over 35, be concerned. Career mobility only exists in certain areas. VPs, SVPs, EVPs, and Executives move around a lot but middle-management and senior associates are stuck. Firm is also years behind in technology compared to its competitors but it is trying to catch up.

Title: Great Place to Start you Finance Career
View8:
- Pre-pandemic office culture 
- Great place to get your education and licenses
- Benefits
- Established firm, respected in the industry
View10:
They have no clue how to keep their employees happy during this Covid world. Your voice will never be heard. The firm's true colors started to show once reps had to work from home. They don't care what your skillset is, what motivates you, and how well you can fit with another team. If your scorecard isn't green forget about moving up in the company.

There's a reason why people are sprinting to Robinhood, but the leadership refuses to acknowledge reality. Instead they spend the exit interview belittling their reps decisions to leave and it's not a good look.

Title: Great place to work for self motivated people.
View8: Knowledgeable staff, top notch technology, excellent benefits.  Hands down the leader in the industry in just about everything they do.  If you want to be surrounded by the smartest people and the best systems - Fidelity is the place to be.  401k and other benefits will not be beat by any other institution.
View10: Lower end of the salary scale.  Management is more supervisory leaving it up to you so search out ways to grow and learn.  Expect to spend your own time searching for ways to improve.  Prepare for a heavy workload which will only grow with the more experience you gain.

Title: Great place to work, but the pay for entry level is not so great
View8: Fidelity is a great place to work when it comes to work/ life balance.  Overtime is minimal (not necessarily a good thing).  There are currently alot of opportunities in Texas with several positions moving from the Northeast.  The atmosphere is a great team environment.  For entry level, this would be a great position if you are looking to go back to school.  Fidelity does provide tuition reimbursement up to $10,000 a year.
View10: Salary is less than competetive for entry level analysts.  It can be somewhat hard to distinguish yourself from your peers because there are so many analysts at the entry level.  Maybe it's typical for the corporate world, but it seems that most analysts get the same performance reviews.  So, if you aren't very good at your job, you will probably still get the same rating as someone who meets expectations... not a lot of motivation to do any more than the minimum.

Title: Fidelity is a great place for a hard worker willing to work for their rewards!
View8: I definitely think working at Fidelity has been my best career decision. I have worked at other places and seen many different management styles and business models, and while everyone has its downfalls. Overall Fidelity does a great job of giving workers the opportunity to grow professionally as long as you are willing to work hard enough to  take advantage of it. I think if you are not willing to work hard to get where you want to be than Fidelity might not be the best place to work.
