However, if you enjoy the opportunity to work hard and let your actions speak for themselves, as well as many different opportunities to keep you interested than Fidelity is the place to work.
View10: When you first start you do work twice as hard and the pay isnt that great. I think the biggest downfall is that compensation isnt as competitive as other places.

Title: A relationship company that cares about employee development.
View8: There are very clear pathways to advancement.  Fidelity really seems to take care of its employees.  I heard when I first joined, and it seems to be true, that you can do your basic 9-5 and be fine.  No one bats an eye.  But if you go above and beyond, then you'll be rewarded with promotions & salary.  Pays well with sizeable end-of-year and 401k bonuses.  Benefits are good, 401k match is fantastic, as you would expect of a company that specializes in retirement plans.  The only people I've seen be let go by the company really deserved it.
View10: "Relationship company" means politics are everywhere, especially in middle management.  Every decision is made by committee, which while great for consensus forming means that every decision takes 10x as long as it needs to be.    Constant reorganizations.

Title: Supportive growth, red tape being cut, and innovation focused
View8: The company stands by the principles it echoes - from wanting to focus on employee health by reducing costs of healthy meals (60% or less than "unhealthy" options) to allowing mobility within the company at countless levels, it is an amazing company to work for. The campuses are beautiful and well kept, the people give hours and hours of volunteer work because Fidelity cares and allows it, and everyone I've met has very little reason to want to go somewhere else.
View10: You're in an office. If you don't like sitting at a desk and knocking out work within a cubicle then this isn't the most modern work space. Changes are in place to move everyone to a more creative space but it's not quite happening yet. However, you can get out and move around and take walks around the campus (if you are not in Boston) to refresh.

Title: Good place to work for a few years, then get a better job elsewhere.
View8: Good place to start out, get some experience; and move on.
View10: I've seen people promoted to positions they did not deserve, while the person who puts in 100% gets passed over time and time again.  I have been through three major "re-orgs," and had my title changed, pay changed, managers changed (three times in one year once), and have seen good people leave due to the overwhelming feeling of discouragement when they are passed up for a promotion yet again given to an incompetent person who "knows" someone.  It is difficult to work like that everyday, and I can understand why people leave.  It is also highly compartmentalized, which means that once you have worked there for a few years or more; it becomes difficult to be marketable to another company.

Title: Used to be a great company to work for, but is slipping and is now just mediocre.
View8:
- Benefits and compensation are still good (although not what they once were).
- The company still has good core values thanks to the Johnson family.
View10:
- Short-sighted leadership lurches to a new strategy every 12 months, eventually coming back full circle but wasting enormous amounts of money in the process.
- Disorganized and you'll have a new manager every 6-12 months.
- Your job is very likely to be relocated to another state, or off-shored to cheaper labor in another country.

Title: Same thing, over and over and over
View8: Great benefits and resources.  In depth training.  VP's are great resources and very kind, understanding people.
View10: Montony.  If you are a phone representative, there is big brother watching over you.  Every second you are logged in, you are monitored.  You could give the best possible customer service, but if you are not meeting Fidelity's standards, there is an issue.  This place is micromanaged to a fault and gives little opportunity to let their employees shine.

Title: Fidelity is going through many changes but is still a great place to work.
View8: The benefits are excellent.  There are not many companies where you get 17% of your annual salary put into your 401K when you contribute 7% pretax.  The culture is excellent.  Everyone in the org chart is extremely easy to approach and is called by their first name.  There is an implied understanding that if work needs to get done it gets done.  Lots of overachievers in the company.
View10: The red tape associated with any large company can get in the way of progress.  Six sigma efficiencies are being applied to practices where the human element is a major factor in decision making.  The corporate culture that made Fidelity great is being shredded apart by huge veils of secrecy with the new leadership.  While Ned Johnson is still the chairman of the board a lot of the decision making is being done by the new president.

Title: Lost within Fidelity's vortex.
View8: I like it here because the people are friendly and smart. The managers are understanding of your family needs. It is within walking distance from home and it is very laid-back.
View10: I've worked at Dot-Com's, Start-ups and a few Fortune 500's and Fidelity has the worst management I've ever seen. The work is off the charts boring and the Business cares more about their bonus than the customer.

Title: This job will suck the life and drive out of you.
View8: It is easy because your job becomes repetitive. They have nice benefits that convince you to stick around.
View10: There is no end to the work load. From the second you pick up the phone, you will take call after call for 8-10 hours, day after day, year after year. I have been here a few years and have talked to 1 or 2 people who actually enjoy working here. Trust me or not, but if you make the move I want you to think about the moment you read this and doubted what you're reading.

Title: Good place to work with great people. Fidelity is a great company
View8: Benefits are great and the pay is decent. You won't feel rich by any means. The peers that you work with are great too
View10: Call center environment which causes stress and anxiety. Rude people are all over the place and you have the opportunity to speak with them all over the phone it seems. Not for someone who takes things personally

Title: Declining opportunities for IT staff
View8: Location (for Boston Employees), multiple fringe benefits. Some good middle managers. It really depends which part of Fidelity you work for though - FMR is the way to go with less likelihood of being outsourced or down sized.
View10: Lack of opportunity for career advancement in IT. Locations (non-Boston). There is an unspoken expectation in some departments that you will work above your normal hours and not complain or expect any compensation for the time.

Title: Overall, good place to work.
View8:
- Great benefits
- Some of the best co-workers that I've worked with; well educated, positive outlook on life, you can tell Fidelity picks the cream of the crop.
- Decent salary; bonus is based on how well you treat customers rather then on sales.
- Great opportunity if you work hard; everything is merit-based.
View10:
- If you're not willing to move (out of state for example) it's harder to move into a branch role.
- Being tied to the phones is exhausting; doing the same thing day in and day out can get boring fast, which is the reason why everyone wants a branch job which in turn makes it hard to get into.

Title: As others have said, It's a good place to start.
View8: Benefits are great - 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing, paid vacation and sick time, medical, dental, life insurance... All around great benefit package. If you want to work overtime it's there and it's abundant. A lot of great people and excellent training.
View10: No matter how much you enjoy people, the phone eventually wears on you... I worked with a lot of very great people but you quickly realize the only reason they're still there is because it's a way to make ends meet. At the Jacksonville site, the vast majority of the jobs are on the phone so there's very little opportunity to escape it. You will quickly find yourself wanting more out of your day to day and start looking for a job elswhere.

Title: Financial Consultant - Branch
View8: Great training (actual curriculum and off sight classes), great benefits (7% match on 401k, profit sharing), great tools and resources (internal and external tools). Leads generated for you, and pretty good experience with all phone site reps and "spokes."
View10:
Great place to work for a very specific demographic. Everything is sales based, regardless of the "relationship model" that you hear about. Your success can depend on your geographical location, too. Some branches are extremely "flow heavy," while you really have to grind at others. 

There's a lot of talk about being wealth planners, but you may spin your wheels if you attempt it; there's simply no time to focus on anything that isn't closing a sale. 

Need to be employed for a whole year before match or profit sharing start. Vesting doesn't begin until you've been employed 2 full years.

Title: Sales Employee
View8: Good licensing and support for more certifications. Retirement benefits are good. Great financial license teachers and ongoing training. Good work/life balance. Good starter company for the industry then get out after vesting as so many do.
View10: Salary is the worst especially given the number of competitors in close proximity. No raises this year and many positions being cut. A fellow employee was literally let go due to persistently low customer surveys which you have to get a perfect score. Anything else counts as an F. If you get a good score you're still screwed. This employee had his CFP and masters paid for by the company. What an asinine  policy to spend all that money on someone and then walk them out.

Title: Financial Consultant
View8:
Great 401k match, profit sharing
Exposed to a lot of clients, so you get a lot of experience
View10:
Managers can dictate your future. They control lead flow, and can make you fail if they want.
Higher value leads are given to their inner circle
They say clients first, but it Fidelity's pockets first
They really only care about you selling managed accounts and annuities, and it's a big wheel you are running on. Every year it starts over, not what you did yesterday, what you are going to sell today and tomorrow.
They expect you to be making 40 calls per day, and having 3-4 appointments per day.
They attempt to stress work life balance, but it is impossible to take all that time off if you are running on the sales wheel.

Title: So-So
View8: The experience! You're surrounded by the best of the best-which makes you work that much harder. There can be great opportunity for advancement as long as you can keep your head down when need be, not step on too many toes and don't screw up.
View10: Ultra competitive, ALL THE TIME! Also not always the friendliest co-workers. It is often very political. If you rub someone the wrong way it can really set you back. It's also hard to get a lot of visibility for a job well done due to the shear size and the politics of the day to day.

Title: Fidelity has changed, but not for the better.
View8: Benefits were very good. In the early years there were people to share knowledge and people cared about one another. Back then it was possible to move ahead based on your work ethic and accomplishments.
View10: In recent years the company has created an atmosphere that seems to breed hostility and a need to put others down in order to keep a manager happy. No knowledge sharing because the general feeling is, if I don't tell anyone else, they cannot take my job away. Does not work, your job is probably going overseas anyway. Overseas not held to the standards stateside employees are. So it's not perfect, no problem. Not a way I ever thought Fidelity would behave.

Title: Past performance is not indicative of future returns-
View8: Finest facilities.  Great benefits and time off.  Flexible working hours for sales positions.  Terrific resources for information and training. done
View10: Lower level managers tend to be dropouts from the telephone rep positions.  They typically assume the "we" vs. "them" attitude toward reps.   The problem is that they stop listening to anything from below and develop a cutthroat attitude about their own careers.   Blackballing promotions of reps is common.   A manager has the last word on whether they want their rep to be promoted, regardless of who would like to hire them.    You will see managers advance many times before you move on yourself.

Title: It is very difficult to get ahead here
View8:
Profit Sharing/Company Match
Abundant work resources
Good camaraderie amongst most associates
The company genuinely puts the customer first
View10:
Compensation at Fidelity is extremely low. The company as an explicit policy of paying its associates far below market rate. The company cites its share programs and other ancillary benefits as a compensatory alternative. However, those benefits are doled out on a case-by-case basis. Most employees don't benefit from these programs. Also, compensation figures are arbitrary and there is a lack of transparency into compensation. Bonuses are literally figures on the back of a napkin
Management is generally clueless about the day-to-day and treats employees like indentured servants. Brown-nosing is the only way to get ahead in this company. Management only values the opinions of the sycophants within the company, which creates an acrimonious and preferential environment. The company is ultra-poltical; and, management is only concerned with appearances, as opposed to doing the right thing.

Title: Not Horrible- Not Great
View8: They pay for your 7 and 63 right off the bat. Young corporate culture, lots of room for growth
View10: Room for growth limited to positions in the call center. They will talk about other areas career-wise but those positions are extremely rare and very taboo to get into i.e. Branch, research, rotational programs, marketing etc. Hard time retaining talent because of pay scale and willingness to pay external hires much more than the people they hire in initially. Entry-level service managers come off arrogant and micro manage to the point the job is unbearable. Boast about retirement benefits when in reality you do not see profit sharing nor match for the first full year and none of it vests immediately after that. Job itself incredibly repetitive and not empowering for someone with a college degree.

Title: Fidelity - changing for the better or out of business in 5 years?
View8: Comp and benefits are solid.  Company is less "risky" than other financial institutions.  Even with the rough times over the last few months...some areas of the company are doing quite well.  Fidelity is also very large, so there are many internal opportunities.  Being private is also sometimes a positive since hitting quarterly earning targets is not a requirement and they can spend $$ if needed.
View10: Last couple of years have been a continual circle of re-organizations and changing priorities, projects are not finished before they are cancelled and the next one begins.  As a result morale is pretty low, and most associates are just going through the motions.  Many of the Sr. mgt team are from "the outside" so many of the strategies are new.

Title: Great company to start in
View8: Benefits are pretty amazing, 7% match dollar for dollar and 10% profit sharing as well.  great options for health insurance as well.  Training is also pretty good and you get a great opportunity to learn the industry.
View10: Depending on your role you could get stuck there for a while if there are no other job openings.  It's also pretty hard to move throughout different business units, so once you're in a certain business unit you're pretty much stuck there.  There's not a clear understanding of what other business units and do and what jobs are available there and how they pay.

Title: Director
View8: Great benefits, challenging projects, smart people who work hard and deliver quality output.
View10: Hard to move up in your career.  Your manager isn't really focused on your career growth just their success. I wish I could stay and grow my career with the company but feel like I am hitting a ceiling in my career. They really don't help you or encourage you to move outside of your group. You need to leave the company to pursue your next upward career move, get that next level of experience and then re-apply for a more senior position at Fidelity in order to move up in your career.  Sad to say but it is the reality at Fidelity.

Title: Old-fashioned giant in a shrinking industry
View8:
- Work life balance
- Good benefits
- 401k business is sheltered from global competition
View10:
- Technology org is extremely slow and inneffective
- Financial services industry is shrinking 
- Last real innovation from Fidelity was freedom funds which was decades ago
- Discriminates heavily against males
- Half the folks in leadership are empty suits

Title: Run FAR Away!!!
View8: Pretty campus,  promotes healthy eating, good benefits
View10: In accounting you are expected to make every deadline at cost. A co worker went to the hospital and was told "don't they have Wi-Fi?". They tout being able to work from home and having a laptop as a benefit. Sadly it just enables the expectation that you are available at all hours.  Tasks are often assigned with no training and there is a high possibility that most management doesn't know how to do it. However you are held to perfectionist standards with exacting measure. My department was constantly reorganizing and for several days in a row no one was quite sure what their job parameters or management was. Needless to say many people are leaving and they are not filling their spots. The poor people left are taking on the slack. It is not uncommon to see long leaves of absence due to the stress this job puts on your body. One co-worker had a medical exception on file and I constantly saw her having to work well outside what was advisable.

Title: Best Benefits Available, Great Opportunities For Advancement
View8:
Very focused on the employee experience.
The best, most extensive, and most customized benefits of any company I've ever worked for.
Well expressed values.
There is a lot of chance to try new things, moving  up, sideways, or diagonally while still remaining at the same company.
Leaving each day feeling that I actually had a down-steam impact on helping someone increase their financial wellness.
View10:
Pay tends to be lower than equivalent roles at other firms, but when you factor in the tax-advantages of the benefits offered, you often come out ahead of what a competing firm would pay.
There is a LOT of hierarchy here, So many departments and divisions that it is easy to loose touch with all that the company does.
It takes a couple years to get used to the internal Jargon - everything has an acronym!

Title: Associate Fund Reporting Analyst
View8: Low stress for associates and good flex to work from home. Bonus is decent if you get graded SP or above. Managers and most of the team are friendly people. It does provide good knowledge to take with you elsewhere.
View10: Pay is OK if you come somewhat experienced from the outside, but they screw over internal candidates which breeds a little bit of resentment from others (at least if you are on the outside). Recent org changes are causing frustration and gossip. Two team members in particular are complaining non stop.

Title: great company, great benefits, but things are different
View8: Fidelity has a great name.  Customers trust Fidelity.  The firm has tried to come up with innovative benefits to retain talent.
View10: Pay is low relative to the industry.  Fidelity's best days are behind it, but still a strong company.   Unfortunately management has evolved over recent years and now there is a bit of a toxic culture, where appreciation is not shown or felt by the rank and file.  The "new breed" of branch management is primarily to blame for this.

Title: Excellent Excellent Company— Terrible Pay
View8: Benefits, benefits, benefits. You’ve heard it before probably and they will drill it into your brain once hired. Their 7% plan match, 10% profit sharing, chairman shares, healthcare, and vacation structure is phenomenal. As a man, I received 6 weeks paid time off for paternity leave,  in addition to my regular 4 weeks PTO for vacation. Culture is great as well. Many things and perks to keep you happy while employed.
View10: You will hate your life. You will have mental break downs if you’re working on the phones. They push you to the absolute edge. The overtime pressure is relentless and the pay is below average for what you’re trained to do. Honestly the reason I left is the lay structure.

Title: I used to drink the green kool aid....
View8: The comapny has great benefits and the size means that for a smart, ambitious person, it becomes realyl easy to get ahead.
View10: You are just a number. The attitude was that if you didn't like the way it was, you were welcome to leave because there were always phone jockeys lined up behind you ready to take your job. In the phone sites, the training department and other off-phone jobs were so few and far between that politics and drama ensued as people tried desparately to keep their cushy jobs without phone headsets.

Title: Fidelity Investments is a great place to grow a career.
View8: Fidelity Investments is the ideal place to begin a career. The top-down leadership approach creates a culture of trust, transparency, friendly competitiveness and excellence. All levels of leaders invest countless hours in the development of their employees and the support provided to enhance your career is second to none. The company's values are visible in everything they do. It feels amazing to work for a company that sets clear direction, empowers employees to excel and then recognize and reward those who achieve.
View10: The sheer size of the company can seem overwhelming, but this is easily overcome by having such great leaders in place to provide guidance to their employees.

Title: Awful place to work.
View8: Decent, but expensive medical benefits, 20% computer purchase reimbursement, $250 annual fitness reimbursement, 7% company 401k match. Profit sharing.
View10: Pay below industry standard. They like to tell you that you are lucky that they hired you. Wear a short skirt, you can go far, or at least get paid for not working. If you make your CEI (Customer Experience Index) goals and lead goals, they raqise them so that you can't consistenly meet your goals so they don't have to pay you all of your bonus. Treated like your contribution is miniscule. This is a terrible place to work. Strange how so many young people are at Westlake. No one stays for very long. So many people just walk off the job, but they tell the new hires that "we're growing, that is why we're hiring". HA !

Title: Fidelity Financial Rep.
View8: The training program is one of the best training programs you could go through.  They do a good job of teaching you how to answer the phone in a professional manner and how to use the systems.  They give you study guidelines that will help you pass the Series 7 and 63 licenses.  Paid training, which includes studying for your licenses.
View10: Have to pass the Series 7 and 63 licenses within 3 months of starting there. They tell you that you will be studying completely for the first 6-8 weeks, but you end up answering phone calls for the 2nd half of the day starting the 4th week. And the first 3 weeks are teaching you how to answer phones and use the systems.

Title: general
View8: First and foremost Fidelity has been the best employer for my career  they hire great people and they know how to manage the potential of great leaders  many opportunities exist for transferring to other business units as well as locations which makes them Flexible  as a private company they value technology and networking with other great companies to remain the leader in the financial services industries of which I'm glad to be a part of
View10: Sometimes due to call volume overtime can be overwhelming therefore balancing life outside of work is a must  compared to other times of the year when call volume is not as much

Title: It's not quite the Borg, but it is an intense place to work. Not for the squeamish.
View8:
Diverse business lines present opportunities for internal movement
Many smart, customer-focused, collaborative professionals
Compensation including bonuses is lucrative, depending on job role
Many opportunities for internal training, especially for managers
Very structured, hierarchical environment which some people like
View10:
Extremely siloed, due to the diverse business lines and operational complexity
Constant, relentless organizational changes at all levels, with entire groups being relocated, realigned or disbanded without sufficient explanation
Communication from executive and senior management was lacking and/or confusing
Middle managers were under intense pressure to produce results but often not given the needed resources
Depending on group, morale was often a problem due to offshoring concerns

Title: Most toxic Corporate IT environment
View8:
Stable working environment and decent 401k benefits.
Working location in Boston is very good, right next to South Station
View10:
- Toxic and bullying IT environment
- Stupid and long-term relocation policy that alienates all IT workers. 
- Mostly a waste of time for any young IT professional I have talked to. Everyone left the company within 2 years. 

If you are a IT professional under age 30 and looking for a career, and not just a job that pays the rent, please stay far away from Fidelity. Do not believe anything they say. I once thought that a peaceful corporate environment would be okay. But I learned how a toxic environment can affect a worker's life and career potentials. It is not going to be worth your time to work in a company like Fidelity. I felt so much happier when I leave the place.

Title: Proud alum
View8: Fidelity is an evolving company with lots of opportunity for advancement. Excellent work life balance.  Excellent benefits.  Pay is good but more middle if the road compared to other companies
View10: Although advancement opportunities are good some areas are tough to advance in unless you are in Boston.

Title: Great start in the industry.....but it's a call center
View8:
Great opportunity to get your licenses(7 & 63)
Excellent benefits including tuition reimbursement and travel discounts
Thorough training program covering all manner of content
$1000 sign on bonus
View10:
Call center environment is physically and emotionally draining
Once you're branded a phone rep you have very little mobility unless you're willing to go to a branch or another phone role
Firm pushes career development focus but the only ones that move up either know the right people or get continually rejected for years until eventually getting a break
Having every second of your day tracked is nerve wracking

Title: I would not recommend Fidelity as an employer to my friends.
View8: The benefits are decent, you'll never get fired, and depending on the department, there usually is not much o/t required. Also they generally invest a fair amount in technology, unlike many other companies. The annual Christmas party is decent as well. There is no communication, within departments, from senior management on down, and within divisions. Most management is promoted to the highest level of their incompetence. The pay sucks, as do raises, because they think the fidelity name will make up for it (it won't).
View10: There is no communication, within departments, from senior management on down, and within divisions. Most management is promoted to the highest level of their incompetence. The pay sucks, as do raises, because they think the fidelity name will make up for it (it won't). The benefits are decent, you'll never get fired, and depending on the department, there usually is not much o/t required. Also they generally invest a fair amount in technology, unlike many other companies. The annual Christmas party is decent as well.

Title: Fidelity Investments Institutional Services
View8:
Very generous benefits - tuition reimbursement, computer & fitness reimbursement, $1:$1 company match on 401k up to 7%, free access to professional books with Safari Online, etc.
Comfortable working facilities.
Some really great managers (amongst those not so great).
Many career paths if you take the iniative to learn new areas of the business and are willing to relocate.
View10:
Unstable job security.
Frequent turnover of senior leaders which results in constant changes in direction.
Company is in a cost cutting mode and looking for opportunities to ship job overseas, even to places that do not have the experience to perform well (save a dime now to spend a dollar later to fix things up!)
New hires seem to be coming in at salary rates lower than what they used to offer - another cost cutting strategy.

Title: Living in the past, no opportunities
View8: Great benefits, beautiful campuses, great "fit" regime w/ great healthy food available in the cafeterias where it is dirt cheap for what you're getting, especially compared to the less healthy food.
View10: Very strict, living in the past, no opportunity for job growth. Employees are trapped in roles everywhere they go and are lied to about the role they are getting into. Management says one thing and does another - always tries to make things seem like what they are not. No vacation time available, ever. Only certain amount of hours on certain days allotted for the department and they'll be gone early in the year. Required overtime. "Clock in, Clock out" environment.

Title: Fidelity Investments
View8: Great company values - customers are first; generous benefits package (17% contribution to 401k); smart and dedicated employees.
View10: A lot of talk about career development and mobility but, unless you are SVP and above, efforts on this are check the box and not sincere. Biggest gap with this is at the VP/Director level since most SVPs don't sincerely help their directs with this since they have a "what's in it for me" attitude. To this - most promoted to SVP level based on being good talkers/managing up well even though they are horrible people managers (some of worst in firm).

Title: Not For Young Professionals
View8: Biggest selling point they offer is their benefits (generous PTO, student loan reimbursement, 401k match, etc.)
View10: I worked here full time for over three years and it was my first "real job" out of college.  Company has a very "boy's club" mentality. Most VPs, SVPs, Managers, etc. (in my experience and that I encountered) were men.  If you start here young and fresh out of college, I can almost guarantee you will want to leave after a couple years, but most likely sooner than that. The corporate environment is stifling. Position title means more here than the quality of the individual.  Fidelity's values and corporate policies will state otherwise, but that should only be taken at face value. You may luck out and end up having a great boss and senior leadership team, but from my experience, those are few and far between.  You are just a number here.

Title: Tiring and Thankless Job
View8:
- Will hire almost anyone who applies
- Benefits are good
- 401k match
- Potential to get licensed, where you go after that is up to you
View10:
- Definitely a call center, anyone who tells you different is lying
- Turnover rate is ridiculous, they hire 30 people a month to fill all the vacant roles
- Only real incentive is monetary
- Monitored on every call and if you don't have a high enough calls per hour you get in trouble
- You do not learn any real transferable skills, unless you go to another call center
- If you think you will switch roles quickly so you are not on the phones, expect to do a minimum of two years answering phones for 8 hours a day
- They tell you the customers are nice, but that is very far from the truth I would say roughly half are very rude

Title: On the brink of success or failure?
View8: There are great people here.  You need to stay away from the bad people and do not let them get you down.  It begins to feel like family and co workers really protect each other in there own group.
View10: Pay can be stingy at times and dumb VPs are left to run aprts of the company when they should be booted. My biggest pet peeve is how other groups abuse the crap out of each other.  Within your own group things are fine, but it is your group against the rest of the company.  There is no team work across the company.  Many of our issues here could be solved by some good old teamwork and dicussion.  The Fidelity Fifedoms are still very evident and those barriers need to be broken down.

Title: An OK place to start a career, but greatly stifling to young talent.
View8:
Good benefits, excellent 401k matching and profit sharing opportunities.
Opportunity to work on very large and very visible systems.
High-quality employees, lots of talent.
View10:
Salaries are not competitive - below industry standards.
Lots of shuffle in upper management, too much "old" talent at those levels.
Salt Lake City in particular, not a great place to work at Fidelity due to lack of visibility compared to Boston/east coast locations.
No possibility for very talented young workers to advance to appropriate positions, leading to boredom and general lack of job satisfaction.

Title: HR and Management are good at using fear as a motivator.  Leadership is non-existent.
View8: Co-workers are pleasant and accommodating for the most part. Work environment is clean and well kept.
View10: Top heavy HR and management at all levels have created an environment where fear is the motivator. Knowledge, skill, and experience are not factors in determining raises and promotions. Managers and some co-workers who seek attention from management will agree to any ridiculous request and deadline. This company has lost many high quality employees and will continue down this long and slippery slope until they figure out how to create a real team culture.

Title: This place is a joke!
View8: Good experience to use on a resume, even though the job was absolutely horrible.
View10: If you want to work in a call center then this is the job for you! Mindless "diversified" managers who are absolutely clueless. They will say you are trained as a "trader" but you are only a client service rep working for crap money. They preach the "culture" and "what is possible". Well, the reality is the culture is corporately sickening and the fact that the ones who have a clue leave before the green Kool Aid totally zaps the life out of you. ISR managers are a joke. They call ISR a "sales job", but they are just phone jockeys who can only talk about target date funds. Good luck to any of you who get sucked into the rah rah! Get your experience and run away as fast as you can.

Title: Brokerage Operations Associate
View8: Benefits are competitive (401K, health insurance etc.). However, salaries are below industry average.
View10: Management disconnect (poor understanding) of the actual work their teams perform.... team managers are mainly responsible for administrative tasks to ensure teams continue to function! Many team managers lack the technical skills and professional certifications that many in their teams are required to possess. This leads to a very confined way of working and thinking about processes, problems, and solutions in the department as a whole. Plus the metrics used to assess employee / team performance are outdated.... based on production type of work environments (like sales call centers, manufacturing etc), and not suitable for a company operating in the financial services industry.

Title: Come for the salary but don't stay for career advancement.
View8: High salary.  Many offices subscribe to a 9-5 day and don't expect much overtime so it can be a family-friendly atmosphere. A lot of smart, talented people. Generally thorough review process means you'll get regular feedback (even though it might not turn into any recognition for a job well done).
View10: Very little opportunity for career advancement in a lot of groups, and unclear criteria for promotion. Top-heavy management bloat and low turnover prevents upward movement. There's a good chance your role & responsibilities will get narrower over time, rather than broader and more challenging/exciting. Expect many of your colleagues to be frustrated that they're not being used to their potential.

Title: Getting Better, still will work you to the bone.
View8: Benefits are the number one reason people work at Fidelity.  The 401k match is 7%, then another 10% in profit sharing in January each year. Its pretty amazing, but understandable since the money goes straight into Fidelity funds.  The people are generally good at there jobs and work very hard for the company.
View10: Fidelity will work you to the bone, especially in technology where Senior Management continually picks arbitrary dates for when projects need to be delivered.  This causes cramped analysis time and due to the archaic architecture, issues always come up at the last minute.

Title: Decent first job out of college but do your research on what career path you would like to take.
View8: Great people to work with. You go through extensive, thorough training with people you will get to know very well with great facilitators leading your class. Great benefits such as 401(k), medical, dental, life insurance etc. You may also attain a number of professional licenses in the financial industry depending on your position. Good opportunity for advancement if you are the type of person that can handle taking calls.
View10: If you work in one of the call centers, the work can become repetitive. You have to adhere to rather tight schedule requirements such as 15 minute breaks and 2-3 hours at a time taking inbound calls. Also, you are evaluated on criteria such as how many calls you take in a certain time frame and how long the conversations take you to complete. If you like speaking with people over the phone, however, you may enjoy it.

Title: Group's leadership is ruthless
View8: Compensation is generous. Time can be flexible. Benefits are outstanding. Negative culture is limited to my current group - however, it's a Con that the bad behavior is an open secret in the firm.
View10: Leadership is lacking. Fear is the current culture. Employees in my group are not valued. There is no credibility in reporting - negative messages are not accepted. Mobility is not encouraged or tolerated. Group leadership uses position and the necessity of partnering relationships with other groups to intimidate and manipulate outcomes.

Title: Great place to work, if you find the right people or work
View8: Senior leadership's heart is in the right place. They are trying to up skill their workforce and the technology stack. Decent incentives and benefits. Modernization improves every year.
View10:
Base pay is pretty good wrt their traditional competition, but not wrt to technology companies, you might be disappointed if you don't shop around first.

Senior leadership likes to start new initiatives, but not follow through on them for more than a year.

There are certain key people in the company who like to build kingdoms, and play politics. This can be tough for a naive hard working employee trying to get recognition for their job.

Business people are still very tech illiterate.

Title: Business Analyst
View8: Great PTO, Work Life Balance, Culture is non-competitive, and multiple chances for people to improve. In other words, you have to really do terrible, and I mean show up for work every single day late, talk back to the manager, never do any work, in order to be fired because if you are trying your best and doing okay they will work with you. This is a place I would love to have when I'm 40-Retirement.
View10: If you are young, it isn't a place where you are put under the gun. Extremely slow growth and tenor means everything. So if you are trying to grow your career I would not go here because it is slow and you will be extremely frustrated. In addition, pay is mediocre because they make up for it in benefits, which you aren't too concerned about when you are young.

Title: Workplace Investing transaction processor
View8: Great benefits - 401K, PTO, healthcare, profit sharing, etc. there’s almost no other companies that can match all of what fidelity offers associates
View10: They pay way less than competitors and keep you here due to the good benefits. Work life balance is bad and Workplace Investing does a terrible job of making their associates feel valued. Upper management seems to be completely disconnected to the associates who actually do all the work and put all the hours in to make the operation go smoothly. It’s hard to get out of WI unless you know someone or put the time in shadowing other depts for months and months before any position is available.

Title: Overall Incredible, typical challenges with large institution
View8: Unparalleled Benefits. Work from Home, Great Managers, Excellent leadership, Industry leader, Unbelievable training and development programs
View10: Company internal Politics, difficult to break out of certain role types

Title: High stress role, but an excellent place to start a career
View8: People are friendly. Management are very supportive. There is a lot of room to grow and change to new roles within the company. I'm a white trans woman and never got misgendered once while at work (except occasionally by clients), no one treated me weird and I even got offered promotions and things.
View10: The phones role is high stress, so an ability to separate work time from your personal time is vital. This is hard to do when everything is work from home. The licensing can be tough. There wasn't a lot of room for people with learning differences to get support during licensing. If you're not a good test taker and struggle to read all day and memorize information for an exam, you will have to advocate for yourself for the support you need.

Title: Lately it is not the "Great Company" to work for that it once was!!
View8: Benefits, education, and the ability to work with some of the best people in the industry.
View10: With the so called Global economy salaries and benefits are not what they once were. Also, with the recent layoffs and consolidation of jobs, this creates more work and hours for those of us who are left and for less pay.

Title: Employees are micromanaged "resources"
View8: It was until recently, in growth mode and was a very positive place to work.  The layoffs have put an extreme dark cloud on the job.  Coworkers and people there have been fantastic to work with.  I've made good friendships and have found it to be a professional and friendly environment.  Work-life balance in my group was really great.
View10: Serious lack of career growth and opportunities for advancement.  I am treated like a contractor -- not like an employee. And you can expect to be micro-managed to the greatest degree possible.     I would have thought it was just me, but it also happens to my coworkers.  Also, I am constantly referred to as a "resource" vs. a team member.

Title: Great benefits,but hard to move up the ladder
View8: The people are generally bright and very pleasant to work with.  The company invests a lot in training and development.  They'll pay for professional certifications and have a generous tuition reimbursement plan.  Retirement and health benefits are excellent- 7% match, plus profit sharing and a company funded retirement health savings plan.  Private ownership and strong financial status make it a relatively secure place to work.
View10:
The base pay is mediocre.  There is little opportunity to advance from entry to mid-level positions.  In some groups the politics and favoritism can be an issue, but it definitely not the case everywhere in the company. 
The review system does not do a great job of differentiating between employees, so it can be difficult to stand out.

Title: The most political and conservative organization in the world!
View8: Fidelity's name brings business, large book given to account executives to manage, decent work/life balance, good medical, good retirement benefits if you can make it that long
View10: pay between job functions is very unfair. people are promoted because they need to fill a seat. it is the most political organization in the world.  people are fired at the drop of the hat and are often targeted for termination. they often implement changes to the compensation structures well into the quarter and then make it back dated.

Title: Rep
View8: They have great benefits, although their employee insurance cost is still high.
View10: Not much opportunity for pay increases once you're hired even if you change jobs within the organization.  They have a superficial purpose to increase how many women work there.  They definitely try to keep the women out of the higher paying positions and o at them less to start  with.  They are very male dominating company because for years and still now in most of their departments it is run my (some older) white males, especially in Utah and for many remote positions.  They promote women or give them accolades only when they have to show they ate equal opportunity.   And that's just the beginning of their discriminating atmosphere.  Their CEO is amazing but she doesn't get any respect from her male EVPs or VPs from overhearing them talk.

Title: Wonderful place to work, if you’re in the right business unit at the right time given constant transformation.
View8: Oppourtunities and professionalism of the company.
View10: Depending on when and where “transformation” travels, can get tough.

Title: Fidelity has changed for good!
View8:
Lots of smart people
Excellent Benefits and compensation
Very good work life balance
View10: It's a very big organization and it can be complicated to maneuver around within different business lines

Title: Fidelity is great and Audit is an excellent place to start a career, but back office work can get stale after a while.
View8: Excellent work/life balance and culture. Benefits are unrivaled and base pay is competitive. Strong emphasis on collaboration and personal development. Exposure to a wide range of businesses and functions with room to specialize in areas of interest. Great pool of talent to work with/learn from. The work is dynamic and engaging, but never overwhelming.
View10: Highly political, promotions are generally based on time served instead of merit, adoption of Agile has resulted in more time spent in meetings than auditing. Leadership is more focused on pleasing clients than issuing good audit reports. High turnover as a result of top talent often being underutilized.

Title: Great company to work for
Position: Fidelity High Net Worth - Financial Representative
View8: Fidelity has a good culture and great group of people to work with. Very supportive and many opportunities to move up within the company. There are opportunities every quarter and you can get promoted multiple times in a calendar year if you're performing. And if you're not performing, they're typically very supportive and try to find constructive ways to help you improve.  Benefits are great. You start off with 18 days PTO and after 2 years you get 23 days PTO off per year. OT is frequently available if you want it.
View10: The calls can beat you up on some days. Majority of the managers I've had were good,  but just like any job your experience will also partially depend on who you have as a boss. There are some that are not ideal; however, most managers are encouraging and helpful in your career path.

Title: Fidelity is a good place to work if you want to work in the financial sector.
View8: The best reasons to work for Fidelity are the benefits, the compensation versus other financial institutions, and the ability to work from home when it is necessary.  I wa blown away by the compensation I got this year and how it shows that they actually pay for performance.
View10: There is a lot of red tape around getting things done, especially at the software development level.  Sometimes they also squash creativity but it gets better over time.  The one thing to know about this is that it is all about the group that you get into and who you work for.

Title: Mobility is the biggest benefit to Fidelity!
View8: It is unlikely that you'll ever get bored in a role at Fidelity.  However, if you do get bored or feel like you need a new challenge, Fidelity is usually able to accommodate!  Along with mobility, you get experience, and with experience you become more valuable to the company.  Fidelity is very good about allowing its employees to gain other experience.
View10: The company is very numbers-driven so, with that said, it should come as no shock that meeting and exceeding rigid quotas is of utmost importance...to the point where quality is sacrificed just to 'crank out the numbers.'

Title: Great company but something to consider
View8: Overall I think Fidelity is a great company, the fact that its privately own makes it more immune to market volatility and the year-end bonuses have been fairly consistent
View10:
The promotion process is a complete mystery and it appears to be highly political
Once you reach a certain level (director) within IT at least there are no annual market adjustments, so every year you are in theory making less money.  Plus there are no catch-up adjustments.
When applying to a job at the same level the policy is that you cannot get a salary increase, even if the job is vastly different and within a different business unit.  Which means overall you are stuck at your current salary unless you look outside the firm

Title: Financial Sales
View8: Very flexible with schedules and time off for family reasons. great 401k match plus yearly pension payment. health insurance is affordable, HSA yearly payment from the company.
View10: very very slow making changes to be more competitive.  There are some very poor EVPs, mis-matched alignments in upper management service groups managing sales organizations and the resulting loss of long term focus and goals.  This call center is very "good ole boys club",  promotion is all about who you know.  The pay is very low compared to competitors in the same region.  For being a privately held company who manages a trillion dollars have not had a pay increase in over 10 years and management of my group has very specifically changed quarterly comp goals in order to pay employees less for the same amount of work.  Can be a very toxic environment but those situations seem to come and go

Title: Limited career advancement
View8:
Good pay for a high school graduate.  Good benefits. Standard 40 hr week.  If you want a place where you can do minimal effort and answer calls all day, while still receiving a paycheck- this is it. 
Great company to start your career if you only plan to stay 2 years or less.
View10: No upward mobility. Top heavy senior management.  Company does not reward for education or experience.  Negligible pay raises.  If you care about advancement and challenge, look elsewhere.  Not a place to grow a career.

Title: Great but not perfect
View8: Great company with customer-centered culture. Great benefit package, and depending on your role, you may have flexible schedule or the ability to work some of your shifts from home as an option. Great at helping employees earn licenses, certifications, and business related degrees.
View10: They tend to compensate employees below the average for the industry and hope that the benefits are enough to keep employees around. If not, they seem to prefer hiring and training new employees to paying current employees more in an effort to retain them.

Title: Tough love
View8: Fidelity has some of the highest paying jobs out there in New Hampshire, but unfortunately that doesn't say much (see below). Fidelity is a very easy place to start a career in financial services and learn the business from the ground up.
View10: Being a huge company can make getting noticed not so easy here. The corporate culture discourages risk-taking but I think that is something upper management is starting to realize. Fidelity used to be a place that encouraged and developed risk-taking, entrepreneurialism and bold ideas. Office politics are rampant here. The pay is good but much more can be made elsewhere if you take the initiative to look and to relocate outside New Hampshire.

Title: Deteriorating culture, talent pool diminishing , management self serving, seasoned reps run.
View8:
Fast promotion early phase career due to seasoned talent leaving pockets for movement.
Fair work life balance.
Free coffee. 
Benefits are ok but they are slowly being taking away
50 years of brand recognition (good)
Great relationships with peers.
View10:
Firm having identity crises. Technology is getting worse with wasteful spending. Clients are treated like numbers, now that reps are forced to act like a Wire house brokers. I 
 Don't know many SAE's who want to stay. They are all looking they just don't want the firm to know. Reps know company surveys to employees can be pulled so it's incorrect data.
Micro management is immense!!! They even make the reps enter the data for the spreadsheets for upper management. Reps can not even do their job with these time wasters.

Title: Good training program, learned a lot, but definitely not a career
View8:
-Comprehensive Training
-Medical/dental insurance start immediately
-Plenty of overtime available
-On-site gym ($20/month), additional insurance $$ for healthy living incentives
-On high-call days the company tries to do something nice for the team (snacks, food, etc)
View10:
-Out of an 8 hour day, expect to be on the phones all 8 hours. Little development time
-Very poor optical insurance
-Overtime is expected and will effect your bonus
-Very repetitive (almost every call is someone wanting to raid their 401k)
-No discretion so customers will yell at you and there often are long holdtimes to get help on a call
-All your time is monitored (typical call center) so everytime you go on break, lunch or to the bathroom expect it to be tracked

Title: Great starter job
View8: My manager is really nice. The work and life balance is pretty good. Teammates are very willing to help. As a fresh college graduate, this is a great opportunity to learn about the IT industry and to sharpen my programming skills.
View10: There was a big learning curve about the application that I am supporting and a lot of knowledge are not well documented in the team. It was a lot of trial and errors for me to figure out exactly how things are being done here. Even though we are agile, people are working on their own stuff and there isn't a lot of communication between team members. It also seems like performance isn't really based on merit but rather the length of time you have been in the team.

Title: Great Company
View8: Benefits are awesome! I can't complain about any of them.  The cafeteria can be good.  It has a lot of healthy choices.  Most of which are cheaper than the less healthy choices.
View10: I wish it were easier to change shifts. The cafeteria is not available after the lunch hours.  I find this inconvenient for the later shifts.  There is a shop that is open a little later, however, the food available is not as good.  Mostly sandwiches that are not as healthy.  They are very limited in choices.  There is no time to leave, if you are on the phones, so bringing a lunch is almost always the choice.

Title: Work with clients that have assets of 250k or more.
View8: Flexible schedule and a lot of very nice people. There's very good support in anything you do. The benefits of having a 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing is ok but not great.
View10: The pay is low compared to other companies and taking call after call is tiresome. Newly hired people are started off at higher rates than long term employees. They always brag about the benefits but don't pay enough to actually use them. It's possible to actually be driven to quit by management if they don't like you. I've seen it happen too often and the company is somewhat sexist towards men.

Title: Great place to begin your career in financial planning
View8: Good culture that rewards you for taking great care of clients. Fidelity contributes 17% of your salary into your 401k each year (7% match plus 10% profit sharing contribution). Health care plan is affordable and has amazing coverage (90 / 10). Great coaching and mentoring staff - you have all the other consultants in the office to learn from (many of them CFP practitioners), your branch manager who used to be a consultant, another dedicated coach to help you be a better planner, and various product experts (annuities, life insurance, LTC, managed money products, etc.). Fidelity also paid for 100% of my CFP coursework, classes, and exam.
View10: Compliance documentation can take some getting used to. Advancement has been limited to backfilling turnover right now (headcount neutral) as opposed to adding jobs. No ETA on if/when job growth will pick back up.

Title: Good Place to Work, but it depends on the project.
View8:
Nice people, good benefits.
The company is not publicly held so things are stabler than other large tech companies.
There's a lot of opportunity for growth if you stay in the company.
Many people stay for a long time because there is opportunity for good work life balance.
View10:
Business runs everything, ultimately.
Many resctrictions and blockers because of security and the scale of their projects.
 If you work in tech, this gets in the way of innovation and using the newest technologies. 
The difficulty and pressure of the job depends on the project you have.
The project I was working on was very high profile and very high pressure.

Title: A Great Place to Start
View8: Big Office environment with great exposure to corporate culture. Very friendly and open culture in the back and middle office, Great in the job training with a huge knowledge base within the company
View10: Its very easy to get lost and go unnoticed because of the size and scope of the operation. Trying to be an agent of change is also very difficult because of the size of the company. Benefits and pay are the best in the industry for middle office jobs but the grind and the lack of tools to use that are available in the industry are difficult to overcome

Title: Good postgrad job or for moving up the call center "status" ladder
View8: Benefits package. Onsite amenities. Weight "Fidelity Investments" carries on a resume going forward into any field, not just financial, due to reputation and vetting process.
View10: WAY TOO CORPORATE. Ramrod you through training and expect you to be an expert afterwards. "Coaching moments" just corporate bullet points, no concrete help to improve. It's a call center, and it's in regards to people's money to amplify it - very stressful being on the phone all day. The only vertical movement is moving up financial customer service rolls via licensing, etc. while still being on the phone all day. It's a meat factory. If you don't pick it up right away once you're on your own (become an "expert") you're in trouble.

Title: A retirement company you will not retire from. Over 8000 American jobs offshored.
View8: Good pay and benefits but over the years they have lessened as profits continue to soar.
View10:
Profits continue to soar but could start doom and gloom predicted. I mean how much many billions does the Johnson family need? 

18 years and replaced by offshore and then asked to train them. You will not retire here unless your executive management or in the circle of trust. Now they are offering age 55 and over buyouts even with 20% 3.4B in record profits  2/17.

Title: Excellent Community to be a part of!
View8: Fidelity is genuinely a good company that seeks to do the right thing for their customers and their people. They invest heavily in trying to improve and prepare for the future and respond to what clients and associates need to feel supported.
View10: Like all large companies, people quit managers more than they quit jobs. The company does try and help managers improve, but it is still a challenge if you do not get a good one. Also, many departments can feel like a silo; you may not like the lack in variety of jobs in your business arm and it can sometime feel difficult to move to a different department if you have already established yourself in another one. Again, I feel this is recognized and investment is made to try and fix it to move more freely across the company, but some roles will not change.

Title: Good place to work, weak management
View8: Excellent benefits. Health Insurance for a family is reasonable, the 10% drop into your 401K for profit share each year was always a plus in January. No vision insurance offered, but good dental, 4 weeks of vacation after 5 years, plus all market holidays. Seldom have to work weekends or past 6pm.
View10: Management has way to may priorities throwing you in a number of different directions. The fire drill method of management makes it hard to no what to focus on. The middle management is hit or miss, you either have someone to help you move up, or someone who is afraid you'll take their job.

Title: Associate
View8: great and knowledgeable associates, good benefits, just-announced student loan assistance program.  fitness equipment reimbursement program.
View10: The company's hyper obsessed with statistics, and although the benefits are pretty good, the pay isn't.  Fidelity demands a lot out of you.  It leaves very little free time.  The roles are sometimes very stressful.  As somebody in another comment said, this company's trying to be way too many things at once.  They send WAY too many "xxx manager's joining this team" emails that come across as self-congratulatory and crowd out more relevant messages.  Some managerial decisions--especially re: recent software updates--make no sense (financial or otherwise).  The company--and some managers in particular--love to micromanage associates, though I've heard that may change starting next year.

Title: Full Trader
View8: They will teach you everything you need to know about the stock market, the training is exceptional. Pay and benefits are average but they are very generous with bonuses. In the middle of a growth spurt so lots of new opportunities and career progressions. They are also hugely profitable and a Juggernaut in the industry, you will have no fear in the company going under.
View10: They are growing their client base faster then they can hire new representatives. As a result the work load is severe, inflexible hours and mandatory overtime. You have to book your vacations about 6 months in advance in order not to have corporate operations deny your time off requests. The job is also very repetitive once you know what you are doing and as such it is very easy to burn out.

Title: Employee-Centered
View8: Fidelity provides amazing benefits, looks out for their people, and makes sure to stay competitive in pay and perks. I have never encountered an employer that put so much toward the well being of their employees! Your manager pulls for you personally, even if you're applying for a different department, and coaches you to your full potential.
View10: With the amazing benefits, Fidelity does expect a significant turnaround of work. There is occasionally mandatory overtime for service-level associates, and average stats are expected, since there are so many associates to keep track of, so your evaluation isn't always very personalized-feeling when it comes to applying for other roles in the company.

Title: Work Culture is changing rapidly
View8: Good total compensation (Base+Bonus+Profit Sharing (10% flat goes to 401k account)+7% $to$ 401K match+ Good Health Insurance). That's why the total comp otherwise the base may be lower than other companies. It helps if you are more than 5 years with the company.
View10: Work Culture is changing rapidly. It is not the company that it used to be, regularly laying off senior people with some or other excuses and hiring at the same time at lower level. Being a very big company, groups works in silos. So, some group may be worst than the other, specially if you are applying in SIPD group, careful. Very unstable.

Title: very lukewarm, uxd intern
View8: Probably the biggest perk is the great pay as an intern. There are a bunch of really smart and friendly people to learn from if you seek them out, and the culture is really fun. People are generally  very friendly.
View10: Management was oppressive, even as an intern. No one seemed to know really what should be going on, and direction was incredibly scattered. Really likes to brag about their tech capabilities and resources, but interns were using incredibly old and faulty computers that many times would fail when we needed them to do our work.

Title: Toxic culture for those looking to become the best version of themselves
View8: The people I work alongside everyday and Fidelity's clients are amazing. They are what I'll always reflect back on as being the best part of my experience while being at the company.
View10: If you want leaders who are just as enthusiastic about the success of others as they are their own, you will never find that at any level of the company. If you are looking for a meritocracy where the best ideas win out, where the best performers are recognized, and where the right people end up in the right positions, you will never find that at Fidelity Investments.

Title: Great Company, Average Environment
View8: Great benefits, including tuition reimbursement and student debt repayment. Large company so it stands out on your resume for the future.
View10: Like with most larger companies, the people doing the most work are being paid the least to do what everyone in the company agrees is the worst job: answering phones. A lot of talk about mobility, but once you come into a certain position, you're pigeonholed into that career track unless you want to take a pay cut.

Title: Zero leadership, not worth the stress
View8: Large company, lots of designers, benefits
View10: Too large a company, the product teams you're working with are rarely if ever in the same state and there is very limited leadership or guidance from management. Onboarding took about a month, and there were delays in getting set up with equipment but meetings with teams and product were set up day 1, without any insight from leaders about what we were expected to design. Their mentality is to drop you in the ocean and see how you do, but it's unfair and unrealistic expectations.

Title: Love this place in 1999.  It is a completely different company to work for in 2011.
View8: a) Benefits - Medical, Vacation and 401k Match
View10:
I am not sure what happen between 1999 and 2011, but this place is completely different.  They treat their US employees like cattle that they can move to any location in the US to save a dollar and they think we will all follow like little lambs.  How much money does the Johnson family need?  Boston is where they made this company what it is today, and now they are leaving.  They say it is not due to costs - but is clearly is the reason.  

There are minimal promotion opportunities for the hard-working employee.  Only those who play politics get anywhere at Fidelity.  It forced the people who really get the work done to look elsewhere.

Title: Good for short-term
View8:
1. Beautiful Campus 
2. Nice cafeteria and break-areas
3.Professional and competent staff. 
4. Management is hands-off
5. Availability of resources required to complete work
View10:
1. Management is aloof, arrogant. Doesn't know whats really going on. Out of touch with staff. 
2. Management draws conclusions without investigating facts.
3. Contractors are not treated as part of the team. For example, contractors are three to a cubicle while employees have their own. There are many unoccupied cubicles.

Title: bad work environment and bad company policies.
View8: the pay was decent, the benefits are better than nothing and the 401K was ok but only if you work there your entire career
View10: the work place is very cliquish and catty. Women are treated badly, there is an undercurrent of sexism. If you are too intelligent or too attractive, be prepared for a lot of hostility. Also very bigoted. They employ minorities but then treat them as "token" employees and there is definitely an undercurrent among white workers that you don't socialize or date outside of your race. If your a conservative , very conservative bigot ..and a very suburban woman..then you'll probably do just fine

Title: Gave my all to a company that didn't give it back.
View8: The salary for entry-level associates is great and there are a lot of benefits given to the employees
View10: Fidelity's quality and effectiveness goals have been increased steadily so that even one misspelled word, missed punctuation, or keeping a client on hold more than 30 seconds can cause you to get written up. Also there's hardly ever openings for promotions.

Title: Good start in financial services but other firms probably pay better.
View8: Great training, opportunity to learn the business and get licenses. Challenging roles allow you to learn a good deal about the brokerage business.
View10: Squeeze every ounce of patience by adherence to at least 5-10 metrics while your also dealing with demanding customers. Rigid and non flexible hours. Internal staffing doesn't care about your career development, it actually seems easier to look for a job outside than internal. Limited opportunities to advance from a phone role, not much in terms of support, almost feels like the company doesn't want you to move.

Title: Solid salary, great benefits and hard-to-beat work/life balance
View8: 401(k) profit sharing plan appears unequaled, benefits truly show that employees are valued, salary is solid and the work/life balance is one of the biggest perks.
View10: Can only speak for IT, but management has demonstrated a remarkable disconnect with employees and created confusion and discontent with some of their most valuable employees through poor and inexplicable promotion and assignment decisions.

Title: Solid company (I'm in IT dept) who wants to stay up to date and ahead of the curve
View8: Work/life balance, pay and benefits, LEAP training program, opportunities for advancement, recognition for good work (I have a great manager and team, there's only so much the company can do vs the people you work with), internal moves not only available but encouraged. Tons of discounts, from cell phone bill to cars. NC offices received new desks that can raise and lower ans well as two huge monitors
View10: Some people can be difficult to deal with, but that applies to any job anywhere. That's about it in terms of the company itself.

Title: Great company  overall.
View8: Great company, with lots of resources. Fantastic benefits and good pay. Company is evolving, and well poised for the next phase of industry shifts. Incredibly strong brand in financial services. Highly ethical and virtuous company. Privately owned, less susceptible to market cycles.
View10:
Big companies can be slow to change, but Fido is heading in right direction. 

The fundamental belief in active management from senior leaders sometimes slows the pace of innovation and is too often the reason for decisions vs. data or industry trends. 

Like everywhere in financial services, expense management is intensely tight.

Title: Glorified call center job
View8: Reputable private company with good benefits.
View10: The company/hiring managers are not looking for experience, creativity, or diversity in candidates. They want young and cheap (and White.) They want you to advice clients with written scripts and one-size-fit-all investment models, albeit the obvious fact that each client is unique. Team-oriented culture usually means everyone looks and sounds identical. It is a private company, so they can run the business whatever way they want, without any pressure from the public in regards to diversity and inclusion. In interview, they often tell you that the median pay for FC is around 165k, with many earn above 200k. The base is about 45k, most people get paid around the base. That's one of the many reasons why the company struggles with high turnover.

Title: Be prepared to be pressured to upsell and micro managed.
View8: Benefits, technology and people are great.
View10: On surface, Fidelity tell you to do the right thing and best interest for client. On paper you are expected to push managed account, annuity, have 30 appointments. They will force you to hit metrics to avoid weekly one on one with management and come up with a plan on how will you improve going forward. They are constantly hiring of consultants, when I came in with another new hire. The other guy left after 4 months and I stuck it out for 8 months because I need a new job. You can expect weekly meetings on everyone’s production numbers and put you on the spot if you did not meet management expectations. Fidelity will churn and burn you and there will be a next person to replace you.

Title: I miss what it used to be.
View8: It's a solid company, for the most part, and I say that knowing that my job will soon be coming to an end. My business unit is going away, but they have been upfront with us about that decision and I appreciate that. I'd have no intention of leaving if it wasn't for the fact the my job is going away.
View10: It has been Dilbert-ized a lot in recent years. I have loved working for this company, but it has gone down hill a lot since Roger Lawson came in. I'm glad he's leaving, but I think it's a bit too late.

Title: A Great Place to Start
View8:
Series 7 & 63 are paid for and the training program is excellent, they are paying a lot of money to license you and really want you to pass.
There are multiple shifts available to you which you bid for, and most people receive their first choice in shifts.
Amazing, supportive co-workers.
The best technology I have used in the Finance industry.
401(k) matching is among the best in the industry, but annual salary is not competitive.
Good work/life balance.
Team outings each quarter.
View10:
The call volume is ridiculous, and you spend most of your time resetting passwords, even once you are on the full-trader gate.
Fidelity talks a lot about career development, but team meetings and one-on-one coaching sessions with your manager are constantly canceled due to call volume.  A manager cannot develop his/her employees without ever speaking with them.
Even when you are promoted you do not get a raise, you get an increase in variable comp, and that is determined by whether you hit your metrics.  You can get a "promotion" without ever getting a "raise".
Management is hit-or-miss.  I worked for a couple of amazing, hands-on managers who were very engaged with their teams. I also worked for a few managers that appeared to do nothing other than sit around and play games on their phones all day.
A lot of push-back from different departments when you try to transfer calls.
Metrics are constantly changing.  What is important one quarter may be meaningless the next quarter.  It makes it very difficult to try to establish a routine on your calls when you don't know what measurements your bonus will be based on.
This is a call center job.  Don't try to kid yourself, you will be on the phones 8 hrs/day.  Unless you get a position in a branch, you will be on the phones, even if you are "promoted" to another role.

Title: Disappointing
View8: Good benefits, Honest company with good morals
View10: Two pay cuts in less than 6 months, Overly concerned about liability to the point that it can be detrimental to the customer, Job flexibility and work/life balance has been significantly reduced

Title: Pay for Performance is not all it is cracked up to be
View8: Has opportunity for those willing to work extremely hard, Benefits are great, and the company is stronger than most financial services firms out there.  They are a private firm so there are no "Shareholders" to pander to.
View10: 40 hour work week is not an option need to work 55+ hours per week and not get paid for it, Bonus restructured so TOP employees get all comp others get minimum.  Employees who have worked there a long time get small changes in comp while new hires comp is more premium.  you need to leave the company and come back in a higher postion to get any significant changes in compensation or title

Title: Did a summer internship there.  Dilbert became less a joke and more of a documentary after.
View8: Paid very well, silly but nice perks with things like a gym with personal trainers and pretty nice cafeteria.  Nicely maintained grounds.
View10: Everything else, nepotism was king.  Meritocracy died a lonely death a long time ago.  Large meetings were sessions of the "blame game" with discussions about how things should be "moving forward".  X Y scatter plots are not to be used in presentations, even if they are the only sane way to display the information.  We love pie, and pie charts.

Title: Phone sites good, branches bad
View8: Great benefits, excellent training and if you are working in one of the large sites, there is lots of opportunity for movement.  Pay isn't based on commission and Fidelity has a great pipeline for business so the leads come to you.
View10: Pay is lower than at other firms and the company is super conservative.  Guidance and recommendations will be based on tools with almost zero actual input from the financial reps themselves.  If you want to interact with clients, you'll either be on the phones or in a branch.  The branches have very little room for advancement and depending on the manager, can be very frustrating and demoralizing.  Average tenure for an Account Executive is less than a year due to attrition.

Title: Good place to start...Positive atmosphere...Low pay
View8:
1.) The company invests a lot of money in Learning and Development including paying for your licenses and maintaining them in 53 states.

2.) The morale of the place is very encouraging for the most part. Upper management really does well at maintaining a positive work environment that is uplifting for its employees.

3.) Benefits package is pretty spectacular if you stay for over a year.

4.) You take so many calls that you are forced to learn ALOT and FAST! It's very good if you don't have a finance background like myself.
View10:
1.) Low Pay
2.) Small Bonuses
3.) The micromanaging of call stats
4.) On the phone all day and since the company is the biggest in the financial industry the calls never stop coming. ever.

Title: Decent place to get your financial licenses, and thats about it.
View8: Paid study time to pass exams.
View10: Fidelity is one of those "we grew too fast for our own good" companies.  From 1990 to 2000, the employee base grew exponentially and alot of people who had no business being in any sort of management role found themselves in charge of other people in management.
