Fidelity now cannot care about their new recruits having bachelor's or master's degrees, because many of the site directors have only high school diplomas to their name.  The national director of phone centers is working on a bachelor's degree.  There is no reward for education or effort, and for a while the quickest way to get into a manager position was to be female--hardly any other qualification was needed.

Title: High Net Worth Representative
View8: If you are lucky to land on a great team there will be unlimited opportunities for your personal advancement and flexibility with your work schedule. High performers stand out and are quickly recognized. Very generous profit sharing and 401K plan matching.
View10: Conversely, the wrong team manager will make your life miserable by micro managing and being completely inflexible. There are many of these new managers that do not recognize the need to manage people as individuals - instead everyone is painted with the same broad brush and treated as an inexperienced new hire.

Title: Bit of a tradeoff...
View8: Good work environment. Great benefits. Fidelity cares about the customers and their employees. Flexibility with your schedule is also a plus.
View10: I worked at a call center and I can tell you that taking calls all day was very draining. I use to like talking to people but this job has made me antisocial. If you have the right manager, you can last there for a few years and you will want to because of all the great benefits. But when you start to feel like you don't even want to say "Hi" to the Publix cashier, thats your sign to either move into a more challenging role or time to get out.

Title: Great work life flexibility and culture!
View8: Great benefits, promotes from within, opportunity to move to various roles within the firm, work-life flexibility
View10: Pay is not competitive initially, only way to see big jump in salary is to move roles (yearly increases barely keep up with inflation and are pretty much up to manager discretion, not performance of the individual), be ready and open to change because your manager will probably change 4 times in a year

Title: Great mid term company
View8: Great company to start your career.  Opportunity is available to those who show desire to achieve.  Be prepared to be flexable with your career and change directions as the company changes.  As the internal saying goes "If you don't like something at Fidelity, wait a year and it will change."  Change is constant and those who adapt are rewarded.
View10: Company lacks loyalty to its employees while demanding loyalty from them.  I have seen numerous 20+ year employees let go in down times in the market.  I have been very suprised at this lack of company loyalty and it has certainly been an eye opener for me.

Title: Fidelity is a GREAT building block and FOUNDATION
View8: If you are starting out in the financial industry you can get your series 7, 63, and 66 within a year to a year and a half at Fidelity. You are constantly in training. I would stay at fidelity for at least the first 5 years moving from department to department learning as much as you possible can. Then if they do not compensate you the way you want...MOVE ON.
View10: The competition. I work in a phone site where there are over 1,000 people, and everyone wants the same higher paying jobs. The last job interview I had within the department was against 100 other people fighting for a handful of jobs

Title: Fidelity is a Great Place to Launch a Career
View8: Fidelity (CSS ) is a great place to launch your career. There is alot of support and systems that are in place to ensure you are successful. Fidelity is a great place for wholesome people who want to work and a friendly, family-oriented environement. Its not the place for a gunslinger who wants some action. Wrong culture.
View10: The use of call flows is like being a robot. You can't really help the customers on the call's because of the liability Fidelity feels comes back on them, in my opinion. However, I don't think Fidelity really encourages there employee's in CSS to be better at helping customers with Investment Education calls.

Title: Good Benefits, poor Salary and Management
View8: Very good benefits, strong 401K matching and profit sharing plans.  You get a pretty good amount of vaction after the first few years.  Fidelity seems like a pretty ethical place to work at with good people from good backgrounds.
View10: Very poor salary, bonuses, and raises.  There isn't a lot of opportunity to move within the company.  Everything is driven by leads and acquiring new business whether you are in a sales function or not.  If you don't want to go into sales you won't ever be given the chance to even interview for the job within the company you would excel at.  Management does a poor job of using the talent they have within the company to fill the positions where it is needed.

Title: A great place to work if you can stand projects moving very slowly
View8: Great benefits, competitive salary, lots of diversions in the way of talks by high profile outside speakers, art tours in the building, classes at the gym, etc.. etc.  Very nice and intelligent people work at this company and the majority are very committed to the firm.  In that way, it is truly refreshing.
View10: Projects move at a snail's pace.  A lot of politics three and four ticks down from the CEO.  If you like fast paced and challenging, this is not the place for you.  If you want to be more than just a small cog in a huge machine, this is not the place for you.  If you mind the ever-present feeling that Big Brother is watching everything you do (in and out of work), this is not the place for you.

Title: I miss working at Fidelity
View8: Fidelity has great benefits and pay very competitively. When I was there, they tried to hire and pay at the 75th percentile, so I had a lot of great coworkers. There were lots of opportunities inside the company, so it was pretty easy to stay engaged and content.
View10: It's financial services... not rocket science. Even though it's a fantastic company, I eventually got bored. I was in a smaller regional office, and there weren't a lot of opportunities to move around without moving. And I disagreed with the "culture" the local business head was creating - definitely not a Fidelity norm.

Title: 5 year+ veteran reflecting on current state of Fidelity.
View8:
Great retirement benefits, vacation time and profit sharing all though it's starting to get scaled back. 
The work/life balance is great. 
Great people in every department. Your co-workers really make Fidelity a great enjoyable place to work.
View10:
The base pay is average at best and merit increases are almost nonexistent. The increases are rarely reflective of performance, but really where you fall in the range of your salary grade compared to your co-workers. 
Their is a lack of opportunity for advanacement, politics are heavy, and to move up you really need to know someone.

Title: Above average
View8: Brand Name. Off on weekends. Plenty of OT if you want/need it. 401(k) - 1$ for 1$ Co Match up to 7%, plus Profit Sharing Contributions. Many Corp perks/discounts available. Family owned company. Huge on customer service 1st, profits 2nd. Classroom training (8 wks).
View10: Crazy call volume with recent market volatility. Call Center environment. Performance metric goals/standards are set too high and can be a challenge to achieve at times.Managers have way too much fun while reps are constantly busting butt. Managers are not proactive enough, so be prepared to take ownership of your development so you don't get left behind by your peers. Also, expect a new manager every 6-8 mths.

Title: Great company to settle down and retire from; not best for earlier in your career if you wish to learn.
View8: Great perks. In terms of bonus, profit sharing, 401(k) match, health and insurance benefits. If you are good management usually goes at length to keep you happy and retain you. Does respect work life balance.
View10: Bit of bureaucracy and personal interests make environment little rigid in terms of work and future roadmaps. Since a big part of salaries ( specially from senior levels) are tied to bonuses, focus changes from overall team goal to personal goals and marketing, making environment unpleasant. If you are a technical personal specially earlier in your career and want to grow technically, this might not be the right place to start.

Title: Financial Representative Full Trader
View8: The initial training in attaining your 7 and 63 is unbeatable. The support system is great, they don't just hand you the books and tell you to go study, they stay with you throughout the process to ensure you get licensed. Theres an initial self study period followed by a class that, if you put the work in, will thoroughly prepare you for the exams.
View10: The training thereafter in becoming a trader is incomparable. What apparently used to be a year and a half long process has been condensed into two months. They have a system of call overflow that results in inexperienced traders engaging with clients coded as private client group looking to do multi-leg options trades that their traders are not at all prepared for.

Title: Large company that provides all of the resources needed
View8: Fidelity is a very large company that provides lots of opportunities for career development and advancement. They have a history of filling openings with internal candidates. Benefits are great and they have a culture that encourages strong collaboration. Technology is the best that I have seen and they are constantly looking to plan 5 years ahead in order to constantly improve business.
View10: Opportunities to transfer can be limited if you restrict your search to one location. Company has a history of layoffs which can impact job security if an employee is not performing a critical role. On the plus side, they provide a generous severance package. Don't regret working there as the experience was great.

Title: Soul sucking
View8: Salary, Benefits, 401k matching, casual attire, beautifully maintained sites (that you cannot enjoy because of harshly restricted metrics)
View10: From the moment you walk in, your time is LITERALLY micromanaged to the MINUTE. Sexism, Favoritism, Hardcore metrics, high turnover, not open to suggestions for optimizing culture/customer experience

Title: If you work here, leave as soon you can.  If offered a job, respectfully decline it.
View8: There are no more good reasons to work here, they are all gone.  Over 15 years in IT at this company and they have layed off the brightest and most valuable employees.  The 'real' workers are gone, teams cut to the bone and expected to still get the work done.  Fidelity is cutting IT  and are preparing to outsource the whole thing over the next 5 years.  Get a job at a company who is going to provide the outsourcing.  You are expected to do your job with a blindfold on and both hands tied behind your back.  Benefits are going to be cut, demotions are days away, salaries will be cut and no pay raises expected this year.
View10: Too many to list in the space provided.  Run away and don't look back.

Title: Fidelity can be a great place to work if you get in the right group.
View8: Good employee investment plan (I've heard it changed since though..) Excellent intranet communications - including online training and other programs. Mature organization - policies and procedures are clear and well formed. Opportunities for reward and bonus are consistent. Strong. progressive corporate culture.
View10: Politics over substance in some areas with occasionally over-managed resources. Review process seems more subjective than objective. From my perspective, Fidelity can be a great place to work if you get in the right group. Unfortunately, I joined a group that had a high turnover rate that began before I joined and continued after I left.

Title: Constantly becoming more difficult
View8:
Retirement benefits are realtivley good compared to other companies.
Long term incentives exist to those with high potential.
The talent level of employees is exceptional
View10:
Becomes more difficult to work here each year.  All incentives for staying at the company are paired back with the downsizing of beenfits each year.  

Also, in the past 5 years the company has been developing and implementing a site strategy that has caused numerous people to be moved all over the country.  Taking the package also does not mean safety in your job as numerous people have been let go only a year into moving.

Title: Great company to work for if you are in it for the long term
View8:
-Very transparent for the client unlike a lot of Wall Street banks
-Excellent brand name within the marketplace and the general public
-Benefits 401k and work/life balance
-Quick opportunity for advancement, especially in the last few years
View10:
-Salary: The phone roles are grossly underpaid considering the amount of responsibility and the value the role adds for the company. This role is one of the most difficult in the company and is compensated the least.

-Extreme micro-management on the phone roles especially with metrics, breaks and lunch

-Lack of communication: Often times as employees we find out about breaking news/advancements the company is involved in, at the same time as the general public

Title: Good place to work
View8: Challenging environment, good benefits, great technology, always changing
View10: Lots of distributed technology teams offshore causes challenging time schedules if you want a good work/life balance.  Risk of New England based positions being moved is constant - but what is the benefit?

Title: Culture is Shifting
View8: Health/Dental/Life insurance. Unlimited growth potential. Tuition/Computer/Gym/Insurance reimbursements. Management is (somewhat) supportive of coaching/growth of reps. Sick days. 3 weeks Vaca. Paid holidays. Overtime is paid at almost 3X. Profit sharing is huge. Employer match is huge. Ability to work as much as you'd like.
View10: Culture is shifting within the firm to focus more on the bottom line rather than clients. Increasing micromanagement. Call center environment. There is a disconnect between decisions made from upper management and actual impact on associates/clients. 5 year graduated vesting for company match. MINIMUM 10% overtime during tax season to accommodate for inefficient/poor hiring schedule and practices.

Title: A Values Based Company that you can build a long term career with!
View8:
I am in my second decade with the firm and I am so happy I chose to work here out of college.

Family Owned:
This company takes care of its people.  I have been through 3 major economic downturns in my career and the firm always takes the long view and does cut into muscle and bone during trying times.  The Johnson family thinks in the here and now, but they also have a view 50 years out.  They are humble and grounded individuals that are always looking for opportunities to improve our business and our employee experience.  

Benefits:
We are industry leading, period.  Childcare assistance, tuition reimbursement, college loan repayment, healthy meals at a deeply discounted rate, onsite gyms, onsite healthcare facilities, onsite CFP programs, 6 months of leave for moms, computer purchase assistance, etc, etc, etc...  
If that wasn't enough, the firm isn't comfortable with out offering in this space.  We are in the midst of a major benefits reassessment.  Abby and her new head of HR are leading the charge in this effort.

Work Environment:
The family and the company goes to great length to ensure we have the best facilities for our teams.  Our major corporate campuses are spread across the country in beautiful locations.  While Fidelity is a conservative company, they build our buildings to last centuries and the are constantly refreshing them.  

I have read many posts about the call center environments.  I felt compelled to respond.  Call centers with any company are tough.  There is no way around it, it is a tough job.  However, it is an entry level position where you can learn a lot in and then leverage that learning to different roles in the future.  I know of 5 Executive Vice Presidents, several SVPs, and VPs who started in the same positions at the firm.  If you are coming out of college, you will likely start in an entry level position at some firm and you will have plenty of opportunities to work up and sideways from there.   

The firm could do a better job of facilitating that movement, but I will mention it further in the "cons" section.
View10:
Career counseling: 
Many of us were told early in our career that you needed to pull yourself up by your own bootstraps when it comes to career planning. Essentially meaning, the cream will rise to the top, and the driven folks will figure it out. 

While there is merit in this strategy,it is outdated for the size of our company.  Like many companies of our size it can become difficult to navigate.  I feel that is why many of the comments on glassdoor related to this topic are correct from the perspective of the person writing the review.  However, this is absolutely not the intention of senior leadership.  The leadership team wants to hire college grads and watch them progress out of entry level positions and branch out throughout the business.  The individuals who do, are generally immensely successful.  

The problem lies in the lack of programmatic career planning conversations and marketing of the internal opportunities and job matching. To their credit, the firm has recognized this issue and I have heard is working on building career centers to help facilitate these dialogues and career plans.  I would expect comments related to issue to start to subside as this rolls out. 

To make a long story short, the sr. team has shown that they care and want to help find the solution.

HR systems and training:
Simply put, we have antiquated systems in HR, and training needs to be modernized to adapt to the way college grads learn.  A better mix of classroom training integrated with a lacking digital solution that ties to our HR systems. 

HR system and staffing:
HR needs an overhaul.  Specifically in staffing.  We have a very traditional model and staffing and HR are loaded with career HR and staffing people.  We need to take a cue from Silicon Valley companies and add more business consultants and business leaders to the HR function to modernize it.  We need to keep about a 1/3 of this business unit as traditional HR and Staffing consultants, but there is a serious lack of creativity and challenge of old processes because of the the similar backgrounds of everyone in the group.  Until we do, we are destined to be average in this space.

Title: Great Benefits - Lots of Politics
View8: Company works hard to create a pleasant environment and provide great retirement benefits, standard bonus brackets, and private stock options for excellence in performance.
View10: There is a culture at Fidelity that you have to learn.  Your main success comes from ensuring you don't walk in the door from the outside and try and lead and influence people who have been in the company 20 years without their permission first.  A bit of political advice that can go a long way  People never leave there cause their 401K keeps growing and that creates some havoc for opportunities.

Title: Decent place to work
View8: Fidelity is a pretty good place to work.  I have been in the Corporate HQ for almost 3 years.  It genuinely cares about its employees and has great benefits (maternity/paternity, profit sharing, 401k plan).  I have worked on interesting projects in the fast-evolving financial services space and felt like i have made a difference to the business. There is reasonable work-life balance compared to many other managerial jobs.
View10:
- Below-market pay at mid-level and senior manager positions
- Bureaucratic and byzantine structure - lots of layers and siloed groups
- Can be political - more about who you know and how you're perceived than the actual quality of your work / ideas

Title: financial rep 15 years
View8: They have a great benefit package
View10: managers don't care about associates only stats. Advancement is all about who you know and who likes you not your skill level. Really just a glorified call center role. Pay increases are a joke. Management is awful and treat associates like children. To be successful you have to make friends with management outside of work to be in the click.

Title: Greatest Company I Have Worked For!
View8: I have worked for several financial companies. This company truly cares about the employees as well as the clients that it serves. I don't think i could find a job with better benefits. They also want you to grow in the company by providing opportunities to see how other departs are and talk with managers. Fidelity values the emotion well being of its employees as well. I have not had to work more than 40 hrs unless I wanted  to. It is a great company that allows you flexible hrs to have time with family or have a social life.
View10: I do feel like training was way to long but I understand they just want people to start at their best.

Title: Loved working with corporate management but regional management was very inexperienced  and lacked the resouces to grow.
View8: Pay and incentives are good but not always rewarded fairly.  If you align yourself with the right people you can move up fast.  The culture has changed a lot in the past 10 years.  Very different when Ned Johnson was in charge.  Not sure if that is a con or pro only time will tell.
View10: Many employees get positions on who they know not what they know.  It seems they only want to be seen as a company of miliniums and put very little value in hard work and a good  work ethic.  Trying too hard to be a tech culture without the knowlege of what it takes.

Title: Random reorgs and layoffs
View8: Great overall compensation and perks like subsidized healthy lunches.
View10: Periodic cost-cutting methods include layoffs of more senior, more highly compensated employees.  This was referred to as a "youth movement."

Title: Analyst
View8: Lots of opportunity to move to other positions
View10: No profit sharing for the New Mexico site. Also no retiree health plan Mostly entry level job roles, hard to move up or anywhere if you are tenured at the New Mexico site

Title: Nice company but very draining job
View8: Fidelity is very generous in terms of pay and benefits. It also grants a lot of time for training individuals for the job, no matter what background you may have come from before joining Fidelity, they will teach you all the basics of the industry.
View10: If you are joining Fidelity through a call center role, be prepared because it can be a very draining job. You will have nothing but back to back calls for a vast majority of your day and are lucky if you get a full minute or two to breath between calls. You will also have to keep an eye on metrics, one of which is regarding number of calls taken within an hour. Basically, if you are entering into this role just be prepared to take on extra stress in your life.

Title: Your experience will depend on your team
View8: Good pay, great benefits, and most of the people there are good people. The CEO really does care about everyone within the company. She takes a vested interest in her employees. I have nothing but respect for Abby.
View10: I say most because there are some people who love to play office politics and make life hell for the rest of their coworkers. There were times where I would get frustrated with the politics and eventually just decided to quit. It's not worth sacrificing my mental health over.

Title: They treat you like a computer
View8: Company match, salary, vacation time is front loaded. Fresh lunch options.
View10: No work/life balance. It's looked down on if you call in sick. Schedules are highly competitive. You must meet your quotas constantly on the phone. Calls must be dealt with as quickly as possible. If the rest of your numbers are good, but your call time is too long, no chance for any other opportunities in the company. Must have supervisors permission to apply for a different job in the company. If they say no, you will be stuck on the team. You work on a timer. You are given breaks, and a short 30 minute lunch which makes it difficult to eat the fresh lunch they provide since it takes almost 15 minutes to receive your food. You are expected to always be taking calls.

Title: An once great company that is going downhill.
View8: Fidelity is a large company with locations around the world. Compensation can be good, but the level of political game-playing is very high, making it hard to get ahead unless you are really friendly with someone at a higher level.
View10: Ned Johnson used to run the company in a way that treated most people fairly, but executive management changes constantly. Every time there is a new executive, the domino effect is seen and productivity is severely impacted. Roger Lawson is currently doing his best to decimate the company of the best and brightest employees.

Title: Project Manager Review
View8: The people I have worked with for the past 10 years have been great and have made it easy to come to work.  In the beginning there were many perks and management really made you feel good about working at Fidelity.  The campus is beautiful.
View10: The culture is very political.  Your manager may have been hired becuase of a realtionship he/she had with a director or VP not becuase they were great at their job.  Fidelity is not a place for great managers or leaders of people.  Since the introduction of Six Sigma Fidelity has become an assembly line, you have your job to do and I have my job to do and I will not help you becuase I may be held responsibel if something goes wrong.

Title: Opportunity for Advancement
View8: Within 2 years, opportunities to help train new hires, work in multi-practice customer support, and advance to provide interim team support have left great aspirations to continue to strive for success.  They do not reward showing off or doing what's expected, so to get ahead, you need to network and do something for your manager like being a load-lifter in some way to show your worth, in addition to doing your job well.
View10: There are so many people, it can be hard to stand out.  Not all opportunities will apply to you or your business unit and sometimes information regarding availability might not be available with much notice.

Title: Easy to get in, hard to move up
View8:
Fidelity does a lot of solid training, considerably more than a lot of competitors in the field. 

Benefits are very good. Pay is a little less at Fidelity but when you consider benefits in the compensation package it is competitive.

Workplace environment is reasonably professional and not stuffy.

For the most part front-line managers are willing to work with associates to find a favorable resolution to personal issues.

Managers don't throw you under the bus to customers just to make the customer feel better about a problem.

There are some great employees and managers who care about the customer and care about the employees.
View10:
Middle and upper management appears to have no idea where they are trying to steer the company, so the company swings from taking an idea to the extreme to a complete 180. Today they may be focusing on customer satisfaction and personalizing the interaction and in a few months decide to strip down customer interactions to scripted nonsense.

There are very few outlets for good ideas to arrive at implementation. Although there are feedback channels that may from time to time result in small changes, the bigger process issues or customer/client issues are completely controlled from the top by people who don't understand (and at times take pride in not knowing) what they manage so they don't know how to recognize or fix problems. So something may be a problem for years before somebody decides to do something about it, and even then the "solution" may aggravate the problem.

Fidelity is very political. Fidelity is obsessed today with it's brand image to the public, but one thing that is always constant at Fidelity is the constant obsession about your "brand". Gossip is taken as gospel and can ruin your brand in a second. What people have to say about you will override your performance in virtually all cases. Many managers would rather sink one of their employee's opportunity for advancement to be able to keep that person's performance in their numbers. A lot of backstabbing and stealing credit occurs.

There's not a lot of advancement opportunity. When the economy was great in 2007 it wasn't that hard. If you were great in your job, you could move on to a slightly better position, and when you did well there, you could move to another slightly improved position, until you were where you wanted to be. Once the economy crashed in 2008 that all stopped. I get it. That happened everywhere. However, it also stopped all discussions of professional development and no effort was made to give opportunities to develop skills for the current role or another. As a result, future promotion will be very difficult because internal candidates won't be as competitive against external candidates.

Recruiting/HR and their processes are absurd. It can take months after applying for a position before you get an interview. You can apply for a role, not hear anything for several months, and then get an email that you have an interview the next day. So you end up with no opportunity to prepare and made no efforts to prepare because you never heard anything back. Feedback from interviews rarely exists or is very generic. Hiring managers are lazy and don't follow through. 

For every great manager there are ten clueless unhelpful managers. It's obvious that middle and upper management have no idea how to manage their people because there's very little accountability or responsibility on the part of front-line managers. Directors believe yelling at people is the only way to manage, so they will yell at their managers when the numbers are bad, and that's pretty much the extent of direction or vision executed at the management level. I have heard several managers complain that they don't feel it's right that their performance is judged based on the performance of the people they manage. Well, that's what managers are there to do. If they aren't managing towards success, then they aren't doing a great job. I understand there are low performers, etc. but when I see managers playing ping pong for hours in the break room, there's not a lot of accountability in the system.

There's a lot of infighting between different business units. Everybody points fingers but nobody takes ownership over problems and fixes them. Customers and employees get stuck in the middle with no way to get out.

Fidelity no longer places a premium on its talent. Since 2008 the company has eliminated whole business groups with no effort to keep around people with tenure with tremendous transferrable skills. It does very little to help grow talent or keep it from leaving. Where a few years ago employees were loyal to the company and that loyalty was returned, the company has completely eliminated that loyalty. As a result, the company keeps losing great talent and keeps hiring new people who underperform and embarass those of us who strive to be great at our jobs. 

While all of the above things are common among businesses and I have, as most people, experienced similar trends at other jobs, what I will point out is that these problems were not institutionalized in a company that performs with mediocrity and accepts laziness in its overall perforamce. Fidelity is a top competitior in its markets and a lot of its strength historically came from the loyalty to and from its employees. Fidelity has worked very hard to treat its employees with indifference and management -- from the very top -- has set the company afloat with no real vision or guidance other than keep trying to make things that don't work struggle to work.

Title: Continuous improvement makes for continual employment
View8: Continuous improvement both technically and professionally is one of the basis-es of  employment.  FI holds all employees, business partners, vendors, and contractors accountable to the highest ethical standards.  Management is diverse, but most will provide defined expectations to give their employees the ability to improve and grow.  FI provides decent compensation to their employees.  The work environment is great = great people, quality professionals.
View10: Management expects proof of ability over word.  This means if you are being considered for a promotion, such an employee is given the ability to prove their abilities.

Title: Moving IT jobs out of Boston
View8: Some great people have gone through the doors at Fidelity.  Fidelity has traditionally invested heavily in technology and smart people.
View10: Unfortunately the company is relocating its IT jobs out of Boston and loosing its talent base and domain knowledge in the process.  The company is currently focused on cost cutting and outsourcing rather than talent retention.   A large inventory of legacy applications is a drag on innovation and its IT budget.  More cost effective products from competitors, such as ETFs, threatening their business model.

Title: Milk Them For All You Can
View8: Good place to build your career in financial services because of the training, structure, pay, and benefits.  Good brand recognition from customers, but this can turn into a negative if you lack humility.  Most reps are not as good as you think.  The green machine is doing a lot of the heavy lifting, but those who are good at building value and relationships can transfer those skills to an RIA and do really well.
View10:
- Although micro-management is mentioned in almost every review, I think it stems from not trusting your veteran representatives.  Fidelity feels like they have to control people from the top, having branch managers regurgitate sentiments from the top.  This also leads to *bleep* rolling downhill.  Some managers did prove themselves as good salespeople, but eventually have to drink the Kool-Aid or they won't last long.  Either that or they give up because they can't change the system.  Other managers were opportunists who rose through the ranks quickly, moving fast enough before people can realize they aren't as good as they appeared.

- Compensation:  Yes, you can make very good money here, but if you're really good, you can make way more outside.  Compensation is figured out ahead of time and they reverse-engineer the compensation plan to get AE's back to target comp.  The last couple of years, they've reduced some of the pay, like basis points on new flows, coinciding with the S&P at historical highs.  Oddly enough, they had a reduction in force in 2009 because they based payroll on the S&P and had to cut people.  So when the market's down, you're screwed, and when the market's up, you're also screwed.  Ultimately, you can't keep lying about AE/SAEs being in relationship roles when your compensation is still based on selling products.  And this relationship model is 5 years old.

Title: HNW Services Representative
View8: 7% company match. Good, but expensive medical / dental insurance and four weeks vacation after five years.
View10: Salaries are definitely sub-par. The company keeps raising goals, thus eliminating/ reducing quarterly bonuses. Often treated like children and insulting our intelligence. Office politics are the norm. Old and slow employee technology. Real problem of group think here. You HAVE to drink the cool-aid here or you won't go anywhere. Want you to think "out-of-the-box" as long as it's their box. Keep changing plans no real direction for this company. If you work here, get your licenses and leave.

Title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
View8:
1 ~ Many would tell you the best thing about Fidelity is the people you work with and I agree. I have made several life-long friends and look forward to seeing them every day. Asking around you will find many people also found their significant others at work as well.

2 ~ Upward mobility and job opportunities. I may be biased from working at the Westlake campus where there are over 6000 jobs but it is also relatively easy to move to other locations within the company. There was a time years ago when it might have felt like you had to go to Boston to move up in the company but those days are gone and there are many great leadership positions throughout the country.

3 ~ Brand recognition you can be proud of and sleep well at night. Fidelity is a discount broker so not ripping people off with high loads or fees. They did not get caught up in the mischief so many other firms did with the mutual fund scandals or financial crisis.
View10:
The best things about Fidelity are also the worst things about Fidelity. 

1 ~ If you end up in the wrong department with the wrong boss your life can be a living hell. Fidelity is very liberal in its HR policies which can be good but also means they let things fester for a long time before taking action. There is a percentage of people that will take advantage of this and especially if you are on a small team you may end up constantly covering for a weak link.

2 ~ It is an American dream to start in the mail room and work your way up to VP someday and that is totally possible at Fidelity. In fact, it may be a bit too easy. It is completely common to attend leadership meetings and hear from senior executives "I started on the phones just like you!"  Well, that is fine once in a while but at some point you do want people leading you to actually have some training and experience. Fidelity is full of hundreds maybe thousands of Directors, VP's and SVP's that started on the phone "just like you" and it shows.

3 ~ Fidelity has managed to stay out of the news but there are plenty of unsavory things they do behind the scenes. They are currently very worried about the Department of Labor proposed Fiduciary Rule. Their current employer benefits business model is already unethical but if the rule is enacted will be illegal as well. It has long been a major IRA rollover sales lead source to take advantage of relationships with employers to gain access to employees. Fidelity is the world's largest 401k record-keeper and should this lead source be taken away it will be a huge hit to their personal investing sales model in which two thirds of the new assets are from internal rollovers. The Fidelity brokerage business would be nowhere near what it is today without having taken advantage of these workplace business relationships.

Title: Good Benefits, Diverse Products, Interesting Projects, Much Politics
View8:
Opportunities for growth are plentiful along with the resources to enact on that growth. 

Benefits structure is generous with a large emphasis on health and retirement benefits.

Huge focus on delivering a good customer experience as well as a focus on ethics in its dealings with customers.

A varied and diverse product line that allows for personal development and varied experiences across business units.
View10:
Bureaucracy coupled with frequent organizational change. Structures are created and disassembled with lightening fast rapidity, inhibiting associates ability to deliver.

Managerial empire building is rife along with the political minefield that creates across the organization.

Title: Great benefits and atmosphere
View8:
The benefits are amazing. Between the health care, the on-campus cafeteria, and all of the various perks, it's unbeatable. The company pays for you to get your series 7 and series 63 exams. You work with licensing trainers to learn the material. You will have to sacrifice a lot during the licensing period, and won't have much free time. 
They really do work on making sure the employees are happy. They like to hire within for other positions, and encourage movement within the company.
View10: For the CRA position, you are expected to answer calls while in licensing. I felt as though it was difficult to talk about the investments while you were learning about them. This lead to customers being frustrated that we could not help them, and we would have to transfer them instead.

Title: Outstanding Company and Career
View8: Leaders and Managers truly care about your success and career. There is always help available including developmental opportunities, skills training, education, certification programs, tuition reimbursement, loan programs to test out other organizations and peer groups. Customers and Employees are at the center of every decision made by leadership. Major investments are made consistently in technology to perform job functions better and easier with customers and employees always at the forefront.
View10: Like any job, there are duties you have to perform. Business demand picks up heavily for this role during Q4 every year which means we travel a lot more and are away from our families. This is part of the role and understood and also balances out during the course of the year.

Title: Good company, but for how long?
View8:
Overall compensation at Fidelity is very good - however you are expected to contribute a lot to earn it.  Advancement is available for top talent.

Fidelity is very flexible with its work options - telecommuting, flex time, etc.  Management is very well versed in leadership and helping people to provide resources to bring out the best in their work.
View10:
Currently undergoing a transformation that may commoditize the company and make top performers leave.  Reluctant to eliminate low-margin business from its portfolio.

Much of the company is territorial and rather than working well as a team, things can be quite difficult to accomplish.

Title: High net work phone representative.
View8: Fidelity has a good compensation package. They pay better than most of their direct competitors. The training is also good.
View10: My division no longer exists. It was consolidated into another division. In the last few years before the consolidation, management did not seem to care that their approach to managing the company was very detrimental to employee morale i. e. revoking scheduled vacation for some employees within a few weeks of the scheduled vacation due to customer call volume. They knew the end was near for them and they simply did not care.

Title: Phenomenal employee relations...
View8: The training you receive at a job says a lot about your employer, and Fidelity invests a lot of time and resources in their new employees.  Throughout your training there are constant opportunities to sit down with your on-boarding manager to talk about your progress and career development, including what direction you want to take after your current position.  It's almost as if Fidelity wants you to improve and move onto bigger and better opportunities within the company more than you do.
View10: At the start there is a lot of time commitment that you need to make outside of the workplace.  Getting securities licensed takes a lot of time at work and a lot of time at home.  If that's not something you are used to or don't have available it can be a big adjustment.

Title: They do not value industry exp. or knowledge. A private company that is run more like a public one.
View8: Some locations offer free parking. Casual dress and jeans on Friday. Not much more to say than that.
View10: They don't provide formal reviews or offer development. You need to start there right out of school in order to succeed. Value isn't what you know about the industry but how to figure workarounds for their convoluted systems. Not a lot of opportunity for those coming from the outside.

Title: A great place to start your career so that you can move on and take your experience elsewhere.
View8: Over my career at Fidelity I worked with some amazing people, had a lot of development opportunities and great benefits.  I left voluntarily with a strong professional network and tremendous experience, for which I am grateful.
View10: The culture of the company has really deteriorated - there have been many management changes and shifts in direction.  The benefits are still great, but I don't think the compensation is as competitive as it used to be.  This is a big company and you must learn to deal with a lot of bureaucracy in order to accomplish things - a person who succeeds at Fidelity is flexible, patient, smart, politically aware, knows when to give up, and can shift direction with little to no lead time.

Title: A good place to spend some prime years in your career; comp can plateau out in some cases, but generally a rewarding pla
View8: Many high quality professionals at lower and mi levels within the company,particularly on the technology side of the company.  Within the business leaders, the typical political class emerges and operates as such.  Internal communications is a priority for most of these executives.
View10: Overt focus on personal brand management and career advancement by the middle class.  As these executives are often paid well, they can be defensive and self serving due to the low likelihood comp can be replaced somewhere else.

Title: "Leaders" are bullies
View8: A lot of career opportunities and ability to move around to work on new things. The work is very interesting and challenging. Performance is rewarded.
View10: This place is trying to go in too many directions at once and be everything to everybody....can't get out of their own way with products, technology, and initiatives.

Title: Firefighting every day is the norm at Fidelity.
View8: Pay and benefits are very good.  They spend money like it is going out of style.  The compensation is good but you have to be cautious what the HR reps promise you. They will promise you anyting just so you will accept.
View10: Fidelity is a lifestyle not just work. You work 24X7.  No room for family.  Way too much paperwork to do your job.  Boston rules, Raleigh is treated like India outsourced.  Where I worked, I only got to know the 5 people that I worked with. Also, if you work in Raleigh, be wary of the Boston people.  They  are not friendly and are  not interested in helping anyone new.  The NH office resent the Raliegh office with a passion.

Title: Long hours and little recongnition.  Management expects the world of employees but some how managers are able to slack!
View8: Tenure with the company and overall hard working people.
View10: No raise this year.  If you are exceeding expectations you are now considered proficient.  Too many hours and no recognition.  Contractors seem to have a better deal with no accountability compared to full time employees.

Title: Bi-polar
View8: Decent salary.  Huge investment in IT.  Able to move sideways to new jobs. Willing to try new things.
View10: Shuffle, shuffle, shuffle.  Lots of people movement which has to be expensive.  Cutting a lot of IT jobs in Boston and moving to TX, NC or overseas.  sometimes there is too much willingness to try new things; there are 4 tools for everything, little is integrated, and standardization is not often found.  Certain groups have lots of politics. Not a lot of upward mobility.

Title: Balanced Review
View8: Good life work balance and flex time. Benefits are good but not what they used to be. Business casual dress code with jeans on Friday.
View10: Upper management often makes changes or asks staff to participate in projects. These changes and projects have an obvious negative effect on staff ability to get their "regular jobs" done. First line management is required to support these changes and generally does not support staff. There are too many power hungry, hostile managers at all levels.

Title: Good at first,  then downhill from there
View8: I will say that the Series 7 training that they provide is excellent.  Ok for a year, if it's your first job out of college.
View10: Upper management does a great cheer-leading bit but the real world is quite different. Every move you make is recorded and monitored, if you make a rookie mistake they make you feel terrible,  very little praise without a "but". Lot's of nitpicking criticism.  You have no time to socialize because every minute is accounted for.   The work itself is ok but quite a grind when you average 50 calls a day with only 2 15 min. breaks.   Grueling for little pay.

Title: Product-Institutional Services
View8: Good work environment.  Very savvy employees who will go the extra mile for their clients/customers. Work/life balance is present, but as in all walks of life depends on project deadlines and seasonal obligations.  Good pay and benefits.  Many sub-companies enable opportunity to transfer and learn new components of the financial services industry.
View10: Management-information-gatekeeping by some senior level managers negatively impacts the outcome of projects and can be demoralizing to the team.  Some micro-management exists.  Where this occurs it is very difficult to complete tasks.  Periodic RIF activity to eliminate older, longer service employees.

Title: Financial representative
View8: Good environment, good people, good room for growth with in the company. Great pay, fidelity cares about their employees and will set you up with good bonuses, 401ks, and profit sharing.
View10: Every day is exactly the same as the day before it, some managers don't really understand the industry which tends to make the job harder at times specially when your manager is on the computer looking for shoes while you take 100 calls a day. Training could be a lot better then it is. Some of the trainers are horrible teachers and don't know what they are talking about or can't relate the training to the actual job.

Title: Solid Opportunity
View8: I have learned a lot about myself professionally during my tenure here. There have been plenty of opportunities to work with various teams and technologies and I am a much more well-rounded engineer because of it. You get as much out of it as you put in. The teams and management I have worked with have allowed me to gain plenty of visibility with upper management.
View10: Due to the nature of the financial industry and a large financial firm that has been around for over 70 years, it can be difficult to innovate and move quickly on new projects due to a lot of legacy software. There are times where it is difficult to function as a technology company when where are limitations on systems.

Title: You'll Love It Here
View8: BI-yearly bonus, BI-weekly pay,Profit sharing cash every January,Everyone is issued laptops and most teams can work from home, Business casua dress code l including jean's daily, Medical, dental, optical,  long & short term insurance,on-site gym & classes,New buildings redesigned breakrooms & cafes with Hoveys on rack floor, Free Wifi  in the building and while traveling,  Walking trails, Outdoor sitting by lake or waterfall, On-site bicycles to use, New furniture so you can work at your desk or on sofas or arm chairs.
View10: No way to get away from managers who promote those they like instead of those qualified. Promotion of unqualified  team members puts more work on those who have to work with them. Takes a long time to terminate people with bad attendance, bad attitudes, and lazy coworkers.

Title: Good Company - needs to show more organizational maturity
View8: Fidelity is good company for early and mid career opportunities.Excellent use of technolgy for building their business and getting your job done. The benefits are excellent, but you will need to work hard and sometimes work/life balance get be difficult to maintain.
View10: Can be very political and you need to spend a considerable amount of time promoting your accomplishments up the organization. Need to stay close to your boss and whoever he/she reports to to receive deserved recognition. If you want to move up you will need to an inordinate amount of time managing up. There can be a sense of entitlement amongst the longer term employees, but that is changing.  Fidelity makes money despite itself and spends money foolishly at times.

Title: No career growth or work/life balance
View8: Inexpensive insurance plans and good 401k match. They offer good options for healthy eating  and promote a healthy lifestyle and reimbursements.
View10: No work/life balance. They precode overtime every week because of their refusal to hire additional employees to ease the work load and look down on you for opting out occasionally. There is no opportunity to advance to different areas of the company even if you are certainly qualified although they lure you in with the promise of moving around the company easily. I would not recommend.

Title: Financial Service Rep
View8: This is probably the best company I have ever worked for.  Management is very organized and always there to assist you with any questions or needs you may have.  The culture here is absolutely amazing and the happiness of their employees is something Fidelity takes very serious.  The starting pay is $42000.00 which is very competitive for the industry.  You get bonuses based on your performance every quarter.
View10: The only con I can think of is this is a call center environment.  I am just not the type of person who sees myself working in a call center for the rest of my life and decided to make a career change.

Title: Land of lateral opportunity
View8:
There is significant opportunity to change jobs within the firm due to the diversified businesses within the company (employer services, fund accounting, capital markets, operations, technology).  

The benefits programs are strong.  Employees can receive tuition reimbursement, gym membership reimbursement, computer assistance and even back-up day care.  Some sites offer on-site health clubs and/or walking trails.
View10:
Employees are just cogs in the wheel at Fidelity.  Two examples reinforcing this opinion are: entire business units are relocated on a whim and development programs are non-existent.

Raises and bonuses are “capped” minimizing the importance of excellent performance. In the end, the really great performers leave seeking appropriate compensation. Many end up returning shortly after for a matching (or higher) salary indicative of their true worth (dictated by the market for their services).

Title: if you like to stay in one job for a long time go with Fidelity
View8: profit shareing bonus is awsome 10% of salary after the first full year of working there.  Also they match dollar for dollar up to 7% every pay check.  Great for getting securities licences.  Also the education match is helpful for people going to school they will pay up to $10,000.  However, my manager said this started right away when I was hired he lied I had to wait 6 months before they would pay me back.
View10: no upward movement... once your in a role you feel stuck in a box you cannot get out of

Title: Who you report to is critical
View8:
Retirement benefits are quite good
Physical workspace and tech support are top notch, typically not hurting for technology
Depending on the group, willing to take risks
Be sure to know the "star power" of who you work for - makes a difference for reviews and promotions
Major investment areas are FMR Co (asset management) and retail distribution, especially in the branch network
View10:
Going through a growing pain - condensing business units.  Constant spot layoffs as the continually try to right-size their new look.
A weak boss will leave you highly vulnerable to a layoff / demotion
Hyper-political atmosphere

Title: Great company, horrible, horrible job.
View8: 401k/health benefits are phenomenal, you can switch jobs almost ever 6 months to 1 year, quarterly/annual bonuses, easy to win other rewards which can add up to several thousand a year for doing almost nothing.
View10: Micromanagement.  Every minute of my day is tracked and translated into an efficiency percentage, which if it goes too low, I'm penalized.  I'm not allowed to spend more than an average 480 seconds on the phone with a customer, or I'm penalized.  I'm required to generate sales leads in a non-sales job, or I'm penalized.  I'm required to stick to my minute-by-minute schedule, or I'm penalized.  And last, the job is definitely dependent on if your manager likes you.

Title: Good place to work if you're having a hard time finding work
View8: Large company with great benefits. There is some opportunity for mobility within the company. Also, even if you start out on the phones, if you do well, they recognize it.
View10: Working on the phones is miserable. You're tied to your phone and it is very hard to earn your bonuses. You have to earn so many points and for every minute you are off on your adherence (to your alotted breaks) or if a customer gives a bad review for a person they talked to before or after you, it still affects your score. Also the wage is barely above the poverty line.

Title: Great Place to Grow a Career
View8: Fidelity cares not only about their associates, but cares tremendously about the customer.  They do what is right by the customer, not what is easy for them  They treat their employees and customers with respect and dignity, and make you proud to be a member of the team.
View10: There are not many downsides that I can think of, but if I had to provide one it would be that there is not a Utah site that is not located directly in a metropolitan area.  Some of the other locations are campuses, which is nice - it would be great if we could get one here in Utah.

Title: Solid and Steady growth opportunity
View8: Work-life balance is great. If you are performing well, most managers are very understanding of personal needs. Steady-safe employment, once you have a foot in the door and you are delivering satisfactory work there is very low turnover. People and culture are great, very supportive and looking to set you up for success.
View10: While steady and safe employment is a plus, it means that career advancement is slow going, so make sure you enter the company at the appropriate level to your experience and skillset.

Title: Experience varies with the groups
View8: Some of the best people I've ever met were my peers/coworkers, and I am still friends with them to this day!
View10:
It seems the higher up folks get, the more disconnected they become from the actual roles they manage, and they plan for and focus on the wrong things - what is best for their bottom line, not what is best for the customer.
There is an illusion of management caring about their teams, and while individuals might care, overall workers are just a number and are disposable.  Those with the loudest voice, not the best ideas, are heard - and it's often to the detriment of the team or customer.

Title: Focus Is On Call Volume Not The Customer
View8:
- Benefits
- High Quality Employees
View10:
-  Fidelity's HNW and PCG groups now focus primarily on call volume rather than the clients. Your goal will be to take 5.5-7 calls per hour with two fifteen minute breaks during an 8 hour shift.   
- Financial Representatives are undervalued and will find difficulty moving to different departments within the company.

Title: Good company to start, but you probably want to jump ship ASAP
View8: Very thorough and organized onboarding process & trainings. Lots of learning opportunities at Fidelity in the beginning. For the most part, co-workers and managers are friendly and competent. Good healthcare benefits & great profit sharing (6% match).
View10:
Almost all the job opportunities at Fidelity require you to speak to customers on the phone. Mostly horizontal movements unless you network well & have great relationships with your managers. Job can get stressful and at some point of time, you will get yelled at by customers. 

It's a big company, so even though sometimes management asks for your opinion, they'll make changes that does the opposite. You're just a number in the company and most people leave within a year or two.

Title: Get your license and quit
View8: -Paid Training and licensing during first several months. Classes ar e very educational and they set you up to pass all the Series licenses
View10:
-Absolutely no room for growth. They purposely have a system that keeps you stuck in the call center. My manager was there for 15 years and even he ended up leaving because he couldn't find a role outside of the call center. Fidelity Investments and the Fidelity call center might as well be two completely different companies. The only positions available to you are in sales or some other medial phone position. Managers either can't help you out or won't help you out. Like my headline says I would take the position, get the licenses and then start applying elsewhere.
-Pay is much lower for similar positions at other companies

Title: Great place to work if you are not out all for yourself
View8:
Privately held, they "Do the right thing" for customers.  Though changes take a lot of time to happen, they are on the right path.  They are very innovative and have been very successful over the last few years at using technology to build scale and profitability.
The benefits are fabulous, especially the profit sharing and match for 401k contributions.
Great to work for a private company that is not totally concerned about profitability and earnings from one quarter to the next.  Company is conservatively managed so they have not gotten tripped up by the credit debacles.  Growing company which has a great future.
View10: Somewhat political in promotion processes.  Probably could make more money elsewhere though the position would be less secure.

Title: Best company to work for in America.
View8: Great compensation structure, even for unlicensed Representatives starting out in the industry.  Company spends considerable amount of time and resources on professional development of employees.  There is a really strong sense of healthy competition amongst the associates.  The company does everything it can to recognize and compensate those who perform above their benchmarks.  As a matter of fact, I've seen approximately 10 associates get promoted in the less than 5 years I have spent here.  There is a lot of room to grow as well, even for those who have plenty of industry experience.  The support structure is amazing, the company really goes out of its way to make sure every associate is successful.
View10: Different demographic of the community is a big determinant of your compensation.

Title: Entrepreneurial Vision Hanging in the Balance
View8: Fidelity is a large, multifaceted umbrella of companies affording a range of opportunities.  Benefits are good -- especially the 401k since Fidelity is the premier provider of mutual fund services.  The entrepreneurial spirit of its Chairman still there but needs a boost.
View10: Fidelity is increasingly feeling its size and is not as nimble as it once was.  Investments in technology are there but so are attendant bureaucratic obstacles.  If Fidelity endeavors to retain the core cadre of good people it has recruited in the past and bring their insights to bear, they could well maintain their standing and, potentially, go on to new heights.

Title: Fragmented and constant restructuring
View8:
- Excellent benefits (401k matching, discounts with major companies, free portfolio mgmt, etc..)
 - Great if you want a job that is laid back
 - A lot of flexibility to move laterally
View10:
- Salaries are not competitive
 - Boss had very little power in giving reasonable raises because of "company policy"
 - The work is not as challenging as it could be
 - Lots of red tape when you wish to use software that is not on the company list of "compliant" software
 - Business casual dress code forced on software engineers is never a good idea

Title: Good benefits and compensation; sweatshop environment; they own you
View8: Excellent compensation, benefits and bonus.
View10: Company has you tethered 24/7 with remote and mobile access technology; highly political environment; tough to get ahead; co-workers compete with one another; company only values highly aggressive associates without regard to whether they are of good character; people always looking over their shoulder in fear of losing their well-paying positions; not a team-oriented environment and not for the faint of heart! 40-hour workweek uncommon. High burnout employer.

Title: Fidelity might be a good place for you to work, depending on what's important to you...
View8: The total compensation is very generous. I worked there for 10 years, from 2001-2011 and every year we received 20% profit sharing bonus, even though the economy was terrible 2008-2010. Which means they were always profitable.  They are focused on on growing their asset share, and if you are good at sales, you will excel and be promoted often.
View10: The employees aren't the most friendly and helpful people, it is a culture of help yourself and you will do well. They are always focused on the bottom line of reaching their outrageous asset goals, at any cost, even lying to their clients. They change CEO's every four of five years which means you have to adapt to a new "vision" to drive sales.

Title: Regional Investment Consultant
View8: Fidelity brand is strong in the industry. Nice place to go to work-cafeteria, gym, etc.
View10: Quantity over Quality is what the Sales Desk wants at Fidelity Investments. You are a dial monkey-simply as that. I had 4 years of being a internal wholesaler at another well respected firm prior to joining Fidelity. Westlake is in the middle of no where-terrible commute from Dallas or Fort Worth. Many of the Sales Managers were once Internals and understand the frustrations of the job but have little empathy. The turnover on the Sales Desk is the highest that I have seen in my career and through friendships build at other companies.

Title: It's OK for a financial company.
View8:
- Very nice facilities
- Cheap food
- Ability to work semi-remote
- Some really smart people
View10:
- Politically driven, high pressure culture. 
- People rewarded for being cozy with management instead of delivering work. 
- A lot of roles filled with mediocre people in order to check a box and feel good. 
- Clueless, jaded employees can get away with being on their iphone all day and still get paid.
- Super paranoid about data loss. You have no control over your work hardware.

Title: Good if you are a "follower or a conformist"
View8:
- Work life balance it almost impossible due to the company going lean.
- Ethical company.
- Company politics play a continuing theme and reward employees who conform to the 'kool aid' standard.
- Many layoffs and movement of positions to employees who earn less.
View10:
- Overly hierarchical in certain areas with little access to senior management. 
- Senior management makes all strategic decisions with little input from associate level.  
- Not much transparency when is come to plans from upper management.
- Pay is not industry standard.
- Work/life balance difficult with increased demand and less headcount.

Title: Don't Recommend
View8: They pay you through all of your studies until you get all of the required licenses needed for the job. There are also a lot of career opportunities as long as you are okay being stuck in a call center taking calls for awhile.
View10: I had such a bad experience with their hiring process, but I decided to take their offer anyway to give it a try. There is no flexibility with your schedule once you are out of training, and benefits choices are definitely not as good as advertised, especially with their health and dental insurance. They really don't offer a lot of options and they are very expensive comparing to what the market has to offer.

Title: We'll all judge companies by how they treat people during tough times.
View8:
Fidelity was always a great place to work, now that covid-19 has hit they have stepped up beyond compare. Within days most employees were working from home, a week later new benefits we're rolled out to support people in these tough times. Incredible 😍

Leaders have stepped up beyond belief, I've always heard over communicate but now after 20+ years in software I've finally seen it in action. Daily and weekly updates with videos and open sessions to ask questions and just talk. 🤩
View10: None that I know 💪

Title: It's a stepping stone at best.
View8: Fidelity has an incredibly in-depth four month long training program that will not only bring pre-licensed financial representatives up to speed to pass their Series 7 and 63's (even for those completely new to the industry), but will also familiarize you with all of the software that would be used on a day-to-day basis. Generally speaking, upon completion of the program, financial representatives are capable of adequately performing the job duties in what is objectively a complicated job function without any sort of assistance. Also, barring a layoff climate or doing anything illegal, job security is very, very high; never hitting your numbers will still get you your weekly paycheck. If you play the game, opportunity is most certainly there to advance (and your manager will be first in line to assist you in achieving your goals), but you can only go so far in the call center, both in terms of job duties and salary.
View10: Unfortunately, the training program is where my positive experience ended. Employees are reminded every day from the first time they peruse the careers website, to the job interview, to on-boarding, to training, to team meetings, that Fidelity isn't like Merrill Lynch, Schwab, JP Morgan, or any other player in the game; Fidelity is a family-owned company and doesn't have to play to it's shareholders, and thus they are one of the few in the business "for the customer". That sure sounds nice, but beyond being family-owned, it's just not true. This job is in a 24/7 call center, and just like every call center in the world, metrics are king. You'll never move up anywhere in the company for retaining a multi-million dollar account or preventing perilous actions through education of financial instruments or any other morally outstanding action... you'll move up for finishing your calls on an average of less than eight minutes. This "time = money" focus exacerbates an already-beaurocratic business structure by incentivizing representatives to transfer their calls or to be curt to the point of being entirely unhelpful. That's fine, and almost expected from most call center representatives with other companies, but in financial services, it's unacceptable; you're dealing with people's retirement accounts and livelihoods. On the sales side, recommendations are limited to proprietary target-date funds and bloated, high-fee "managed" accounts. Going above and beyond to solve problems that are repeatedly surfacing and are consistently unaddressed is a habit discouraged by management: "that's not your job". Other than their own propaganda, nothing differentiates this company from the other financial services firms--do not take a potential paycut to choose Fidelity over them with the idea that you'll be working for some sort of Red Cross organization, even though they will spin it that way. At the end of the day, this is a 24/7 call center (where your job is to verify customers, reset passwords, give website support, send checks, and enter trades at their direction...financial professional is thrown around very loosely around Fidelity, but I would not consider the FR to be one) that is ALWAYS hiring. If you weren't able to deduce, there is an unhealthy amount of turnover at Fidelity due to employees leaving for increased responsibilities and salaries (most Jax representatives went to Merrill, which was literally across the street!). On the other hand, if you have some sort of relevant degree or experience and are out of work, there is a ton of job security and experience to be gained here. It's a stepping stone at best.

Title: Leaving Fidelity was the dumbest thing I ever did
View8: Fidelity Investments’s is one class act. Great culture. An undying commitment to doing what is best for their clients, their associates and the community where they do business. I spent nearly eleven years at Fidelity and those years were the highlight of my professional life. I feel proud to say I’m an alumni and still consider the company as ‘my company’. I left on June 30 as part of an ‘early retirement’ offer that was to good to pass up. Four months later, I’m seriously regretting ever leaving.
View10: Very few. Maybe the only thing that I could complain about is the company has an irritating habit of ‘reinventing the wheel’ every five minutes. Blink twice and something has changed.

Title: Program Manager
View8: High quality people. and leadership.  Great benefits. and pay.  Industry leader.  High ethical standards.  Customer first focus.
View10: Almost impossible to get to VP level.  Too many high quality people in high level roles who don't move on, making it difficult for talented directors or managers to get promoted.  Company is very focused on targeting and accommodating millennials creating the impression that previous experience and approaches to getting work done are not valued in new operating models.

Title: "Advanced" Call Center
View8: Excellent Benefits, Flexible Hours, Competitive Pay,  Volunteered Time Off, Competitive Bonus System
View10: mo·not·o·nous IS AN UNDERSTATEMENT, Poor Bonus System, "Middle School Reward System", Poor Technology, Lazy Co-workers. Brown Nosed Stuck Up Arrogant individuals thinking they are better than you because they are "managers of a call center."  The hiring process does not make you aware that this is ENTIRELY a PHONE JOB!  BE AWARE OF WHAT YOUR GETTING YOURSELF INTO!

Title: Great place to work
View8:
Friendly work environment.  Many very nice and noble people.
Good pay (unimpresive base salary but high bonus + profit sharing + ...)
Company greatly values my job and return with great reward.
Company cares about employees' life-work balance and career advancement..
Great opportunity to work with financial aspect and with financial and business people.
When they layoff people due to business decision they inform several months ahead and then provide nice package.  They also allow laid off people to stay in office and use their work computer for weeks to look for jobs.  I guess they trust laid off people won't do any harm to company because company treat them very reasonably.
Ted John is a very sensible person.
View10: There are a lot overhead, although all people work very very hard, the outcome is not as much.

Title: A great place for a career.
View8: They are a very strong believer in change.  Change allows for improvement but may not always be the case especially in the short term.  Benefits are good.  Pay is fair.  Private company allows for flexibility and accountability to the work product - not share holders.  A very high % of employees are there 10-15+ years.  Retention is good for a reason.
View10: Work-life balance options is only supported in some business units.  High-performers are sometimes rewarded appropriately but not consistent.  Low/non-performers are not rewarded but are also difficult to terminate from Fidelity.  Instead, they are passed around Fidelity instead of managed out.  This can/has hurt morale of teams.

Title: Call center experience.
View8: Extremely well managed. The training I received was by far the best I received in any corporation I've worked in. There were constant opportunities to add more training. Once you've been in a position for at least six months you can apply to transfer departments or advancement.The process was easy. Management was generally hired from within.
View10: Even small infractions of company policy or procedures were a permanent part of your employee record. Even these minor things came up in my department transfer interview. In spite of this I was still successful. During a training week I was given a written warning about using foul language. I never had. That was someone else, but I was written up despite the fact it wasn't me. There was no process for defending oneself when accused.

Title: Financial Representative
View8: Good benefits- life, dental and health insurance; 401k match and profit sharing; computer and fitness reimbursement, Holiday pay, OT, Paid sick and vacation time, etc.
View10:
They continually ask you to do more and more while the pay stays the same (i.e., taking on other responsibilities, taking more phone calls due to lack of proper staffing, etc.) The work / life balance is not very good. 

Many managers also like to play favorites, so even if you hit all of your goals you are still screwed and will have a hard time moving up or receiving any bonuses/ raises.

Title: It really depends on which department you land in...
View8: Excellent technology, great in-house software, top-notch training and support, great benefits, and lots of overtime opportunities. A very good place to start if you are fresh out of college.
View10: Really depends on what sub-department you work in. Some of the worst have: Cliques, bullying, back stabbing, high burnout, and lots of turnover. Not every department has these issues, just a few. The occasional bad manager or horrible coworker have a tendency to stay on with the company forever. Trust me, you won't outlast them. I tried and failed.

Title: It's a great place to work if you have kids. Innovative for a financial company.
View8:
-Cafeteria fit meals while not the best tasting, are very reasonably priced 
-Co-workers are very friendly all around. 
-They care about the customer, since we use the products there's extra motivation to have them be effective
-They have some fun benefits like gym reimbursements and computer purchasing assistance plans
-The manager discusses your goals and tries to develop you as a person
View10: -Too bureaucratic, all access requires tickets don't assume you get everything needed for your role when you first come onboard, it'll take time -People follow process blindly, and it takes a lot of effort to modify it

Title: Best Financial, Technical and Innovating Company
View8:
1. A lot of opportunities to learn and grow.
2. Lesser internal politics.
3. Support from the manager on both personal and professional.
4. Excellent collaboration with teammates.
5. Planning ahead and for future.
6. Clear Vision and directions from senior management.
7.  Availability of open forums to raise issues and concerns to the higher management.
8. Strict adherence to company policies and rules.
9. Zero tolerance on sexual or non-sexual misconducts.
10. Common goals among the enterprise business units.
11. Very good bonus and benefits.
12. Industry best 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing.
13.  Good Work-life balance.
14. And Many more :)
View10: There are some legacy problems but we are moving fast and will be able to resolve them quickly.

Title: Great company with growth potential
View8: Great place to start off a career because they offer so much growth potential in the financial industry. Management is excellent here and always respectful of their employees. Great benefits as well.
View10: A lot of the people I worked with were lazy and constantly trying to get out of actually having to work, but eventually that's why they don't get promoted and those who work hard do.
