Also I've heard that the salary is a bit lower than similar positions within the industry, but they make up for it with benefits.

Title: Awesome place to work with thoughtful long term diversified strategy
View8: Excellent bonus structure. Never missed the annual bonus.. ever.. Huge 401K benefits package. You have to experience the 401K benefits to believe it. High performers get private company shares which are worth A LOT over time. This company does not think short-term both in their strategy as well as in their benefits & compensation structure. Apart from benefits, the company culture and treatment of employees is genuine in nature. Company strives for people to move around & encourages it. So, you are not stuck doing one this for a long time.
View10: Promotions might be very hard to get due its flat structure, but compensation overall is good given its broad base. Things will get frustrating because it is slower to move on important things, but its understandable in any large company.

Title: FMR
View8: all the overtime you want, later shift to accommodate personal life, always changing for the good, starbucks inside
View10: your work ethics do not matter here its literally ALL about who you know and no what you know. SO you have to constantly "network" to get ahead in the company. Some (not all) of the managers literally have their favorites and will do any and everything to make sure their favorites are well taken care of and make sure they succeed first, and that's because those people were the ones kissing butt. So if you like sucking up to folks, networking and stomping on others to get ahead then by all means work there!

Title: Needs to refocus on employees
View8: Fidelity has great health benefits, PTO, profit sharing,, 401k match, fitness reimbursement, etc..  They have fairly competitive salaries and bonus opportunities.  Depending on the department you are working in, there is some flexibility in schedule.
View10: Employee morale  has taken a nose dive as Fidelity restructures organizations.  Less emphasis on taking care of their employees and more on bottom line and efficiency.   A lot of  bureaucracy to get things done.   Large company where decisions take a long time to be made.    Environment can feel very political and times.

Title: Investment representative
View8: Good steady base salary and benefits. Matching of 7% and 10% profit sharing after 1 yr.
View10: Bait and switch of promising you account executive role with an IR position saying that you need tolerance the FIdelity way first before promotion to AE role. Once in IR role, it's really ur luck whether position opens up and ur relationship with ur manager and your numbers compare to the rest of the IR ranks. (Have 8 yrs of exp) I don't need this crap...

Title: Good company, good benefits, room for growth ... up to a certain point
View8: Great for young college grads to continuously learn, very good 401k match + profit sharing plan, lots of smart people doing very interesting work, for such a large company the tech is very good
View10: Management don't care about advancing your career once you've hit a certain salary grade, if too long in a position you are basically pigeon-holed, HR practices are there to defend the Firm not employees, politics get in the way of work and on-the-job happiness, despite a good line-up and impetus diversity & inclusion are not (really) a priority.

Title: Changing Culture
View8: Great profit sharing and 401k.Ccmpany pays for CFP education etc
View10: It's a call center with very little room for real advancement.Pay raise for the very best review was 3%.Wages stuck at 2005 levels.Variable comp is always reconfigured to pay less or same as prior year.Very understaffed for the call volumes so rather than hire more people they demand overtime and at the same time blame the employee inefficiency as the cause.It's so micromanaged that a long trip to the potty might get you a "tardy".Use them to get licensed and trained then hit the road

Title: great benefits but job can burn you out.
View8: excellent training for series 7 and 63 exams, good retirement benefits with matching and professionally managed 401k.  Good training for financial representative role.   You will learn a lot about the industry.
View10: As a financial rep you are answering phone calls all day one after the next, for me it was enough to burn me out after a few months.  You get a lunch break and two short breaks in the day while the rest is answering calls.  Promotions just lead to other phone jobs for the most part.

Title: nice
View8:
Recommends
Positive Outlook
Approves of CEO
I have been working at Fidelity Investments full-time (More than 10 years)
Pros
Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work.
Fidelity provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for …

Title: Review
View8: Great benefit package ( employer match, profit sharing, quarterly bonus, student loan assistance.. There were a lot of perks on the campus (gym, basketball court, walking trail, cafeteria).
View10:
The work environment was very stressful. I worked in the call center, calls were continuously shoved down our throats. You really can't spend too much time researching customer issues or else management will say you're avoiding calls.

Very little career growth, generally if you start out on the phones, that's where you'll remain until you decide to leave the company

Title: Investor Center Manager
View8: Despite its many layers and different internal organizations, Fidelity provided an overall great experience. Solid training, cutting edge technology and likely the top benefits package in the industry. Brand recognition and commitment to marketing are also great advantages.
View10: Fidelity tends to continually change the compensation plan for their reps and management teams. Very corporate culture which was always a bit heavy on conference calls and offsite meetings. Identity crisis at times in terms of promoting a sales versus customer satisfaction culture. All depends on whose in charge at the time.

Title: Depends where you are in your life
View8: Good benefits. Co-workers are nice. Work is super easy and doesn't take much time if you are smart. Great for coasting into retirement.
View10:
Not a good place for people who are implied leaders. It's a very top-down culture. You have no budget even as a VP, no freedom to push outside the "Fidelity way". Most people have been here for the last 20 years and it shows how out of touch these leaders are with how workforce of today looks at leadership and work in general. Long tenured middle managers and individual contributors also show a strange indentured servitude behavior. Many don't have the spine to say the truth, stand up for their beliefs and do the right thing. The culture is to sugar coat bad news and push all decision making as far up as possible. 

This might be fine if you come from a top-down, command and control culture. If you have worked in a culture of empowerment, this will be a stifling place. 

The company is headed towards uncharted territory but people up top lack the will to get rid of the "leadership" crud that only knows status-quo and actively tries to stonewall new ideas. A vast majority started their careers in phone sales - so they are not equipped for todays and tomorrows world. It will be an extremely hard task to correct the current heading of this ship. Drastic measures are needed to clean house but I doubt it will happen. I am waiting to see what happens in the next year.

Again, if you are a young, go-getter this might not be a place for you.  If you want to build a career that enables you to work in another company later, don't count on developing yourself as a leader here. If you want to be told what to do and just want to spend a few more years until retirement, this place is great and has excellent benefits.

Title: Worst environment I've ever seen for UX designers
View8: Oh, none. I'm sure other departments are better — it's a big company. Also, the Starbucks and front desk people are very nice.
View10: Horrible, horrible environment. I've been in enterprise UX design for years, and I've never seen something so bad. First, most of the "design" team doesn't come from a software design background (think "first job after local graphic design agency") — they have very strange, inefficient, and ingrained processes. Members of management are emotionally volatile, manipulative, and aggressive to the point of creating a truly unhealthy environment (something I wouldn't say lightly). There is an incomprehensible Mean Girls culture where no one talks to each other openly and everyone throws their other team members under the bus to get ahead. I walked out of this job (something I never thought I would do) and I can't recommend it to anyone.

Title: Benefits like these are hard to find
View8: You are given great resources in order to obtain your licenses. Training is hands on when learning the role. The company has been working hard to open up mobility opportunities for those that are on the phones. Of course it is up to you what you do with those opportunities.
View10: Even though you are licensed, this is absolutely 100% an inbound phone/chat role. One can get burnt out easily as it can become repetitive. The nature of a phone role means that you will be micromanaged and judged off your stats.

Title: Great Company, Bad Jobs
View8: Great benefits if you stay long enough. Don't take work home with you. A lot of PTO. Managers are pretty supportive.
View10: Not enjoyable day to day jobs. Stuck taking phone calls 8+ hours a day for 5+ years if you want to advance. When seeking next promotions, managers don't know of any career paths other than the next tier phone taking job. Disconnect on expectations vs. reality, but that is true at any big company. Can get stuck on bad shift (SAT, SUN, or Nights). Constant ask for Overtime and even "Pre-scheduled Overtime" which is essentially them putting overtime in your schedule without asking and is very frowned upon if you opt out. Low base pay that basically never increases.

Title: The company has become very rigid, not a place to build a technology career.
View8: It used to be the people, the compensation, and benefits - in that order.  The employees are now either burned out or focused on creating impressive data about their implied productivity.  Compensation and benefits are being eliminated or drastically reduced.
View10: No opportunities for advancement in current environment.  Senior management is extremely disrespectful of employees.  This is primarily driven by the current economic environment where employers have the edge in this buyers market.  The company is a creating a potentially permanent bad reputation that may carry forward if the economic environment shows improvement.  Most senior management just waiting until their retirement.

Title: Better days to come?
View8: Some of the smartest people I have ever worked with, many truly care about the customer and doing right by them.  The company allows for tremendous growth and mobility, and, over the years, one can build a very rich skillset by working in different areas.  Fidelity also has seemingly infinite resources, and invests in research and new ideas.  Innovation is rewarded and encouraged.
View10: Fidelity is a relationship company, and decisions are often made based on who is "in good graces" with the current leadership.  Often, stakeholders on a project or activity can number in the dozens, and strong opinions are encouraged.  Conflict and competition are also encouraged

Title: Excellent benefits, decent compensation, responsible for own career.
View8: Retirement benefits are unparalleled, paid time off from day one, fantastic training, beautiful campus and facilities, wonderful co-workers, own your own development, great place to gain experience and start a career, great team atmosphere, weekends and all holidays off are a definite plus.
View10: Hard to get help on career advancement in such a big company, unrealistic sales goals, slow to adopt new technology, high turnover, almost impossible to get ideas implemented, annual merit raises not in line with costs of living increasing, management has so many of their own projects that it is difficult to get guidance, hard work not always recognized.

Title: long
View8: Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work. Fidelity provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for tho
View10: retail is open 24 hours, causing scheduling conflicts for some candidates Career tracks within the firm can be limited due to licensing requirements, or lack of licensing flexibility in the groups

Title: Okay Job
View8: Benefits, time off during off-season, flexible lunch and breaks in schedule
View10:
Monotonous phone call after phone call. This is a CALL CENTER but you'll never hear it referred to that way. No opportunities for growth within the company and whatever job there is, it will be taking inbound phone calls for customer service as well. Shift assignment is "random" and you could be like me and get stuck working 
2-11pm for the first 6 months when you were told it would be a 9-6 during the interview process. Even now I'm still not on a day shift. Very little time not taking phone calls and it can be 8 hours of back to back customer service calls during busy season.

Title: Excellent training
View8: The licensing is tough but they'll help you every step of the way.  The firm contributes to your quality of life every way they can - dental visits in the mobile dental unit, softball teams, HSA, health insurance, matching 401k, creating an all-for-one-and-one-for-all approach to challenging seasons (think tax time, end of business year).
View10: It's corporate America, so if you feel uncomfortable sharing your credit history and more about yourself before you are hired, or don't like being held to metrics for your bonuses and performance reviews, it's not the place for you.

Title: Great place to start to get licensed and trained.
View8: Retirement benefits with an automatic 10% profit sharing and $ for $ match on 401k up to 7%.  Ability to work overtime for time and a half pay.  After 5 years you have 4 weeks paid vacation plus 10 holidays paid.
View10: Tied to a phone with headset over 90% of the time.  Working in cubicle city.   After a couple of years you are rarely challenged mentally and continuously repeat the same menial task and conversations with customers.  You do not generally work with the same customers so you are constantly talking to new people and the customers get different answers and advise from rep to rep.  Very political management team.

Title: Fidelity: great place to break into the business
View8: Great way to break into the financial market and obtain your series 7.  Options for overtime are amazing.  You can work many hours more than the usual 40, in order to make additional time.  I knew people that worked 80 hours a week and more than doubled their salary.
View10: Sometimes you may not get the exact shift that you want. You might be required to work the evenings, though you are able to submit your preference.   you might have long hours on the phone, but the calls are very diverse.  One call might be from a multi millionare, the next, from a student investing his first $200 in the stockmarket.

Title: Good place to work. Company led by a great family, the Johnson,  who do things the right way.
View8: Decent pay, especially for younger employees who work hard. Great benefits. Ability to move up quick and get experience in many different parts of the financial industry. Amazing training.
View10: Goal and compensation change frequently. Management is constantly focusing on something different. At one time my goals consisted of how much money i brought in, how much went into product (mutual funds, managed accounts, annuities, fixed income), how many referrals i received, how many retirement plans/ income strategies i went through, and so on. It it impossible to do great at everything which means management is always stressing something.

Title: No upward mobility
View8: Great benefits package, great culture, great environment
View10: Poor pay for those with longevity, no loyalty to those with longevity. They are much more interested in bringing in Millennials and are incentivizing non-millennials to take packages and leave. Once you are hired its next to impossible to move out and around the company. They would rather let you quit to get a better job instead of making internal promotions possible,

Title: Working at Fidelity is like being among the walking dead!!
View8: Privately held company, high-level of ethics, decent pay
View10: They take advantage of high-performers, They would rather listen and be driven by consultants with MBAs rather than their own people, They are right now de-leveling the organization and enforcing a uniform corp structure without regard to what actually makes sense, They are easily lured to thinking that process improvement strategies are going to have a huge impact on the business (such as Six Sigma and Transformation)

Title: Great place to work
View8: Really employee and client focus, lots of investment in technology and constant training. Great team evironment and really loved working their except being on the phone all day.  Was doing good until schedule change.  Each team is like their own company with lots of competition among the teams and amazing rewards and opportunity to advance.
View10: The only down size to this place is that it's a Call center but I left because my manager sucked, well not really but he was a negative.  I left to pursue other opportunity with my spouse.

Title: Not Worth It
View8: Fidelity has a good benefits package... decent salary and retirement program... there is flexability in being able to accomodate a work life balance for the most part but keep it mind, it will come with a cost... typically you not getting paid.
View10: Fidelity is run by a certain group of individuals. Most of the management and senior management are brought in from their headquarters in Boston... so if you think your going to get someone that understands anything about the culture of where you are living, you are wrong. They play favorites and there is alot of backbitting and position jocking happening on a continual basis.

Title: Great Company, but Uninspired Employees
View8:
- Average to Better-than-Average Benefits
- Good Pay and Great Bonus Structure
- Nice Office Environs
- They Hire the Best Allowing for Efficiency in a True 9-to-5 Day (so people aren't overworked carrying others' workloads)
View10:
- While my team is fantastic, the overall culture of the company is very conservative and lacking in humor / comraderie.  This is difficult as my (and many other) team(s) get moved and broken up to different locations, so you lose that cohesion.
- I've seen that if you don't enter at a higher position, it may take a VERY long time to get promoted

Title: Old processes, politics and a slave driving, unrelenting busy day will have you begging for mercy
View8: education, series 7 and 63. Job made me realize what evil is and to quit and follow my dream
View10: Everything else. If you decide to take the financial representative role, be prepared to give your life away. Call after call after call of nothing but angry abusive customers. Fidelity refuses to update their computers or programs, so you will be working with outdated processes with no support. If you like dealing with negativity all day, this is the job for you. Horrible job. Horrible!

Title: Awful! Impossible metrics!
View8: Excellent benefits and 401k match
View10: They drive out older, longer teřm employees, job security depends on customer surveys and less than a perfect score is equal to failure, so on a 7pt scale a 6 is a fail. All scores and comments apply to the phone rep EVEN if the comment has nothing to do with your service or skill and management will not budge or modify metrics. If the back office fails to deliver, they don't get the bad score or comment, the innocent phone rep does-- Fidelity shoots the messinger.

Title: ﻿Are you a Software Engineer & love spaghetti? You belong
View8: If you love creating complex, untraceable bugs and a 9-5 M-F paycheck, there’s no better place than Fidelity
View10:
No “Agility”
Knowledge, expertise and creativity are all liabilities
You’ll report to young veterans whose whole engineering careers has been at Fidelity. These out of college lifers will lecture you in software design and “best practices”
These best practices are expected to produce serious bugs which are “normal” and “part of life”
You’ll be very busy adhering to Einstein definition of insanity as you create more bugs while fixing an old one.
Your “completed”, months overdue, deliverables will also entertain customers, who’ll find fascinating features as they test your application in production and with real money

Title: Retirement solution representative WPC 2
View8: Plenty of OT available. Some schedule flexibility, ability to het higher bonus depending on performance
View10: Pay not competitive, limited yearly raise ( top performers got 2% last year), promotions from this level require personal connection and friendship with next level management. Lots of politics involved  in being promoted. Being a top performer is not the decisive factor! Team members don’t have a way of reviewing managers. Upper management has no way of knowing what team members think of their bosses. Very top down management style

Title: The company that was formerly the great Fidelity Investments is on a path to mediocrity, well on its way to obscurity
View8: Learn the business, earn a paycheck, get some experience then leave and go to somewhere who will give you more respect and pay you more
View10: Company has no vision, no respect for employees, it is a heavy, bloated, top heavy organization that is not capable of strategic thinking.  Be prepared for reorg after reorg, management having no idea what is going on. The slow drip drip of the real talent has now become a roar and the good people are leaving in droves.

Title: I used to think I died and went to heaven!
View8: Terrific opportunities to learn and there are a wealth of talented individuals.  The work/life balance has been great; no issues with workig from home and getting time off when needed.
View10: All evaluations are considered "subjective" and not measurable so management can't be held accountable.  You have no idea where you stand compared to your peers.   There are no guidelines for bonus programs.  The middle management is the worse as they all try to protect their turf and do nothing to develop or support their teams.  Any feedback on performance is based on hearsay and anomomous feedback.

Title: A great company that focuses on hiring and training quality people.
View8: An atmosphere that truly promotes personal development. I've never worked anywhere that cared so much about the services that they offer. I genuinely feel that everyone at Fidelity has the best interest of the customer in mind. Also, there is a lot of opportunity for growth.
View10: Entry level pay is low when compared to similar roles in the financial industry. The company can feel a little too big and that there is some disconnect between different functions.

Title: Financial Representative
View8: The pay is decent and the benefits are great. I love my teammates.
View10: They expect too much out of the employees. Certain months of the year overtime is mandatory, which they do not tell you when they hire you. If you get hired in through the call center it is nearly impossible to get a job off of the phones. They say they want to help you move up in the company, but that is only true if you want to get licensed and move into another job where you are still on the phones every day.

Title: Good Opportunity if you can put up with a lot.
View8: I received an opportunity to work at Fidelity as an Advisory Representative which is just a fancy word for customer service representative. The training at Fidelity is unbelievably thorough. Fidelity has its training down to a science and it is incredible. It is also a good opportunity to network with your fellow coworkers.
View10: Now, the actual work itself is not fun. Every other call is someone upset and ready to yell at you. It would feel a little more tolerable but you essentially get paid $12 an hour. Since this is a large company mobility is close to impossible.

Title: Below Industry Average Pay
View8:
- Good company culture
- Free fit meals in cafe and fitness reimbursement plan
- 401k match and profit sharing
- Good health benefits
- Large firm with lots of opportunities for movement (if you know the right people)
View10:
- Managers can hold you back from advancing in your career
- Poor management is rampant and though there are annual manager effectiveness surveys nothing changes
- Pay is WELL below industry average for most positions so good talent is consistently walking out the door, leaving only terrible associates who managers refuse to fire in some groups

Title: I thought it was a great place to work my first few years but the longer I'm there I see the true side of management.
View8: Benes aren't bad. Starting to offer more flexible schedules.
View10: Bonus based on client's surveys. Clients answer the surveys based on what they think of the firm not the rep. It's unfair for the rep to get a poor bonus when the rep did their job really well.

Title: Challenging place to work, in every sense of the word
View8: Privately owned company historically not afraid of investing in up and down markets.  No quarterly Wall Street pressure means management can take a long view.  Historically, very good compensation packages at all levels.  Intellectually challenging environment with lots of talented people.
View10: Recent, sweeping management changes have been tough on the rank-and-file, and the outcome isn't entirely clear, yet.  Technical innovation is often dampened by "big systems" thinking and, recently, tight budgets and timelines.  The downside of lots of talented / smart people is that one occasionally encounters staggering levels of arrogance.

Title: Fast-paced professional and ethical place to work
View8: The benefits ( 401k, profit sharing, vacation, health/dental) are top tier .  The access to technology to complete your daily job functions is tremendous.  There are a tremendous amount of resources (if you know who/where to look)  to help accomplish your job function.  The majority of colleagues/people very responsive to questions and inquiries.
View10: You must be self-motivated and have the ability to succeed with minimal training and guidance.  You really need to ask the right questions/get a consensu answer from multiple sources to obtain the correct answers.  Obtaining resources is very beurocratic and painful to get.  Too many forms/blind e-mail inboxes to submit to get things completed with great difficulty in getting updates on requests.

Title: Despite the recent events, all in all a good place to be
View8: With respect to the changes being made due to the economic downturn, through 2008 the benefits package was outstanding in my opinion.  Health care was well covered. Salary, bonus and profit sharing was a nice combo.  Additionally,  the work/family balance was very nice and there was a high level of flexibility.  I also liked the number of community volunteer activities that you could choose from.
View10: It had become a bloated company with too many senior level people (a number without staff to manage). Additionally, I believe the review process could use overhauling (mixed signals on ratings/ranking) coming from HR and the department management.

Title: Privately-held company offers major benefits...
View8: Smart, driven employees. Everything isn't governed by quarterly earnings like most investment firms. Leader in almost every space it operates in. Lots of opportunities to move laterally, explore other career paths. Multi-year phantom stock grants create super sticky employees. Great internal training and development programs.
View10: Competition can be cut-throat at times, advancement (in responsibility and earning power) can feel overly orchestrated and prolonged. Longevity of some employees can create inertia within middle management.

Title: Good Place to Work
View8:
Benefits - although prices of medical kept going up.
Growth Opportunities - lots of opportunity here if you put in the effort.  Have seen many success stories.
Compensation - very good overall benefits package.
View10:
Not as personal as it once was - you are expendable no matter how long you were there, how dedicated you were or what level you were.
Expectations have increased so much, work life balance suffered.
Strategic direction keeps changing with each new senior division leader.  Very frustrating.

Title: Recently changed for the worst
View8:
Awesome benefits
Incredible co-workers
In house subsidized cafeteria
View10:
Unstable, too many layoffs
Poor work life balance
Highly political, gets in the way of getting your job done
Constant change with lack of planning, lack of completely funding, lack of follow thru
So many layers of management that higher levels have no idea of true status of projects, or work conditons

Title: Great Place to Start a Career
View8:
-decent comp & especially benefits
-thorough review & training processes to facilitate personal growth
-relative autonomy (at least in my group) and recognition of contributions
-flexible culture, work-from-home options, etc.
-leadership is respectful and open to feedback
View10:
-it is VERY difficult to move and grow in your career across business units unless you know people...resumes are ignored and it's all about the name game
-lots of dead weight (maybe this is an issue at all large organizations?), especially directors and VPs who don't understand their subject matter but realized they can coast and still earn six figures at this stage
-extrovert bias, salesmanship is often prioritized over skill

Title: A Lot Like High School
View8: Well-known company with a diverse set of financial services businesses,   Well-established in its markets.
View10: Extremely bureaucratic organization. Company stopped rewarding risk-takers years ago.  Attitude of most employees. is is to get what they can out of Fidelity because Fidelity is not going to do much for them.  Huge amounts of expertise were  let go (ie, senior subject matter experts, IT people) in past five years to reduce salary costs;  now is literally hard to find people who understand the business they work in.  Company communications to employees are of the rah-rah We are Great! sort.  Compensation levels are below industry standards.  A policy of no promotions for past seven years or so for mid and senior IT people adds to dissatisfaction.

Title: A great place to get your start
View8: Every branch environment is different, this is very evident in the DC area because there are branches in DC, 3 or 4 in VA, and 3 or 4 in Maryland and they each have different cultures. This is a great thing, but also plays a big part in branch metrics, promotions, and availability. I have learned a lot and met some really fantastic people! The benefits package is top-notch!
View10: Upward mobility is limited by the size and availability of the next job up within the branches. If one were to consider moving to another branch, or geographic location entirely, then the availability greatly increases. Onboarding is definitely not very great, they have an OTJ training mentality, which can be difficult in the DC area with "DC-type" clients.

Title: Phone Associate
View8: It is a stable company so layoffs are extremely rare. The 401k match is pretty good. Overall their benefits are decent.
View10: Management has an agenda in terms of who gets promoted and quite often it is not based on merit. Nepotism occurs everywhere, but at Fidelity it's an epidemic. However Fidelity has mastered the method. If you don't fit into their cookie cutter template or don't have a close friend or relative blazing a trail, plan on being stuck in your role for years while relative new hires leave you in their dust.

Title: Financial Consultant
View8: Well run company with exceptional training and resources. Hard work is rewarded and the personal retirement benefits are best in class. The company has great benefits and annual profit sharing. Really looks after its employees.
View10: Depending on the branch you are in, you can find yourself limited in promotions if you are in a branch that has highly tenured representatives who never seem to want to move on. The sales goals are fairly aggressive and they always go up but that just means making more money if you hit them.

Title: Reverting to the 80's
View8: Benefits package is excellent, including 401k match and insurance.  Many of the people (not in leadership roles) have the best of intentions and treat others well.  Generally a positive culture.
View10: In the past couple of years the culture has reverted significantly.  Between leadership changes and major layoffs, the result is a leadership team with no other voices providing them with real info about how the rest of the world works in 2018.  Many long-tenured white males in New England in charge of national initiatives who are truly living in the past.

Title: Love my job!
View8: Amazing people, great culture that truly exemplifies the company’s values, and wonderful benefits all around. Fidelity has been great to me!
View10: Work/life balance is hard sometimes as a salaried employee. They fill my plate with many tasks, meetings, projects, etc. and I still have to find time to coach and develop my associates as well as show my face at events where senior management is present. If I could have a little less work and focus on my team a little more I’d have nothing to complain about.

Title: Like dating a complex woman
View8: Fidelity has a great retirement plan, great health insurance choices, and can change jobs internally with little difficulty.   As a salary person you start off with three weeks of vacation and after five years you get four.
View10: Working for a private company has both its ups and downs, sometimes you have no idea what top management will do.  If the owner has a strange dream we might be starting a new business.  Sometimes the pay at Fidelity can be less then at other companies.

Title: Fidelity is a great place to work.
View8: Great working environment.  Friendly atmosphere.  Micro-managing is NOT the style there, big plus for the day to day.  Great reimbursement programs for things like tuition (90%), computer purchase (20%), exercise equipment ($250/yr).  Flexible work environment. Fitness center.  Great cafeteria options.  Kitchenettes with sink, coffee pot, microwave and fridge in every area make it easier.
View10: Corporate politics.  Depending on the type of information you would be exposed to on a daily basis your own personal stock trading will be affected in the following ways: You'll need approval before every trade (buy or sell), You must hold any purchase for at least 90 days, If you do sell within 90 days you must surrender the profit.

Title: Decent pay, all positions are similar, has become much more "the numbers" in recent years and less about the people
View8: Decent pay, mostly intelligent co-workers, good benefits, good 401k matching and profit sharing, company as a whole does right by its employees
View10: Call-center environment, micro-management, bonuses are based on performance of others in department (team-based), very few positions outside of call-center positions in Jacksonville, FL, too much focus on call center statistics,  "thinking outside the box" or going above and beyond for customers ends up hurting you because you are straying from the strict structure

Title: Good place to work overall, but experience can vary wildly depending on manager and group
View8: Great compensation package- higher than average salary for IT, excellent health benefits, good bonuses, matching 401k, profit-sharing, yearly raises plus the chance for extra money through "internal shares" (it is a private company).  Can be a great place to spend some time and get some good experience.
View10: It's big, and made up of very individual groups that rarely interact with each other.  If you're not careful, you can get lost.  Same politics as everywhere else, and middle-management turnover is huge.  New manager comes in and brings all his/her friends with them (at all levels).  That's pretty much expected here.  If you're not part of that "in" crowd, you're on the outside looking in.

Title: 2-5 years and then move on quickly  (Technology Groups)
View8:
Benefits are excellent (retirement, health savings, profit sharing, education).
If you are lucky enough to receive training the you will benefit, but if you work for group that doesn't put emphasis on it then you are on your own.
View10:
Directors spend 80% of their time managing up and 20% of their time protecting their bonuses .
Some of the worst people managers in the business. 
Poor project planning which results in cost over runs and rework. 
The "Yes Man" culture is embraced and rewarded.

Title: Working at Fidelity is just like high school.  High turnover rate
View8:
Benefits are slightly above average, just as good as all other big companies.
They will hire anyone.
Good Training
Fidelity is a great place for a customer, great products, customer first culture is awesome.
View10:
The office politics are really bad
Very high turnover rate, highest in the industry
the computer technology is all over the place
Fidelity cares way too much about email Surveys.
Not much promotion from within
The promotions are like little baby steps and often never include a pay increase

Title: Financial Consultant
View8: Benefits- that's it.  Can't even come up with the five word requirement for this section.
View10: Treat you like crap. Worked there for 8 years finally couldn't take it anymore.  Can't decide what they want to do.  Decided to double the amount of people in my position in 2 months which is just reckless.  You are just another number to this company.  They do not value their employees or their clients.  The market manager told us to stop calling people in "our book" and only work with new clients.  Mandatory to have 18 appointments per week.  Leaves no time to respond to clients calls or put in any effort to plan for client appointments which is the most important part of Financial "PLANNING".

Title: Security Representative II
View8:
They usually train SR's in AML, which can translate to a great future job.

Lots of down time to work on AML cases and schoolwork if you have it.

Plenty of programs to take advantage of in order to advance your career.
View10:
Since its such a small region you will stay security with no promotion, most likely. Unless you get a degree or excel at one of the investigations programs. Even then there is no guarantee, unless you are willing to relocate. You could potentially work as an SRII for 5 years.

Might as well look at it as a career step and take the downtime and use it to advance yourself in some way.

Title: Sr. Portfolio Specialist
View8: Great company with amazing benefits, and high integrity. They are client obsessed in culture and put the customer first, and willing to make changes to improve things for clients and employees.
View10: Annual pay increase most years didn't keep up with national inflation rates. Most all employees love the company, but job satisfaction has declined in that last year or two.

Title: Fund Accounting Analyst
View8: Fidelity Investments is by far the best company I ever worked for.  The environment is top notch professional, yet comfortable and relaxed.  They're honest with their customers and treat their employees with respect.  My coworkers were always intellegent, caring individuals and good friends.  Most managers I worked with were equally caring, and tried to help you succeed.  I no longer work for the company (I was laid off with scores of others) but still hold the firm in the highest regard.
View10: The salaries were on the low side.

Title: Horrible.The manager I was under lacked knowledge on the job itself.
View8: The company has good benefits.
View10: Fidelity managers do a lot of double talk.Rigid environment and some employees are rigid.People walk around like zombies.The manager I was under always stated on our breaks to get away from our desk,go outside for fresh air but how in the world can you go outside when your breaks are 15 minutes and how the building is built it would be impossible to go downstairs,take in fresh air and be back upstairs and on the phone  in 15 minutes and your metrics are being monitored every second,what a joke.I was let go after being on the floor for a month stating my metrics wasn't where they should be and I was being rude to customers and this never occurred. This comopany

Title: Financial Representative
View8: Easy Series 7 training.  The benefits are pretty decent.
View10:
Phones, phones, phones, phones.... get the picture?

This job is mundane at the core.  Every single task is repetitive.  It is a constant stream of taking glorified service calls over and over, with the same requests again and again.  

There is very little outside opportunities, or work responsibilities.  

Managers are nothing but micro-managing and just want to see themselves go up the ladder.

All promotions are just another form of phone job in a service or sales related role.

How many times do you have to explain rules of IRA distribution before you go insane?

Title: Management Can Be Difficult
View8: They have great benefits, very competitive pay, and I was able to work from home three days a week.
View10:
Some management could be difficult, and it seemed certain employees were favored.  There was very little positive reinforcement in my group.  There were too many directors and managers, and there was a lot of bureaucracy at Fidelity.  It can be frustrating to get things done or affect good changes.

Also, while I was able to work from home, I also had offshore resources from China on my project teams.  This required me to conduct meetings either very early in the morning (around 6:00am) or very late in the evening (after 8:00pm).

Title: Just pay your reps
View8: Best benefits package in the industry. The best training to get your licenses in the industry. Impeccable company record throughout the industry.
View10: The best benefits package in the industry means below average pay regardless of profession. There are limited options once you reach a certain point at the phone sites. Fidelity is a great place to have a career but not for motivated reps.

Title: Good company, terrible jobs
View8: Fidelity is a great company with good benefits and strong ethics. Compared to friends who worked at other financial services firms, I never felt pressured to do anything unethical or against the best interests of the customer.
View10: Almost all the jobs in Utah are call center jobs. By their nature, they're like having your soul sucked out of your nose on a daily basis. I love this company, but if this is the kind of jobs they're offering here I'll never go back.

Title: Going through big changes, but slowly
View8: Fidelity generally treats its people very well. Great benefits, very competitive pay, generally decent culture.
View10: Far too many people have worked there 20 years or more, with little outside experience. Privately (family) held, difficult to advice for new ideas. Small circle of leaders close to Abby Johnson has too much influence. Difficult to do anything new or quickly. Very risk averse culture.

Title: Top Notch Company that allows harassment
View8: The employees outside of management are great. The cafeteria is awesome and the building is beautiful. There is a reason for this.
View10: The beauty covers the horrific harassment that is taking place in this company. There is a male manager that goes after women as his prey and tries to force them out of the company. The higher ups know about this and continually cover it up. I hope the owner reads this and goes to the Morrisville NC site to take a deeper look at all male managers. There are women managers that like to bully. This needs addressing as well. I would never recommend this company to anyone. As you see the beauty of the building it quickly deteriorates into a horrible reality that no woman should have to endure.

Title: Good for the right personality type
View8:
1. Structured - Every approach, every answer, every interpersonal communication is proscribed by the company. As a 22 year old, this was beneficial for me.
2. Hours - They never asked me to work weekends. They never cut my hours and demanded I work a greater number of hours.
View10:
1. Structure! - What was beneficial for my 22 year old self was stifling several years later. 
2. Office politics - Promotions were political, because the managers filled the majority of openings with girlfriends or boyfriends before the positions were announced to the office at large.

Title: Great company but has  its  challenges
View8: Progressive company trying to reinvent itself for the new age of financial services.  Great benefits and comp packages
View10: Some administrative areas of the firms are still in the old culture and haven’t been transformed. Additional senior executive need to be mobilized. Still a lot of passive aggressiveness and clicks, limited transparency and openness.  Too focused on who likes you.  Other BUs that are revenue focused are in a much better place.

Title: Working Here Will Turn You Into an "Accidental Diminisher" (See the book Multipliers)
View8: They pay OK and top-level management seems to have the right goals. Bonus's are basically a complete crap shoot because performance is likely to be evaluated by someone who doesn't understand your role and who has failed to set concrete goals or provide guidance.
View10: Culture is extremely negative, especially within the Personal Investing group. There is very little accountability for either management or other co-workers, and very little transparency into how to accomplish the goals of your job. Priorities shift like the wind, since concrete goals are rarely established.

Title: Fidleity is a great place to work
View8: Fideltiy is an organizatiion that demonstrates integrity in their policies and actions.  Individuals at times lose the vision at times, but the organition is self correcting over time. The products and services are excelelent and the vlue to the clients is as good or better than most competitors.  Fidelity has strong and solid senior management, fair treatment of employees, a excellent business plan in their retail services. Cannot comment on other parts of the organization.
View10: Politics, lack of recognition for excellent work.  Processes are in place to do so, but they are hollow at times.

Title: Micro-managed to death
View8: Friendly and supportive coworkers, decent benefits but not great, fun employee get-togethers, good work/life balance. Questions are encouraged and for the most part, more senior employees are willing to help new employees learn the ropes. I was impressed by Fidelity Investments' e-newsletters and client brochures. They're professional-looking and more importantly, easily understood by clients.
View10: I was micro-managed to death despite strong work performance. There is very little employee autonomy. Fidelity Investments is a highly bureaucratic organization that offers very little room for creativity. If you want to work in a branch office, there are limited career advancement opportunities. Fidelity Investments tends to hire smart, hard-working individuals, but then they are forced to follow a highly regimented structure.

Title: Has its benefits
View8: Great place to start right out of college. Good reputation, and you get licensed. In sales, you are mostly inbound with a couple outbound blocks to call out to current clients, no cold calling. Salary.
View10: Big corporate company. Give you a schedule you have to adhere to. With any big company there are politics, which can be good if your personable and can "play the game." Not always flexible when it comes to time off, they want phone coverage at the expense of your family trips. Efficiency efficiency efficiency

Title: Good introduction to retail finance. But this a call center through and through. Do not be deceived
View8:
-extensive training program
-licensing help
-good introduction to finance
-genuinely nice coworkers 
-good computer systems 
-get to be a customer as well
View10:
-extreme micromanagement 
-does not care for ability or knowledge, only that you meet your call metrics. There is a person on my team that has to call for help over 10 times a day, but no worries  because they take 50 calls. 
-job goes from remedial customer service work to having to explain complex investing and tax strategies.. no consistency in service. 
-management is all about the flavor of the day: for a couple of months it was having great conversations with clients, then it was all about having a good workplace to be in.. now it's about taking as many calls as humanely possible with no rest. 
-management likes to hype up the small things.. like wireless headsets, or taking a break when you want to... but they will pass a long all bad news to the lower level managers and will not face the front line reps at all. They refuse to hear any criticism on policy updates. Some are so far removed from helping any client that it's comical what they expect.
- lately they have been devaluing the high net worth service reps. They used to allow for casework and follow up on issues, but they've tossed that in favor of handling as many clients as possible. So now the client with 2 mill as equal standing as client with 2k. 
-management treats all reps the same, no matter fresh out the dorm room or seasoned worker. Can be frustrating..
-this is not a role to stay in for long. Go the sales route. Stay away from customer service. 
-refuse to be competitive in pay
- bonuses are a joke.. almost insulting 
- if all else fails, other firms in town have better pay.

Title: Fidelity Used To Be A Great Company
View8:
-Compensation used to be very good
-Smart people work there
-invest in technology
View10:
-Comp has gone down dramatically due to change to long-term share program changes
-layoffs of good people are making it very hard on remaining employees
-the company is doing well, but treating employees as if the company is not doing well
-it's become extremely political, which gets in the way of getting the work done.

Title: Great Starter Job
View8: Great Benefits, friendly people.  Not in downtown, location is perfect.
View10: Low pay, low bonus pay out, constant changes, constant reorgs, feedback not tolerated, behind on technology and services, low morale and negative environment.  Continuous layoffs the last 2 years.  Opportunities within the company hard to get unless you know the right person, jobs aren't posted.

Title: Lot's of career path opportunities. Great benefits. Great compensation.
View8: There is a lot of focus on helping you advance your skills and career. They reward hard work and the people you work with are typically very professional and passionate about what they do. It would be very hard to leave the generous benefits and compensation once you have moved into a more advanced role.
View10: Sometimes it feels that senior management doesn't realize that their metrics and standards actually make it harder to help clients. They are great at taking small rocks out of the way, but the bigger rocks are next to impossible to move. Even when it is clear that they should be.

Title: Good place to work...could be great
View8: nice facility, beautiful grounds.  Compensation is good once you get past a certain level but getting there can be challenging.
View10: Lot of variability in your experience depending on who you report to.  Not very many opportunities to advance, but a lot of chances to move around.  Benefits are great but would be nicer to make more money instead.

Title: Financial Associate
View8:
This is a company that cares and provides opportunity to show it.
1. Benefits
2. The pay is very good especially considering the work/life balance: I declined a job that paid 10k more, but fidelity pays overtime, where as the other job was gonna work me 55-65hours per week. NOT worth it. Fidelity provides a very good pay with the ability for those who want to work over-time to make more money.
3.Great opportunities for growth. They pay you to get your licenses, they have great tuition reimbursement benefits. If you are ambitious and want to grow, Fidelity is your place. I am already planning to get my licenses, an MBA, a masters in law, and move up in the next 6-7 years. 
4. A great culture with efficiency to its core.
5. Healthy lifestyle emphasis. They have the FIT food which means salads and healthy food is super cheap. How affordable? $2 for a salad vs $10 for hamburger. Yes, they want their employees to be healthy and thank goodness. They also have a recreation center and a health center.
6. Ability to get involved with community and company. They have great affinity groups for LGBT, AfricanAmerican/Hispanic, Women, and Veterans. They also have FidelityCares so it is great for people who enjoy social groups.
View10:
This is financial services and it is highly regulated, what does it mean, there are rules. LOTS OF RULES. But that is only a bad thing if you are one of those people that can't follow rules or can't follow order.

The rules are very simple: Don't be late. EVER. Not a minute. Why? Because it affects the entire company. This company handles big clients with big expectations. It handles other peoples retirements, which means their futures. Yes, there is a high level of commitment, but there is also a high level of opportunity.

Title: A company in a major transition, experiencing the pain of change; future is unclear.
View8: Large company with option of moving to a different group to gain career.  Different groups are often like different companies; therefore, having the ability to move between groups is a good way to boost your career.  Good compensation structure - historically anyway.
View10: Very political and bureaucratic.  Titles are very inconsistent across business units, meaning a VP in one unit is a director in another.  Accountability at the senior levels is weak.  Due to frequent re-orgs a senior business leader is often moved to a new area and therefore is not in a position to own the impact of the changes they make.

Title: Constant contact
View8: The benefits are amazing, the work environment is great and lots of good people to work with - very sharing and  helpful.
View10: There is no work/life balance. Workload is so heavy that I was never able to go on vacation without taking my laptop. Forget about taking a day off - the blackberry chirped constantly. Hundreds of emails daily and keeping up with everything was nearly impossilbe.

Title: Too much time spent dodging shrapnel.
View8: The company has tremendous resources.  I had the opportunity to work with some very smart and capable people.  Excellent work/life balance, and the benefits were very good.  Decent career opportunities *IF* you're willing to live where the company wants you to.
View10:
Not long after I was hired, the company went into a cut & outsource mode.  Salaries stayed flat during my tenure, as with most of the financial services industry at the time.  Too much of my time was spent changing jobs to avoid being relocated. 
Truly horrid 'Human' Resources.  While driving my child to school one morning, I learned of the latest RIF over the radio.  My child looked at me and asked, "Are we okay?".

Title: If you are willing to relocate multiple times you'll do well.  If you want stability, look elsewhere.
View8:
Exposure to some brilliant and highly educated individuals
Good benefits and programs such as healthcare, profit sharing, on-site fitness and health centers, fitness and computer reimbursement, bonus opportunities
View10:
Can achieve work/life balance but usually not without paying a price (limited or no advancement opportunity, limited or no pay increases)
Under-achievers often get recognized and promoted if they know the right people and can play them to their advantage
Jobs are constantly relocated or eliminated on senior management's whim with little regard for the impact to the people or businesses they support

Title: Welcome back to high school
View8:
Great technology
You have your own office
They have billions under management somehow
View10:
You are constantly told that if you are in the top 10 on the regional ranking reports that you will be promoted (this is totally untrue as I witnessed numerous people at the bottom get promoted over the highest performing colleagues).  
You are driven to set as many appointments as possible (and tag as much business as possible) so that you look better than your peers
The only way to get ahead is to brown nose your superiors and those that have access to give you potential leads (thus people are being promoted on the basis that they were  "liked" in the company and not by their performance).
All that matters is your Fidelity "Buzz" 
There is very little to no upward movement for promotions.

Title: Financial Red
View8: The company provides great benefits for this entry level position, and provided excellent prep for the series 7 and series 63. The people were very nice, and you build great phone skills.
View10: The job itself was rather unpleasant. You were essentially tied to a phone for hours at a time, and each minute on site was highly regulated. While the training and support was nice, the job itself was not fun.

Title: Fideility Investments (Good)
View8: Good pay and benefits.  Excellent 401k plan with 7% matching and 10% profit sharing.  Remote work options for many.  Fidelity knows how to make money.  Strong bottom line.
View10: Depending on the group, you could be working a good amount of time: averaging 50+ hours per week.  Can be very slow in receiving promotions.  You need to be prepared to specify your accomplishments in detail during promotions.  Do not be shy.  Expecting management to recognize your worth and reward you for it can many times leave you behind and frustrated.  Yes, speaking from experience.

Title: All Good until its not Good any more an the millennials run the playground
View8: Location, Parking, Cafeteria (expensive) Free Coffee (you will need it), Benefits, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Vacation PTO, Walking Paths, mobility, internal chat.
View10:
Management is very disconnected from associates below director  level. If you are a women dont believe the BS they want more women in senior level position. Very little senior women in technology side or any organization.

If you are over 40 you are playing Russian rullet with career with fido. Culture  is being geared  towards millennial to make them happy only to turn around an layoff tenor employees 

12 year employee still trying to move up while fresh faced 20's come in an refuse to perform the same work as a tenors associate does and is praised like a toddler. 

Dont forget H1B1 visa associates  preferred associate than USA citizen!!!!

Title: Pay is low on the spectrum , but benefits are great, along with the culture.
View8: Benefits, experience, and work-life balance. Specifically, the work from home option is a big plus. The people who work here are really nice, as well. They are open to ideas, most groups really push creative thinking. Although, good ideas are not going to bring a promotion.
View10: No cons besides the low pay and the location is out of the way of the metroplex. Management also seems to have positions filled before they have even posted. Not much room for growth within the groups. It seems like most of the older people in management have spent their whole careers at Fidelity. As for the younger managers, they have industry knowledge outside of Fidelity.

Title: Fidelity needs to show me the money!
View8: 401k match of 7%, profit sharing, medical/dental/vision benefits, even know we offered Roth 401k to our clients for the past year or more just last week we now get to participate...why so long?...voluntary time off unpaid but useful when you need time off for appointments/vacation. I've liked my managers! People are cool for the most part!
View10: with the phones are schedules are dictated by a console...so a 15 min break can't be more or less. Unpaid lunch without the option of not taking a lunch. Not enough money!

Title: Summer Intern
View8: Generous compensation, lots of training & educational programs for interns.  Challenging work.  Friendly people for the most part. Great 401k plans and retirement benefits.
View10: Opportunities for upward mobility in the company are limited.  Management can take a narrow focus, often has a hard time seeing the big picture

Title: Company does not have a clear direction
View8: Benefits at Fidelity are great, but are more structured towards the long term.  Most of the management are long-termers, so while there is some political in-fighting, it's mostly limited and directed towards the "newcomers" in management.  Good and bad, depending which side of the coin you fall on.  Not a bank, but still nice to be privately owned in this environment.
View10: Corporate infighting, and some of the downsides of working at a large firm.  Adequate compensation just isn't there at the associate level.

Title: Overall, Fidelity is a good company but there is way too much bureacracy.
View8: Pay and benefits are pretty good for most positions. Work hours are not as demanding and unreasonable as other financial services companies I've worked.
View10: Too formal and bureacratic. You need to have a meeting about having a meeting to get something done. It is absolutely insane! Also, senior management is not hands on at all- they have no clue as to what their underlings are doing or often what their staff actually does in detail on a day-to-day basis.

Title: Management deficiencies at every level.
View8: Good compensation and benefits.  Beautiful campus.
View10: Management skills are not measured or appreciated.  Position is more often political and based on who you know rather than qualifications.  Mismanagement has resulted in a entirely dysfunctional IT organization that is hobbled by a bizarre anti Microsoft sentiment that is supposedly present at the highest levels.  Company spends millions trying to integrate mismatched solutions rather than just adopting any single vendor.  Used to be a technology leader but is currently technology schizophrenic.   This company also used to develop its management leaders internally, those days have seemingly ended with recent management additions brought in form various other Wall Street firms.

Title: Great place to coast by or finish your career ... otherwise avoid it!
View8:
- Good benefits plan and bonus packages, amazing 401k contributions/matches

- Large enough company to move around in and chart a career path

- Pockets of great situations (good leadership, interesting work, challenging opportunities)
View10:
- Those pockets of great situations are growing fewer and further between each day, the amount of influence one's boss can have on their career at Fidelity is astounding ... in 3 different jobs, I was rewarded (1) on par/average, (2) over-the-top with $$$ and shares and promotions, and (3) not at all .... my approach to the work didn't change in any of those jobs, so it shows that people of equal talent and skills could expect significantly different experiences at this company

 - Jobs are moving out of Boston, so local opportunities are few and far between ... those that pop up are usually pre-reserved for a hiring manager's friend (i.e. probably not the most qualified candidate), so the talent base is watering down, causing animosity, and those that want to advance their career in the Boston-area have to look elsewhere

- There is a layer of lifers at the Director / VP level that have settled into a comfort zone, earning high salaries from the days of raises/big bonuses (long gone), they are staying off the radar, and don't want to rock the boat ... so they are stifling innovation, they are roadblocks to progress, and they are blocking career opportunities for younger, talented, innovative staff members.

- Didn't get a raise in 3 years despite the company pulling in $2.2-2.4B in profit each year, was told it'd be made up to me in the form of a "higher bonus", but the bonuses were the same each year. The company manages the bonus %s, the share rewards #s, and the raise $$ in a way to keep people looking forward to something, but the overall pool of compensation rewards is shrinking every year.

Title: High Net Worth Associate
View8: Lots of great resources, training is definitely better than average for the industry, lots and lots of great employer provided benefits, facilities are very up to date and modern, tons of resources at your disposal, and a great place to learn more without necessarily having to be in a pure sales or commission environment.
View10: Pay and bonus structure is significantly subpar - every time this is brought up you're reminded "how great" Fidelity's non-salary benefits are, which is somewhat true, however the fact that I have access to all kinds of benefits that don't apply to me ,or don't really have any personal benefit to me, personally, irrelevant.  I can't pay rent, buy food, or pay all the other bills I have will my "great benefits."  Money is the only thing that helps with that - and the salaries Fidelity pays, compared to the broader industry, are ridiculously low.  Moreover, there have been numerous changes that have occurred in the last 12 months that are ostensibly to "make things better" for the customer, as well as the associate, but the net effect has been the opposite ... for both.  They've basically significantly increased the scope of the role, while narrowing the performance metrics ... all while creating an increasing environment where it essentially makes it impossible for you to provide the positive experience the customer is expecting, and meet your goals.  How this has played out out to associate is ... you can kiss making more than the bare minimum for your quarterly bonuses (which also ... in not very much at all) goodbye.  Also, over the last 12 months or so, there seems to have been a dramatic concern with turnover, primarily among the associates who have been with the company less than 12 months.  The company has become ridiculously preoccupied with finding ways to keep this demographic with the company that they're basically throwing everything but the kitchen sink at them in the misguided hope it will keep them from leaving.  Basically ... they're focusing all their measures on increasing salary, compensation, and quality at work to the employees who have been there the least, and contribute the least to the company's overall functionality.  I've been with the company, and in this function for years, and even though I've been given yearly bonuses and increases I sit next to people who have been licensed less than 6 months, and are making the same amount in salary as me, or more.  It's really insulting, not to mention makes all the experienced, and seasoned employees feel extremely unappreciated.  Then there's also the issue that performance and ability really have no bearing whatsoever towards promotions or recognition for achievement - the current situation at the location where I work reminds me more of my senior year of high school, and everything boils down to a popularity contest.  The end result is you have people who weren't even competent to begin with and routinely failed to meet even the most basic of their performance metrics, being given increased levels of responsibility and management if they're "popular."  Granted this exists to some degree or another no matter where you work, however the level I've witnessed over the years is on the order of 20 times worse than anything I've experienced in nearly 15+ years in the workforce.

Title: Financial Adviser at Fidelity  = Churn and Burn
View8: If you work hard and you are smart you can make an attractive income in the Financial Adviser (Consultant) role. Company benefits are fantastic. Fidelity has a very respected and recognized brand. Largest 401k provider in the US, provides amazing cross selling opportunities.
View10:
There are many.

1) Financial Advisers have 300-1000 households to support and no real help to do so. The support staff is too inexperienced to do much more than help with some admin stuff and if they are good enough to actually help clients they move into a Financial Adviser role.

2) Your experience as an adviser can be made much worse by terrible managers who micro manage and have little knowledge of what you actually do.

3) Assuming 1 and 2 above, Financial Consultant role is too much of a grind to be a career. You either spend 2-5 years there and then move into management or you burn out and leave.

Advisers have 300-1000+ households and there is no meaningful compensation for retention of assets given the book sizes. ($40k year for a $200 mil managed money book? - book generates $1.5 - $2 mil annual revenue and you give the adviser $40k?)

Vast majority of your comp is tied to annual sales and what you have done in the past means nothing. Therefore clients that have a plan and 100% wallet share are undesirable.

Since company is so large and has so many clients they need to fill the chairs with advisers quickly. Many advisers are 20 and 30 somethings with little or no background in finance, they do the bare minimum for planning and only want to sell products and managed accounts. There is little incentive to really deliver a sound plan because that actually takes time and who has time with 1000 clients?

Overall - the reality is Fidelity is good for “mass affluent” financial help but they are too big and cookie cutter to truly help people with more than  $3-$5 mil. Due to size they have to reduce services to lowest common denominator to ensure consistency.

Title: The base salary is not competitive but the overall "benefit package" is good I guess
View8: Not super expensive health insurance. Good 401k match and profit sharing (yearly into your 401k - avg. 10%)
View10:
The environment in the regional centers is not very modern. Males dominate the industry and it's very clear when looking around. If you aren't one of the "it" people or popular, you're out, or they will not be on your side like others. 
The benefits are somewhat skewed to a specific group of employees, so not everyone gets to benefit from them. 
They aren't very competitive with base pay and put a lot of money you could be making in your pocket into your 401k.

Title: Very good company to work for
View8: Very good name recognition.  The company has a strong history of performance.  A local Boston-area company that has gone national.  The profit sharing plan is excellent (10% of base salary), which is on top of the 7% 401(k) company match.  Salaries are competitive to the rest of the job market.  Overall, a very good company to work for and one I'm proud to be employed by.
View10: In downcycles of the market there are often many rounds of layoffs, so job security can be tenuous.  Certain depertments can be highly stressful, and the work culture is one where those who stick to a regular 8 hour day are frowned upon.

Title: "Would not suggest  working at Fidelity long term"
View8: The company has very good benefits (aka golden handcuffs). The company is also good at training its employees to understand the basics of the investment industry.
View10: The management is poorly run, and is only concerned with it's bottom line. This is ironic because we work for a private company, yet profits are held to as high a standard as it would a public company with shareholders. The company expects it's clients to be treated well, however they choose not to treat their employees well.

Title: Overall good place to work if you like a large company with entrenched culture
View8: Fidelity has good benefits package and there are opportunities for growth for well qualified and competent, talented associates.  The company has a strong set of core values.
View10: Fidelity can be slow to move and recognize industry trends and seems to be stuck in the old mentality that someday Magellan will rise again.   Senior management seems to be willing to spend money even when an opportunity has little market value.

Title: Challenging environment, until they kick you out
View8: Good challenging work. If you thrive on pressure, this is good for you. You should be able to get opportunities to work on new and interesting tasks. Compensation is good - bonus and benefits.
View10: It seems that management learned to avoid plant-closing laws by phasing their layouts over time. From roughly 2009 through 2011, we would hear about a layoff at one business group or another on the first Tuesday of each month. Later in 2011 and 2012. there was a heavy push on "site strategy", where they were moving jobs out of Boston and other Northeast offices to Texas, North Carolina and offshore. Lots of disruption with that.

Title: Cushy jobs, but not an IT industry leader
View8: Great office facilities. Good benefits. A pro and a con, the office is empty at 5pm, literally. Good if you've got kids, bad if you're a workaholic. The company belongs to the Johnson family so you don't have the "make the quarter numbers or bust" attitude you'll find at publicly traded firms.
View10: Sparse vacation, only 15 days a year. Company is constricting, merit raises were half of inflation across the IT groups this year. Technologies used internally are well behind the leading edge and well behind peer institutions.

Title: Need to be a Brown Noser
View8: Decent benefits overall but more expensive than other firms in the industry. You will learn a lot if you know nothing about the business to begin with.
View10: Overcrowded, work area is smaller than an elementary school desk. Advancement is based on arbitrary targets and how much networking you can fit into your 30 min lunch. Previous education, experience and overall ability matter very little and can be detrimental as everybody starts in the same place. The entire organization has a culture where they have customers and most employees believing they are all about service and not profit.

Title: Good company to work for
View8: Decent opportunity to develop skills, very established infrastructure. Company provide very good benefits. Good life work balance overall. There is a certain degree of on job training as well.
View10: Bureaucracy and process driven sometimes. Expectation for more junior level people can be more on the process side. Highly driven by needs of the senior management. Sometimes it will take a long time to go through process and get something done, which can be painful.

Title: Senior Management Enjoys While The Rest Suffer
View8: Still incredibly profitable company, but lack of new products and vision becomes clearer everyday.
View10:
They should look at top 2 layers of management to see why they are where they are, not the layers down that actually do work.
Review system sets goals, you exceed them but then they tell you that the best ratings are only available to the top 5% who exceed at kissing butt,
If you are not a mindless sycophant you will just be lumped in with good performers.
Off shoring jobs, moving jobs to NC and Texas as the answer to poor leadership.

Title: A Job to nowhere with a very low compensation at all levels
View8:
Mostly good honest people to work with. Diverse.
A good company for entry levels positions (but that's it).
Very nice and large campuses nationwide.
Can jump between departments if you want to make a change (but mostly horizontal movement that can last for years with no pay change)
View10:
The fund a accounting group methodology of work is one big mess of excel spreadsheet macros with errors written by very few people at Fidelity and hold the knowledge and responsibility of why/what this job is about. The rest just push buttons and fake it. 
If you took 1-2 finance classes in college you will probably learn nothing new to help you in the industry. The monitoring and problem solving skills learned are 100% based on troubleshooting of departmental chaotic/confused processes of using excel and/or internal softwares. 
Managers don't (mostly) have any managerial skills or passion to manage and do so in order to climb the latter. In reality, they are analysts who stayed at Fidelity the longest (or when everybody else left after 2-3 years). 
Those who leave (which is almost all employees except managers) do so after realizing they will never be able to support an adult life/family with the low pay (including all "unique benefits"). 

In conclusion, 
To demonstrate the shortsightedness and focus on internal computer troubleshooting I will use this fact: Most managers and directors can tell you a lot about how to find a variance due to miscalculation of an Excel's spreadsheet formula but no very little to nothing about the stock market, bond market, and most importantly the nature of mutual fund investing. 

After a while it becomes a very sad, and discouraging, work environment. 
Not a long-term company for go getters

Title: Good, But Not What It Once Was
View8: Benefits - numerous benefits outside of the standard package. Take advantage and it will pay off later for you personally.
View10: The mantra at Fidelity is "Do more, With Less". Every year you are asked to do exactly this. The work is 24/7. When you are out of the office there are no backups and you are expected to check in on vacations. You can be very succesful here and have a great career; just know that your work is priority number 1, 2, 3. Everything else is a distant runner-up.

Title: Tax Exempt Rep
View8: Easy to get in the door as a way to get experience in the financial industry. Company will pay for you to get your Series 7 and 63 if you are interested in that.
View10: Management in the call center has little to no management skills for the most part and tends to be too friendly with their staff. Most employees on the phone are there to just punch a time card and then leave at the end of their shift they don't want to excel at their job. There  is not much room for growth even though they will promise it.

Title: Good place to work
View8:
Cannot beat benefits
Great training for FINRA exams
Flexible work life balance with benefits
Tons of opportunities for lateral movement into new departments
View10:
Call center position, easy to get burnt out and little to break up your day
