Pay isn’t great, but when factoring benefits, it makes up for the few thousand that you might miss in direct compensation. 
No clear path for upward mobility into roles off the phones

Title: Great role, great benefits
View8: Great overall company. Benefits are best in the industry. Company is well managed with integrity and long focused business plan (due to the company still being privately owned by the Johnsons). Work/Life Balance, 10% profit share at year end and 7% 401k match is top notch. Salaries paid are decent, in line with competition.
View10: Management is constantly micromanaging and breathing down your neck. Every single dial and metric is closely scrutinized. Because fees and price compression have taken a deep hold on the retail brokerage industry, management has been raising monthly goals for years. It can feel like a hamster wheel with no end in sight

Title: Wide range of career options if your are flexible and willing to work hard.
View8: Great people, The company makes getting in the door a really hard process.  A sense of team exists once you start working here.  Good balance between work and life.  Most phone site campuses are loaded with activities such as baseball, basketball & soccer courts.  Also onsite gyms and food services as well as laundry services
View10: A lot of silo work results in re-runs and overlaps in effort and technology.  Poor communication between different business units.  Still plenty of Chinese Walls between Retail and Institutional services.

Title: Fidelity: Another transition
View8: Great brand name.  Able to work with newer technologies. A sense of empowerment is given but some managers are micro managers.  Others are so hands off you do not get any feed back at all.
View10: lower pay, expected to be available 24x7, poor recognition, only the managers get the credit, slow to promote. There are a lot of job positions but the qualifications are such you do not have the background necessary to be considered.  Definately more of a who you know than what you know.  In order to advance, it seems important to network instead of working more on an actual skill set.

Title: Ok place, great benefits but lots of politics
View8:
1) Great Benefits
2) Ability to move within the organization
3) Great pay if you negotiate it upfront .
4) Good work life balance in some groups
View10:
1)  Lot of politics
2)  Frequent re-organizations and changes within the company. No stability in senior management.
3) New hires can be hired at much higher salaries.A person hired at a lower level could have much higher salary than yours.
4) Work life balance can be bad in some groups.
5) Lots of employees in IT are not proficient in their fields.

Title: a once great place to work
View8: Strong benefits packages, many smart people, top technology,.   You will be challenged.  Lots of exposure to a variety of issues in financial services
View10: Ever since the economic meltdown, coupled with mediocre investment performance, and significant competitive pressures, Fidelity has turned into a place where most people are constantly looking over their shoulder for the next RIF, or move to another locale.  A lot of management by fear which eliminates any real risk-taking by employees.

Title: Stepping Stone
View8:
Decent pay for a phone job.

7% company match 
10% profit sharing match
Good benefits

Good culture from a team member perspective.
View10:
Survey's are unrealistic. Score scale is from 1to 7. 7 is extremely great service and only 7's count. Very subjective grade scale. Way too much emphasis is placed on surveys. Surveys affect 100% of your bonus. 

You can't short stocks or buy long puts in personal accounts. Employees should have the freedom to short stocks in their accounts because of their trading strategies. 

Lots of politicking and favoritism.  You learn which managers like who very quickly.

Title: Cheap.  is this a non profit?
View8:
They are all about benefits  17% free for 401K. 
Great campus. 
Great work life balance.  
Cafeteria and gym on campus.
View10:
base pay is super low.  Accounting and Finance majors expect better.  
No Pay for Performance/  no bonus
no long term advancement / opportunity for a campus of 5000
whole industry is putting money towards automation and offshoring 
Some have to get second jobs

Title: Technical Intern
View8: During this internship I was able to learn many new things and concepts. I was on the QA track where I learned about automation testing for many of the applications that Fidelity Create and use on a daily basis.
View10: The only cons of this internship were that I was more interested in the software engineering track. Unfortunately I was interviewed by the Quality Assurance group first and they really liked me so they chose me before I got to interview with the software engineering group.

Title: Conservative investment firm with excellent benefits.
View8: After 2 year service, dollar for dollar 401k match up to 7%, additionally an extra 10% (of your gross wages including OT) profit sharing bonus deposited to you 401j each January. Most workers are hourly and receive 1.5x OT for their efforts. 10k per year toward higher education expenses.
View10:
Five year vesting for employer 401k contributions, in 20% increments.
Start us out with more vacation time! How about a sabbatical every few years of service!

Title: Account Executive
View8: Good benefits, extra retirement/health care account if you work there over 10 years
View10: Regional managers and some branch managers have been employees for over 25 years and do not have insight or experience to understand the competition.  Also they were in "sales roles" when Fidelity was pitching mutual funds and they don't have experience or understanding of how to perform consultative sales.  They are not leaders, they follow orders and pass them down.  Very military and micromanaging.  They have said in meetings that the WAS program and those RIA's are their competition.  Definite conflict of interest when selling advice to clients.

Title: Customer Service Role
View8:
-Great benefits such as PTO, 401k Match after 1 year, tuition assistance, even student loan assistance

-Intelligent coworkers and employees

-In Denver they really want to help you enjoy your career

-Management genuinely cares about you and will do what they can to help
View10:
-Taking phone calls for 8+ hours a day can be rough when clients are rude

-Upward movement can be limited based on where you are located. Denver is a small market for Fidelity and therefore not as many opportunities

-The list of benefits keeps growing yet cost of living raises were more preferred

Title: Has Pros and Cons
View8: Nice modern facilities. Company promotes healthy living (cafeteria food, fitness, etc) Company promotes training and education. Industry leading health, dental, and vision benefits. Excellent bonus program.
View10: Extremely high stress environment (for me) which actually made me ill. Divisions in the company are competing and not working together (like the US Congress) Too many CIOs which causes nothing to get done. Senior executives (along with the chairman) react violently to market changes and government regulations causing big layoffs.

Title: Director
View8: Great benefits and training opportunities.
View10: An employee may be delivering great value to the organization and receive great reviews from peers and business partners but if your VP/SVP management doesn't like you forget about career growth.  It has a high school mentality only the people in their 'clique' get opportunties for career growth and guidance. Very sad as you have great employees who are disengaged because of their management employee treatment.

Title: A great place to start, but it can take a while to make a decent salary.
View8: Great place to learn about the financial markets and great benefits.  Tons of customers to work with, don't have to worry about building your own book of clients.
View10: Not a lot of variety in most of the roles at Fidelity.  Need to try hard to make the phone jobs exciting.  Too many campaigns and changing goals in the sales roles.  Tiered approach to bonuses, someone is always at the bottom, no matter what.  Not necessarily paid for what you do (but that's the rules of a salary plus bonus structure).

Title: Good place to work when they want it to be
View8: Fidelity is one of the only equity research jobs where an undergrad can immediately become a lead analyst on 20+ companies with good access to top management of the companies they are researching.  There is also a strong history of talent that you will be surrounded by.  Pay is fair to good for the job.
View10: Management is not honest with employees about current situation of the company and compensation outlook; there has been significant turnover in Fidelity C-suite, and it is unclear what direction the company is heading; limited real time feedback on how well you are doing your job.

Title: good company to work for but can drive a great, devoted employee to quit.
View8: Good benefits, understanding management, encourage personal business developement.
View10: management lack of communication, too much layering, political when it comes to promotions and hires, salary not competitive with industry, company always wants blood from a stone, they rather pay an external higher more $$ that their own who are more capable to do the job, can never get a straight answer about anything.

Title: Ability to learn many industries under one company umbrella
View8: Fidelity offers many different companies and industries to move around in while employed - many opportunities to learn different things. The 'Fidelity' name is very strong to have on your resume. Fidelity provides a fantastic total compensation/benefits package that other companies have a hard time competing with and there are many perks to working on the campus too such as a gym, running trails, softball field and league, etc. It's a home away from home.
View10: Over 36K employees, it's easy to lose your voice and become a number. You're at the mercy of Exec and Sr management making decisions on projects you are working on and invested in. Tough to move up and increase grade level.

Title: Software Engineer in Development
View8:
My team was pretty open minded and technically strong
Your ideas and opinions are valued. They were open to suggestion for new technologies or coding practices
Conducted software engineering meetins, coding mojos and similar things for self improvement
Pretty good work and social life balance
View10:
Salary is not that great for full time employees compared to contracters
Fidelity is pretty diverse in nature. So, the team and location plays a major factor on how technically rich it is. I have seen some teams use outdated technologies

Title: GREAT foot in the door
View8: This is a great company to start off with.  Excellent training (biggest pro I would say), great team atmosphere and great benefits
View10: The double-edged sword for the great benefits is very low pay and right now there is a very low cap for raises - mostly because businesses are tightening their budget. There is a lack self-improvement.  No recognition for performance or improvements as meeting the status quo only matters.  You're only recognized if you have a negative perception.

Title: Let Fidelity pay for your Series Licensing!
View8: Fidelity paid for my licensing
View10: If you have legitimate health issues and must use FMLA, you may as well start your job search now. Don't affect your manager's bottom line or he'll find a way to fire you.
